Second, HCoV-229E-related bat alpha-CoVs are diverse and non-pathogenic in bats, whereas alpaca alpha-CoV caused an outbreak of respiratory disease in infected animals.
Ekyokubiri, akawuka ka HCoV-229E-related bat alpha-CoVs kalimu enjawulo ate tekalwaza buwundo so ng’ate alpaca alpha-CoV kaaleeta ekirwadde mu muyungiro gw’okussa mu nsolo endwadde.
Finally, alpaca alpha-CoV has not been found in feral animals.
Ekisembayo, alpaca alpha-CoV tekazuuliddwa mu nsolo ezaava ewaka ne zidda mu nsiko.
Thus, the possibility cannot be excluded that alpacas obtain the HCoV-229E-related alpha-CoV from humans.
Awo nno, obusobozi tebuyinza kuggyibwawo nti alpacas zijja HCoV-229E-related alpha-CoV okuva mu bantu.
In fact, bats are the direct source of human pathogenic viruses including rabies virus, Ebola virus, Nipah virus and Hendra virus.
Mu butuufu, obuwundo y’ensibuko y’obuwuka obusaasaanya endwadde mu bantu omwo nga mwe muli n’akawuka rabies virus, Ebola virus, Nipah virus ne Hendra virus.
It is therefore not too surprising that bats might transmit HCoV-229E to humans directly.
Awo nno tekyewuunyisa nnyo nti obuwundo busobola okusaasaanya HCoV-229E obutereevu mu bantu.

Alternatively, whereas bat alpha-CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoV-229E, alpacas and dromedary camels might serve as intermediate hosts that transmit viruses to humans, exactly as in the case of MERS-CoV.

Mu ngeri endala, weewaawo bat alpha-CoVs bukola nga ensibuko y’endagabutonde eya HCoV-229E, alpacas n’eŋŋamiya (dromedary camels) ziyinza okukola ng’ekibeerako akawuka ekitasaasaanya ekitambuza obuwuka mu bantu nga bwe kiri ddala ku MERS-CoV.
MERS-CoV serves as an excellent example of interspecies transmission from bats to dromedary camels and from dromedary camels to humans.

MERS-CoV kakola ng’ekyokulabirako ekirungi ddala eky’ensaasaanya okuva mu kika ekimu okudda mu kirala okuva mu buwundo okudda ku ŋŋamiya (dromedary camels) ate n’okuva mu ŋŋamiya (dromedary camels) okudda mu bantu.
The evolutionary origin of MERS-CoV from bats is known at its initial identification and has also been strengthened by subsequent findings.
Ensibuko y’okufuukafuuka kwa MERS-CoV okuva ku buwundo emanyibwa okuva ku ntandikwa eyasooka era okumanyibwa okwo ne kunywezebwa mu bizze nga bizuulibwa.
It is obvious that bats provide a rich pool of virus species for interspecies exchange of genetic fragments and interspecies transmission.
Kyoleka lwatu nti obuwundo bulina ebika by’obuwuka bingi ddala ebitambula mu bika eby’enjawulo ebyeyawulayawula mu bika eby’enjawulo ate ne busaasaana mu bika eby’enjawulo.
Longevity, densely packed colonies, close social interaction and strong ability to fly are all favourable conditions for bats to be an ideal 'virus spreader'.
Obuwangaazi, ebibinja by’obuwundo obungi, okukwatagana ennyo wamu n’obusobozi bw’okubuuka ennyo byonna bisobozesa obuwundo okubeera ‘ekisaasaanya akawuka’.
On the other hand, MERS-CoV has been introduced to dromedary camels for decades.
Ku ludda olulala, MERS-CoV kateekeddwa mu ŋŋamiya (dromedary camels) okumala ebbanga eriwera.
It is well adapted to these camels that have turned from an intermediate host to a stable and natural reservoir host.
Kabeera bulungi mu ŋŋamiya ezo ezaafuuka okuva ku kibeerako akawuka ekitasaasaanya okudda ku kitonde ekyekwatako akawuka.
MERS-CoV causes very mild disease and maintains a relatively low mutation rate in these animals.
MERS-CoV kaleeta obulwadde obutonotono era kazaalukuka kitono nga kali mu nsolo ezo.
Its sporadic transmission to humans is an accident and humans remain a dead-end host of MERS-CoV as its transmission cannot be sustained.
Okusaasaanya kwakwo okw’ebbalirirwe mu bantu kwa ngeri ya kabenje era abantu basigala nga beekwatako akawuka MERS-CoV ako naye ne katasaasaana kubanga okusaasaana kwako tekubeezekawo.
In contrast to the role of camels in the transmission of MERS-CoV, the role of pangolins, if there is any, in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is different.
Mu kugeraageranya omulimu gw’eŋŋamiya mu kusaasaanya MERS-CoV, omulimu gwa pangolins, bwe guba nga weeguli, mu kusaasaanya SARS-CoV-2 gwa njawulo.
Particularly, pangolin beta-CoVs are highly pathogenic in pangolins.
Okusinga ennyo, obuwuka bu-pangolin beta-CoVs buleeta nnyo endwadde mu pangolins.
They might be a dead-end host for SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs, similar to civets in the case of SARS-CoV.
Buyinza okuba ekibeerako akawuka ekitasaasaanya SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs, nga bwe kiri ku ffumbe ku SARS-CoV.
Several possibilities for interspecies transmission of SARS-CoV-2 from animals to humans have to be ruled in or ruled out in future studies.
Obusobozi bwa maanyi obw’okusaasaanya SARS-CoV-2 mu bika eby’enjawulo okuva ku nsolo okudda mu bantu obulina okukakasibwa oba okusazibwamu mu kunoonyereza okujja eyo mu maaso.
First, bats could be the reservoir host of a SARS-CoV-2-related virus almost identical to SARS-CoV-2.
Okusooka, obuwundo buyinza okuba ekyekwatwako ky’obuwuka obwekwanya ku SARS-CoV-2 nga kumpi bufaanagana ne SARS-CoV-2.
Humans might share the ecological niche with bats through butchering or coal mining.
Abantu bayinza okufaananya engeri gye bibeerawo mu ndya ne mu kusima.
Second, pangolins could be one of intermediate amplifying host to which a SARS-CoV-2-related virus had been newly introduced.
Ekyokubiri, pangolin zisobola okubeera ekibeerako akawuka ekisaasaanya obuwuka obwekwanya ku SARS-CoV-2 kwe bwakateekebwa.
Humans contract the virus through butchering and consumption of game meat.
Abantu bakwatibwa akawuka nga kayitira mu kutta n’okulya ennyama enjigge.
It is possible that many mammals including domestic animals are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2.
Kisoboka nti ensolo eziringa omuntu omwo nga mwe muli n’ezirundibwa ewaka zisobola okukwatibwa SARS-CoV-2.
A survey of domestic and wild animals for antibodies is warranted.
Okunoonyereza ku nsolo z’awaka n’ez’omu nsiko okuzuula abasirikale b’omubiri abazirimu kwetaagisa.
Third, as mentioned above, recombination and adaptation of SARS-CoV-2 might have occurred in a third species that has contact with both bats and pangolins.
Ekyokusatu, nga bwe kyogeddwako waggulu, okugattagatta endagabutonde n’okumanyiira kwa SARS-CoV-2 kuyinza okuba nga kwagwawo mu kika ekyokusatu ekikwatagana n’obuwundo ne pangolin.
The search for the animal origins of SARS-CoV-2 is still on.
Okunoonyereza ku nsibuko ya SARS-CoV-2 mu nsolo kukyagenda mu maaso.
Apart from different types of the animal hosts, three major factors on the viral side are also important in facilitating CoVs to cross species barriers.
Ng’oggyeeko ebika by’ensolo ebyekwatwako obuwuka, ensonga enkulu ssatu ku ludda lw’obuwuka nazo nkulu mu kubeezaawo CoVs okusala ebiziyiza okubuuka okudda mu bika ebirala.
First of all, their relatively high mutation rates in RNA replication.
Ekisookera ddala, okuzaalukana kwabwo okulabika nga kuli waggulu ddala mu kuzaalukana kw’endagabutonde (RNA).

In comparison to other single-stranded RNA viruses, the estimated mutation rates of CoVs could be regarded as “moderate” to “high” with an average substitution rate being ~10-4 substitution per year per site 2, depending on the phase of CoV adaptation to novel hosts.

Mu kugeraageranya obuwuka obulala obukozesa endagabutonde (single-stranded RNA viruses), omuwendo gw’obuzaalukanyi bw’obuwuka guteeberezebwa okubeera wakati “w’omusaamusaamu” ne “ogwa waggulu” nga guliko omuwendo omukkati oguli wakati wa ~10-4 buli mwaka buli kifo 2, okusinziira ku mutendera gwa CoV ogw’okumanyiira n’ekyekwatako akawuka ekibadde tekimanyiddwa.
CoVs have a proof-reading exoribonuclease, deletion of which results in exceedingly high mutability and attenuation or even inviability.
Obuwuka bwa CoVs bumanyi okutebuka ekirungo ki exoribonuclease, era nga bwe kisangulwa kivaamu okufuukafuuka okw’amaanyi n’okukendeera oba oluusi n’obutasoboka.
Interestingly, the nucleotide analogue Remdesivir is known to suppress CoV replication through inhibition of this exoribonuclease and the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
Ekyewuunyisa, ekirungo nucleotide analogue Remdesivir kimanyiddwa ng’ekinyigiriza okuzaalukana kwa CoV nga kiyitira mu kuziyiza exoribonuclease n’endagabutonde (RNA) eyeesigamye ku RNA polymerase.
Remdesivir is one of most promising anti-SARS-CoV-2 agents to be tested in clinical trials.
Remdesivir kye kimu ku birungo ebirwanyisa SARS-CoV-2 ebigezesebwa mu kugezesa kw’ekisawo.
Nevertheless, mutation rates of CoVs are about a million times higher than those of their hosts.
Ebyo ng’obiggyeeko, ekigero ky’okufuukafuuka ekya CoVs kiri awo nga mu mirundi kakadde nga kiri waggulu w’ekyo eky’ekyekwatibwako akawuka.
In addition, mutation rate is often high when CoVs are not well adapted to the host.
Mu ngeri y’emu, ekigero ky’okufuukafuuka kitera okuba waggulu bu CoV bwe buba nga tebumanyidde kintu kwe bwekutte.
Compared to SARS-CoV with a high mutation rate, the mutation rate of SARS-CoV-2 is apparently lower, suggestive of a higher level of adaptation to humans.

Bw’ogeraageranya ne SARS-CoV akalina ekigero ky’okufuukafuuka ekya waggulu, ekigero ky’okufuukafuuka ekya SARS-CoV-2 kirabika nga kiri wansi, era ng’ekyo kiraga nti kati kagenze kamanyiirira ddala abantu.
Presumably, it has already been adapted to another host close to humans.
Kyandiba nga kaamala dda okumanyiira ekintu ekirala ekifaananako n’abantu.
In addition to SARS-CoV-2, this also applies to MERS-CoV, which is well adapted to dromedary camels.
Ng’oggyeeko SARS-CoV-2, kino kikola ne ku MERS-CoV, akaamanyiira edda eŋŋamiya.
Theoretically, it is unlikely that genetic drift would render vaccines and antivirals against SARS-CoV-2 ineffective quickly.
Mu kulowooza, kirabika nga enkyukakyuka mu ndagabutonde eyinza okuleetera eddagala erigema n’erirwanyisa obuwuka bwa SARS-CoV-2 obutakola mu bwangu.

Second, the large RNA genome in CoVs exerts extra plasticity in genome modification for mutations and recombination, thereby increasing the probability for interspecies co-evolution, which is advantageous for the emergence of novel CoVs when the conditions become appropriate.

Ekyokubiri, ekirungo kya RNA genome ekinene mu CoVs kinyigiriza enfuula ya genome olw’enfuukafuuka n’engattagatta, olwo ne kyongera omukisa gw’ebika ebyenjawulo okubeerana mu nkula yaabyo, ekintu ekirungi mu kusibuka kw’akawuka ka CoV akatamanyiddwa embeera bw’eba ng’eganya.
This is supported by the copious unique open reading frames and protein functions encoded towards the 3′ end of the genome.
Kino kiwagirwa enkola ya copious unique open reading frames n’omugaso gwa puloteyini ebeera mu 3′ end eya genome.
Third, CoVs randomly and frequently switch templates during RNA replication through a unique “copy-choice” mechanism.
Ekyokusatu, CoVs butera ate mu ngeri ya kulabira awo okukyusa obutiba mu kiseera ky’okuzaalukana nga buyita mu nkola eya “koppa-kyolonzeeko”.
In a host that serves as the mixing vessel, strand switching occurs frequently during CoV RNA transcription.
Mu kibeerako akawuka ekikola ng’ekikompe ekitabula, enkyukakyuka ebaawo nnyo mu kiseera kya CoV RNA transcription.
Highly homologous full-length and subgenomic RNAs could recombine to generate new CoVs.
Endagabutonde (RNAs) ezifaanagana ennyo wamu ne subgenomic RNAs zisobola okwegattagatta okufunamu bu CoV obulala.
Phylogenetic evidence of natural recombination has been found in both HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-OC43, as well as animal CoVs such as bat SL-CoV and batCoV-HKU9.
Obubaka bw’enfuukafuuka y’obuwuka ey’okwegattagatta okw’obutonde erabiddwa mu HCoV-HKU1 ne mu HCoV-OC43, wamu ne CoV ow’ensolo gamba nga bat SL-CoV ne batCoV-HKU9.
Virus-host interaction in relation to transmission
Enkolagana y’akawuka n’ekibeerako akawuka mu nsaasaana y’obulwadde
Besides three viral factors stated above, viral interaction with host receptor is another key factor influential on interspecies transmission.
Ng’oggyeeko ensonga z’akawuka essatu ezoogeddwako waggulu, enkolagana y’akawuka n’ekibeerako akawuka nayo nsonga nkulu ekola mu nsaasaanya y’obulwadde mu bika eby’enjawulo.
Herein, recombination of SARS-CoV is taken as a typical example, which also showed evidence of positive selection during interspecies transmission events.
Mu kiwandiiko kino, okwegattagatta kwa SARS-CoV kutwalibwa ng’ekyokulabirako ekimanyiddwa ekyalaba n’obubaka mu kiseera ky’okusaasaanya obulwadde ekiyitibwa positive selection.

Based on the comparative analysis between isolates of human and civet SARS-CoVs, SARS-CoV is thought to undergo rapid adaptation in different hosts, particularly with mutations at the RBD of the S protein.

Okusinziira ku kwekenneenya wakati w’ebyawuliddwa okwekalirizibwa eby’abantu n’eby’effumbe SARS-CoVs, SARS-CoV kalowoozebwa okufuna amangu okumanyiira ebibeerako obuwuka, naddala mu kufuukafuuka ku RDB mu S protein.
Generally, the RBD in the S protein of a CoV interacts with the cellular receptor and is intensely selected by the host antibody response.
Okutwaliza awamu, RBD mu S protein eya CoV ekolagana n’ekifuna obutaffaali era nga kirondebwa nnyo abasirikale b’omubiri mu kibeerako obuwuka.
In SARS-CoV, the RBD is in the 318th to 510th amino acids on the S1 fragment, which binds to the human ACE2 as well as its coreceptors for viral entry.
Mu SARS-CoV, RBD eri mu amino acid owa 318 okutuuka ku 510 ku S1 fragment, eyeekwata ku ACE2 mu bantu wamu n’ebyo ebifuna obuwuka okuyingirirako.
The RBD of SARS-CoV is capable of recognizing the ACE2 receptors of various animals, including bat, civet, mouse and raccoon dog, allowing interspecies transmission of the virus.
RBD eya SARS-CoV esobola okukenga ebifuna obuwuka ACE2 mu nsolo ez’enjawulo, omuli akawundo, effumbe, emmese n’embwa (raccoon dog), ekkiriza okusaasaana kw’akawuka mu bika eby’enjawulo.

In fact, only 6 amino acid residues were observed to be different from human and civet viral isolates in the RBD and 4 of them locate in the receptor-binding motif for interaction with the ACE2 receptor.

Mu butuufu, ebisigalira bya amino acid 6 byalabibwa nga bya njawulo okuva ku ebyo ebyawulibwa mu bantu n’effumbe mu RBD ate nga 4 ku byo bisangibwa mu nfaanana y’ebifuna obuwuka olw’okukolagana n’ekifuna obuwuka ACE2.
Civet SARS-CoV has K479N and S487T mutations in its RBD, which might increase the affinity of the interaction of spike protein with human ACE2 receptor.
SARS-CoV ow’effumbe alimu okufuukafuuka kwa K479N ne S487T RBD we, ekiyinza okwongeza enkwatagana y’enkolagana ya spike protein ne ACE2 ey’ekifuna akwuka mu bantu.
In other words, these two amino acid substitutions might be critical to viral adaption to humans.
Kwe kugamba, ebika bya amino acid ebibiri ebisikira ebirala biyinza okuba nga bya maanyi nnyo mu kumanyiira kw’akawuka mu bantu.
It is noteworthy that SARS-CoV-2 shares the same cellular receptor with SARS-CoV.
Kikulu okumanya nti SARS-CoV-2 kagabana ekifuna obulwadde eky’obutaffaali obufaanagana ne SARS-CoV.
A 30% difference between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV in the S1 unit of the S protein implicates that the binding affinity of its S protein with human ACE2 might have altered.
Enjawulo ey’ebitundu 30% wakati wa SARS-CoV-2 ne SARS-CoV mu kigero ekya S1 ekya S protein kitegeeza nti y’enyweza oluganda eya S protein ne ACE2 mu bantu eyinza okuba nga yakyuka.
Indeed, a cryo-EM study indicates a 10- to 20-fold higher affinity of this binding than that between human ACE2 and SARS-CoV S protein.
Mu butuufu, okunoonyereza kwa cryo-EM kulaga 10- ku-20 kulimu oluganda lwa maanyi mu kunyweza kuno okusinga ACE2 mu bantu ne SARS-CoV S protein.
It will also be of interest to determine whether any other coreceptor might be required for SARS-CoV-2 transmission.
Kijja kuba kirungi era okulaba oba nga ekintu ekirala ekifuna obuwuka kiyinza okwetaagisa mu kusaasaanya SARS-CoV-2.
Intriguingly, HCoV-NL63 also binds to ACE2 but with a different part of S.
Mu ngeri eyeewuunyisa, HCoV-NL63 nakyo kinyweza ACE2 naye nga kikozesa akatundu ka S akalala.
There exist many other HCoV receptors, such as aminopeptidase N for HCoV-229E, and 9-O-acetylated sialic acid for HCoV-OC43.
Waliwo n’ebifuna HCoV ebirala bingi, gamba nga aminopeptidase N ku HCoV-229E, ne 9-O-acetylated sialic acid ku HCoV-OC43.
They might also account for successful adaptation of these CoVs in humans after interspecies transmission from their animal hosts.
Busobola era okunnyonnyola okumanyiira obulungi okw’obuwuka bwa CoV mu bantu oluvannyuma lw’okusaasaanira mu bika ebyenjawulo nga buva ku nsolo kwe bubeera.
In addition to cellular receptors, the outcome of interspecies transmission of HCoVs is also governed by other host dependency and restriction factors.
Ng’oggyeeko ebifuna obuwuka eby’obutaffaali, ekiva mu HCoV okusaanasaanira mu bika eby’enjawulo kifugibwa ensonga endala ezeesigama ku kibeerako obuwuka n’ebikugira.
The divergence of these host proteins between humans and natural reservoir hosts of HCoVs such as bats, dromedary camels and rodents might constitute a barrier to interspecies transmission.
Enjawulo mu host proteins wakati w’abantu n’ebitonde ebisaasaanya HCoVs gamba ng’obuwundo, eŋŋamiya n’emmese ( rodents) biyinza okukola ng’omuziziko mu kusaasaanya obulwadde mu bika eby’enjawulo.
HCoVs have to usurp host dependency factors and subvert host restriction factors for a successful interspecies transmission.
HCoVs bunaayiza ekibeerako obuwuka era ne kyewala ebikugira by’ekibeerako obuwuka olw’okusaasaanya obulungi obulwadde mu bika eby’enjawulo.
In this regard, molecular determinants in this important area of virus-host interaction remain to be identified and characterized.
Mu ngeri eyo, ebisalawo ku molecule mu kitundu kino ekikulu eky’akawuka-ekibeerako obuwuka kikyetaaga okulengerwa n’okunnyonnyola.
An unbiased genome-wide screening of host dependency and restriction factors for SARS-CoV-2 using the state-of-the-art technology of CRISPR might be fruitful.

Okusunsula mu genome okw’awamu okutaliimu kyekubiira (genome-wide screening) okw’ekibeerako obuwuka n’ebikugira bya SARS-CoV-2 omuli okukozesa tekinologiya ow’ekika ekya waggulu kiyinza okuvaamu ebibala.
Emergence of novel HCoVs: back to ground zero
Okubalukawo kwa HCoVs abadde tamanyiddwa: okuddayo ku ntandikwa
The diversity of bat CoVs provides ample opportunities for the emergence of novel HCoVs.
Enjawulo mu CoVs ow’obuwundo aleetawo emikisa gya maanyi mu kubalukawo kwa HCoVs obubadde tebumanyiddwa.
In this sense, bat CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoVs.
Mu ngeri eno, CoV ow’obuwundo bukolanga ng’ensibuko ya giini eza HCoVs.
In addition, rapid mutation and genetic recombination also drive HCoV evolution and serve as two important steps in this process.
Okwongereza ku ekyo, okufuukafuuka okw’amangu n’okwegattagatta kwa giini nabyo bifuga enkula ya HCoV era bikola ng’emitendera ebiri emikulu mu nkwajja eno.
For example, the acquisition or loss of novel protein-coding genes has the potential to drastically modify viral phenotypes.
Okugeza, okufuna oba okufiirwa entereeza ya giini za protein (protein-coding genes) okubadde kutamanyiddwa kulimu obusobozi bw’okukyusiza ddala enfaanana y’obuwuka.
Among SARS-CoV accessory proteins, ORF8 has been thought to be important in adaptation to humans, as SARS-CoV-related bat viruses were isolated but found to encode divergent ORF8 proteins.

Mu SARS-CoV accessory proteins, ORF8 zirowoozebwa okubeera enkulu mu kumanyiira abantu, ng’obuwuka bwa SARS-CoV obwekwanya ku buwundo bwayawulibwa naye ate ne busangibwa nga bulina divergent ORF8 proteins.
A 29-nucleotide deletion characteristic of SARS-CoVs has been found in strains isolated at the beginning of the human epidemic.
Akabonero ka 29-nucleotide deletion aka SARS-CoVs kasangiddwa mu bwawuzi obwayawulibwa ku ntandikwa ya nawookeera w’ekirwadde kino mu bantu.
This deletion splits ORF8 into ORF8a and ORF8b and is thought to be an adaptive mutation that promotes the switch of hosts.
Okusangula kuno kwawulamu ORF8 mu ORF8a ne ORF8b era nga kirowoozebwa okubeera enfuukafuuka y’okumanyiira etumbula okukyusakyusa ekibeerako obuwuka.
Besides, SARS-CoV has a possible recombination history with lineages of alpha- and gamma-CoVs, where a large number of smaller recombinant regions were identified in the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

Ng’oggyeeko ekyo, SARS-CoV kalina ebyafaayo by’obusobozi bw’okwegattagatta mu nnyiriri za alpha- ne gamma-CoVs, omwalabibwa omuwendo gw’okwegattagatta mu nkula omutono mu RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
Recombination locations were also identified in the nsp9, most of nsp10, and parts of nsp14.
Ebifo ebimu eby’okwegattagatta byalengerwa mu nsp9, ebisinga mu nsp10, n’ebitundu bya nsp14.
Likewise, it has been shown that the epidemic MERS-CoV experienced recombination events between different lineages, which occurred in dromedary camels in Saudi Arabia.
Mu ngeri y’emu, kiragiddwa nti nawookeera w’ekirwadde kya MERS-CoV yalimu okwegattagatta wakati w’ennyiriri ez’enjawulo, okwaliwo mu ŋŋamiya mu Saudi Arabia.
Besides SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, recombination events have also been observed in other HCoVs, in which the HCoVs recombine with other animal CoVs in their non-structural genes.
Ng’oggyeeko SARS-CoV ne MERS-CoV, emirundi gy’okwegattagatta era girabiddwa mu HCoVs obulala, HCoVs mwe bwegattira ne CoVs ez’ensolo mu giini zaazo eziyitibwa non-structural genes.

It should also be cautioned that artificial selection can contribute to unintended changes in viral genomes, most likely resulting from relieving viruses from selection pressures exerted, such as by the host immune system.

Kisaana era okulabula nti okulondoba okukolebwa abantu kusobola okuleetawo enkyukakyuka ezitalabiddwa mu viral genomes, ng’okusinga ennyo kiva ku kuwewula ku buwuka ku kunyigirizibwa kw’okulondoba, gamba ng’okwo okuva ku busibage bw’ekibeerako obuwuka.
An example of these effects is the loss of a full-length ORF4 in the HCoV-229E prototype strain, owing to a two-nucleotide deletion.
Ekyokulabirako ky’okukosebwa kuno kwe kufiirwa okw’amaanyi okwa ORF4 mu HCoV-229E prototype strain, nga kiva ku kusangula kwa nucleotide kwa mirundi ebiri.
While intact ORF4 could be observed in bat and camel viruses related to HCoV-229E, the alpaca alpha-CoV displays a single nucleotide insertion, resulting in a frameshift.
Weewaawo nga ORF4 atafuusefuuse asobola okulabibwa mu buwuka bw’obuwundo ne mu ŋŋamiya obwekwanya ku HCoV-229E, alpaca alpha-CoV kooleka okusonsekebwa kwa nucleotide, okuva ku frameshift.
Last but not least, the evolution of novel HCoVs is also driven by the selection pressure in their reservoir hosts.
Ekisembayo naye nga si kye kisemberayo ddala, okukula kwa HCoVs akabadde tekamanyiddwa era kufugibwa okusindiikirizibwa kw’okulonda mu kibeerako obuwuka.
Asymptomatic or only mild symptoms were detected when bats were infected with CoVs, indicating the mutual adaptation between CoVs and bats.
Obutalaga bubonero oba obubonero obutono bwalabibwa ng’obuwundo bulwadde CoVs, nga kiraga okumanyiira okw’awamu wakati wa CoVs n’obuwundo.
It appeared that bats are well adapted to CoVs anatomically and physiologically.
Kyalabika nti obuwundo bwamanyidde bulungi CoVs mu nkula yaabwo (anatomically) ate ne mu mbeera z’obulamu obwa bulijjo.
For example, defects in the activation of pro-inflammatory response in bats efficiently reduce the pathology triggered by CoVs.
Okugeza, obunafu mu kuzimba okujjawo mu buwundo bukendeeza embeera etali ya bulijjo ereetebwa CoVs.

Besides, the natural killer cell activity in bats is suppressed due to upregulation of inhibitory natural killer cell receptor NKG2/CD94 and low expression level of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules.

Okwongereza ku ekyo, okufa kw’obutaffaali okw’obutonde mu buwundo kuzibikirwa nga kiva ku kukendeeza kwa butaffaali bw’obutonde obw’ekifuna obuwuka NKG2/CD94 wamu n’okweyoleka okwa wansi okw’amaanyi okw’obukolaganyi bwa molecules ez’ekibinja I.

Moreover, the high level of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated from high metabolic activity of bats could both suppress CoV replication and affects proofreading by exoribonuclease, thus providing the selection pressure for the generation of virus strains highly pathogenic when introduced into a new host.

So ng’ate, ebika bya oxygen species (ROS) ava mu kukola emmere mu mubiri mu buwundo kuyinza okunyigiriza okuzaalukana kwa CoV n’okukosa proofreading by exoribonuclease, ne kivaamu okunyigiriza kw’okulonda okuleeta ebika by’akawuka ebireeta ennyo endwadde nga biteereddwa mu kitundu ekirala ekibeerako obuwuka.
More pathogenic CoV strains might also evolve by recombination, leading to the acquisition of novel proteins or protein features for host adaptation.
Obuwuka bwa CoV obulala nabwo buyinza okukula nga bwegattagatta, ne kireetawo protein ezibadde tezimanyiddwa oba obubonero bwa protein obusobozesa ekibeerako obuwuka okumanyiira.
Thus, it is not by chance that three novel HCoVs have emerged in the past two decades.
Awo nno, si kya mukisa bukisa nti HCoVs obubadde tebumayiddwa bubaluseewo mu myaka abiri egiyise.
CoVs are non-pathogenic or cause mild symptoms in their reservoir hosts such as bats and camels.
CoVs tebuleeta ndwadde oba buleeta obubonero butono mu ekyo ekisaasaanya gamba ng’obuwundo n’eŋŋamiya.
They replicate robustly without eliciting a strong host immune response.
Buzaalukana nnyo ate nga tebuleeta busibage bwa maanyi ku kintu ekibeerako endwadde.
Herein lie the secrets of why asymptomatic carriers are seen and what causes the severe cases in human infection.
Muno mwe muli ekyama ekireetera ebisaasaanya endwadde ebitalina bubonero okulabibwa n’ekireetawo obulwadde obw’akabi ennyo mu bantu.
The severe symptoms are mainly due to the hyperactivation of immune response and the cytokine storm wherein the stronger the immune response, the more severe the lung damage.

Obubonero obw’akabi businga kuva ku kutanula obusibage n’obubonero obw’akabi ennyo (cytokine storm) ne kiba nti obusibage gye bukoma okuba obw’amaanyi, n’okukosebwa kw’amawuggwe gye kukoma okuba okw’omutawaana.
In contrast, in asymptomatic carriers, the immune response has been de-coupled from CoV replication.
Mu kugeraageranya n’abantu abatalabikirako bubonero, obusibage bulemesebwa okwekubisaamu mu kuzaalukana kwa CoV.
The same strategy of delinking the immune response might have beneficial effects in anti-SARS-CoV-2 therapy.
Akakodyo ke kamu ak’okuggyawo obukwatane bw’obusibage kuyinza okuba n’emiganyulo mu kujjanjaba SARS-CoV-2.
The interferon response is particularly strong in bats.
Enkola ya interferon ya maanyi nnyo mu buwundo.
Thus, administration of type I interferon at least in the early phase of SARS-CoV-2 infection in humans should be beneficial.
Awo nno, okukola ku type I interferon waakiri ng’okukosebwa kwa SARS-CoV-2 kwakalabika mu bantu kuteekwa oba nga kuvaamu ebirungi.
In addition, NLRP3 inflammasome activation in bats is defective.
Mu ngeri y’emu, okuleetera okukola kwa NLRP3 inflammasome mu buwundo tekivaamu kantu.
By this reasoning, inhibition of NLRP3 inflammasome with MCC950 might be useful in the treatment of COVID-19.
Mu ntegeera eno, okukugira kwa NLRP3 inflammasome nga kuli wamu ne MCC950 kuyinza okuyamba mu bujjanjabi bwa COVID-19.
The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 follows the general theme by which SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV arose.
Okubalukawo kwa SARS-CoV-2 kugoberera omulamwa ogw’awamu omwasibukira SARS-CoV ne MERS-CoV.
Whereas a bat beta-CoV sharing 95% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV has been found, there also exists a bat-CoV sharing 96% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV-2.
Weewaawo kizuuliddwa nti beta-CoV kagabana ebitundu 95% ebya nucleotide ne SARS-CoV, waliwo era ka CoV k’akawundo akagabana ebitundu 96% ebya nucleotide ne SARS-CoV-2.
Whereas civets and other animals in the markets have been found to harbour viruses identical to SARS-CoV, immediate intermediate hosts for SARS-CoV-2 have not been identified.
Weewaawo effumbe n’ensolo endala ezitundibwa mu butale zizuuliddwa okukweka obuwuka obufaananako ne SARS-CoV, ekibeerako obuwuka ekitasaasaanya SARS-CoV-2 tekinnazuulibwa.

Pangolin beta-CoVs strikingly homologous to SARS-CoV-2 have been found, indicating that pangolins might serve as one of intermediate hosts or pangolin beta-CoVs could contribute gene fragments to the final version of SARS-CoV-2.

Pangolin beta-CoVs obwewuunyisa okufaanagana ne SARS-CoV-2 buzuuliddwa, ekiraga nti pangolin ziyinza okukola ng’ekibeerako obuwuka ekitasaasaanya oba pangolin beta-CoVs kayinza okuba nga kalina obutundutundu bwa giini bwe kaleeta ku nkula ya SARS-CoV-2 esembayo.
Although questions remain, there is no evidence that SARS-CoV-2 is man-made either deliberately or accidentally.
Weewaawo nga wakyaliwo ebibuuzo, tewali bubaka bulaga nti SARS-CoV-2 yakolebwa muntu mu bugenderevu oba mu ngeri etali ŋŋenderere.
CoVs have returned to the limelight due to the recent outbreak of SARS-CoV-2.
CoVs bukomyewo okumanyika mu bantu olw’okubalukawo kwa SARS-CoV-2 okuzzeewo emabegako.
The study of CoVs in bats and other animals has drastically changed our perception of the importance of zoonotic origins and animal reservoirs of HCoVs in human transmission.
Okunoonyereza ku CoVs mu buwundo n’ensolo endala kukyusizza mu ngeri ey’amangu entegeera y’omugaso gw’endwadde eziva mu nsolo n’ensolo ezibeerako obuwuka bwa HCoVs mu kusaasaanya endwadde mu bantu.
Pervasive evidence has shown that SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 have a bat origin and are transmitted to humans via intermediate hosts.
Obubaka obw’amaanyi bulaze nti SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV ne SARS-CoV-2 buva mu buwundo era nga busaasaanyizibwa mu bantu nga buyitira ku bintu ebibeerako obuwuka ebitasaasaanya.
Given that SARS-CoV infection originates from the contact between humans and civets in the markets, closing wet markets and killing civets therein could have effectively ended the SARS epidemic.

Olw’okuba nti obulwadde bwa SARS-CoV buva mu nkwatagana wakati w’abantu n’amafumbe mu butale, okuggala obutale obutundibwamu ebintu ebibisi n’okutta amafumbe kyandiyambye nnyo mu kukomya nawookeera wa SARS.

By the same reasoning, pangolins should be removed from wet markets to prevent zoonotic transmission, in view of the discovery of multiple lineages of pangolin beta-CoVs closely related to SARS-CoV-2.

Mu ngeri y’emu, pangolins zirina okuggyibwa mu butale obutundibwamu ebintu ebibisi olw’okuziyiza okusaasaanya endwadde eziva mu nsolo okudda mu bantu, nga tutunuulira okuzuula ennyiriri ez’enjawulo eza pangolin beta-CoVs ezeekwanya ennyo ku SARS-CoV-2.
However, whether and how SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted to humans through pangolins and other mammals remain to be clarified in future investigations.
Wabula, oba nga SARS-CoV-2 asaasaanyibwa mu bantu ng’ayitira mu pangolins n’ensolo endala eziringa abantu n’engeri gy’asaasaanyizibwamu kijja kuzuulibwa eyo mu kunoonyereza okujja eyo mu maaso.
On the other hand, MERS-CoV has existed in dromedary camels for a long time.
Ku ludda olulala, MERS-CoV kabadde mu ŋŋamiya okumala ebbanga eriwera.
These camels serve as an important tool for transportation as well as a main source of meat, milk, leather and wool products for the local people.
Eŋŋamiya za mugaso nnyo mu ntambula ate ng’era zivaako nnyo ennyama, amata, amaliba n’ebyoya eri abantu.
They are widely distributed across the Middle East and Africa.
Ziri nnyo mu bitundu bya Middle East ne Afrika.
It is therefore impossible to sacrifice all camels for the control of MERS, as what was done in wild animal markets in China to prevent the spreading of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2.
Awo nno kizibu nnyo okutta eŋŋamiya zonna olw’okuziyiza MERS, ng’ekyakolebwa mu butale bw’ensolo ez’omu nsiko mu China okuziyiza okusaasaana kwa SARS-CoV ne SARS-CoV-2.
To stop the recurrent outbreaks of MERS, a comprehensive approach should be taken to develop effective vaccines against MERS-CoV for camels, in combination with other infection control measures.

Okusobola okuziyiza okubalukawo kwa MERS okutatadde, enkwata y’obulwadde buno erina okukulaakulanyizibwa okukola eddagala erigema MERS-CoV ery’eŋŋamiya, nga likolera wamu n’engeri endala eziziyiza obulwadde.
As we are not able to eliminate these viruses, new genotypes might emerge to cause outbreaks.
Olw’okuba nti tetusobola kumalawo buwuka buno, ekika ky’obuwuka obulala kisobola okubalukawo okuleeta nawookeera omulala.
A variety of zoonotic CoVs are circulating in the wild.
Obuwuka obw’enjawulo obwa CoV obusaasaanya endwadde okuva mu nsolo okudda mu bantu bubunye mu nsiko.
Particularly, bat CoVs with zoonotic potential are so diverse.
N’okusingira ddala, bu CoV obw’obuwundo obulina obusobozi bw’okusaasaanya endwadde okuva mu nsoolo okudda mu bantu bwa ngeri nnyingi.
There are plenty of opportunities that these zoonotic CoVs evolve and recombine, resulting in the emergence of new CoVs that are more transmissible and/or deadly in humans in future.
Waliwo emikisa mingi nti bu CoV obusaasaanya endwadde okuva mu nsolo okudda mu bantu bwegattagatta nga kiva mu kubalukawo bu CoV obupya obutambuzibwa amangu ne/oba mu bantu eyo gye bujja.
The culture of eating wild animals in some places of China should be abandoned to reduce unnecessary contact between humans and animals.
Empisa y’okulya ensolo ez’omu nsiko mu bifo ebimu mu China erina okusuulibwa okukendeeza ku nkwatagana eteetaagisa wakati w’abantu n’ensolo.
With the ordeals of SARS, MERS and COVID-19, a better preparedness and response plan should be in place.
Nga tuli mu katyabaga ka SARS, MERS ne COVID-19, okweteekateeka okusingako obulungi n’enteekateeka ey’okubyaŋŋanga zirina okubeerawo.
In fact, many viruses have existed in the planet for a very long time.
Mu butuufu, obuwuka bungi bubaddewo mu nsi okumala ebbanga ddene ddala.
They stay in their own natural reservoirs until there is a chance for spillover.
Bubeera mu bifo byabwo eby’obutonde okutuusa lwe walabikawo omukisa ne bubuukayo okugenda ewalala.

Although bats have many features that favours the spreading of viruses, the chance for humans to be in contact with bats and other wildlife species can be minimized if people are educated to stay away from them.

Newankubadde ng’obuwundo bulina obukole bungi obubusobozesa okusaasaanya obuwuka, omukisa gw’abantu okukwatagana n’obuwundo n’ebika ebirala eby’omu nsiko gusobola okukendeezebwa abantu bwe bategeezebwa okwewala okubisemberera.

Continuous surveillance in mammals is necessary for better understanding of the ecology of CoVs and their natural hosts, which will prove useful in preventing animal-to-human transmission and future outbreaks.

Okwekaliriza entakera kwetaagisa mu nsolo eziringa abantu olw’okutegeera enkula ya CoVs mu ngeri esingako wamu n’ebyo ebibeerako obuwuka ebyobutonde ebijja okulabika nga bya mugaso mu kuziyiza okusaasaanya endwadde okuva ku nsolo-okudda-mu-bantu wamu ne nawookeera ow’omu maaso.
To conclude, the most effective way to prevent viral zoonosis is for humans to stay away from the ecological niches of the natural reservoirs of the zoonotic viruses.

Mu kufundikira, engeri esinga obulungi ey’okuziyiza obuwuka obuva ku nsolo okudda mu bantu be bantu okuva ku bintu eby’obutonde ebibeerako obuwuka obusaasaanya endwadde okuva ku nsolo okudda mu bantu.
Several pieces in the puzzle of the zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2 are still missing.
Waliwo ebintu bingi ebitannaba kutegeerekeka ku nsibuko y’obulwadde bwa SARS-CoV-2 obuva mu nsolo okudda mu bantu.
First, if bats transmit an ancestral virus of SARS-CoV-2 to pangolins, it will be of interest to see under what circumstances bats and pangolins could share the same ecological niche.
Okusookera ddala, oba ng’obuwundo busaasaanya akawuka akasibukamu SARS-CoV-2 mu pangolin, kiba kisaana okulaba embeera obuwundo ne pangolin mwe bigabanira okubeerana mu bifo gye bibeera.
Second, if bats play a more direct role in human transmission, how humans get into contact with bats should be determined.
Ekyokubiri, oba ng’obuwundo buzannya ekifo ky’okusaasaanya obulwadde obutereevu mu bantu, olwo nno engeri abantu gye bakwataganamu n’obuwundo erina okufiibwako.
Third, if a third mammal acts as the true intermediate host, how it interacts with the different species including humans, bats and pangolins has to be clarified.
Ekyokusatu, ensolo eringa omuntu bw’eba nga y’ekola nga ekibeerako obuwuka ekitasaasaanya ekituufu, engeri gye kitabaganamu n’ebika ebirala omuli n’abantu, obuwundo ne pangolin erina okutangaazibwa.
Finally, since many mammals including domestic animals might be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, both surveillance and experimental infection should be conducted.
Ekisembayo, olw’okubanga ensolo nnyingi eziringa abantu omwo nga mwe muli n’ez’awaka ziyinza okuba nga zikwatibwa mangu SARS-CoV-2, okwekaliriza n’okugezesa kw’obulwadde byombi birina okukolebwa.
Should it be a bat, a pangolin or another mammal, it is expected that SARS-CoV-2 or its parental viruses that are almost identical will be identified in its natural hosts in future.

Singa kanaaba kawundo, pangolin oba ensolo endala eringa omuntu, kisuubirwa nti SARS-CoV-2 oba obuwuka obulala obusibukako obulwadde nga kumpi bufaanagana bujja kuzuulibwa mu kibeerako obuwuka obwo eky’obutonde eyo gye bujja.
Continued investigations in this area will elucidate the evolutionary pathway of SARS-CoV-2 in animals, with important implications in the prevention and control of COVID-19 in humans.
Okunoonyereza entakera ku nsonga eno kujja kutangaaza omugendo gw’enkula ya SARS-CoV-2 mu nsolo, omuli n’ebivaamu eby’omugaso mu kutangira n’okuziyiza COVID-19 mu bantu.
Preliminary Estimates of the Prevalence of Selected Underlying Health Conditions Among Patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019 — United States, February 12–March 28, 2020
Ebiteeberezebwa Ebisookerwako ku Birondeddwa mu Mbeera z’Abalwadde abalina obulwadde bwa Coronavirus 2019 — United States, Ogwokubiri 12–Ogwokusatu 28, 2020
On March 11, 2020, the World Health Organization declared Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) a pandemic.
Nga 11 Ogwokusatu, 2020, Ekitongole ky’Ensi yonna eky’Ebyobulamu (WHO) kyalangirira obulwadde bwa Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) ng’ekizibu eky’awamu mu nsi.
As of March 28, 2020, a total of 571,678 confirmed COVID-19 cases and 26,494 deaths have been reported worldwide.
Nga 28 Ogwokusatu 2020 we lwatuukira, omugatte gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 gwali 571,678 n’abafudde nga bali 26,494 mu nsi yonna.
Reports from China and Italy suggest that risk factors for severe disease include older age and the presence of at least one of several underlying health conditions.
Ebiva mu China ne Italy biraga nti ensonga ez’obulabe ku bulwadde buno zizingiramu okukulirira mu myaka n’okusangibwamu waakiri obulwadde obw’engeri emu.

U.S. older adults, including those aged ≥65 years and particularly those aged ≥85 years, also appear to be at higher risk for severe COVID-19–associated outcomes; however, data describing underlying health conditions among U.S. COVID-19 patients have not yet been reported.

Abantu abakulu mu U.S. omuli n’abo abalina emyaka ≥65, ate naddala abo abalina emyaka ≥85 nabo balabika bali mu bulabe bwa maanyi obw’okulumbibwa ekirwadde kya COVID-19; wabula, obubaka obunnyonnyola obulwadde abalwadde ba COVID-19 bwe balina tebunnaba kutegeezebwa.

As of March 28, 2020, U.S. states and territories have reported 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases to CDC, including 7,162 (5.8%) for whom data on underlying health conditions and other known risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections were reported.

Nga 28 Ogwokusatu, 2020 we lwatuukira, amasaza ga U.S. gaategeeza nti waliwo abalwadde ba COVID-19 abawera 122,653 mu U.S. ku CDC omwo nga mwe muli 7,162 (5.8%) abaggyibwako obubaka obukwata ku ndwadde endala n’obulabe obulala bwe balina mu muyungiro gw’okussa.
Among these 7,162 cases, 2,692 (37.6%) patients had one or more underlying health condition or risk factor, and 4,470 (62.4%) had none of these conditions reported.

Mu balwadde bano 7,162, abalwadde 2,692 (37.6%) baalina obuzibu obw’engeri emu bwe baasangibwa nabwo oba obulabe obulala, ate ng’abalwadde 4,470 (62.4%) bo tebaalina mbeera za ngeri eyo zaategeezebwa.

The percentage of COVID-19 patients with at least one underlying health condition or risk factor was higher among those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission (358 of 457, 78%) and those requiring hospitalization without ICU admission (732 of 1,037, 71%) than that among those who were not hospitalized (1,388 of 5,143, 27%).

Omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 ku kikumi abalina waakiri embeera y’obulwadde obulala oba obulabe obulala gwali munene mu balwadde abaali beetaaga okussibwa ku bujjanjabi obw’amaanyi (ICU) (358 of 457, 78%) n’abo abaali beetaaga okuweebwa ebitanda naye nga tebateekeddwa ku bujjanjabi bwa maanyi (732 of 1,037, 71%) okusinga abo abaali tebeetaaga kuweebwa bitanda mu malwaliro (1,388 of 5,143, 27%).
The most commonly reported conditions were diabetes mellitus, chronic lung disease, and cardiovascular disease.
Obulwadde obwasinga okulabibwa mwalimu sukaali (diabetes mellitus), obulwadde bw’amawuggwe obw’olukonvuba n’obulwadde bw’omutima (cardiovascular disease).

These preliminary findings suggest that in the United States, persons with underlying health conditions or other recognized risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections appear to be at a higher risk for severe disease from COVID-19 than are persons without these conditions.

Ebizuuliddwa bino ebisookerwako biraga nti mu Amerika, abantu abasangibwa n’obulwadde oba obuzibu obulala obw’obulabe obukosa omuyungiro gw’okussa balabika okubeera mu bulabe bwa maanyi obw’okukosebwa COVID-19 okusinga abantu abatalina buzibu bulinga obwo.

Data from laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases reported to CDC from 50 states, four U.S. territories and affiliated islands, the District of Columbia, and New York City with February 12–March 28, 2020 onset dates were analyzed.

Obubaka obuva mu ggezeserezo bwakakasa abalwadde ba COVID-19 obwategeezebwa CDC okuva mu mawanga 50, ebitundu bya U.S. bina wamu n’ebizinga ebikolagana n’amawanga ago, District of Columbia, ne New York City nga 12 Ogwokubiri – 28 Ogwokusatu, 2020 ng’ennaku z’omwezi ezitandikirwako.
Cases among persons repatriated to the United States from Wuhan, China, and the Diamond Princess cruise ship were excluded.
Abalwadde abaali mu bantu abazzibwa mu United States okuva mu Wuhan, China, ne Diamond Princess cruise ship tebaabalibwa.

For cases with missing onset dates, date of onset was estimated by subtracting 4 days (median interval from symptom onset to specimen collection date among cases with known dates in these data) from the earliest specimen collection.

Ku balwadde abataliiko nnaku za mwezi zitandikirwako, ennaku z’omwezi ezitandikirwako zaateeberezebwa na kwawula nnaku 4 (omuwendo omukkati okuva obubonero lwe bwatandika okulabika n’ennaku z’omwezi ezimanyiddwa lwe baggyibwako sampolo mu balwadde abamnyiddwako ennaku z’omwezi ku bubaka bwabwe) okuva ku sampolo ezaasooka okukuŋŋaanyizibwa.

Public health departments reported cases to CDC using a standardized case report form that captures information (yes, no, or unknown) on the following conditions and potential risk factors: chronic lung disease (inclusive of asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], and emphysema); diabetes mellitus; cardiovascular disease; chronic renal disease; chronic liver disease; immunocompromised condition; neurologic disorder, neurodevelopmental, or intellectual disability; pregnancy; current smoking status; former smoking status; or other chronic disease.

Ebitongole by’Ebyobulamu byategeeza CDC nti waaliwo abalwadde nga bikozesa alipoota eyali etegekeddwa okuva mu bubaka obwakuŋŋaanyizibwanga (yee, nedda, tekimanyiddwa) ku mbeera zino wammanga n’ensonga eziyinza okuba ez’obulabe: obulwadde bw’amawuggwe obw’olukonvuba (omwo nga mwe muli olufuba, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], ne emphysema); sukaali (diabetes mellitus); obulwadde bw’omutima (cardiovascula disease); obulwadde bw’ensigo obw’olukonvuba (chronic renal disease); obulwadde bw’ekibumba obw’olukonvuba (chronic liver disease); obusibage obutakola (immunocompromised condition); obuzibu ku muyungiro gw’obusimu (neurologic disorder), obulemu ku busimu (neurodevelopmental disability), oba obulemu ku bwongo (intellectual disability); abalina embuto; okunywa oba obutanywa sigala mu kiseera kino; eyali anyweddeko oba atanywangako ku sigala oba endwadde endala ez’olukonvuba.

Data reported to CDC are preliminary and can be updated by health departments over time; critical data elements might be missing at the time of initial report; thus, this analysis is descriptive, and no statistical comparisons could be made.

Obubaka obuweerezebwa CDC bwa kiseera era busobola okutereezebwa ebitongole by’ebyobulamu nga wayise ekiseera; wayinza okubaawo ebibula mu bubaka obwo mu kiseera we busooka okuweerezebwa; noolwekyo okwekenneenya kuno kunnyonnyozi era tewali bibalo byandiyinzizza kukolebwa.
The percentages of patients of all ages with underlying health conditions who were not hospitalized, hospitalized without ICU admission, and hospitalized with ICU admission were calculated.

Emiwendo ku kikumi egy’abalwadde ab’emyaka gyonna abalina obulwadde bwe baasangibwa nabwo abataaweebwa bitanda, abaaweebwa ebitanda ne bataweebwa bujjanjabi bwa maanyi, n’abaaweebwa ebitanda ne baweebwa objjanjabi obw’amaanyi gyabalibwa.
Percentages of hospitalizations with and without ICU admission were estimated for persons aged ≥19 years with and without underlying health conditions.

Emiwendo ku kikumi egy’abalwadde abaaweebwa ebitanda mu malwaliro ne bassibwa ku bujjanjabi obw’amaanyi n’obutali bwa maanyi bwateeberezebwa okuba mu bantu abalina emyaka ≥19 abaasangibwa n’abataasangibwa na bulwadde bulala.
This part of the analysis was limited to persons aged ≥19 years because of the small sample size of cases in children with reported underlying health conditions (N = 32).
Ekitundu ky’okwekaliriza kino kyakugirwa ku bantu abalina emyaka ≥19 olw’omuwendo gw’abaana omutono ogugeraageranyizibwako abaategeezebwa nga baasangibwamu endwadde endala (N = 32).

To account for missing data among these preliminary reports, ranges were estimated with a lower bound including cases with both known and unknown status for hospitalization with and without ICU admission as the denominator and an upper bound using only cases with known outcome status as the denominator.

Okusobola okufaayo ku bubaka obubulako mu alipoota ez’ekiseera, emiwendo egy’ebigero gyateeberezebwa n’egya wansi omwo nga mwe muli n’abalwadde abamanyiddwa n’abatamanyiddwa oba baafuna ebitanda mu malwaliro ne bafuna oba ne batafuna bujjanjabi bwa najwulo nga kye kikozesebwa ng’ekisalirwako ate era n’okusalira ku balwadde abamanyiddwako embeera y’obulamu bwabwe nga bamaze okukeberebwa.

Because of small sample size and missing data on underlying health conditions among COVID-19 patients who died, case-fatality rates for persons with and without underlying conditions were not estimated.

Olw’omuwendo omutono ogugeraageranyizibwako n’obubaka obutaliiwo ku bulwadde abalwadde ba COVID-19 bwe baasangibwa nabwo naye ng’abalwadde abo baafa, emiwendo gy’abalwadde abaafa nga balina oba nga tebalina bulwadde bulala tegyateeberezebwa.
As of March 28, 2020, a total of 122,653 laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases (Figure) and 2,112 deaths were reported to CDC.
Nga 28 Ogwokusatu 2020, omugatte gw’abalwadde 122,653 abaakeberebwa mu ggezeserezo ne bakakasibwa nti balina COVID-19 (Ekifaananyi) n’abaafa 2,112 be baaweerezebwa ku CDC.
Case report forms were submitted to CDC for 74,439 (60.7%) cases.
Foomu z’abalwadde 74,439 (60.7%) enzijuze zaaweerezebwa ku CDC.

Data on presence or absence of underlying health conditions and other recognized risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections (i.e., smoking and pregnancy) were available for 7,162 (5.8%) patients (Table 1).

Obubaka ku baasangibwa n’obulwadde oba abataasangibwa nabwo n’obuzibu obulala obw’obulabe ku muyungiro gw’okussa (kwe kugamba, okunywa sigala n’okubeera n’olubuto) bwaliwo era nga bwa balwadde 7,162 (5.8%) (Omweso 1).
Approximately one third of these patients (2,692, 37.6%), had at least one underlying condition or risk factor.
Mu kuteebereza, abalwadde ebitundu nga kimu kyakusatu (2,692, 37.6%), baasangibwa n’obulwadde oba n’obuzibu obw’obulabe.
Diabetes mellitus (784, 10.9%), chronic lung disease (656, 9.2%), and cardiovascular disease (647, 9.0%) were the most frequently reported conditions among all cases.
Sukaali (diabetes mellitus) (784, 10.9%), obulwadde bw’ekibumba obw’olukonvuba (656, 9.2%), n’obulwadde bw’omutima (647, 9.0%) bwe bulwadde obwasinga okulabika mu balwadde bonna.
Among 457 ICU admissions and 1,037 non-ICU hospitalizations, 358 (78%) and 732 (71%), respectively occurred among persons with one or more reported underlying health condition.

Mu balwadde 457 abaaweebwa ebitanda ne bassibwa ku bujjanjabi obw’amaanyi n’abalwadde 1,037 abaaweebwa ebitanda naye ne batassibwa ku bujjanjabi bwa maanyi, 358 (78%) ne 732 (71%), ng’emiwendo bwe gigoberegana be baazuulibwa mu balwadde abaasangibwa n’obulwadde obw’engeri emu oba okusingawo.
In contrast, 1,388 of 5,143 (27%) COVID-19 patients who were not hospitalized were reported to have at least one underlying health condition.
Mu kugeraageranya, abalwadde 1,388 ku 5,143 (27%) abalina COVID-19 abataaweebwa bitanda mu ddwaliro baategeeza nti baasangibwa waakiri n’obulwadde obw’engeri emu.

Among patients aged ≥19 years, the percentage of non-ICU hospitalizations was higher among those with underlying health conditions (27.3%–29.8%) than among those without underlying health conditions (7.2%–7.8%); the percentage of cases that resulted in an ICU admission was also higher for those with underlying health conditions (13.3%–14.5%) than those without these conditions (2.2%–2.4%) (Table 2).

Mu balwadde abaalina emyaka ≥19, omuwendo ku kikumi ogw’abalwadde abaaweebwa ebitanda naye ne batassibwa ku bujjanjabi bwa maanyi gwali munene ku abo abaasangibwa n’obulwadde obulala (27.3%–29.8%) okusinga abo abataasangibwa na bulwadde bulala (7.2%–7.8%); omuwendo gw’abalwadde ku kimu abaaweebwa ebitanda ne bassibwa ku bujjanjabi obw’amaanyi nagwo gwali waggulu mu balwadde abaasangibwa n’obulwadde obulala (13.3%–14.5%) okusinga abo abataasangibwa na bulwadde bulala (2.2%–2.4%) (Omweso 2).
Small numbers of COVID-19 patients aged < 19 years were reported to be hospitalized (48) or admitted to an ICU (eight).
Omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 mutono abaalina emyaka egikka wansi wa 19 kyategeerekeka nti baaweebwa ebitanda (48) oba baaweebwa obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi (munaana).
In contrast, 335 patients aged < 19 years were not hospitalized and 1,342 had missing data on hospitalization.
Mu kugeraageranya, abalwadde 335 abaalina emyaka egikka wansi wa 19 tebaaweebwa bitanda ate 1,342 tebaalina biboogerako kulaga oba nga baaweewa ebitanda.

Among all COVID-19 patients with complete information on underlying conditions or risk factors, 184 deaths occurred (all among patients aged ≥19 years); 173 deaths (94%) were reported among patients with at least one underlying condition.

Mu balwadde ba COVID-19 abaalina obubaka obujjuvu ku bulwadde obulala bwe baasangibwa nabwo, abalwadde 184 baafa (bonna baali mu balwadde ab’emyaka ≥19); abaafa 173 (94%) kyategeezebwa nti baali mu balwadde abaasangibwa waakiri n’obulwadde obulala.

Among 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases reported to CDC as of March 28, 2020, 7,162 (5.8%) patients had data available pertaining to underlying health conditions or potential risk factors; among these patients, higher percentages of patients with underlying conditions were admitted to the hospital and to an ICU than patients without reported underlying conditions.

Mu balwadde 122,653 mu U.S. aba COVID-19 abaaweerezebwa ku CDC nga 28 Ogwokusatu 2020, abalwadde 7,162 (5.8%) baalina obubaka obubakwatako ku ndwadde endala ze baasangibwa nazo oba obulabe obulala; mu balwadde abo, omuwendo ku kikumi munene ku abo abaasangibwa n’obulwadde obulala baaweebwa ebitanda era ne bassibwa ne ku bujjanjabi obw’amaanyi okusinga abalwadde abataasangibwa na bulwadde bulala.

These results are consistent with findings from China and Italy, which suggest that patients with underlying health conditions and risk factors, including, but not limited to, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, COPD, coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, chronic renal disease, and smoking, might be at higher risk for severe disease or death from COVID-19.

Ebyazuulibwa bino bikwatagana n’ebyazuulibwa mu China ne Italy, ekitegeeza nti abalwadde abaalina endwadde endala n’obulabe obulala ng’obumu ku bwo mulimu sukaali (diabetes mellitus), puleesa (hypertension), COPD, obulwadde bw’omusiwa ogutwala omusaayi ku mutima, obulwadde bw’obwongo (cerebrovascular disease), chronic renal disease, n’okunywa sigala, bayinza okuba n’emikisa gy’okulwala ennyo oba okuttibwa COVID-19.

This analysis was limited by small numbers and missing data because of the burden placed on reporting health departments with rapidly rising case counts, and these findings might change as additional data become available.

Okwekaliriza kuno kwakomerwa emiwendo emitono n’obubaka obutaaliwo olw’okukaluubirirwa ebitongole by’ebyobulamu kwe byasanga mu kutegeeza obubaka obwo olw’obungi bw’abalwadde abeeyiwa mu malwaliro, era ebyazuulibwa bino biyinza okukyusa obubaka obulala bwe bunaafunika.
It is not yet known whether the severity or level of control of underlying health conditions affects the risk for severe disease associated with COVID-19.

Tekinnaba kutegeerekeka oba ng’obuzibu bw’obulwadde obulala omuntu bw’aba nabwo oba okujjanjaba obulwadde obulala omuntu bwasangiddwa nabwo kikosa obulabe bw’obulwadde obw’amaanyi omuntu bwe yandifunye nga buva ku COVID-19.

Many of these underlying health conditions are common in the United States: based on self-reported 2018 data, the prevalence of diagnosed diabetes among U.S. adults was 10.1%, and the U.S. age-adjusted prevalence of all types of heart disease (excluding hypertension without other heart disease) was 10.6% in 2017.

Obulwadde obwo obulala bwa mwero nnyo mu United States: okusinziira ku bubaka abantu bennyini bwe beewaako mu 2018, omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba sukaali abaasangibwa mu bantu abakulu mu U.S. baali ebitundu 10.1%, ate omuwendo ogwakyusibwamu mu U.S. ogw’abalwadde abalina obulwadde bw’omutima obw’engeri zonna (ng’oggyeeko puleesa omutali ndwadde za mutima ndala) gwali 10.6% mu 2017.
The age-adjusted prevalence of COPD among U.S. adults is 5.9%, and in 2018, the U.S. estimated prevalence of current asthma among persons of all ages was 7.9%.
Emyaka bwe gyakyusibwamu obulwadde bwa COPD mu bantu abakulu mu U.S. ne gidda ku 5.9%, ate mu 2018, U.S. yateebereza nti obulwadde bw’olufuba obwali mu bantu ab’emyaka gyonna bwali ku 7.9%.
CDC continues to develop and update resources for persons with underlying health conditions to reduce the risk of acquiring COVID-19.
CDC kigenda mu maaso n’okukulaakulanya n’okuzza obuggya ebikozesebwa abantu abalina obulwadde obulala okusobola okukendeeza ku bulabe bw’okukwatibwa COVID-19.

The estimated higher prevalence of these conditions among those in this early group of U.S. COVID-19 patients and the potentially higher risk for more severe disease from COVID-19 associated with the presence of underlying conditions highlight the importance of COVID-19 prevention in persons with underlying conditions.

Omuwendo oguteeberezebwa ogw’embeera ezo mu abo abali mu kibinja kino ekyasooka eky’abalwadde ba COVID-19 mu U.S. abalwadde ba COVID-19 wamu n’obulabe obw’amaani obw’obulwadde obw’obulabe obuva ku COVID-19 obwekwanya n’obulwadde obulala bwe baalina bulaga bulungi omugaso gw’okutangira COVID-19 mu bantu abalina obulwadde obulala.
The findings in this report are subject to at least six limitations.
Ebizuuliddwa ebiri mu alipoota eno bikugirwa waakiri ebintu mukaaga.

First, these data are preliminary, and the analysis was limited by missing data related to the health department reporting burden associated with rapidly rising case counts and delays in completion of information requiring medical chart review; these findings might change as additional data become available.

Ekisooka, obubaka buno bwe busookerwako era okwekaliriza kwakugirwa obubaka obwekwanya ku kitongole ky’ebyobulamu ekyategeeza obuzito bw’okufuna abalwadde abangi wamu n’okulwawo okujjuza obubaka obwali bwetaagisa okwekaliriza ekipande ky’omulwadde; ebyazuulibwa bino bisobola okukyuka obubaka obulala bwe bunaafunika.
Information on underlying conditions was only available for 7,162 (5.8%) of 122,653 cases reported to CDC.
Obubaka obukwata ku ndwadde endala abantu ze balina bwaliwo ku balwadde 7,162 (5.8%) ku 122,653 abaaweerezebwa ku CDC.
It cannot be assumed that those with missing information are similar to those with data on either hospitalizations or underlying health conditions.
Tekisobola kutwalibwa butwalibwa nti abo abataliiko bubaka obwo be bamu n’abo abalina obubaka ku kuweebwa ebitanda oba abaasangibwa n’endwadde endala.
Second, these data are subject to bias in outcome ascertainment because of short follow-up time.
Ekyokubiri, obubaka buno bwandibaamu kyekubiira ku bivaamu olw’obudde bw’okulondoola okubeera obumpi.
Some outcomes might be underestimated, and long-term outcomes cannot be assessed in this analysis.
Ebivaamu ebirala biyinza obutateeberezebwa bulungi ate ebivaamu eby’ebbanga eggwanvu tebisobola kwekalirizibwa mu kwekenneenya kuno.

Third, because of the limited availability of testing in many jurisdictions during this period, this analysis is likely biased toward more severe cases, and findings might change as testing becomes more widespread.

Ekyokusatu, olw’obufunda bw’okukebera mu bifo ebimu mu kiseera kino, okwekenneenya kuno kulabika okubeeramu kyekubiira ku balwadde abali obubi ennyo era ebizuuliddwa bino bisobola okukyuka obubaka obulala bwe bunaafunika.

Fourth, because of the descriptive nature of these data, attack rates among persons with and without underlying health conditions could not be compared, and thus the risk difference of severe disease with COVID-19 between these groups could not be estimated.

Ekyokuna, olw’okuba obubaka buno bunnyonnyozi okulwala kw’abantu abaalina n’abataalina bulwadde kusobola okugeraageranyizibwa era bwe kityo enjawulo mu bulabe bw’obulwadde bwa COVID-19 wakati w’ebibinja bino busobola okuteebereebwa.
Fifth, no conclusions could be drawn about underlying conditions that were not included in the case report form or about different conditions that were reported in a single, umbrella category.

Ekyokutaanu, tewali kukubira kuyinza kutuukibwako ku bulwadde abantu bwe baasangibwa nabwo obutaateekebwa ku foomu y’alipoota z’abwalwadde oba ku mbeera ez’enjawulo ezaategeezebwa ku kibinja ky’abalwadde ab’ekika ekimu.
For example, asthma and COPD were included in a chronic lung disease category.
Okugeza, olufuba ne COPD bwateekebwa mu kibinja ky’obulwadde bw’amawuggwe obw’olukonvuba.

Finally, for some underlying health conditions and risk factors, including neurologic disorders, chronic liver disease, being a current smoker, and pregnancy, few severe outcomes were reported; therefore, conclusions cannot be drawn about the risk for severe COVID-19 among persons in these groups.

Ekisembayo, ku bulwadde obulala abantu bwe baali nabwo n’obulabe obulala omwo nga mwe muli n’obulemu ku bwongo, obulwadde bw’ekibumba obw’olukonvuba, okubeera ng’onywa sigala mu kiseera kino n’okubeera n’olubuto, ebivaamu bitono ebyategeezebwa; awo nno, tewali kukubira kuyinza kutuukibwako ku bulabe bwa COVID-19 mu bantu abagwa mu bibinja bino.
Persons in the United States with underlying health conditions appear to be at higher risk for more severe COVID-19, consistent with findings from other countries.
Abantu b’omu United States abalina obulwadde obulala balabika okuba n’obulabe bwa maanyi okukosebwa ennyo COVID-19, era nga kino kifaanagana n’ebyazuulibwa mu mawanga amalala.
Persons with underlying health conditions who have symptoms of COVID-19, including fever, cough, or shortness of breath, should immediately contact their health care provider.
Abantu abalina obulwadde obulala era nga balina obubonero bwa COVID-19, omuli olusujja, okukolola, oba okukaluubirirwa mu kussa, balina okutuukirira abasawo baabwe amangu ddala.

These persons should take steps to protect themselves from COVID-19, through washing their hands; cleaning and disinfecting high-touch surfaces; and social distancing, including staying at home, avoiding crowds, gatherings, and travel, and avoiding contact with persons who are ill.

Abantu bano balina okubaako bye bakola okwetangira COVID-19, nga banaaba engalo; okulongoosa n’okutta obuwuka kungulu kw’ebintu; n’okwewa amabanga, omwo nga mwe muli okubeera ewaka, okwewala ebifo ebirimu abantu abangi, enkuŋŋaana, n’okutambula, n’okwewala okukwatagana n’abantu abalwadde.
Maintaining at least a 30-day supply of medication, a 2-week supply of food and other necessities, and knowledge of COVID-19 symptoms are recommended for those with underlying health conditions.
Okubeera n’eddagala lya nnaku waakiri 30, okugula emmere ya wiiki 2 n’ebyetaagisa ebirala n’okumanya obubonero bwa COVID-19 bisembebwa okufiibwako eri abantu abalina obulwadde obulala.
All persons should take steps to protect themselves from COVID-19 and to protect others.
Abantu bonna balina okubaako bye bakola okwekuuma COVID-19 ate n’okukuuma abalala.
All persons who are ill should stay home, except to get medical care; should not go to work; and should stay away from others.
Abantu bonna abalwadde balina okusigala ewaka, okuggyako nga bagenda kufuna ddagala; tebalina kugenda kukola; era balina okwewala okusemberera abantu abalala.
This is especially important for those who work with persons with underlying conditions or who otherwise are at high risk for severe outcomes from COVID-19.
Okusingira ddala, kino kikulu eri abo abakola n’abantu abalina obulwadde obulala oba abo abali mu bulabe obw’amaanyi obw’okukosebwa ennyo COVID-19.

Community mitigation strategies, which aim to slow the spread of COVID-19, are important to protect all persons from COVID-19, especially persons with underlying health conditions and other persons at risk for severe COVID-19–associated disease (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/community-mitigation-strategy.pdf).

Obukodyo bw’ekitundu obukugira, obuyamba okukendeeza ku kusaasaana kwa COVID-19, bukulu mu kutangira abantu obutakwatibwa COVID-19, naddala abantu abalina endwadde endala n’abo abali mu buzibu bw’okulumbibwa endwadde endala ezeekuusa ku COVID-19 (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/community-mitigation-strategy.pdf).
What is already known about this topic?
Kiki ekimanyiddwa ku nsonga eno?

Published reports from China and Italy suggest that risk factors for severe COVID-19 disease include underlying health conditions, but data describing underlying health conditions among U.S. COVID-19 patients have not yet been reported.

Alipoota ezifulumiziddwa okuva mu China ne Italy ziraga nti ensonga ez’obulabe ku COVID-19 ow’amaanyi mulimu endwadde endala naye obubaka obunnyonnyola endwadde endala mu balwadde ba U.S. abalina COVID-19 bwe balina tebunnaba kutegeezebwa.
What is added by this report?
Kipya ki ekiri mu alipoota eno?

Based on preliminary U.S. data, persons with underlying health conditions such as diabetes mellitus, chronic lung disease, and cardiovascular disease, appear to be at higher risk for severe COVID-19–associated disease than persons without these conditions.

Okusinziira ku bubaka obusookerwako mu U.S., abantu abalina obulwadde obulala gamba nga sukaali, obulwadde bw’amawuggwe obw’olukonvuba (chronic lung disease), n’obulwadde bw’omutima, balabika okubeera mu bulabe bw’endwadde ezeekuusa ku COVID-19 ez’amaanyi okusinga abo abatalina bulwadde bwa ngeri eyo.
What are the implications for public health practice?
Bino bitegeeza ki eri ebyobulamu mu mbeera z’abantu?

Strategies to protect all persons and especially those with underlying health conditions, including social distancing and handwashing, should be implemented by all communities and all persons to help slow the spread of COVID-19.

Obukodyo bw’okukuuma abantu bonna naddala abo abalina endwadde endala, omwo nga mwe muli n’okwesuula amabanga n’okunaaba mu ngalo, bulina okukolebwako abantu bonna mu bitundu byabwe wamu n’abantu bonna kiyambeko mu kukendeeza ku nsaasaana ya COVID-19.
Emergence of a Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19): Protocol for Extending Surveillance Used by the Royal College of General Practitioners Research and Surveillance Centre and Public Health England

Okubalukawo kw’Akawuka ka Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19): Enseetuka y’Okwongezaayo Okulondoola okukolebwa Royal College of General Practitioners Research and Surveillance Centre and Public Health England

The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) and Public Health England (PHE) have successfully worked together on the surveillance of influenza and other infectious diseases for over 50 years, including three previous pandemics.

Ekitongole kya The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) ne Public Health England (PHE) bikoze bulungi mu kulondoola yegu (influenza) n’obulwadde obulala obusiigibwa okumala emyaka 50, omwo nga mwe muli ne nawookeera wa mirundi esatu mu bbanga eriyise.
With the emergence of the international outbreak of the coronavirus infection (COVID-19), a UK national approach to containment has been established to test people suspected of exposure to COVID-19.
Nawookeera wa coronavirus (COVID-19) bwe yabulakawo mu nsi yonna, enteekateeka y’okumulwanyisa yakolebwa mu UK okukebera abantu abateeberezebwa okubeera ne COVID-19.

At the same time and separately, the RCGP RSC’s surveillance has been extended to monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community as well as assess the effectiveness of the containment strategy.

Mu kiseera kyekimu ate mu ngeri ey’enjawulo, okulondoola kwa RCGP RSC kwongezeddwayo okulondoola eby’omunda n’eby’omu bitundu ebirala ebikwata ku bulwadde bwa COVID-19 wamu n’okwekaliriza enkola y’obukodyo obukozesebwa okulwanyisa obulwadde buno.

The aims of this study are to surveil COVID-19 in both asymptomatic populations and ambulatory cases with respiratory infections, ascertain both the rate and pattern of COVID-19 spread, and assess the effectiveness of the containment policy.

Ekiruubirirwa ky’okunoonyereza kuno kwe kulondoola COVID-19 mu bantu abeeyolekerako obubonero n’abo abalondoolwa obulondoolwa abalina obuzibu mu kussa, okukenga omuwendo n’ensaasaana ya COVID-19 wamu n’okwekaliriza enkola y’obukodyo bw’okutangira ekirwadde kino.
The RCGP RSC, a network of over 500 general practices in England, extract pseudonymized data weekly.
Ekitongole kya RCGP RSC, omuli abakola ku byobulamu abasukka mu 500 mu Bungereza bafuna obubaka obukwekeze buli wiiki.
This extended surveillance comprises of five components: (1) Recording in medical records of anyone suspected to have or who has been exposed to COVID-19.
Okulondoola kuno okwongezeddwayo kulimu ebintu bitaanu: (1) Okuwandiika mu biwandiiko by’ekisawo eby’omuntu yenna ateeberezebwa okubeera oba alina COVID-19.
Computerized medical records suppliers have within a week of request created new codes to support this.
Ebiwandiiko by’ekisawo eby’oku kompyuta abaweereza bye babeera nabyo mu wiiki emu mwe babisabidde kyaleetawo enkola empya okuwagira kino.

(2) Extension of current virological surveillance and testing people with influenza-like illness or lower respiratory tract infections (LRTI)—with the caveat that people suspected to have or who have been exposed to COVID-19 should be referred to the national containment pathway and not seen in primary care.

(2) Okugaziya okulondoola kw’okunoonyereza n’okukebera abantu abalina yegu (influenza) oba obulwadde bw’omuyungiro gw’okussa ogwa wansi (lower respiratory tract infections (LRTI))—nga waliwo akakwakkulizo nti abantu abateeberezebwa oba abalina COVID-19 balina okuweerezebwa bakolebweko ng’enteekateeka z’eggwanga bwe ziri so si kukolebwako mu malwaliro agasookerwako.
(3) Serology sample collection across all age groups.
(3) Okufuna sampolo z’oluzzizzi mu bantu ab’emyaka gyonna.
This will be an extra blood sample taken from people who are attending their general practice for a scheduled blood test.
Wajja kubaawo sampolo y’omusaayi endala eneggyibwa ku bantu abakola emirimu gyabwe egy’ekisawo egya bulijjo era ng’omusaayi ogwo gwa kukebera okuteeketeeke.
The 100 general practices currently undertaking annual influenza virology surveillance will be involved in the extended virological and serological surveillance.

Abakola ku byobulamu eby’awamu 100 abakola ku kulondoola obuwuka bwa yegu okwa buli mwaka bajja kwetaba mu kulondoola okwongezebwayo okwekenneenya obuwuka ne sampolo (virological and serological surveillance).
(4) Collecting convalescent serum samples.
(4) Okukuŋŋaanya sampolo ku abo abawonye obulwadde (convalescent serum samples).
We have the opportunity to escalate the data extraction to twice weekly if needed.
Tulina omukisa okugaziya enkuŋŋaanya y’obubaka okudda ku mirundi ebiri buli wiiki bwe kiba nga kyetaagisa.
Swabs and sera will be analyzed in PHE reference laboratories.
Obugoye obuyisibwa mu kamwa n’oluzzizzi bijja kwekalirizibwa mu magazeserezo ga PHE.
General practice clinical system providers have introduced an emergency new set of clinical codes to support COVID-19 surveillance.
Abakola ku byekisawo eby’awamu bataddewo enkola ez’amangu empya okuyamba mu kuwagira okulondoola kwa COVID-19.
Additionally, practices participating in current virology surveillance are now taking samples for COVID-19 surveillance from low-risk patients presenting with LRTIs.
Mu ngeri y’emu, abakola ku kulondoola okwekenneenya obuwuka kati bakuŋŋaanya sampolo za kulondoola COVID-19 okuva ku balwadde abataliiko bulabe bwa maanyi abalina LRTIs.
Within the first 2 weeks of setup of this surveillance, we have identified 3 cases: 1 through the new coding system, the other 2 through the extended virology sampling.
Mu wiiki ezaasooka 2 ez’okuteekawo okulondoola kuno tufunyeeyo abalwadde 3: 1 ng’avudde mu nkola empya, ate abalala 2 okuva mu kwongezaayo okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’okwekenneenya obuwuka.
We have rapidly converted the established national RCGP RSC influenza surveillance system into one that can test the effectiveness of the COVID-19 containment policy.
Tukyusizza mu bwangu omuyungiro gwa RCGP RSC ogw’okulondoola yegu ne tugufuulamu ogwo ogusobola okukebera enkola y’okulwanyisa COVID-19.
The extended surveillance has already seen the use of new codes with 3 cases reported.
Okulondoola okwongezeddwayo kuteereddwamu enkozesa ya koodi empya n’abalwadde 3 ne bamanyibwa.
Rapid sharing of this protocol should enable scientific critique and shared learning.
Okugabana amangu enkola/enseetuka eno kusobola okusobozesa okukolokota kw’ekinnassaayansi wamu n’okuyigira awamu.

The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) is a network of general practices (GPs) with a nationally representative population that provides pseudonymized data for weekly surveillance of infectious diseases.

Ekitongole kya Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) ntabiro ya kukolera wamu (GPs) n’abantu abakiikirira abalala mu ggwanga lyonna abaggyibwako obukwekeze buli wiiki ey’okulondoola endwadde ezisiigibwa.
The disease surveillance program is commissioned by Public Health England (PHE) and covers 37 infectious diseases, including influenza.
Enteekateeka y’okulondoola endwadde yassibwawo Ekitongole ky’Ebyobulamu mu Bungereza (Public Health England (PHE)) era nga kikola ku ndwadde ezisiigibwa 37 omwo nga mwe muli ne yegu.
The RCGP RSC and PHE have an established collaboration of over 50 years in influenza and respiratory disease surveillance and are now in their 53rd season of surveillance and analysis.
RCGP RSC ne PHE birina enkolagana eyassibwawo emaze emyaka egisukka mu 50 mu kukola ku yegu n’endwadde z’omuyungiro gw’okussa era kati bali mu kiseera kya 53 mu kulondoola n’okwekaliriza.
The RCGP RSC extracts pseudonymized data from a nationally representative sample of over 500 urban and nonurban GPs each week covering a population of over 4 million.
RCGP RSC kiggya obubaka obukwekeze okuva mu sampolo ekikiirira eggwanga lyonna okuva mu bantu b’omu bibuga n’abatali ba mu bibuga 500 mu GP buli wiiki okuva mu bantu abasukka mu bukadde 4.
Data from these practices are reported online in a weekly return, which includes monitoring weekly rates of influenza-like illness (ILI) and other communicable and respiratory diseases in England.

Obubaka obuva mu kukola okwo bulagibwa ku muyungiro gwa yintaneeti mu buli wiiki, omuli okulondoola emiwendo gy’obulwadde obwefaananyiriza yegu (influenza-like illness (ILI)) buli wiiki wamu n’endwadde endala ez’omuyungiro gw’okussa mu Bungereza.
We also produce an annual report.
Tukola ne alipoota eya buli mwaka.
The RCGP RSC data set includes all coded data and all prescribed items including vaccine exposure.
Obubaka bwa RCGP RSC bulimu obubaka obuliko ennamba wamu n’ebintu ebirala ebinnyonnyoddwa omuli n’eddagala erigema.
The RCGP RSC conducts virology surveillance each influenza season, with 100 GPs participating in the 2019-2020 season (Figure 1).
RCGP RSC kikola okunoonyereza ku buwuka buli mulundi yegu w’abeerera omungi, nga mulimu GPS 100 ezeetabamu mu kiseera ekya 2019-2020 (Ekifaananyi 1).
These virology sampling practices are also recruited to be nationally representative (Figure 1).
Okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku buwuka era kutwalibwa ng’okukiikirira eggwanga lyonna (Ekifaananyi 1).
GPs take nasopharyngeal swabs from persons showing acute respiratory illness within 7 days of the onset of symptoms.

GPs bayisa obuwero mu nnyindo ne mu mimiro (nasopharyngeal swabs) okuva ku bantu abalabikirako obubonero bw’okukosebwa ennyo mu kussa mu bbanga lya nnaku 7 okuva obubonero lwe butandise okubeeyolekerako.
Nasopharyngeal swabs are taken from children younger than 5 years showing symptoms of acute bronchitis or bronchiolitis.
Okuyisa obuwero mu nnyindo ne mu mimiro (nasopharyngeal swabs) kikolebwa ku baana abataweza myaka 5 egy’obukulu abalabikirako obubonero bw’olufuba (acute bronchitis) oba bronchiolitis.
Additionally, nasopharyngeal samples are taken from anyone 5 years and older showing acute onset of ILI and respiratory synctial virus.

Mu ngeri y’emu, sampolo eziggyibwa mu nnyindo ne mu mimiro (nasopharyngeal samples) ziggyibwa ku muntu yenna alina emyaka 5 n’okusingawo alabikirako obubonero bwa ILI obw’amaanyi wamu n’akawuka akayitibwa respiratory synctial virus.
Swabs are tested at the PHE Respiratory Virus Unit for influenza to monitor positivity rates and circulating strains, as well as for measuring vaccine effectiveness.
Obuwero bukebererwa mu kitongole kya PHE Respiratory Virus Unit okulaba oba mulimu yegu okulondoola emiwendo gy’abo abalina obulwadde n’ensaasaana wamu n’okupima enkola y’eddagala erigema.
The RCGP RSC successfully conducted a pilot collecting serological samples from adults and linking them to a patient’s medical records during the 2018-2019 influenza season.

RCGP RSC yakola bulungi okugezesa kw’okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’omusaayi (serological samples) okuva mu bantu abakulu n’okuzikwanaganya n’ebiwandiiko by’abalwadde eby’ekisawo mu kiseera kya yegu ekya 2018-2019.
This pilot was in collaboration with the PHE Seroepidemiology Unit and added to the residual blood samples submitted to PHE by National Health Service (NHS) laboratories.

Okugezesa kuno kwakolerwa wamu n’ekitongole kya PHE Seroepidemiology Unit era kwayongera ku sampolo z’omusaayi ogwasigalawo ogwaweerezebwa ku PHE nga kikolebwa amagezeserezo ga National Health Service (NHS) laboratories.

Serology can provide important information about background population immunity, and sentinel networks can provide a mechanism for systematic data collection and linkage to medical records and health outcomes.

Okukebera omusaayi (Serology) kusobola okukuwa obubaka obw’omugaso obukwata ku byafaayo by’obusibage bw’abantu, ate obunyigirizi mu nkolagana (sentinel networks) busobola okuteekawo enkola y’okukuŋŋaanya obubaka n’okukwanya ebiwandiiko by’ekisawo n’ebivaamu.
The serology pilot has demonstrated the ability of the network to collect serology samples in adults.
Okugezesa kw’okukebera amazzi g’omu mubiri (serology) kulaze obusobozi bw’obuyungirizi mu kukuŋŋaanya sampolo mu bantu abakulu.

With the COVID-19 outbreak, PHE and RCGP RSC have adapted existing influenza surveillance to monitor the spread of COVID-19 in the community, and this protocol sets out the basis for that collaboration.
Olw’okubalukawo kwa nawookera wa COVID-19, PHE ne RCGP RSC bikozesezza okulondoola okuliwo ku yegu okulondoola ensaasaana ya COVID-19 mu bantu, era enkola eno y’eteekawo omusingi gw’okukolagana okwo.

The primary national strategy for COVID-19 infection is containment, with patients who are at high risk managed via the telephone help system NHS111 and the PHE health protection teams, but the RCGP RSC surveillance is entirely separate.

Akakodyo akasookerwako ak’eggwanga ku bulwadde bwa COVID-19 kwe kumutangira obutasaasaana, mu balwadde abali mu bulabe obw’amaanyi abakolebwako n’okubakubira essimu mu nkola ya NHS111 ey’okubayamba wamu n’abayambi b’ebyobulamu aba PHE, naye okulondoola kwa RCGP RSC kwo kwa njawulo ddala.

The RCGP RSC, by extending its established work, will provide virological and serological surveillance to monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community, and assess the effectiveness of the containment strategy.

RCGP RSC, mu kigaziya emirimu gyakyo gye kikola, kijja kukola ku kulondoola eby’omunda n’eby’omu bitundu ebirala ebikwata ku bulwadde bwa COVID-19 wamu n’okwekaliriza enkola y’obukodyo obukozesebwa okulwanyisa obulwadde buno.
We would not be working in isolation on this research.
Tetuyinza kuba nga tukola ffekka ku kunoonyereza kuno.

We will share the protocol with UK colleagues and the I-MOVE consortium who have recently obtained EU Horizon 2020 funding from the stream “Advancing knowledge for the clinical and public health response to the novel coronavirus epidemic”.

Tujja kugabana enkola ne bannaffe ab’omu UK era enzikaanya ya I-MOVE abaafuna emabegako awo ssente z’okunoonyereza eza EU Horizon 2020 okuva mu “Advancing knowledge for the clinical and public health response to the novel coronavirus epidemic”.
It is anticipated that great efficiencies in project management will result through this collaboration than that obtained from countries acting alone.
Kiteeberezebwa nti okukola obulungi okusinga mu nkwata ya pulojeti kujja kuva mu nkolagana eno okusinga bwe kiri mu mawanga agakola gokka.

The aim of this study is to identify whether there is undetected community transmission of COVID-19, estimate population susceptibility, and monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community.

Ekiruubirira ky’okunoonyereza kuno kwe kuzuula oba nga waliwo okusaasaanya kwa COVID-19 mu bantu okutakengeddwa, okuteebereza abantu abali mu buzibu, n’okulondoola abantu ab’omunda n’ab’omu kitundu ekinene omusaasaanidde COVID-19 mu kitundu.
The objectives of this study are as follows:
Ebigendererwa by’okunoonyereza kuno bye bino:
To monitor the burden of suspected COVID-19 activity in the community through primary care surveillance and clinical coding of possible COVID-19 cases referred into the containment pathway
