Okusoola okulondoola okuteeberezebwa kwa COVID-19 mu bitundu nga tuyitira mu kulondoola obujjanjabi obusookerwako n’okulamba okw’ekisawo okw’abayinza okuba ne COVID-19 abaweerezebwa mu bifo gye bakuumirwa

To provide virological evidence on the presence and extent of undetected community transmission of COVID-19 and monitor positivity rates among individuals presenting ILI or acute respiratory tract infections to primary care

Okuleeta obubaka obukwata ku kunoonyereza ku buwuka ku kubeerawo wamu n’obusaasaane bw’obulwadde bwa COVID-19 wamu n’okulondoola abantu abalina obulwadde mu bantu kinnoomu abeeyolekerako obuzibu bwa ILI oba obuzibu obw’amaanyi obw’omuyungiro gw’okussa mu bujjanjabi obusookerwako
To estimate baseline susceptibility to COVID-19 in the community and estimate both symptomatic and asymptomatic exposure rates in the population through seroprevalence monitoring

Okuteebereza ebisookerwako mu kukosebwa COVID-19 mu kitundu era n’okuteebereza abeeyolekerako obubonero n’abeeyolekerako obubonero mu bantu nga tuyitira mu kulondoola abantu abalina obulwadde (seroprevalence)
To pilot implementation of a scheme for collection of convalescent sera with antibody profiles among recovered cases of COVID-19 discharged to the community
Okugezesa enkozesa y’enkola y’okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’abalwadde abagenda bawona nga tukozesa antibody profiles mu balwadde ba COVID-19 abawonye ne basiibulwa ne baddayo mu bitundu byabwe
We intend to capture the following.
Tusuubira okukuŋŋaanya bino wammanga.
Clinical workload related to reports of COVID-19 using the codes created to flag cases, those being assessed and where the infection is located are excluded (Figures 2-​-44)
Emirimu gy’ekisawo egyekwanya ku alipoota za COVID-19 nga tukozesa koodi eziteekebwa ku balwadde, abo abeekalirizibwa ate n’ekifo obulwadde we buli tebibalibwa (Ebifaananyi 2-​-44)
Foreign countries visited in the last 28 days
Amawanga g’ebweru agakyaliddwa mu nnaku 28 eziyise
Existing codes that may have utility (Tables 1-​-3).3).
Koodi eziriwo eziyinza okubeera n’omugaso (Emyeso 1-​-3).3).
Many GPs and primary care teams may not realize that important relevant data can be coded.
Abasawo aba Bulijjo (GPs) bangi n’abakola ku bujjanjabi obusookerwako bayinza obutakirengera nti obubaka obw’omugaso obwetaagisa bwetaagisa okuteekebwako ennamba.
There is also the potential during any pandemic to monitor the effectiveness of any transmission control measures.
Waliwo n’obusobozi mu kiseera kya nawookera okulondoola obulungi bw’enkola z’okutangira okusaasaana kw’obulwadde.
Reliable coding of letters and test results that will show an infection has become either confirmed or excluded
Okuteeka koodi ku bubaka okwesigika ne ku bivudde mu kukebera okunaalaga obulwadde kufuuse okukakasibwa oba okutabalibwa

The methods will follow the approach used in the current influenza surveillance system and recent serology study, and includes five components: (1) primary care clinical surveillance; (2) virological surveillance; (3) population serological surveillance; (4) convalescent sera in cases; and (5) data curation.

Obukodyo bujja kugoberera enkola egobererwa mu kulondoola yegu mu kiseera kino n’okunoonyereza ku musaayi okwakolebwa emabega era kulimu ebintu bitaanu: (1) Okulondoola obujjanjabi obusookerwako; (2) okulondoola obuwuka (virological surveillance); (3) okulondoola okunoonyereza ku musaayi mu bantu; (4) okunooyereza ku balwadde abagenda bawona; ne (5) okukola ku bubaka obukuŋŋaanyiziddwa.
The NHS uses the Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) system of coding, which is normally only updated twice annually.
NHS kikozesa enkola ya Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) ey’okuteekako koodi, ng’enkola eno ezzibwa obuggya emirundi ebiri gyokka buli mwaka.
There was added complexity as some computerized medical record (CMR) suppliers use the Read coding systems (Read clinical terms version 3 – CTv3), which is no longer updated.

Waaliwo n’obuzibu obulala obweyongerako nga ebiwandiiko by’eddwaliro ebimu eby’oku kompyuta (CMR) bikozesa enkola ya Read coding systems (Read clinical terms version 3 – CTv3), ate nga yo tekyazzibwa buggya.
Additionally, there were no clinical codes to record COVID-19 in early February 2020.
Mu ngeri y’emu, tewaaliwo koodi za kisawo okuwandiika COVID-19 mu mwezi Gwokubiri 2020 nga gutandika.
Therefore, the two main GP system suppliers added the five terms shown in Table 4 as system-wide local codes.
Awo nno, Enkola enkulu ebbiri eza ba GP abaweereza baayongeramu ebimiimo bitaanu ebiragiddwa mu Mweso 4 nga koodi z’omu muyungiro ezikozesebwa mu kitundu.
A UK emergency release of SNOMED CT concepts for COVID-19 was also subsequently made available across all CMR systems (Table 4).
Okufulumya okwakolebwa mu UK okwa SNOMED CT concepts for COVID-19 kwateekebwa mu miyungiro gya CMR (Omweso 4).
The intention is that these will eventually be mapped to the new SNOMED CT concepts as they become available, allowing recording of relevant data (Multimedia Appendix 1).
Ekigendererwa kye kino nti oluvannyuma lwa byonna bino bijja kulambiwa ku bitegeero bya SNOMED CT nga bwe binaaba bizuulibwa, ng’obubaka obwetaagisa buwandiikibwa (Ekikookero kya Multimedia 1).

The key requirements for this release were the ability to code (Table 4) a case of COVID-19, exposure to risk of infection (travel to an area where there may be a higher risk), contact with anyone infected with COVID-19, a report that a person had been tested for COVID-19, and that the disease had been excluded (likely a negative test).

Ekyetaagisa ekikulu eky’olufulumya luno bwe busobozi bw’okuteeka ennamba (Omweso 4) ku mulwadde wa COVID-19, okubeera mu bulabe bw’okukwatibwa obulwadde (okugenda mu kifo ewayinza okubeera obulabe obw’amaanyi), okukwatagana n’omuntu yenna alina COVID-19, alipoota etegeeza nti omuntu yali akebeddwa COVID-19, era nti obulwadde bwali tebulabiddwa (nga kirabika talina bulwadde).
In addition, practices are now able to code any foreign travel undertaken, including the ability to record visits to multiple countries (implemented February 8, 2020).

Okwongereza ku ekyo, ebikolebwa kati bisobola okulamba okutambula kwonna omuntu kw’agenzeeko ebweru, omwo nga mwe muli n’obusobozi bw’okuwandiika okukyala mu mawanga ag’enjawulo (kyatandika nga 8 Ogwokubiri 2020).
Figures 2-​-44 show the EMIS web implementation.
Ebifaananyi 2-​-44 biraga enkola ya EMIS ey’oku mutimbagano.
Currently, virology samples for influenza surveillance are accompanied by a standard request form.
Mu kiseera kino, sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku buwuka (virology samples) ku kulondoola yegu ziteekebwako foomu eya bulijjo esaba.
For COVID-19, we will create a new request form that will record:
Ku lwa COVID-19, tujja kukola foomu empya ey’okusibirako ewandiikibwamu:
Date of onset of symptoms
Ennaku z’omwezi obubonero lwe butandise
Diagnosis of any of the following:
Okukebera ekimu ku bino wammanga:
Acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis in those younger than five years
Olufuba olw’amaanyi/bronchiolitis mu abo abataweza myaka etaanu
Lower respiratory tract infection (LRTI)
Obuvune mu kitundu ky’omussizo ekya wansi (LRTI)
History of fever (Y/N); measured (Y/N); if yes, level
Ebyafaayo by’omusujja (Yee/Nedda); apimiddwa (Yee/Nedda); bwe kiba yee, eddaala
Shortness of breath (Y/N), if measured: oxygen saturation and respiratory rate
Okubaka omukka (Yee/Nedda), bw’aba apimiddwa: omukka gw’alina mu mubiri n’embiro kw’assiza
Recent travel (Y/N); if yes, countries visited in last 14 days
Okutambula okw’emabegako (Yee/Nedda); bwe kiba yee, amawanga ge yakyalamu mu nnaku 14 eziyise
Contact with a named person with confirmed COVID-19 (Y/N) with a free text comment about the level of certainty
Okukwatagana n’omuntu ayogeddwako alina COVID-19 (Yee/Nedda) nga waliwo ebigambo ebiraga okwekakasa ku bulwadde bw’omuntu oyo

These codes will be grouped ontologically into “definite”, “probable”, “possible”, and “not a case” using our standard approach to grouping codes (Table 5), which has been used previously across disease areas.

Koodi ezo zijja kubinjawazibwa okusinziira nga bwe zajjja mu bibinja nga “kikakasika”, “kirabika”, “kisoboka”, ne “si mulwadde” nga tukozesa enkola yaffe ey’okubinjawaza koodi (Omweso 5), eyakozesebwako emabegako mu bifo by’endwadde.
The RCGP RSC definition for ILI is shown in Multimedia Appendix 2.
Enyinyonnyola ya RCGP RSC eya ILI eragibwa mu Nkookero ya Multimedia 2.
Public Presentation of Data Using an Observatory and Dashboards
Okulaga obubaka mu lwatu omuli Okukozesa Ekyekalirizo (Observatory) ne Dashboards
We will develop an observatory to present data nationally and a dashboard for feedback to practices about their data quality and collection of virology and serology samples.

Tujja kukolawo ekyekalirizo okulagiramu obubaka mu ggwanga lyonna ate ne dashboard tufuniremu ebiva mu bantu ku bikwata ku bikolebwa ku mutindo gw’obubaka n’enkuŋŋaanya y’obubaka obw’okunoonyereza ku buwuka wamu n’okunoonyereza ku musaayi.
This is based on coding described in Table 4.
Kino kyesigamiziddwa ku kuteekako ennamba okulagiddwa mu Mweso 4.
Definite case will be presented on our dashboard as “cases” of COVID-19.
Omulwadde akakasiddwa ajja kulagibwa ku dashboard yaffe nga “abalwadde” ba COVID-19.
Possible cases will be presented as “Under investigation” (investigating).
Abalabika okuba abalwadde bajja kulagibwa nga “Abakyanoonyerezebwako” (okunoonyereza).
“Not a case” will be presented as “Excluded”.
“Si mulwadde” ajja kulagibwa nga “Tateereddwamu”.

Online data has been established within the initial few weeks in the COVID-19 Observatory (Figure 5), indicating the overall number of patients and rate per 10,000 patients of cases confirmed or under investigation, as well as where the virus is excluded.

Obubaka obw’oku mutimbagano bukakasiddwa mu wiiki entono ezaasooka mu Kyekalirizo kya COVID-19 (Ekifaananyi 5), ekiraga omuwendo gw’abalwadde bonna n’ekigero ky’abalwadde ku buli balwadde 10,000 abakakasiddwa oba abakyanoonyerezebwako ate ne mu mbeera akawuka we kataafiibwako.
We have the option to move to twice weekly surveillance reports with a scope to change this to daily reporting.
Tulinawo omukisa gw’okutandika okukolera ku mirundi ebiri mu wiiki nga tukola alipoota z’okulondoola nga tulina n’ebbanga ery’okukyusa ne tudda ku kuwa alipoota buli lunaku.
We will continue virology sampling from our sentinel practices, rather than discontinuing as seasonal influenza declines.
Tujja kweyongera okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku buwuka okuva mu bye tukola okunoonyereza ku bitundu omuli obulwadde, mu kifo ky’okubisazaamu ng’ekiseera kya yegu kikendedde.
Additionally, we will recruit more surveillance practices.
Mu ngeri y’emu, tujja kuleeta enkola z’okulondoola endala.
The RCGP RSC virology practices will aim to undertake 200-300 nasopharyngeal swabs per week across the RCGP RSC sentinel network, collecting specimens across all age bands.

RCGP RSC by’ekola ku kunoonyereza ku buwuka bijja kuluubirira okuggya sampolo z’omu nnyindo ne mu kamwa 200-300 buli wiiki mu bitundu bya RCGP RSC byonna bye bakoleramu okulaba ebifo omuli obulwadde, nga bakuŋŋaanya sampolo mu bantu ab’emyaka gyonna.

In addition to the inclusion criteria for influenza virology surveillance (ILI, acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis), participating practices will take nasopharyngeal swab samples from any people showing acute symptoms of LRTI if the onset of symptoms is within 7 days.

Okwongereza ku ky’akakwakkulizo k’okwongeramu okulondoola obuwuka ku yegu (ILI, acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis), abakola bajja kukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’omu nnyindo ne mu kamwa okuva ku bantu ab’engeri yonna abeeyolekerako obubonero bwa LRTI kasita kiba nti obubonero obusoose bulabikidde mu nnaku 7 ezisooka.
RCGP RSC research officers and practice liaison staff will manage practices to achieve a total national sample of 200-300 swabs per week.
Abanoonyereza ba RCGP RSC n’abakola ku nsonga z’abantu bajja kukola ku bikolebwa okufuna sampolo za swab 200-300 mu ggwanga lyonna buli wiiki.
This could be increased if PHE modelers require more samples.
Ziyinza okwongezebwa singa abakola ku PHE beetaaga sampolo endala.
Samples from each practice would be spread across the following age groups: < 5 years, 5-17 years, 18-64 years, and 65 years and older
Sampolo okuva mu buli ekikolebwa zijja kuggyibwa mu bantu ab’emyaka egy’enjawulo: abataweza myaka 5, myaka 5-17, myaka 18-64, n’emyaka 65 years n’okusingawo
Samples (swabs or serum) collected will be sent via prepaid envelopes addressed to the appropriate PHE laboratory for analysis.
Sampolo (swabs oba serum) ezinaakuŋŋaanyizibwa zijja kuweerezebwa mu mabaasa aganaaba gamaze okusasulirwa mu magezeserezo ga PHE agasaanidde zeekalirizibwe.
All samples collected will be tested for the presence of influenza and COVID-19.
Sampolo zonna ezikuŋŋaanyizibwa zijja kukeberebwa okulaba oba nga mulimu yegu ne COVID-19.
Additionally, PHE will retrospectively test any influenza virology samples collected between early and mid-February 2020 for COVID-19.
Mu ngeri y’emu, PHE kijja kuddayo kikebere sampolo z’obuwuka bwa yegu ezaakuŋŋaanyizibwa mu Gwokubiri wakati, 2020 okulaba oba nga mulimu COVID-19.

Practices will still follow the PHE protocol for COVID-19 with respect to people at risk of infection who should be signposted down the containment pathway, rather than physically attend their practice.

Ebikolebwa PHE bijja kweyongera okugoberera enseetuka ya COVID-19 nga bafaayo ku bantu abali mu buzibu bw’okukwatibwa obulwadde abalina okufiibwako mu kaweefube w’okutangira ekirwadde mu kifo ky’okubatuukako obutereevu.
Direct testing of those who attend surgery remains permitted, but we have also rolled out self-swabbing at home.
Okukebera obutereevu okw’abo abalongoosebwa kukkirizibwa naye nga kati tutaddewo n’entegeka y’omuntu okwekolera swab ewaka.
Summary of processes are detailed in Multimedia Appendix 3.
Ekifunze ky’enkwajja kinnyonnyoddwa mu Kikookero kya Multimedia 3.

Everyone with an ILI or a respiratory illness who contacts a GP (eg, phones for an appointment) should be asked specifically about recent travel to China and other countries flagged in current PHE advice, or if they have had contact with other people with COVID-19.

Buli muntu yenna alina ILI oba obulwadde bw’okussa era ng’atuukiridde GP (okugeza, n’akuba essimu okukola akalagaane) alina okubuuzibwa oba ku ntambula ze yakola emabegako e China ne mu mawanga amalala agalambibwa mu kimanyiso kya PHE, oba bw’aba ng’abadde akwataganyeeko n’abantu abalala abalina COVID-19.
If these screening enquiries are positive, the patient would be advised to not come to the practice but instead to follow the PHE flow sheet.
Okukebera kuno bwe kulaga nti balina obulwadde, omulwadde aweebwa amagezi aleme kujja kumujjanjaba naye agoberere ebiragibwa PHE.
This can be by a reception or clinician staff, depending on individual practice protocol.
Kino kisobola okukolebwa omuntu atuukirwako ku kifo oba omusawo, okusinziira ku nseetuka ya buli omu nga bw’eri.
These calls should be coded into the GP CMR system and can be reported as part of the RCGP RSC weekly return.
Amasimu gano agakubibwa galina okuweebwa ennamba mu muyungiro gwa GP CMR era galina okulagibwa ng’ekitundu ku bikolebwa RCGP RSC buli wiiki.
We have developed training material to support this coding (Multimedia Appendix 4).
Tuteeseteese ebiwandiiko ebitendekerwako okuwagira enkola y’okuteekako ennamba (Ekikookero kya Multimedia 4).
These include prompt cards for:
Muno muzingiramu kaadi ez’amangu eza:
Practice reception or triage staff: for coding of any patients calling the practice with symptoms of acute respiratory infection with a history of travel to important areas based on PHE advice

Abakola ku kifo ewatuukirwa oba abategeka abalwadde: okuwa ennamba omulwadde yenna akuba essimu okufuna obujjanjabi ng’alina obubonero obw’amaanyi mu kussa ate nga yatambulako mu bifo ebikulu okusinziira ku kimanyiso kya PHE
Administrative staff or clinicians who code: to encourage consistent coding of results for any suspected cases, including coding of negative results for exclusion

Abakola ku nsonga z’obukulembeze oba abasawo abateekako ennamba: okuwagira okuteekako ennamba entakera ku biva ku mulwadde yenna ateeberezebwa, omwo nga mwe muli n’okuwa ennamba ebivudde mu kukebera eby’atalina bulwadde byawulwe
Practices participating in virology surveillance will opportunistically collect blood samples from patients coming into the practice for a routine blood test.
Abakola ku kulondoola okunoonyereza ku buwuka bajja kubeera n’omukisa gw’okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’omusaayi okuva ku balwadde abakeberwa omusaayi oluvannyuma lw’akaseera.
Patients who attend their practice for a routine blood test will be asked to provide an additional sample for serology.
Abalwadde abagenda okubajjanjaba olw’okubaggyako omusaayi ogwa bulijjo bajja kusabibwa okuwaayo sampolo y’omusaayi omulala olw’okukola okunoonyereza kw’omusaayi.
We have conducted initial searches within the RCGP RSC database to look at the number of full blood count (FBC) results and overall rates in adults and children (Figures 6-​-9).9).
Tukoze okunoonya okusooka mu kkuŋŋaanyizo lya RCGP RSC okulaba omuwendo gw’ebiva kukebera omusaayi okujjuvu (FBC) wamu n’emiwendo egy’awamu mu bantu abakulu n’abaana (Ekifaananyi 6-​-9).9).
An FBC is one of the most common tests performed, and we hope this will give an approximate indication of overall numbers of blood tests performed.
FBC y’emu ku kukebera okukolebwa, era tusuubira nti kino kijja kuwa okuteebereza ku miwendo egy’awamu egy’omusaayi ogukeberwa.

The sampling rate, per 100,000 patients was highest for children 15-17 years of age and 60 year or older in adults, with the lowest rates in children 0-4 years of age and 18-29 years of age in adults (Figures 6-​-99).

Omuwendo ogukebererwako, ku buli balwadde 100,000 gwali waggulu mu baana ab’emyaka 15-17 egy’obukulu n’ab’emyaka 60 oba okusingawo mu bakulu, era ng’omuwendo omutono gwali mu baana ab’emyaka 0-4 egy’boukulu ne 18-29 egy’oubkulu mu bakulu (Ekifaananyi 6-​-99).
We will provide 1000 serology baseline samples across all ages that reflect the varying rates of attendance by age.
Tujja kuwaayo sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku musaayi ezisookerwako 1000 mu bantu ab’emyaka gyonna abalaga enkyukakyuka y’emiwendo gy’abo abakolebwako okusinziira ku myaka.
Additionally, we will test if we can obtain these all from virology practices to enhance the yield.
Okwongereza ku ekyo, tujja kugezesa oba nga tusobola okubifuna byonna okuva mu bujjanjabi bw’okunoonyereza ku musaayi olw’okwongera okunyweza ebizuulibwa.
A good geographical spread is important, so PHE can advise on areas where serology will most usefully be collected.
kikulu nnyo okukolera mu bifo eby’enjawulo, awo nno PHE nakyo kijja kuwa amagezi ku bifo ebigasa okukoleramu okunoonyereza ku musaayi.
This will be followed by 800 samples monthly.
Kino kijja kugobererwa sampolo 800 buli mwezi.
The sample will be stratified with 200 specimens for prepandemic survey (100 for monthly) in the following age groups: < 5 years, 5-17 years, 18-64 years, and 65 years or older.

Sampolo ejja kubinjawazibwa mu butu (specimen) 200 mu kunoonyereza nga nawookera tannabaawo (100 buli mwezi) mu bibinja by’emyaka bino: emyaka egitawera 5, emyaka 5-17 , emyaka 18-64 , n’emyaka 65 n’okusingawo.
The younger patients, in many practices younger than 14 years, and in nearly all for children younger than 8 years will require pediatric serology surveillance.

Abalwadde ab’emyaka emimpi, mu kunoonyereza okusinga nga tebaweza myaka 14, ate ne mu kunoonyereza kumpi kwonna ku baana abataweza myaka 8 bajja kwetaaga okulondoola kw’okunoonyereza ku musaayi mu baana abato.
We will develop a new request form for practices to capture recent travel and exposure to COVID-19.
Tujja kukola foomu y’okusaba empya ey’obujjanjabi okufunirako ebikwata ku kutambula okwakolebwa emabegako n’okukwatagana ne COVID-19.
We will pilot a scheme for collecting convalescent serology from people with confirmed cases and who have had an acute virology sample at the time of their infection.

Tujja kukola okugeza kw’okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’abalwadde abagenda bawona okunoonyereza ku musaayi gwabwe okuva mu bantu abaakakasibwa nti balwadde ate nga balina sampolo y’obuwuka obw’amaanyi mu kiseera obulwadde we bwabakwatira.
This is to identify a carrier state in patients who have recovered from the virus but may continue shedding the virus.
Kino kijja kuyambako mu kumanya embeera y’abalwadde abalina akawuka abawonye akawuka naye nga bayinza okweyongera okubeera n’akawuka.
If there are a small number of cases, this may assist in developing a test kit for patients to take to their own GP and explore its acceptability to patients.
Bwe kiba nga waliwo abalwadde batono, kino kiyinza okuyamba mu kukulaakulanya ekiyamba mu kukebera mu balwadde okutwala eri omusawo waabwe era ne bekkaanya engeri abalwadde baabwe gye bakirabamu.

If there are a large number of COVID-19 cases nationally, convalescent samples could be collected from RCGP RSC practices where there are confirmed cases, with the ability to link to the full medical record.

Bwe waba nga waliwo ennamba y’abalwadde ba COVID-19 nnene mu ggwanga lyonna, sampolo z’abalwadde abagenda bawona okuva mu bifo bya RCGP RSC bye baakakasibwa nti balwadde, n’obusobozi bw’okubikwataganaya n’ebiwandiiko by’ekisawo.

This process may include checking pseudonymized NHS numbers for positive individuals at RCGP RSC practices, checking current PHE guidance regarding considerations of infectiousness for confirmed cases, and offering the patient an appointment following the previously mentioned process.

Omutendera guno guyinza okubaamu okukebera ennamba za NHS enkwekeze ez’abantu abalina obulwadde mu bifo bya RCGP RSC, okukebera okuluŋŋamya kwa PHE okuliwo okukwata ku kufaayo ku kusiiga obulwadde ku balwadde abakakasiddwa, n’okulaga omulwadde lw’anajja ku ddwaliro nga bagoberera enkwajja eyayogerwako emabega.
This needs to be carefully coordinated nationally across the network and may require PHE to ensure individuals are not contacted by multiple agencies.
Kino kirina okukolebwako n’obwegendereza mu ggwanga lyonna mu ntabiro yonna era kiyinza okwetaagisa PHE okukakasa nti abantu tebatuukirirwa bitongole bya njawulo bingi.
RCGP RSC could provide a useful structure to channel the initial contact once PHE has made a request.
RCGP RSC kiyinza okulaga enkola ey’omugaso ey’okuweereza omuntu eyasooka okukwataganibwa naye kasita PHE ekola okusaba.
The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of a LRTI.
Ebikolebwa RCGP RSC mu kunoonyereza ku kulondoola obuwuka bwa yegu okwa buli mwaka batandise okukuŋŋaanya sampolo okuva mu balwadde abeeyolekerako obubonero bwa LRTI.
All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
Sampolo zonna ezaafunibwa zikeberebwa okulaba oba nga mulimu yegu ne COVID-19.
The RCGP RSC will explore ways to collect convalescent samples from any patients tested positive for COVID-19 through the extension of the virological surveillance.

RCGP RSC kijja kwekaliriza engeri y’okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’abalwadde abagenda bawona okuva mu mulwadde yenna eyakeberebwa ng’alina COVID-19 nga kiyitira mu kwongezaayo okulondoola ku kunoonyereza ku buwuka.
From the start, we will be carefully curating data to ensure that it can be used for future studies.
Okuva olubereberye, tujja kwegendereza mu kwekaliriza obubaka tukakase nti busobola okukozesebwa mu kunoonyereza okujja mu maaso.
Our clinical data will be linked to virology.
Obubaka bwaffe obw’ekisawo bujja kukwanyizibwa n’obwo obw’okunoonyereza ku musaayi.
We will curate our data using the Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable principles.
Tujja kwekaliriza obubaka bwaffe nga tukozesa emisingi gya Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable.
To facilitate this our data set is listed with Health Data Research UK and the European Health Data Evidence Network.
Kino okukisobozesa obubaka bwaffe butegekeddwa wamu n’obwa Health Data Research UK ne European Health Data Evidence Network.

The statistical methodology is in support of a policy approach to widespread disease outbreak, where so-called nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) are used to respond to an emerging pandemic to produce disease suppression.

Akakodyo k’ebibalo kawagira enkola y’okukwatamu nawookeera w’endwadde abunye wonna, omuli okukozesa enkola ezitaliimu ddagala (NPIs) okwaŋŋanga ekirwadde ekibaluseewo okufuna amagezi agalwanyisa ekirwadde.
This policy aims to reduce contact rates in the population and thereby reduce transmission of the virus.
Enkola eno eruubirira okukendeeza ku muwendo gw’okukwatagana mu bantu era mu ngeri eyo okusaasaanya akawuka ne kukendeera.
To implement this the UK government has recently articulated the desire to implement population self-isolation measures.
Okussa kino mu nkola, gavumenti ya UK emabegako awo yalaga obwetaavu bw’okussa mu nkola enkola y’abantu okweggya mu bannaabwe.

By targeting the reproduction number (R) (the average number of secondary cases each case generates) and aiming to reduce the R to below 1, the policy seeks to reduce case numbers to low levels or (as seen in previous outbreaks with severe acute respiratory syndrome and Ebola) to eliminate human-to-human transmission.

Nga tutunuulira ennamba y’okuzaalukana (R) (omuwendo omukkati ogw’abalwadde abasiigibwa buli mulwadde gw’aleeta) ate n’okuluubirira okukendeeza omuwendo (R) gubeere wansi wa 1, enkola eruubirira okukendeeza omuwendo gw’abalwadde gukke wansi oba (nga bwe kyalabibwa mu bulwadde obwabalukawo emabegako omwali obuzibu obw’amaanyi mu muyungiro gw’okussa ne Ebola) okumalawo okusaasaanya kw’obulwadde okw’okuva ku muntu omu okudda ku mulala.
As the experience from the 2009 H1N1 pandemic has shown, NPIs can be a crucial component of pandemic mitigation.
Ng’obumanyirivu ku nawookeera wa 2009 H1N1 bwe bulaze, NPIs kiyinza okubeera ekirungi eky’amaanyi mu kutangira nawookeera.

Key to the focus of our study will be the estimation of peak cases in the population and continual monitoring by data collection and modelling the potential growth and emergence of subsequent peaks in new cases as social distancing measures are relaxed.

Ekintu ekikulu mu kuweefube w’okunoonyereza kwaffe kijja kuba okuteebereza abalwadde ennyo mu bantu wamu n’okulondoola entakera nga tutunuulira enkuŋŋaanya y’obubaka n’enkolako yaabwo mu kulengera okweyongera kw’obulwadde n’okulaba oba nga bweyongera mu balwadde abapya amateeka g’obuteerinaana bwe ganaagenda nga gawewulwa.
There has already been publication of important disease epidemiological measures concerning the outbreak of COVID-19 in mainland China.
Waliwo okunoonyereza okumaze okufulumizibwa ku kukwata ku bulwadde n’ebikolebwa ku kubalukawo kwa COVID-19 mu ggwanga lya China.
A further fundamental measure in pandemic dynamics is the length of time from infection to when a person is infectious to others and the mean duration of infectiousness.
Ekintu ekirala ekikulu ekikolebwa mu kwaŋŋanga nawookeera bwe buwanvu bw’ebbanga okuva omuntu lw’abufunye ne w’atandikidde okubusiiga abalala wamu n’ebbanga ly’amala ng’abusiiga.
These factors, if estimated accurately, will give good predictions for the likely length of the pandemic, the final number of infected cases.
Ensonga zino bwe ziteeberezebwa obulungi zijja kuwa okuteebereza okulungi ku bbanga nawookeera ono ly’anaamala, omuwendo ogusembayo ogw’abalwadde.
We intend to apply approximate Bayesian inference (ABC) to (possibly spatially heterogeneous) Susceptible-Exposed- Infectious-Removed (SEIR) stochastic epidemic models.
Tusuubira okukozesa enkola za approximate Bayesian inference (ABC) to (possibly spatially heterogeneous) Susceptible-Exposed- Infectious-Removed (SEIR) stochastic epidemic models.
Such techniques are highly parallelizable and have been successfully applied to many fields including disease transmission modelling.
Obukodyo obw’engeri eyo bwawulibwa nnyo mu nneekaliriza era bukozeseddwa bulungi mu bisaawe bingi omwo nga mwe muli n’okuteebereza ensaasaana y’obulwadde.
They are particularly suited to situations where likelihood functions are absent and where more traditional approaches such as Markov chain Monte Carlo are impractical.
Bukozesebwa mu ngeri emu mu mbeera enteebereza ey’omugaso w’etabeererawo ate ne mu mbeera enkola eza bulijjo gamba nga Markov chain Monte Carlo nga tezisobola kukola.

Such an approach has been demonstrated to work effectively on the ASPREN surveillance data, a network of sentinel GPs and nurse practitioners who report deidentified information on ILIs and other conditions, where issues such as missing data and the need to model the observation process itself has been successfully addressed.

Enkola ey’engeri eyo eraze nti ekola bulungi ku kulondoola kw’obubaka bwa ASPREN, enkolagana ya GPs ey’ekiraga okubaawo kw’obulwadde n’abajjanjabi abategeeza obubaka obukwekeze ku ILIs n’embeera endala, awali ensonga gamba nga obubaka obutaliiwo n’obwetaavu bw’okukola ku nkwajja y’okwekaliriza yennyini ekoleddwako bulungi.
Furthermore, peaks in new cases have been estimated by distributional methods.
Ekirala, okutumbuka mu balwadde abapya kubadde kuteeberezebwa na nbukodyo bwa busaasaane.

Estimates of the parameters of the SEIR model are tractable on large data sets because of parallelizability, and these methods have been implemented in several R libraries; we intend to use the libraries ABSEIR (deposited on GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) and abctools (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) to estimate epidemic measures on a weekly basis.

Okuteebereza kw’obukodyo bwa SEIR model tekukola ku bubaka bungi olw’okuba nti busobola okwawulibwa era obukodyo buno bukozeseddwa mu magezeserezo mangi aga R libraries; tusuubira okukozesa libraries ABSEIR (ng’esangibwa ku GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) ne abctools (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) okuteebereza empima ya nawookeera buli wiiki.
Since we are fitting an SIR-epidemic model in the ABC routine, we anticipate that our results will be robust against weekly case data containing relatively small counts.
Olw’okuba nga tugyisa enkola ya SIR-epidemic model mu nkola ya ABC, tusuubira nti ebinaazuulibwa bijja kuba binnyonnyola bulungi obubaka bw’abalwadde obwa buli wiiki omuli emiwendo emitonoko.

For example, see for the ABC methodology applied to the Tristan da Cunha common cold data from 1967, where counts of I (number of infectious cases) and R (number of recovered cases) are in the tens at most.

Okugeza, laba enseetuka ya ABC eyateekebwa ku bubaka bwa ssennyiga wa Tristan da Cunha common cold mu 1967, omwali omuwendo gwa I (omuwendo ogw’abalwadde abasiiga) ne R (omuwendo gw’abalwadde abaawona) gwali awo okusinga ennyo mu makumi.
Finally, in addition to the above methodology we will employ the Kaplan-Meier method with two outcomes (death and recovery) to estimate the case fatality ratio.
Ekisembayo, ng’oggyeeko akakodyo akoogeddwako waggulu tujja kukozesa enkola ya Kaplan-Meier omuli ebivaamu eby’emirundi ebiri (okufa n’okuwona) okuteebereza omuwendo gw’abalwadde abafa.
This approach is independent of the ABC methodology and will allow comparisons between estimates from the two modelling approaches to judge robustness of results.
Enkola eno yeemalirira ku eyo eya ABC era ejja kukkiriza okugeraageranya wakati w’okuteebereza okuva mu njolekera z’okuteebereza zombi okulamula obunnyiinyiitivu bw’ebizuuliddwa.
RCGP RSC’s surveillance with PHE is defined as Health Protection under Regulation 3 of The Health Service (Control of Patient Information) Regulations 2002.
Okulondoola kwa RCGP RSC ne PHE kunnyonnyolwa nga Okwerinda mu Byobulamu mu Tteeka 3 erya Health Service (Control of Patient Information) Regulations 2002.
This has been confirmed by PHE’s Caldicott Guardian’s Office.
Kino kyakakasibwa Wofiisi ya PHE Caldicott Guardian.
We do not see any increased risk to practices or practitioners taking part in this surveillance.
Tetulaba kweyongera kwa bulabe ku bikolebwa oba abakola mu kitundu kino eky’okulondoola.
Infection prevention and control advice will follow extant national guidance.
Okuziyiza okusiigibwa obulwadde n’okutangira kujja kugoberera okuluŋŋamizibwa okw’eggwanga lyonna.
Any cases identified will be managed according to the PHE/NHS guidance in force at the time, including advice for identified contacts.
Abalwadde bonna abanaalabibwa bajja kukolebwako okusinziira ku kuluŋŋamizibwa okunaabaawo mu kiseera ekyo, omwo nga mwe muli amagezi ku bantu be banaaba bakwataganye nabo.
However, our training will include reminders about safe handling of specimens and revision of infection control measures anticipated to be high in our practices.
Wabula, okutendeka kwaffe kujja kuzingiramu okujjukiza ku nkwata ya specimen ennungi n’okwejjukanya ku kutangira okusiigibwa ebintu ebisuubira okubeera eby’amaanyi mu bye tukola.
It is a key part of Regulation 12 about safe care and treatment, periodically inspected by the Care Quality Commission.
Kitundu kikulu mu Teeka 12 erikwata ku kwegendereza n’obujjanjabi era nga lirondoolwa buli kiseera Akakiiko Akakola ku by’Omutindo (Care Quality Commission).
Travel History and Clinical Descriptors of the COVID-19 Infections
Ebyafaayo ku ntambula n’Ebinnyonnyola Obulwadde bwa COVID-19
The RCGP RSC practices have been advised on the clinical coding that has been made available for COVID-19 across all CMR systems.
Abajjanjabi ba RCGP RSC baweereddwa amagezi ku nkola y’okukozesa koodi mu ddwaliro eteereddwawo olw’obulwadde bwa COVID-19 ku miyungiro gya CMR gyonna.
This includes information on coding of clinical descriptors (Table 4) and any recent travel history.
Muno mulimu obubaka obukwata ku binnyonnyola enkozesa ya koodi (Omweso 4) n’ebikwata ku kutambula kwonna okw’emabegako.
Establishment of Extended Virology Sampling
Okumanya ebikwata ku sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku buwuka okwongezeddwayo
The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of LRTI.
Abajjanjabi ba RCGP RSC abeetabye mu kulondoola kwa buli mwaka okw’obuwuka bwa yegu batandise okukuŋŋaanya sampolo ku balwadde abeeyolekerako obubonero bwa LRTI.
All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
Sampolo zonna ezifunibwa zikeberebwa okulaba oba nga mulimu yegu ne COVID-19.
This has led to initial early identification of background spread in low-risk patients.
Kino kireeseewo okukenga okusookerwako mu kusaasaanya mu balwadde ab’obulabe obutono.
As of March 7, 2020, the surveillance system has detected 2 cases of COVID-19 in low-risk patients with no history of travel through extended virological sampling.

Nga 7 Ogwokusatu 2020, omuyungiro gw’okulondoola guzudde abalwadde ba COVID-19 2 mu balwadde abali mu bulabe obutono ate nga tebatambulangako era nga bafuniddwa nga bayitira mu kukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku buwuka.
This protocol describes how we have adapted a national influenza surveillance system to monitor community spread of an unexpected infection of COVID-19.
Enseetuka eno ennyonnyola engeri gye tukozesaamu omuyungiro gw’okulondoola yegu mu nkola ey’okulondoola ensaasaana ya COVID-19 mu bitundu abantu gye babeera.
We have rapidly created and incorporated new codes to allow data recording, and are collecting data to monitor the effectiveness of containment strategies.
Ku mbiro ez’amangu tukoze era ne tuteekamu koodi empya okusobozesa okuwandiika obubaka, era tukuŋŋaanya obubaka okulondoola enkola y’obukodyo bw’okutangira nawookeera.
Through this surveillance, we intend to find out more about the epidemiology of COVID-19 in ambulatory care.
Mu kulondoola kuno, tulowooza okuzuula ebisingawo ebikwata ku nfaanana ya COVID-19 mu bujjanjabi obw’okutuuka ku bantu.
In particular, its rate of spread, both temporal and geographical.
Okusinga ennyo, embiro kwe katambulira munda mu ggwanga ate mu bitundu ebirala.
Our testing of low-risk patients will also inform whether the containment strategy that is based on virology testing of high-risk patients and their contacts plus self-isolation is effective.

Okukebera kwaffe okw’abalwadde abatalina bulabe bwa maanyi nakwo kujja kulaga oba ng’obukodyo bw’okulwanyisa nawookeera obwesigamziddwa ku kukebera omusaayi gw’abalwadde abalina obuzibu obw’amaanyi n’abo be bakwataganye nabo wamu n’omuntu okweggya mu banne bukola bulungi.
Containment should slow the spread, and there may be benefits in the management of spread from intense surveillance.
Okulwanyisa obulwadde kulina okukendeeza ku kukusaasaana kw’obulwadde era wayinza okubaawo emiganyulo mu kukola ku kusaasaana nga kuva ku kulondoola okw’amaanyi.
However, there may come a point at which the virus spreads more widely into the population, as has happened in Italy.
Wabula, wayinza okubaawo ekiseera akawuka we kasaasaanira ennyo mu bantu, nga bwe kibadde mu Italy.
Surveillance of low-risk patients should inform when we reach this tipping point and when infection rates start to remit.
Okulondooal abalwadde abali mu bulabe obutono kulina okutegeeza lwe tulina okutuuka ku ntikko eno ate n’ekiseera emiwendo gy’okukwatibwa obulwadde lwe gitandika okukka.
The epidemiology of COVID-19 remains emergent.
Ebikwata ku bulwadde bwa COVID-19 bikyasoomooza okutegeera.
The registration-based nature of UK primary care means that we will be able to create a complete picture of the cumulative incidence and duration.
Obujjanjabi bwa UK obusookerwako obwesigamiziddwa ku kwewandiisa kutegeeza tujja kusobola okusiiga ekifaananyi ekijjuvu eky’obulwadde bwonna n’ebbanga lye bumaze.
The surveillance system should be able to identify areas where COVID-19 spread is taking place that might be suitable for trials of antiviral therapy.
Omuyungo gw’okulondoola guteekwa okuba nga gusobola okukenga ebitundu COVID-19 gy’asaasaanira ebiyinza okuba ebirungi okukolerayo okugezesa eddagala erigema akawuka.
We could also follow up on the effectiveness or any adverse reactions to these medicines or vaccinations.
Tuyinza era okulondoola obukozi n’obulabe obw’engeri yonna obuleetebwa eddagala erijjanjaba oba erigema.
Finally, early detection of a confirmed COVID-19 case has exemplified the rapid implementation of this enhanced surveillance in the national network.
Ekisembayo, okuzuula amangu omulwadde wa COVID-19 kiraze obulungi bw’okussa amangu mu nkola omulimu guno ogw’okulondoola mu ggwanga lyonna.
Safety of practices is our primary concern.
Eky’okuba ng’ebikolebwa tebiriimu bulabe kye kigendererwa kyaffe ekisookerwako.

The RCGP RSC has operated for over 50 years and has been involved in collecting samples to monitor disease and vaccine effectiveness through the Hong Kong flu pandemic of 1968/69, the Russian flu of 1977/78, and the 2009 Swine flu pandemic.

RCGP RSC ebadde enkola okumala emyaka egisukka mu 50 era ebadde yeenyigira mu kukuŋŋaanya sampolo okulondoola obulungi bw’endwadde n’eddagala erigema ng’eyita mu Hong Kong flu pandemic of 1968/69, the Russian flu of 1977/78, ne 2009 Swine flu pandemic.
We are not aware of any increased risk to practice staff or other patients from involvement in surveillance.
Tetukimanyiiko nti waali wabaddewo obulabe eri abasawo oba abalwadde abalala olw’okwenyigira mu kunoonyereza.
Pandemic preparedness is part of the role of the RCGP RSC.
Okwetegekera ekizibu ky’obulwadde kye kimu ku mirimu gya RCGP RSC.

It is plausible that enhanced coding of information from contacts with the practices in RCGP RSC will reduce the likelihood of people who may be suspected COVID-19 cases being brought to the surgery inadvertently.

Kisoboka okuba nti okulamba obulungi ebikwata ku bantu abasemberera emirimu gya RCGP RSC kijja kukendeeza obusobozi bw’abantu abayinza okuteeberezebwa okuba ne COVID-19 okuleetebwa mu ddwaliro mu butanwa.
Where cases are detected unexpectedly, it is probably helpful for that patient, their contacts, and the practice to know.
Mu mbeera ng’abalwadde bazuuliddwa mu ngeri ebadde tesuubirwa, kya mugaso eri omulwadde oyo, abo abamusemberedde, n’abasawo okumanya.
The impact on practices has been to close for a day, if a case is found, for deep cleaning and then reopen.
Ekibaddenga kikolebwa kwe kuggalawo okumala olunaku, nga waliwo omulwadde azuuliddwa, olw’okulongoosa okw’amaanyi ate ne baggulawo oluvannyuma.
The principal limitations of our system are the number of data points.
Obuzibu obusinga obunene mu nkola yaffe gwe muwendo gw’ebifo by’obubaka ebingi.
We are collecting serology and virology data from 100 sites, which covers a small group of the population.
Tukuŋŋaanya obubaka bw’amazzi g’omubiri n’obuwuka (serology and virology data) okuva mu bifo 100, nga bino bikwata ku kibinja kitono ku bantu be tulina okunoonyerezaako.
This has been satisfactory for monitoring influenza, but we are not certain if this is a sufficiently large sample for the COVID-19 outbreak.
Kino kibadde kimatiza mu kulondoola ssenyiga, naye tetukakasa oba ng’omuwendo gwa sampolo guno munene ekimala ku kizibu kya COVID-19.
Our sites (surveillance practices) are currently fixed, and it could be helpful to be able to rapidly onboard practices in regions where there are more cases.
Ebifo byaffe (surveillance practices) mu kiseera kino bigere, era nga kyandibadde kiyamba okusobola okugattako mu bwangu emirimu egikolebwa mu bitundu ewali abalwadde abangi.
Currently, we will be reporting weekly.
Mu kiseera kino, tujja kuba tufulumya alipoota buli wiiki.
Our existing system can be enhanced to twice weekly, but maybe daily or hourly data should be our current approach.
Enkola yaffe esobola okutumbulwa n’edda ku mirundi ebiri mu wiiki, naye ng’oboolyawo obubaka obwa buli lunaku oba buli ssaawa bwe twandibadde tuddako mu kiseera kino.
Opportunistic sampling for serology in children younger than 10 years might be limited due to the overall reduced rate of blood tests in children.
Okuggya sampolo z’amazzi g’omu mubiri mu baana abataweza myaka 10 kiyinza okukaluba olw’okukendeera kw’okukebera omusaayi mu baana okutwaliza awamu.
The extended surveillance using the RCGP RSC-PHE network for the emergent COVID-19 outbreak has been established rapidly.
Okugaziya okulondoola mu kukozesa enkola ya RCGP RSC-PHE ku bulwadde bwa COVID-19 obwabaluseewo kuteereddwawo mu bwangu.
The model of getting the appropriate informatics to enable capture of the required data has already been a success, with data recording starting the week the codes were created.
Enkola y’okufuna obubaka obutuufu okuyamba okufuna obubaka obwetaagibwa mu kiseera kino ekoze bulungi, ng’obubaka bwatandika okufunibwa mu wiiki ennamba mwe zaatondebwawo.
In addition, modifying the existing surveillance system to collect population data in a parallel way has also been effective.
Okwongereza ku ekyo, okulongoosa mu nkola y’okulondoola eriwo okukuŋŋaanya obubaka okuva ku bantu abanoonyerezebwako mu kiseera kyekimu nakyo kikoze bulungi.

However, we are at present unsure as to whether the scale of this surveillance provides sufficient data to drive local containment strategies or if reporting infrequently meets the need of our information age.

Wabula, mu kiseera kino tetunnakakasa oba ng’omutendera gw’okulondoola gwe tuliko gutuwa obubaka obumala okufuna enkola z’okulwanyisa ekizibu oba okutegeeza obubaka ebbalirirwe kimala mu kiseera kino kye tulimu.
Updating the diagnostic criteria of COVID-19 “suspected case” and “confirmed case” is necessary
Okutuukanya ebisinziirwako okukakasa omulwadde “ateeberezebwa” ne “akakasiddwa” okubeera ne COVID-19 kyetaagisa

On 6 February 2020, our team had published a rapid advice guideline for diagnosis and treatment of 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection, and this guideline provided our experience and make well reference for fighting against this pandemic worldwide.

Nga 6 Ogwokubiri 2020, tiimu yaffe yali efulumizza ebigobererwa eby’amangu mu kukebera n’okujjanjaba abantu abalina 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV), era ng’ebigobererwa bino byali biraga obumanyirivu bwaffe n’okulaga engeri y’okulwanyisaamu obulungi nawookeera ono mu nsi yonna.

However, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge are gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.

Wabula, obulwadde bwa coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) bulwadde bupya, bye tubumanyiiko bigenda byeyongera okusinziira ku bizuulibwa mu kunoonyereza okugenda mu maaso n’ebiyitibwamu mu kujjanjaba; noolwekyo, enkebera n’enzijanjaba nabyo bigenda bikyusibwamu.

In this letter, we answered one comment on our guideline and provided the newest diagnostic criteria of “suspected case” and “confirmed case” according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (seventh version) that issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China.

Mu bbaluwa eno, twayanukula ekibuuzo kimu ku bigobererwa byaffe era ne tuwa ebigobererwa ebisinga obupya mu kusalawo “ateeberezebwa” ne “akakasiddwa” okusinziira ku bigobererwa ebikyasembyeyo mu Kukebera n’Okujjanjaba CoVID-19 (Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (seventh version)) ebyayisibwa National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China.

In December 2019, the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) has caused an outbreak, which is now officially named as the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the virus has been named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

Mu Deesemba 2019, 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) yaleetawo obulwadde, kati mu butongole obwatuumibwa coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) era n’akawuka ne katuumibwa severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
On 11 March 2020, WHO characterized COVID-19 as a pandemic.
Nga 11 Ogwokusatu 2020, WHO yalangirira nti COVID-19 kizibu kya byabulamu mu nsi yonna.
In order to fight against the SARS-CoV-2 infection, our team has developed a rapid advice guideline and that has been published online in Military Medical Research on 06 February 2020.
Okusobola okulwanyisa SARS-CoV-2, tiimu yaffe ekulaakulanyizza ebigobererwa eby’amangu nga byafulumizibwa ku yintaneeti mu Military Medical Research nga 06 Ogwokubiri 2020.
It has attracted a great attention since published.
Byettaniddwa nnyo okuva lwe byafulumizibwa.

Note however that COVID-19 is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge is gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.

Wabula kisaanye okwetegerezebwa nti COVID-19 bulwadde bupya, bye tubumanyiiko bigenda byeyongera okusinziira ku bizuulibwa mu kunoonyereza okugenda mu maaso n’ebiyitibwamu mu kujjanjaba; noolwekyo, enkebera n’enzijanjaba nabyo bigenda bikyusibwamu.

For instance the Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), among 16 January 2020 to 3 March 2020, has issued a total of seven editions with some contexts being substantively changed.

Okugeza Ebigobererwa mu Kukebera n’Okujjanjaba CoVID-19 ebyayisibwa National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), wakati wa 16 Janwali 2020 ne 3 Ogwokusatu 2020, yaakafulumya enfulumya musanvu mulamba ng’embeera ezimu zikyukidde ddala.
Now our guideline received a comment by Zhou et al., they introduced a simple scoring proposal based on their clinical experience.
Ebigobererwa byaffe byayogerwako Zhou ne banne, baateesa enkola ennyangu ey’okwekenneenya nga basinziira ku bye bazudde mu kujjanjaba mu ddwaliro.
Their work added new evidence for our guideline and also make valuable reference for this pandemic worldwide.
Omulimu gwabwe gwayongera obukakafu ku bigobererwa byaffe era boogera ne ku kizibu kino ekiri mu nsi yonna.
We endorse their significant work and express our thanks.
Omulimu gwabwe omulungi tugukkiriza era tubeebaza.
However, their work also needs update according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (Trial seventh version) and recently studies.
Wabula, omulimu gwabwe nagwo gwetaaga okuzzibwa obuggya okusinziira ku Bigobererwa mu Kukebera n’Okujjanjaba COVID-19 ebipya (Olufulumya owomusanvu) n’okunoonyereza okupya.

According to the seventh edition (3 March 2020), to confirm the suspected case needs to combine any one item of epidemiological history features with two items of clinical manifestations to make a comprehensive analysis, or needs to meet three items of clinical manifestations if without clear epidemiological history:

Okusinziira ku lufulumya olwomusanvu (3 Ogwokusatu 2020), okukakasa omulwadde ateeberezebwa kyeetaagisa okugatta ekimu ku bigobererwa ebikwata ku byafaayo by’obulwadde n’ebigobererwa bibiri eby’ekisawo mu ddwaliro okusobola okukola okusalawo okw’enkomeredde, oba kyetaagisa okutuukiriza ebigobererwa bisatu eby’ekisawo mu ddwaliro singa waba tewali bikwata byafaayo bya bulwadde bitegeerekeka:

Epidemiological history: (1) a history of travel or residence in Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 cases had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (2) a history of contact with SARS-CoV-2 infectious cases (with positive nucleic acid test); (3) a history of contacting with patients with fever or respiratory symptoms from Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (4) a history of contacting with cluster of confirmed cases (≥ 2 cases with fever and/or respiratory symptoms occurred within 2 weeks in small areas, such as home, office, class of school, etc).

Ebyafaayo by’obulwadde: (1) okuba ng’omuntu yagendako oba yabeerako mu kibuga Wuhan n’ebitundu ebyetooloddewo, oba ebitundu ebirala ewaazuulwa abalwadde ba COVID-19 mu nnaku 14 ng’obubonero tebunneeyoleka; (2) okuba ng’omuntu yasemberera abantu abalina SARS-CoV-2 (mu kukebera kwa positive nucleic acid test); (3) okuba ng’omuntu yasemberera abalwadde b’omusujja oba abalina obuzibu bw’okussa okuva mu kibuga Wuhan n’ebitundu ebiriraanyeewo, oba ebitundu ebirala ewaazuulibwa abalwadde ba COVID-19 mu nnaku 14 ng’obubonero tebunneeyoleka; (4) okuba ng’omuntu yasemberera abalwadde abakakasiddwa (abalwadde ≥ 2 abalina omusujja ne/oba obuzibu mu kussa baazuulwa mu wiiki 2 mu bifo ebifunda, ng’awaka, woofiisi, ebibiina ku ssomero, n’ebirala).

Clinical manifestations: (1) fever and/ or respiratory symptoms; (2) with imaging features of COVID-19 infection; (3) total white blood cell counts showing normal, decreased, or reduced lymphocyte count in the early onset stage.

Obubonero bw’ekisawo: (1) omusujja ne/ oba obuzibu mu kussa; (2) n’obubonero bw’okukubwa ekifaananyi obulaga okukosebwa COVID-19; (3) omuwendo gw’obutaffaali obulwanyisa endwadde (white blood cells) obulaga omuwendo gwa lymphocyte omulungi, oba ogukendedde mu kiseera ekisooka.

Diagnosing the confirmed case should base on suspected case with any one item of pathogenic or serological evidence as following: (1) real-time PCR test positive for SARS-CoV-2; (2) viral whole genome sequencing showing high homogeneity to the known novel coronaviruses; (3) positive for the specific IgM antibody and IgG antibody to SARS-CoV-2 in serum test; or a change of the SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG antibody from negative to positive, or titer rising ≥4 times in the recovery phase above that in the acute phase.

Okukakasa omulwadde kulina kukolebwa ku mulwadde ateeberezebwa ng’aliko obukakafu bw’obulwadde oba okukeberwa amazzi g’omubiri nga bwe kiragiddwa wammanga: (1) ng’okukebera kwa PCR okw’embagirawo kulaze nti omuntu alina SARS-CoV-2; (2) nga viral whole genome sequencing eraze okufaanana okw’amaanyi n’obuwuka bwa coronaavirus obupya; (3) ng’okukebera amazzi g’omu mubiri kulaze nti omuntu alina IgM antibody ne IgG antibody zennyini ezirwanyisa SARS-CoV-2; oba okukyuka kwa lgG antibody za SARS-CoV-2 zennyini okuva ku negative okudda ku positive, oba titer rising ez’emirundi ≥4 mu kiseera ky’okuwona okusinga ku ezo ez’omu kiseera ky’okubeera obubi.
We can see that the real-time PCR test for nucleic acid in respiratory tract or blood samples was added to the second (18 January 2020) and third (22 January 2020) editions.
Tulaba nti okukebera kwa PCR okw’embagirawo okuzuula nucleic acid mu mussizo oba omusaayi kwagattibwa ku lufulumya olwokubiri (18 Janwali 2020) n’olw’okusatu (22 Janwali 2020).
The pathogenic detection of blood sample was added to the fourth (27 January 2020) and fifth (8 February 2020) editions; and then the serological evidence was added to the seventh edition.

Okuzuula obulwadde mu sampolo y’omusaayi kwagattibwa ku nfulumya olwokuna (27 Janwali 2020) n’olwokutaano (8 Ogwokubiri 2020); ate obukakafu bw’okukebera amazzi g’omu mubiri bwagattibwa ku lufulumya olwomusanvu.

These modifications based on the researchers continued work that to search for an optimal nucleic acid detection kit for rapid diagnosis, as well as the samples from respiratory tract including blood sampling, which increased the availability of different specimens, and supported bringing the specific antibody positive result into the confirmed criteria.

Okukyusaamu kuno kwesigamizibwa ku mirimu gy’abanoonyereza okugezaako okufuna ekintu ekiyinza okukenga obulungi nucleic acid olw’okukebera okw’amangu, awamu ne sampolo okuva mu mussizo omuli sampolo z’omusaayi, nga kino kyayongera ku busobozi bw’okufuna ebikeberwa eby’enjawulo, era ne kiwagira eky’okubeera ne antibody zennyini ng’ekimu ku bisinziirwako okukakasa omulwadde.
Besides, there are more and more evidence that remind us to caution with the atypical symptomatic and asymptomatic patients.
Ng’oggyeeko ekyo, waliwo obukakafu obulala bungi obutujjukiza okwegendereza abalwadde abalaga n’abatalaga bubonero mu ngeri etali ya bulijjo.
Hence, the flow chart of Zhou et al. should be updated, as they classified the person without clinical symptoms as “low risk”.
Noolwekyo, ekipande kya Zhou ne banne kisaanye okuzzibwa obuggya, kubanga kyalaga omuntu atalina bubonero bwa bulwadde nga “alina emikisa emitono (low risk)”.
The score system also needs to be verified in further clinical practice and studies.
Enkebera eno (score system) era yeetaaga okukakasibwa mu kujjanjaba okulala mu malwaliro ne mu kunoonyereza okulala.
To conclude, we hope more direct evidence coming up and call for readers to provide their comments.
Mu kuwumbawumba, tusuubira nti obukakafu obulala obulabikirawo bujja kulabikawo era tusaba abasomi okubwogerako.
For the diagnosis of “suspected case” and “confirmed case”, we suggest to trace and obey the newest guidelines of their home countries.
Mu kumanya “ateeberezebwa” ne “akakasiddwa”, tuteesa eky’okulondoola n’okugondera ebiragiro ebikyasembyeyo eby’amawanga gaawe.
Our team will also timely update our guideline to offer help.
Tiimu yaffe ejja kuzza obuggya mu budde ebigobererwa byaffe okusobola okuyambako.
Bangladesh reports five new deaths due to COVID-19, a daily highest
Bangladesh etegeezezza nti abantu bataanu abalala bafudde olwa COVID-19, nga gwe muwendo omunene ogusinga ku bafa buli lunaku
Yesterday, Bangladesh has confirmed five new deaths due to COVID-19 on the day.
Eggulo, Bangladesh yakakasizza nti abantu bataano abalala baafudde olwa COVID-19 ku lunaku olwo.
This is the highest number of fatalities in a day due to the virus.
Guno gwe muwendo ogusingayo obunene mu lunaku abafudde olw’akawuka kano.

As of yesterday, Bangladesh's Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) reported the number of recorded infected cases included 114 active cases and 33 recovered cases who were staying home.
We bwatuukidde eggulo, Ekitongole kya Bangladesh Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) kyawandiise abalwadde 114 ate abawonye 33 nga bo bali waka.
A total of 17 deaths have been recorded.
Omugatte gw’abantu 17 abafudde.
In an online news briefing, the director of IEDCR, Dr Meerjady Sabrina Flora, said the fatalities included four males and one female.
Mu mawulire agaaweereddwa ku yintaneeti, omukungu wa IEDCR, Dr Meerjady Sabrina Flora, yagambye nti abaafudde baabaddemu abasajja bana n’omukyala omu.
According to Dr Meerjady, two cases were aged above 60, two between 51 and 60, and one 41-50 years old.
Okusinziira ku Dr Meerjady, abaafudde ababiri baabadde n’emyaka egisukka mu 60, ababiri nga bali wakati wa 51 ne 60, ate omu ng’ali wakati wa 41-50 egy’obukulu.
She also said two of the victims were from Dhaka.
Era yagambye nti ababiri ku bantu abo bava Dhaka.
The World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic on March 11.
Nga 11 Ogwokusatu, Ekitongole kya World Health Organization (WHO) kyalangirira COVID-19 ng’ekizibu eky’awamu mu nsi (pandemic).

A hospital official told Anadolu Agency, a local news outlet, that one of the deceased was Jalal Saifur Rahman, a director of Bengali Anti-Corruption Commission, who was cared for at the Kuwait Maitree Hospital.

Omukungu mu ddwaliro yategeeza Anadolu Agency, nga kitongole ky’amawulire, nti omu ku baafa ye yali Jalal Saifur Rahman, omukungu wa Bengali Anti-Corruption Commission, eyali ajjanjabibwa mu Kuwait Maitree Hospital.

On Saturday, in an online video announcement, Bangladeshi Road Transport and Bridges Minister Obaidul Quader said public transport would be shut down for longer than initially planned, until this coming Saturday.

Ku Lwomukaaga, Minista w’Ebyentambula mu Bangladeshi Obaidul Quader bwe yabadde ng’ayisa ekirango ekyalabikidde mu viidiyo yagambye nti entambula yonna ey’olukale egenda kuyimirizibwa okumala ebbanga ggwanvuko okusinga bwe baasooka okutegeka, okutuusa ku Lwomukaaga oluddako.
This public transport shutdown had initially started on March 26 and was planned to end on Saturday, April 4.
Okuyimiriza entambula y’olukale kwali kutandise nga 26 Ogwokusatu era nga kwali kutegekeddwa kukoma nga 4 Ogwokuna.
Transport of essential goods -- medical, fuel and food -- was still allowed.
Entambula y’ebyamaguzi ebikulu -- eddagala, amafuta n’emmere - yo yali ekyakkirizibwa.
The first recorded incidents of COVID-19 infection in Bangladesh were on March 8, in two people who returned from Italy and also the wife of one of them.
Abalwadde ba COVID-19 abaasooka mu Bangladesh baalabika nga 8 Ogwokusatu, nga baali bantu babiri abadda mu ggwanga eryo nga bava Italy ate n’omukyala w’omu ku bantu abo.
As of March 19, these three had already recovered.
Nga 19 Ogwokusatu 19, abasatu abo baali bamaze okuwona.
National Basketball Association suspends season due to COVID-19 concerns
Ekibiina kya National Basketball Association kiyimirizza emizannyo gyakyo olwa COVID-19
On Wednesday, the United States' National Basketball Association (NBA) suspended its professional basketball season due to concerns regarding COVID-19.
Ku Lwokusatu, ekibiina kya United States' National Basketball Association (NBA) kyayimiriza emizannyo gyakyo egy’ekiseera kino olw’ensonga ezikwata ku COVID-19.
The NBA's decision followed a Utah Jazz player testing positive for the COVID-19 virus.
Okusalawo kw’ekibiina kya NBA's kwazze oluvannyuma lw’omuzannyi wa Utah Jazz okukeberebwa ng’alina akawuka ka COVID-19.
The NBA did not release the identity of the player in question in its announcement.
Ekibiina kya NBA tekyafulumizza mannya ga muzannyi oyo mu kirango kyakyo.
They did say he was not present at Chesapeake Energy Arena in Oklahoma City, where the Utah Jazz were to play against the Oklahoma City Thunder.
Baagambye nti teyaliiyo mu luzannya lwabwe mu Chesapeake Energy Arena mu Oklahoma City, Utah Jazz gye yabadde alina okuzannyira ne Oklahoma City Thunder.
According to its press release, the NBA was "suspending game play following the conclusion of [Wednesday's] schedule of games until further notice."

Okusinziira ku kiwandiiko kye baafulumizza, NBA "kyayimirizza enzannya zaakyo oluvannyuma lw’okusalawo kwe baatuuseeko [ku Lwokusatu] ku nzannya zaabwe okutuusa lwe banaddamu okusalawo ku nsonga eno."
The Jazz's game was cancelled, as was another NBA game Wednesday between the Sacramento Kings and the New Orleans Pelicans.
Oluzannya lwa Jazz lwasaziddwamu era nga bwe kyali ne ku luzannya olulala olwa NBA olwaliwo ku Lwokusatu wakati wa Sacramento Kings ne New Orleans Pelicans.
Other games scheduled for Wednesday were still held, according to NBC News.
Emizannyo emirala egyaliyo ku Lwokusatu gyo gyagenda mu maaso okusinziira ku mawulire ga NBC News.

The United States' other major basketball organization, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which runs college basketball, has cancelled its own tournament, March Madness, for both men's and women's leagues.

Ekibiina ekirala ekya United States eky’omupiira ogw’ensero, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, ekiddukanya ensero y’ettendekero, kisazizzaamu empaka zaakyo, March Madness, ez’abasajja n’ez’abakazi.
According to Johns Hopkins University, as of Wednesday, there were at least 1,279 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the United States.
Okusinziira ku Johns Hopkins University, ku Lwokusatu waaliwo waakiri abalwadde ba COVID-19 abaali bakakasiddwa mu United States.
CNBC reported there were at least 118,381 cases worldwide.
CNBC kyategeezezza nti mu nsi yonna mulimu abalwadde waakiri 118,381.
SARS-CoV-2 surpasses one million infections worldwide
SARS-CoV-2 yasussa abantu abalwadde akakadde kamu mu nsi yonna
On Thursday, the total number of cases of the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infections surpassed one million worldwide, Johns Hopkins University data indicated.
Ku Lwokuna, omugatte gw’abalwadde ba SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus baasusse akakadde akamu mu nsi yonna nga bwe kyalagiddwa mu bubaka bwa Johns Hopkins University.
At least 52 thousand deaths were linked to COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.
Waakiri abantu emitwalo 52 baagambibwa okuba nga bafudde COVID-19, obulwadde obuleetebwa coronavirus.
The milestone came the same day Malawi confirmed its first coronavirus infections and Zambia had its first coronavirus-related death.
Kino kyatuukibwako ku lunaku lwe lumu Malawi lwe yakakasa omulwadde waayo asooka ate mu kiseera kye kimu Zambia n’efunayo omuntu omu afa olwa coronavirus.
North Korea claimed, as of Thursday, it was one of the few countries remaining free of coronavirus infections.
North Korea yo yagambye nti ku Lwokuna y’emu ku nsi ezaali zikyasigadde nga tezinnalumbibwa bulwadde bwa coronavirus.
By yesterday, the World Health Organization reported 1,051,635 confirmed cases, including 79,332 cases in the twenty four hours preceding 10 a.m. Central European Time (0800 UTC) on April 4.

Ku lunaku lw’eggulo Ekibiina ky’Ebyobulamu mu nsi yonna (World Health Organization) kyategeezezza nti waabaddewo abalwadde 1,051,635 omuli abalwadde 79,332 abaafunise mu bbanga lya ssaawa 24 obutasukka ssaawa nnya ez’oku makya, mu mbala y’essaawa eya Central European Time (0800 UTC) nga 4 Ogwokuna.
In the United States, over 244 thousand coronavirus cases were recorded, linking to at least 5,900 deaths.
Mu United States, abalwadde abasukka mu 244,000 be baategeezebwa ate ng’abafudde bali waakiri 5,900.
CBS News reported, citing Johns Hopkins University data, there were over 1,000 US deaths on Wednesday caused by coronavirus infections.
CBS News kyajulizza Johns Hopkins University ne kigamba nti, mu US mwalimu abantu abasukka 1,000 abaafudde ku Lwokusatu nga bafudde lwa bulwadde bwa coronavirus.
Around the world, countries announced stricter measures to inhibit the disease from spreading.
Mu nsi yonna, amawanga gaalangirira ebirina okukolebwa ebikakali olw’okuziyiza obulwadde obutasaasaana.
On Thursday, Sergei Sobyanin, the mayor of Moscow, extended the city lockdown to May 1.
Ku Lwokuna, Sergei Sobyanin, meeya wa Moscow, yayongezzaayo omuggalo gw’ekibuga okutuusa nga 1 Ogwokutaano.
Nationally, President Vladimir Putin declared Russians would continue to be paid without going to work until April 30.
Mu ggwanga lyonna, Pulezidenti Vladimir Putin yalangirira nti Abarasha bajja kusasulwa wadde nga tebagenda ku mirimu gyabwe okutuusa nga 30 Ogwokuna.
The parliament of Portugal voted to extend the national state of emergency by 15 days; the vote passed with 215 votes in favor, ten abstentions, and one vote against.
Paliyamenti ya Portugal yakuba akalulu akongezaayo akaseera k’obwerende ka nnaku 15; abasinga obungi 215 baakawagira, kkumi ne batakuba ate omuntu omu n’atakiwagira.
Saudi Arabia extended curfews in the holy cities of Mecca and Medina to last the entire day; previously, the curfew was only in effect between 3 p.m. and 6 a.m.
Saudi Arabia yayongezaayo ekiseera kya kaafiyu mu bibuga ebitukuvu ebya Mecca ne Medina nga kimala olunaku lulamba; mu kusooka, kaafiyu yaliwo wakati wa ssaawa 9 ez’olweggulo ne 12 ez’oku makya.
Thailand planned to implement a curfew between 10 p.m. and 4 a.m.
Thailand yateekateeka kaafiyu wakati w’essaawa 4 ez’ekiro ne 10 ez’ekiro.
The governor of Ohio, Mike DeWine, announced the state had extended its stay-at-home order until May 1.
Gavana wa Ohio, Mike DeWine, yalangirira nti ekitundu ekyo kyongezzaayo ekiseera ky’okubeera ewaka okutuuka nga 1 Ogwokutaano.
Stores in Australia lower toilet paper limits per transaction
Amaduuka g’omu Australia gassa ekkomo ku muwendo gw’ebikookooma omuntu by’alina okugula omulundi ogumu

On Sunday and Saturday evening, Australian store chains Woolworths and Coles lowered their purchase restrictions on toilet paper to two and one package per transaction in all stores on national level, respectively.

Ku Ssande ne ku Lwomukaaga olweggulo, amaduuka g’omu Australia agabuna eggwanga lyonna, Woolworths ne Coles bassa ekkomo lyabwe ku bigulibwa ku bikookooma ng’omuntu agula obuganda bubiri oba kamu wonna mu ggwanga mu maduuka ago gombiriri.
ALDI also introduced a one-pack limit, on Monday.
ALDI nayo yassaawo ekkomo lya kaganda kamu ku Lwokusooka.
These limitations were posted as messages on the checkouts, and on the chains' Facebook pages.
Okukugira kuno kwalagibwa ng’obubaka eri abantu ku miko gya Facebook egy’amakampuni ago.
Buyers were reportedly stocking up due to fears of COVID-19 in case people need to self-isolate.
Abaguzi baagambibwa okubeera nga beeterekera olw’okutya COVID-19 ng’abantu kibeetaagisizza okweyawula.
On Wednesday, Woolworths also limited toilet paper purchases for home delivery to one pack per order.
Ku Lwokusatu, Woolworths nayo yassa ekkomo ku kugula ebikookooma ebigulibwa ne biweerezebwa ewaka ng’omuntu afuna akaganda kamu buli lunaku.
These changes followed the previous four-pack per transaction restriction introduced by Woolworths and Coles on March 4 and 5 respectively.
Enkyukakyuka zino zigoberera okukugira okwasooka okw’akaganda ak’obuna ku buli lugula okwaleetebwa Woolworths ne Coles nga 4 ne 5 Ogwokusatu mu makampuni gombi mu ngoberegana eyo.

Coles, in its March 8 media release, reported that with the four-pack restriction in place, "many stores are still selling out within an hour of delivery", and called the demand "unprecedented", while ALDI, in a Facebook post on Tuesday, called it "unexpected".

Mu kiwandiiko kya Coles ekya nga 8 Ogwokusatu, yategeeza nti okukugira okw’akaganda ak’ebina, "amaduuka mangi gamazaawo mu ssaawa emu yokka we babireetera", era ne bagamba nti obwetaavu obwo “tebubangawo”, so ng’ate yo ALDI, bwe yawandiika ku Facebook ku Lwokubiri yagamba nti kyali "tekisuubirwa".
Sales went up in a "sharp increase" last week, according to a Woolworths spokesperson.
Obutunzi “bwalinnyira ddala waggulu” mu wiiki ewedde okusinziira ku mwogezi wa Woolworths.
Costco's store in Canberra also limited the allowed amount to two packs last week.
Edduuka lya Costco mu Canberra nalyo lyakugira omuwendo ogukkirizibwa ku buganda bubiri mu wiiki ewedde.

To further alleviate the shortage, Coles ordered bigger packages from suppliers and increased delivery frequency, Woolworths ordered extra stock, while ALDI made stocks for a planned Wednesday special available early.

Okusobola okukendeeza ku bbula, Coles yasaba ababaweereza bakole obuganda obuneneko era ne bongeza ne ku mirundi gye babaweereza, Woolworths yalagira eyongerwe ku bye yalina, ate ALDI yaleeta ebirala nga bwe yateekateeka ku Lwokusatu olw’enjawulo bituuke nga bukyali.
Russell Zimmerman, executive director of the Australian Retailers Association, said that retailers try to raise stock, but local council restrictions on the timing of truck-deliveries make it hard.

Russell Zimmerman, omukungu atwala ekibiina ky’abatunzi ba lejjalejja ekya Australian Retailers Association, yagamba nti aba lejjalejja bagezaako okwongeza ku bye batereka okutunda naye okukugira kw’abakulembeze b’ekitundu ku bungi bw’emmotoka ezireeta kwabakaluubiriza.
He expects rising production costs, as suppliers try to meet demand, and fewer specials.
Asuubira okulinnyisa omuwendo gw’ensimbi ezikozesebwa, ng’ababaweereza bwe bagezaako okutuukana n’obwetaavu obuliwo ate n’ennaku ez’enjawulo entono.
On Tuesday, ALDI announced that following the early release of stock, some stores can't run the Wednesday special.
Ku Lwokubiri, ALDI yalangirira nti nga bagoberera okufulumya ebiterekebwa okutundibwa amangu, amaduuka agamu tegasobola kukola kya njawulo kya Lwakusatu.
In a News.com.au report, Dr Gary Mortimer, retail expert from Queensland University of Technology, said the stores fill the stock every night.
Mu alipoota ya News.com.au, Dr Gary Mortimer, omukugu mu kutunda ebya lejjalejja okuva mu Queensland University of Technology, yagamba nti amaduuka galeeta eby’okutunda buli kiro.
He remarked toilet paper is a bulky item, leading to low quantity of stocks in numbers, and, when sold out, leaves vast shelf spaces empty, hardening the feeling of a shortage.

Yagamba nti ebikookooma biba binene, ekireetera ebiterekebwa mu maduuka okutundibwa okubeera ebitono mu muwendo, ne kiba nti bwe bitundibwa ne biggwaawo, amasa agasigala nga makalu gaba mangi ne kireetawo okuwulira nti waliwo ebbula.

"Coles and Woolworths have a view [that] if there was plenty of stuff on the shelf, if product like toilet rolls and sanitiser could be [bought] and are there in quantities, you would probably minimise the panic" said Russell Zimmerman per ABC News.

Russell Zimmerman yagamba mu mawulire ga ABC News nti "Coles ne Woolworths balowooza [nti] bwe waba nga waliwo ebintu bingi mu masa, ebyamaguzi ng’obuganda bw’ebikookooma n’ebinaaba mu ngalo [bigulibwa] ne bibaawo mu bungi, okupakuka kuyinza okukendeezebwa " .
Recycled toilet paper producer Who Gives a Crap said on last Wednesday they'd run out of stock.
Omu ku bakozi b’ebikookooma ateerya mu ntama yagamba ku Lwokusatu nti ebikookooma byali biweddewo.
Kimberly-Clark, which makes Kleenex Toilet Tissue, and Solaris Paper which makes Sorbent, emphasized they were working 24/7 to maintain the supply, according to the News.com.au report.
Kimberly-Clark, abakola Ebikookooma, ne Solaris Paper abakola Sorbent, bakkaatiriza nti baali bakola 24/7 okulaba nti bavuganya n’obwetaavu, okusinziira ku alipoota ya News.com.au.

Domain.com, a real estate site, reported some property sellers offering free toilet paper to the first bidder on auctions in Melbourne, when fewer auctions were held because of buyers having time off on the long weekend of Labour Day.

Omukutu gwa yintanenti Domain.com, ogutunda ettaka n’ebizimbe baagamba nti waliwo abatunzi abagaba ebikookooma eby’obwereere ku muwanguzi asooka ow’oku nnyondo mu Melbourne, nga waliwo obutunzi bw’oku nnyondo obutono olw’okuba nti abaguzi baalina obudde okuwummula ku nkomerero ya wiiki eyali empanvu omuli n’Olunaku lw’Abakozi.
The Thursday edition of NT News, a daily printed in Darwin, included an eight-page insert meant to be cut up and used as toilet paper.
Mu mawuilre g’oku Lwokuna ku NT News, olupapula olufulumira mu Darwin buli lunaku, mwalimu akatabo akasonsekebwamu nga ka miko munaana nga kalina kuggyibwamu ne kakozesebwa ng’ebikookooma.
The stores were originally reluctant to impose restrictions, according to a report from ABC Australia on March 3 in which they said they had no plans to introduce restrictions on the purchases.
Amaduuka mu kusooka gaagaana okussaawo ekkomo, okusinziira ku alipoota okuva mu ABC Australia nga 3 Ogwokusatu nga muno baagamba nti baali tebateekateeka kussa kkomo ku bigulibwa.
Russell Zimmerman added that other products are also in high demand, including masks, sanitiser, dried goods, handwash and flour.
Russell Zimmerman yayongeddeko nti ebyamaguzi nabyo biri ku ttunzi omwo nga mwe muli obukookolo, ebinaaba mu ngalo, emmere enkalu, ssabbuuni w’omu ngalo n’obuwunga.
Similarly, outside of Australia, on Sunday evening online British supermarket Ocado was observed limiting purchases of Andres toilet paper to two 12-roll packs.

Mu ngeri y’emu, ebweru wa Australia, ekawungeezi ku Ssande Ssemaduuka w’oku yintaneeti Ocado yalabibwa ng’akugira okugula ebikookooma eby’ekika kya Andres ng’omuntu agula ebiri wakati wa 2 n’akaganda akalimu 12.
US President Trump declares COVID-19 national emergency
Pulezidenti wa US Trump alangiridde COVID-19 ng’ekiziu ky’eggwanga lyonna
On Friday, United States President Donald Trump declared a national emergency in response to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak.
Ku Lwokutaanu, Pulezidenti wa America Donald Trump yalangirira ekizibu eky’awamu eky’okubalukawo kwa coronavirus.
The move came two days after the World Health Organization declared the outbreak, which causes the COVID-19 disease, to be a pandemic.
Kino yakikola oluvannyuma lw’ekitongole ky’ensi yonna eky’Ebyobulamu okulangirira okubalukawo kw’obulwadde bwa COVID-19 nga nawookeera.
The move gives the federal government access to around US$50 billion in extra funding to combat the pandemic, according to NBC News.
Amawulire ga NBC News gaategeeza nti ekyakolebwa kino kisobozesa gavumenti ez’ebitundu okuweebwa ssente eziwera ng’obuwumbi bwa doola 50 okulwanyisa nawookeera ono.

The proclamation specifically said "the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States constitutes a national emergency" and said the national emergency began on March 1, almost two weeks before the proclamation itself.

Ekirangiriro ekyo kyagamba nti "okubalukawo kwa COVID-19 mu America kizibu kya wamu mu ggwanga" era n’agamba nti ekizibu ky’eggwanga kyatandika nga 1 Ogwokusatu, kumpi nga wayise wiiki bbiri nga tekinnaba kulangirirwa ng’ekizibu.
The United States Department of Health and Human Services declared the outbreak a "public health emergency" on January 31.
Ekitongole kya America eky’Ebyobulamu (United States Department of Health and Human Services) kyalangirira okubalukawo nga "ekizibu ky’ebyobulamu mu bantu bonna" nga 31 Janwali 31.
Trump did not place the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) in charge of the government's response to COVID-19, which Politico reported left some experts in disaster management disappointed.

Trump teyateeka kizibu kya COVID-19 mu mikono gy’ekitongole ekikola ku butyabaga ekiyitibwa Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), ekintu abakugu kye bagamba nti kyabamalamu amaanyi nga Politico bwe yategeeza.

Politico quoted Tim Manning, formerly a deputy administrator at FEMA, as saying "FEMA has an important role in coordinating the larger response to the crisis" and "[i]f there's an emergency, FEMA needs to be involved."

Politico yalaga ebigambo bya Tim Manning, eyali omumyuka w’omukulembeze wa FEMA, ng’agamba nti "FEMA kirina omulimu omukulu mu kukwasaganya ebirina okukolebwa ebisinga obungi ku kizibu" era nti "[singa] wabaawo ekizibu eky’amangu, FEMA kirina okwenyigiramu."
Trump made the decision under provisions of the National Emergencies Act, amongst other governing authorities.
Trump yakola okusalawo okwo ng’asinziira mu Tteeka ly’Ebizibu eby’amangu, National Emergencies Act, omwo nga mwe muli n’ebyobuyinza ebirala ebigobererwa.

The Trump administration also announced other efforts in response to COVID-19, including waiving the interest it collects on federal student loans and increasing U.S. strategic oil reserve oil purchases.

Obukulembeze bwa Trump era bwalangirira kaweefube omulala mu kulwanyisa COVID-19, omuli okuggya amagoba ge baggya ku looni z’abayizi mu gavumenti z’ebitundu wamu n’okwongeza ku mafuta ga U.S. agaterekebwa.
World Health Organization declares COVID-19 pandemic
Ekitongole ky’Ebyobulamu eky’Ensi yonna (WHO) kirangirira COVID-19 ng’ekizibu ky’ensi yonna
On Wednesday, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the ongoing outbreak of COVID-19 — the disease caused by coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 — to be a pandemic.
Ku Lwokusatu, World Health Organization (WHO) yalangirira okubalukawo kwa COVID-19 — ng’endwadde ereetebwa akawuka akayitibwa coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 — ng’ekizibu eky’ensi yonna.
Although the word "pandemic" only refers to how widely a disease has spread, not how dangerous specific cases are, the WHO noted the need to drive governments to action:

Newankubadde ng’ekigambo "ekizibu eky’ensi yonna" kitegeeza butegeeza engeri obulwadde gye busaasaanye, so si kutegeeza ngeri balwadde abamu gye bali ab’obulabe, WHO yalaga nti gavumenti zisaana okwesowalayo zibeeko kye zikola:
"All countries can still change the course of this pandemic.
"Ensi zonna zisobola okukyusa engeri ekizibu kino eky’ensi yonna gye kisaasaanamu.
If countries detect, test, treat, isolate, trace and mobilize their people in the response," said Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the Director-General of the WHO.
Singa ensi zikenga, zikebera, zijjanjaba, zaawula, zirondoola era ne zikunga abantu ku nsonga eno," bye bigambo by’Omukungu wa WHO, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus.
"We are deeply concerned both by the alarming levels of spread and severity and by the alarming levels of inaction."
"Tuwulira nga tukwatiddwako nnyo olw’engeri obulwadde buno gye busaasaanamu ate n’obulabe bwabwo era n’obuteefiirayo obuyitiridde."
According to Dr. Tom Frieden, formerly the director of the United States' Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the pandemic is "unprecedented."
Okusinziira ku Dr. Tom Frieden eyali Ssenkulu w’Ekitongole kya America Ekirwanyisa Endwadde (CDC) yagamba nti ekizibu kino "kyali tekisuubirwa."
He said, in remarks published by CNN in February, "other than influenza, no other respiratory virus has been tracked from emergence to continuous global spread."
Yagamba, mu bigambo ebyafulumira ku CNN mu Gwokubiri nti, "ng’oggyeeko yegu, tewali kawuka kalala kalumba muyungiro gwa kussa kaali kalondoddwa okuva lwe kabalukawo okutuusa lwe kabuna wonna mu nsi."
Ghebreyesus expressed a similar view, saying "we have never before seen a pandemic sparked by a coronavirus."
Ghebreyesus naye yawa ekirowoozo kye kimu, n’agamba nti "tetulabangako ku kizubu kya nsi yonna kireetebwa kawuka ka coronavirus."
He continued, "and we have never before seen a pandemic that can be controlled at the same time."
Yeeyongera okugamba nti, "era tetulabanga ku kizibu kya nsi yonna kisobola kuziyizibwa."
The new status as a pandemic follows the WHO's decision in January to declare the outbreak a public health emergency of international concern.

Ekifo ekipya eky’ekizibu ky’ensi yonna kyajja luvannyuma lwa kitongole kya WHO okusalawo mu Janwali okulangirira okubalukawo kw’obulwadde obwo ng’ekizibu ky’ebyobulamu mu bantu bonna ekikwatibwako ensi yonna.
The United States' National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease's director, Dr. Anthony Fauci, said of the outbreak, "bottom line, it's going to get worse."
Ye omukulu w’ekitongole ki United States' National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease, Dr. Anthony Fauci, yayogera ku kubalukawo kuno nga, "ekitabuusibwabuusibwa kyekino, kigenda kusajjuka."
