Per media reports on 1 April, South Korea has received requests for virus testing assistance from 121 different countries.
Nga 1 Ogwokuna, ebitongole by’amawulire byategeeza nti South Korea yali asabye obuyambi bw’ebikozesebwa mu kukebera akawuka okuva mu mawanga 121.
Iran reported its first confirmed cases of SARS-CoV-2 infections on 19 February in Qom, where, according to the Ministry of Health and Medical Education, two people died later that day.

Iran yalangirira omulwadde waayo owa SARS-CoV-2 eyasooka okukakasibwa nga 19 Ogwokubiri mu Qom, era ekitongole ky’Ebyobulamu (Ministry of Health and Medical Education) kyategeeza nti abantu babiri baafa ku lunaku olwo.

Early measures announced by the government included the cancellation of concerts and other cultural events, sporting events, and Friday prayers, and closures of universities, higher education institutions, and schools.

Eby’okukola ebyasooka okulangirirwa gavumenti mwalimu okusazaamu ebivvulu n’emikolo gy’ebyobuwangwa, emikolo gy’ebyemizannyo, n’okusaba kw’Olwokutaano, n’okuggalawo kwa yunivaasite, amatendekero aga waggulu, n’amasomero.
Iran allocated five trillion rials to combat the virus.
Iran yassaawo obutabalika (trillion) bwa rials butaano okulwanyisa akawuka.
President Hassan Rouhani said on 26 February 2020 that there were no plans to quarantine areas affected by the outbreak, and only individuals would be quarantined.
Nga 26 Ogwokubiri 2020, Pulezidenti Hassan Rouhani yagamba nti tewaaliwo nteekateeka za kuteeka kalantiini ku bitundu ebyali bikoseddwa nti era abantu kinnoomu be balina okuteekebwa mu kalantiini.
Plans to limit travel between cities were announced in March, although heavy traffic between cities ahead of the Persian New Year Nowruz continued.

Enteekateeka z’okukendeeza ku ntambula wakati w’ebibuga eby’enjawulo zaalangirirwa mu Gwokusatu wadde ng’ebidduka bingi ebyentambula z’ebikujjuko by’Omwaka omupya ogwa Persia (Persian New Year Nowruz) byo byagenda mu maaso.
Shia shrines in Qom remained open to pilgrims until 16 March 2020.Iran became a centre of the spread of the virus after China during February.
Ebifo by’okusabiramu ebya Shia mu Qom byasigala nga biggule eri abalamazi okutuusa nga 16 Ogwokusatu 2020. Iran yafuuka entabiro y’okusaasaanya akawuka ng’eddirira China mu Gwokubiri.

Amidst claims of a cover-up of the extent of the outbreak in Iran, more than ten countries had traced their cases back to Iran by 28 February, indicating that the extent of the outbreak may be more severe than the 388 cases reported by the Iranian government by that date.

Wakati mu kulumiriza nti waaliwo okubikkirira ekizibu ky’obulwadde mu Iran, amawanga agasukka mu kkumi gaali galondodde abalwadde baabwe nga baaliko mu Iran olwa 28 Ogwokubiri we lwatuukira, kino nga kiraga nti obunene bw’ekirwadde bwali bwa maanyi okusukka ku balwadde 388 gavumenti ya Iran be yali egamba nti be bali mu ggwanga eryo olunaku olwo we lwatuukira.
The Iranian Parliament was shut down, with 23 of its 290 members reported to have had tested positive for the virus on 3 March.
Paliyamenti ya Iran yayimirizibwa, nga bammemba 23 ku 290 baali bagambibwa okuba nga bakebeddwa ne basangibwa nga balina akawuka nga 3 Ogwokusatu.

On 12 March, the Human Rights Watch urged the Iranian prison authorities to unconditionally release the human rights defenders detained for peaceful dissent, and to also temporarily release all the eligible prisoners.

Nga 12 Ogwokubiri, ekitongole kya Human Rights Watch kyakubiriza aboobuyinza mu makomera ga Iran okuta abamenyi b’amateeka ku ddembe ly’obuntu awatali kakwakkulizo wamu n’okuta abasibe bonna abasaanira okuteebwa okumala ekiseera ekigere.
It stated that there is a greater risk of the virus to spread in closed institutions like detention centres, which also lack adequate medical care.
Kigambibwa nti waliwo obulabe bw’akawuka bwa maanyi okusaasaanira mu bifo ebirimu abantu abangi gamba ng’amakomera, ate nga tebiriimu bujjanjabi bumatiza.
On 15 March, the Iranian government reported 100 deaths in a single day, the most recorded in the country since the outbreak began.
Nga 15 Ogwokusatu, gavumenti ya Iran yategeeza nti abantu 100 baafa mu lunaku lumu, nga guno gwe muwendo ogwasinga obunene mu ggwanga lino okuva obulwadde lwe bwabalukawo.
At least 12 sitting or former Iranian politicians and government officials had died from the disease by 17 March.
Olwa 17 Ogwokusatu we lwatuukira abakulembeze waakiri 12 ku abo abaali bakulembeddeko Iran n’abo abali mu bukulembeze baali bafudde olw’ekirwadde ekyo.
By 23 March, Iran was experiencing 50 new cases every hour and one new death every ten minutes due to coronavirus.
Olwa 23 Ogwokusatu we lwatuukira, Iran yali efuna abalwadde 50 abapya buli ssaawa n’omuntu omu ng’afa buli luvannyuma lwa ddakiika kkumi olwa coronavirus.
According to a WHO official, there may be five times more cases in Iran than what is being reported.
Okusinziira ku mukungu wa WHO, omuwendo gw’abalwadde mu Iran guyinza okuba nga gukubisa emirundi etaano mu ogwo ogwogerwa.
It is also suggested that U.S. sanctions on Iran may be affecting the country's financial ability to respond to the viral outbreak.
Kigambibwa era nti obukwakkulizo America bwe yateeka ku Iran buyinza okuba nga bukosa obusobozi bw’eggwanga eryo okulwanyisa obulwadde.
The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights has demanded economic sanctions to be eased for nations most affected by the pandemic, including Iran.

Ekitongole ky’Amawanga Amagatte Ekirwanirira Eddembe ly’obuntu (UN High Commissioner for Human Rights) kisabye nnati z’ebyenfuna ezaateekebwa ku mawanga okuddirizibwa naddala ago agasinze okukosebwa ekirwadde kino, omwo nga mwe muli ne Iran.
The outbreak was confirmed to have spread to Italy on 31 January, when two Chinese tourists tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 in Rome.
Okubalukawo kw’obulwadde kwakakasibwa okusaasaanira mu Italy nga 31 Janwali, abalambuzi Abachina babiri bwe baakeberebwa ne bazuulibwa nga balina SARS-CoV-2 mu Roma.
Cases began to rise sharply, which prompted the Italian government to suspend all flights to and from China and declare a state of emergency.
Omuwendo gw’abalwadde gwatandika okulinnyira ku mbiro ekyaleetera gavumenti ya Italy okuyimiriza ennyonyi zonna ezigenda n’eziva e China era ne balangirira n’akaseera aka kazigizigi.

An unassociated cluster of COVID-19 cases was later detected, starting with 16 confirmed cases in Lombardy on 21 February.On 22 February, the Council of Ministers announced a new decree-law to contain the outbreak, including quarantining more than 50,000 people from 11 different municipalities in northern Italy.

Ekika ky’akawuka akatakwatagana na COVID-19 kaakengebwa oluvannyuma, nga katandikira ku balwadde 16 abaakakasibwa mu Lombardy nga 21 Ogwokubiri. Nga 22 Ogwokubiri, Akakiiko ka Baminista kaalangirira etteeka eppya okulwanyisa obulwadde, omwo nga mwe muli okuteeka abantu abasukka mu 50,000 abava mu Munisipaali ezisukka mu kalantiini mu bukiikakkono bwa Italy.
Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte said, "In the outbreak areas, entry and exit will not be provided.
Ssaabaminista Giuseppe Conte yagamba nti, "Mu bifo ebibaluseemu obulwadde, okuyingira n’okubifuluma tekujja kukkirizibwa.

Suspension of work activities and sports events has already been ordered in those areas."On 4 March, the Italian government ordered the full closure of all schools and universities nationwide as Italy reached 100 deaths.

Okuyimiriza emirimu egikolebwa n’emikolo gy’ebyemizannyo kumaze okukolebwa mu bifo ebyo. "Nga 4 Ogwokusatu, gavumenti ya Italy yalangirira okuggalirawo ddala amasomero ne yunivaasite mu ggwanga lyonna nga mu kiseera ekyo Italy yali ewezezza abafu 100.
All major sporting events, including Serie A football matches, were to be held behind closed doors until April, but on 9 March, all sport was suspended completely for at least one month.

Emikolo gy’ebyemizannyo gyonna emikulu, omuli n’emizannyo gy’omupiira egy’eddaala A (Serie A football matches), gyalina kuzannyirwa munda mu bizimbe okutuusa nga 1 Ogwokuna, naye nga 9 Ogwokusatu, emizannyo gyonna gyayimirizibwa okumala waakiri omwezi gumu.

On 11 March, Prime Minister Conte ordered stoppage of nearly all commercial activity except supermarkets and pharmacies.On 6 March, the Italian College of Anaesthesia, Analgesia, Resuscitation and Intensive Care (SIAARTI) published medical ethics recommendations regarding triage protocols that might be employed.

Nga 11 Ogwokusatu, Ssaabaminista Conte yalangirira okuyimiriza kumpi buli mulimu gwa busuubuzi okuggyako ssemaduuka n’amatundiro g’eddagala. Nga 6 Ogwokusatu, Ettendekero lya College of Anaesthesia, Analgesia, Resuscitation and Intensive Care (SIAARTI) lyafulumya ebiragiro ebikwata ku bigobererwa mu kunoonyereza okulimu enseetuka ekulembeza okufa ku balwadde (triage protocols) ebiyinza okukozesebwa mu kunoonyereza.
On 19 March, Italy overtook China as the country with the most coronavirus-related deaths in the world after reporting 3,405 fatalities from the pandemic.
Nga 19 Ogwokusatu, Italy yayisa China mu muwendo gw’abafa ekirwadde kya coronavirus mu nsi yonna bwe baategeeza nti baalina abatu 3,405 abaafa nawookeera w’ekirwadde.
On 22 March, it was reported that Russia had sent nine military planes with medical equipment to Italy.
Nga 22 Ogwokusatu, kyategeezebwa nti Russia yali eweerezza ennyonyi z’amagye mwenda mu Italy.
As of 5 April, there were 128,948 confirmed cases, 15,887 deaths, and 21,815 recoveries in Italy, with the majority of those cases occurring in the Lombardy region.
Nga 5 Ogwokuna we lwatuukira, waaliwo abalwadde abakakasiddwa 128,948, abafu 15,887, n’abawonye 21,815 mu Italy, era ng’abasinga obungi ku abo baali mu kitundu ky’e Lombardy.
A CNN report indicated that the combination of Italy's large elderly population and inability to test all who have the virus to date may be contributing to the high fatality rate.
Amawulire ga CNN gaalaga nti olw’okuba Italy erina abakadde bangi okwo nga kw’ogasse n’obutasobola kukebera bantu bonna balina kawuka, kyandiba nga kyongereza ku muwendo gw’abafa omungi.

The United Kingdom's response to the virus first emerged as one of the most relaxed of the affected countries, and until 18 March 2020, the British government did not impose any form of social distancing or mass quarantine measures on its citizens.

Engeri Bungereza gye yasooka okukwatamu obulwadde buno yafaanana okuba nga y’esinga okuba ey’emirembe mu nsi zonna ezaali zikoseddwa, era okutuusa nga 18 Ogwokusatu 2020, gavumenti ya Bungereza yali tennateekawo kiragiro kyonna ku bantu kwewa mabanga oba kalantiini ow’abantu bonna mu ggwanga eryo.

As a result, the government received criticism for the perceived lack of pace and intensity in its response to concerns faced by the public.On 16 March, Prime Minister Boris Johnson made an announcement advising against all non-essential travel and social contact, suggesting people work from home where possible and avoid venues such as pubs, restaurants, and theatres.

N’ekyava mu ekyo, gavumenti yanenyezebwa olw’okwesuulirayo ogwa nnaggamba mu buzibu obwali bwolekedde abantu. Nga 16 Ogwokusatu, Ssaabaminista Boris Johnson yalangirira ng’awa abantu amagezi okwewala okutambula okutali kwa nsonga n’okukwatagana n’abantu abalala, n’agamba nti we kisobokera bakolere ewaka era beewale n’ebifo ng’amabaala, ebifo ebiriirwamu n’ebifo ebisanyukirwamu.

On 20 March, the government announced that all leisure establishments such as pubs and gyms were to close as soon as possible, and promised to pay up to 80% of workers' wages to a limit of £2,500 per month to prevent unemployment in the crisis.On 23 March, the Prime Minister announced tougher social distancing measures, banning gatherings of more than two people and restricting travel and outdoor activity to that deemed strictly necessary.

Nga 20 Ogwokusatu, gavumenti yalangirira nti ebifo ebisanyukirwamu byonna ng’amabaala ne ggimu byali bya kuggalwa amangu ddala nga bwe kisoboka, era n’asuubiza okusasula okutuuka ku bitundu 80% eby’ensako y’abakozi okukoma ku £2,500 buli mwezi okwewala ebbula ly’emirimu mu kizibu kino. Nga 23 Ogwokusatu, Ssaabaminisita yalangirira enkola z’okwewa amabanga enkakali, n’awera enkuŋŋaana ez’abantu abasukka mu babiri n’okuwera okutambula n’ebikolerwa ebweru w’ennyumba nga birina kukolebwa nga ddala byetaagisa.
Unlike previous measures, these restrictions were enforceable by police through the issuing of fines and the dispersal of gatherings.
Ng’oggyeeko ebyokukola ebyasooka okuteekebwawo, obukwakkulizo buno poliisi ye yali erondoola okulaba nga bussibwa mu nkola nga baweesa abantu engassi n’okusattulula enkuŋŋaana zonna.
Most businesses were ordered to close, with exceptions for businesses deemed "essential", including supermarkets, pharmacies, banks, hardware shops, petrol stations, and garages.

Bizinensi ezisinga zaalagirwa okuggalawo okuggyako ezo ezitwalibwa “ng’ez’enkizo” omwo nga mwe muli ssemaduuka, amatundiro g’eddagala, bbanka, amaduuka g’ebizimbisibwa, amasundiro g’amafuta ne galagi.
On 20 January, the first known case of COVID-19 was confirmed in the Pacific Northwest state of Washington in a man who had returned from Wuhan on 15 January.
Nga 20 Janwali, omulwadde wa COVID-19 eyasooka okukakasibwa mu Pacific Northwest state of Washington yali musajja eyadda mu ggwanga ng’ava mu Wuhan nga 15 Janwali.
The White House Coronavirus Task Force was established on 29 January.
Akakiiko ka America akalwanyisa Coronavirus akayitibwa White House Coronavirus Task Force kaateekebwawo nga 29 Janwali.
On 31 January, the Trump administration declared a public health emergency, and placed restrictions on entry for travellers from China.
Nga 31 Janwali, obukulembeze bwa Trump bwalangirira kazigizigi w’ebyobulamu mu ggwanga era ne bateekawo obukwakkulizo ku batambuze abava mu China.
On 28 January 2020, the Center for Disease Control—the leading public health institute of the U.S. government—announced they had developed their own testing kit.
Nga 28 Janwali 2020, Center for Disease Control—ekitongole ekikulu mu byobulamu mu America—kyalangirira nti kyali kikoze ebikozesebwa ebyakyo okukebera obulwadde.
Despite doing so, the United States had a slow start in testing, which obscured the true extent of the outbreak at the time.
Wadde nga kino baakikola, America yatandika kasoobo ng’ekebera, era nga kino kyalemesa okumanya obunene bw’ekizibu ky’obulwadde.

Testing was marred by defective test kits produced by the federal government in February, a lack of federal government approval for non-government test kits (by academia, companies and hospitals) until the end of February, and restrictive criteria for people to qualify for a test until early March (a doctor's order was required thereafter).

Okukebera kwajjamu omugozobano gw’okukozesa ebikebera obulwadde ebikyamu mu Gwokubiri, gavumenti obutakkiriza bikebera bulwadde bitali byayo kukozesebwa (ebikozesebwa abanoonyereza, amakampuni n’amalwaliro) okutuusa ku nkomerero y’Ogwokubiri, n’okukugira abantu nga balina kutuukiriza bisaanyizo bya kukeberebwa okutuusa mu Gwokusatu (oluvannyuma ekiragiro ky’omusawo kye kibaddenga kyetaagisa).
By 27 February, The Washington Post reported fewer than 4,000 tests had been conducted in the United States.
Nga 27 Ogwokubiri, Olupapula lw’Amawulire The Washington Post lwategeezeza nti abantu abatawera 4,000 be baali bakebeddwa mu America.
By 13 March, The Atlantic reported that less than 14,000 tests had been conducted.
Nga 13 Ogwokusatu, The Atlantic lwategeeza nti abantu abatawera 14,000 be baali bakebeddwa.

On 22 March, the Associated Press reported: "Many people who have symptoms and a doctor's order have waited hours or days for a test."After the first death in the United States was reported in Washington state on 29 February, Governor Jay Inslee declared a state of emergency, an action that was soon followed by other states.

Nga 22 Ogwokusatu, Associated Press kyawandiika nti: "Abantu bangi abeeyolekerako obubonero nga balina n’olukusa lw’omusawo balindira essaawa nnyingi oba ennaku eziwera okukeberwa.” Oluvannyuma lw’omuntu eyasooka okufa mu Washington state nga 29 Ogwokubiri, Governor Jay Inslee yalangirira ekiseera ekya kazigizigi, era nga kino ebitundu ebirala nabyo kye byakola.

Schools in the Seattle area cancelled classes on 3 March, and by mid-March, schools across the country were shutting down.On 6 March 2020, the United States was advised of projections for the impact of the new coronavirus on the country by a group of epidemiologists at Imperial College London.

Amasomero mu kitundu ky’e Seattle gaasazaamu ebibiina nga 3 Ogwokusatu era amakkati g’Ogwokusatu we gaatukira, amasomero okwetooloola mu ggwanga gaatandika okuggalawo. Nga 6 Ogwokusatu 2020, ekibiina ky’abanoonyereza ku ndwadde mu Imperial College London kyawa America amagezi ku kizibu kye yali eyolekedde bulwadde obwo.

On the same day President Trump signed the Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Supplemental Appropriations Act, which provided $8.3 billion in emergency funding for federal agencies to respond to the outbreak.

Ku lunaku lwe lumu Pulezidenti Trump yassa omukono ku Tteeka ly’Okuwa Obuyambi obw’amangu (Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Supplemental Appropriations Act) mwe baaweerayo obuwumbi bwa doola 8.3 mu gavumenti z’ebitundu okulwanyisa nawookeera.
Corporations imposed employee travel restrictions, cancelled conferences, and encouraged employees to work from home.
Ebitongole byateekawo obukwakkulizo ku bakozi, byasazaamu enkuŋŋaana, era baakubiriza abakozi okukolera ewaka.
Sports events and seasons were cancelled.On 11 March, Trump announced travel restrictions for most of Europe, excluding the United Kingdom, for 30 days, effective 13 March.

Emikolo gy’emizannyo n’enzannya ezaali zitegekebwa byasazibwamu. Nga 11 Ogwokusatu, Trump yalangirira ebiragiro ku ntambula mu bitundu bya Bulaaya ebisinga, ng’oggyeeko Bungereza, okumala ennaku 30, okutandika ne 13 Ogwokusatu.
The following day, he expanded the restrictions to include the United Kingdom and Ireland.
Ku lunaku olwaddirira yagaziya ebiragiro n’ayongerako Bungereza ne Ireland.
On 13 March, he declared a national emergency, which made federal funds available to respond to the crisis.
Nga 13 Ogwokusatu, yalangirira akaseera aka kazigizigi mu ggwanga lyonna ekyaleetera okukozesa ssente za gavumenti ez’ebitundu okukozesebwa ku bulwadde obuliwo.
Beginning on 15 March, many businesses closed or reduced hours throughout the U.S. to try to reduce the spread of the virus.
Okutandika ne 15 Ogwokusatu, bizinensi nnyingi zaggalawo oba zaakendeeza ku budde bw’okukoleramu wonna mu America nga bagezaako okukekkereza okusaasaanya akawuka.

By 17 March, the epidemic had been confirmed in all 50 states and in the District of Columbia.On 23 March, it was reported that New York City had 10,700 cases of the coronavirus, more than the total number of cases in South Korea.

Nga 17 Ogwokusatu, obulwadde bwali bumaze okukakasibwa wonna mu masaza 50 ne mu District of Columbia. Nga 23 Ogwokusatu, kyategeezebwa nti Ekibuga New York kyalina abalwadde 10,700 aba coronavirus, era ng’omuwendo guno gusinga ogwo ogw’abalwadde abaali mu South Korea.
On 25 March, the governor said that social distancing seemed to be working, as estimates of case doubling slowed from 2.0 days to 4.7 days.
Nga 25 Ogwokusatu, gavana yagamba nti okwewa amabanga kwafaanana okuba nga kuvaamu ebirungi kubanga okwekubisaamu kw’abalwadde kulabika nga kwali kukendedde okuva ku nnaku 2.0 okudda ku nnaku 4.7.

As of 28 March, there were 32,308 confirmed cases in New York City, and 672 people had died from the virus.On 26 March, the United States was reported to have more confirmed coronavirus infection cases than any other country in the world, including China and Italy.As of 8 April, 400,335 cases have been confirmed in the United States, and 12,841 people have died.

28 Ogwokusatu we lwatuukira, waaliwo abalwadde abakakasiddwa 32,308 mu Kibuga New York, n’abantu 672 baali bafudde olw’akawuka. Nga 26 Ogwokusatu, America yali egambibwa okubeera n’abalwadde abakakasiddwa bangi okusinga ewalala wonna mu nsi, omwo nga mwe muli ne China ne Italy. Nga 8 Ogwokuna we lwatuukira, abalwadde 400,335 baali bakakasiddwa mu America n’abantu 12,841 nga bafudde.
Per media reports on 30 March, U.S. President Trump has decided to extend social distancing guidelines until 30 April.
Amawulire ga Per media nga 30 Ogwokusatu gaategeeza nti Pulezidenti wa U.S. Trump yasalawo okwongezaayo ebbanga ly’ebiragiro by’okwewa amabanga okutuusa nga 30 Ogwokuna.
On the same day, the USNS Comfort, a hospital ship with about 1000 beds, made anchor in New York.
Ku lunaku lwe lumu, eddwaliro lya USNS Comfort, erikolera ku lyato eririko ebitanda nga 1000 lyatuuka mu New York.
On 3 April, the U.S. had a record 884 deaths due to the coronavirus in a 24-hour period.
Nga 3 Ogwokuna, America yalina abantu abafudde 884 olwa coronavirus mu ssaawa 24 zokka.

In the state of New York the cases have exceeded 100,000 people on 3 April.The White House has been criticized for downplaying the threat and controlling the messaging by directing health officials and scientists to coordinate public statements and publications related to the virus with the office of Vice-President Mike Pence.

Mu New York abalwadde baali basusse 100,000 olwa 3 Ogwokuna we lwatuukira. White House yakolokotebwa olw’okunyoomereza ekizibu n’okufuga obubaka obufuluma mu bantu nga balagira abeebyobulamu ne bannassaayansi okuweereza obubaka bwonna n’ebiwandiiko ebifulumizibwa mu wofiisi y’Omumyuka wa Pulezidenti Mike Pence.
Overall approval of Trump's management of the crisis has been polarized along partisan lines.
Okutwaliza awamu engeri Trump gy’akuttemu ekizubu kino etunuuliddwa nnyo ng’etambulidde ku kyekubiira.
Some U.S. officials and commentators criticized the U.S. reliance on importation of critical materials, including essential medical supplies, from China.
Abakulembeze abamu mu U.S. n’aboogera ku byamawulire baakolokota America olw’okwesigama ennyo mu kuggya ebweru ebintu eby’amanaanyi ebyetaagisa, omwo nga mwe muli n’eddagala ebiva mu China.
An analysis of air travel patterns was used to map and predict patterns of spread and was published in The Journal of Travel Medicine in mid-January 2020.
Okwekenneenya entambula z’omu bbanga kwakozesebwa okwoleka engeri obulwadde gye busaasaanamu era ne kufulumizibwa mu The Journal of Travel Medicine wakati wa Janwali 2020.
Based on 2018 information from the International Air Transport Association, Bangkok, Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Taipei had the largest volume of travellers from Wuhan.

Okusinziira ku bubaka obwafuluma mu 2018 nga buva mu Kibiina ky’Ensi yonna ku ntambula z’omu bbanga (International Air Transport Association), Bangkok, Hong Kong, Tokyo, ne Taipei byalina abasaabaze abasinga obungi nga bava mu Wuhan.
Dubai, Sydney, and Melbourne were also reported as popular destinations for people travelling from Wuhan.
Dubai, Sydney, ne Melbourne nabyo byayogerwako ng’ebifo ebyettanirwa nnyo abantu abava mu Wuhan.

Bali was reported as least able among the 20 most popular destination cities in terms of preparedness, while cities in Australia were considered most able.Australia released its Emergency Response Plan for Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) on 7 February.

Bali kyayogerwako ng’ekisinga obutaba na busobozi mu bibuga ebituukirwamu ku ebyo 20 ebisinga okwettanirwa ng’otunuulidde okwetegeka, so ng’ate ebibuga mu Australia byayogerwako ng’ebirina obusobozi. Australia yafulumya enteekateeka yaayo ey’okulwanyisa Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) nga 7 Ogwokubiri.
It stated that much was yet to be discovered about COVID-19, and that Australia would emphasize border control and communication in its response to the pandemic.
Kigambibwa nti bingi byali birina okuzuulibwa ku COVID-19, era nti Australia yali erina okutunuulira ennyo ensalo zaayo n’empuliziganya mu kulwanyisa nawookeera.
On 21 March, a human biosecurity emergency was declared in Australia.
Nga 21 Ogwokusatu, akaseera ak’obwerende kaalangirirwa mu Australia.

Owing to the effective quarantine of public transport in Wuhan and Hubei, several countries have planned to evacuate their citizens and diplomatic staff from the area, primarily through chartered flights of the home nation, with Chinese authorities providing clearance.

Olw’okuba nti enkola ya kalantiini ku ntambula y’olukale yakoze bulungi mu Wuhan ne Hubei, amawanga mangi gateeseteese okuggya abantu baago n’abakungu mu kitundu ekyo, era nga kino bakikola nga bakozesa ennyonyi empangise okuva mu ggwanga eryo erinona abantu baalyo nga bakkirizibwa aboobuyinza mu China.
Canada, the United States, Japan, India, Sri Lanka, Australia, France, Argentina, Germany, and Thailand were among the first to plan the evacuation of their citizens.
Canada, America, Japan, India, Sri Lanka, Australia, France, Argentina, Germany, ne Thailand ge mawanga agaasooka okutegeka okuddukira abantu baago.
Pakistan has said that it will not be evacuating any citizens from China.
Pakistan yagamba nti tejja kuggya mutuuze waayo yenna mu China.
On 7 February, Brazil evacuated 34 Brazilians or family members in addition to four Poles, a Chinese person, and an Indian citizen.
Nga 7 Ogwokubiri, Brazil yaddukira abantu baayo 34 oba ab’omu maka agamu okwo nga kw’otadde n’aba Poland bana n’omutuuze wa India.
The citizens of Poland, China, and India deplaned in Poland, where the Brazilian plane made a stopover before following its route to Brazil.
Abatuuze b’omu Poland, China, ne India baaviirmu mu Poland, ennyonyi ya Brazil we yamiriramukko nga tennaba kweyongerayo kugenda Brazil.
Brazilian citizens who went to Wuhan were quarantined at a military base near Brasília.
Bannansi ba Brazil abaagenda mu Wuhan baateekebwa mu kalantiini mu nkambi y’amagye okumpi ne Brasília.
On the same day, 215 Canadians (176 from the first plane, and 39 from a second plane chartered by the U.S. government) were evacuated from Wuhan to CFB Trenton to be quarantined for two weeks.

Ku lunaku lwe lumu, Bannakanada 215 (176 okuva mu nnyonyi eyasooka, ne 39 okuva mu nnyonyi eyookubiri eyapangisibwa gavumenti ya America) baddukirwa okuva mu Wuhan ne babatwala e CFB Trenton bateekebwe mu kalantiini okumala wiiki bbiri.
On 11 February, another plane of 185 Canadians from Wuhan landed at CFB Trenton.
Nga 11 Ogwokubiri, ennyonyi endala ng’erimu Abakanada 185 okuva mu Wuhan yatuuka e CFB Trenton.
Australian authorities evacuated 277 citizens on 3 and 4 February to the Christmas Island Detention Centre, which had been repurposed as a quarantine facility, where they remained for 14 days.

Aboobuyinza mu Australia baddukira bannansi baabwe 277 nga 3 ne 4 Ogwokubiri ne babatwala ku Christmas Island Detention Centre, kye baali bataddewo ng’ekifo kya kalantiini era nga baali balina okubeera eyo okumala ennaku 14.
A New Zealand evacuation flight arrived in Auckland on 5 February; its passengers (including some from Australia and the Pacific) were quarantined at a naval base in Whangaparoa, north of Auckland.

Ennyonyi ya New Zealand eyaddukira abantu baayo yatuuka mu in Auckland nga 5 Ogwokubiri; abasaabaze baayo (nga mulimu n’abamu okuva mu Australia ne Pacific) baateekebwa mu kalantiini mu Whangaparoa, mu bukiikakkono bwa Auckland.
On 15 February, the United States announced that it would evacuate Americans aboard the cruise ship Diamond Princess.
Nga 15 Ogwokubiri, America yalangirira nti ejja kuddukira Abamerica nga batambulira ku lyato, Diamond Princess.
On 21 February, a plane carrying 129 Canadian passengers who had been evacuated from Diamond Princess landed in Trenton, Ontario.
Nga 21 Ogwokubiri, ennyonyi eyaliko abasaabaze ba Canada 129 abaali baddukiddwa okuva mu Diamond Princess baatuuka mu Trenton, Ontario.

In early March, the Indian government began evacuating its citizens from Iran.On 14 March a South African Airways aircraft chartered by the South African Government repatriated 112 South African citizens.

Ku ntandika y’Ogwokusatu, gavumenti ya Indian yatandika okuddukira abantu baayo mu Iran. Nga 14 Ogwokusatu gavumenti ya South Africa, yapangisa ennyonyi ya South African Airways okuddukira abatuuze baayo 112.
Medical screening was performed prior to departure, and four South Africans who were showing signs of coronavirus were left behind to mitigate risk.
Okusunsula kw’ekisawo kwakolebwa ng’ennyonyi tennanasimbula era bannansi ba South Africa abaalabikirako obubonero bwa coronavirus baalekebwa emabega olw’okukendeeza ku bulabe.
Only South Africans who tested negative were repatriated.
Bannansi ba South Africa abataalina bulwadde be bazzibwayo ku butaka.

Test results cleared all the South Africans, including the flight crew, pilots, hotel staff, police and soldiers involved in the humanitarian mission who, as a precautionary measure, all remained under observation and in quarantine for a 14-day period at The Ranch Resort.

Ebyava mu kukebera byalaga nti bannansi ba South Africa bonna baali bulungi, omwo nga mwe muli abakozi bw’oku nnyonyi, abavuzi b’ennyonyi, abakozi b’omu wooteeri, abapoliisi n’abajaasi abeetaba mu kaweefube w’obuyambi, era nga bonna mu ngeri y’okwerinda, baasigala beetegerezebwa era nga bali mu kalantiini okumala ennaku 14 ku The Ranch Resort.
On 20 March, the United States began to partially withdrawal its troops from Iraq due to the pandemic.
Nga 20 Ogwokusatu, America yatandika okuggya abajaasi baayo mu Iraq mu biwagu olw’obulwadde buno.
On 5 February, the Chinese foreign ministry stated that 21 countries (including Belarus, Pakistan, Trinidad and Tobago, Egypt, and Iran) had sent aid to China.
Nga 5 Ogwokubiri, Minisitule ya China ey’ensonga z’ebweru yagamba nti amawanga 21 (omuli Belarus, Pakistan, Trinidad and Tobago, Egypt, ne Iran) gaali gabaweerezza obuyambi.

Some Chinese students at American universities joined together to help send aid to virus-stricken parts of China, with a joint group in the greater Chicago area reportedly managing to send 50,000 N95 masks to hospitals in the Hubei province on 30 January.The humanitarian aid organization Direct Relief, in coordination with FedEx, sent 200,000 face masks along with other personal protective equipment, including gloves and gowns, by emergency airlift to the Wuhan Union Hospital by 30 January.

Abayizi abasibuka mu China nga basomera mu yunivaasite z’omu America beegatta wamu ne baweereza obuyambi mu bitundu by’omu China ebyakosebwa ennyo obulwadde, era nga waliwo ekibiina ekiri mu Chicago ekyaweereza obukookolo obw’ekika kya N95 obuwera 50,000 mu malwaliro g’omu Hubei nga on 30 Janwali. Ekitongole ekigabi ky’obuyambi (The humanitarian aid organization Direct Relief) wamu ne FedEx, baaweereza obukookolo 200,000 wamu n’ebintu ebirala eby’okwesabika omuli giraavu ne gawuni ne bigendera ku nnyonyi ey’obuyambi obw’amangu mu Wuhan Union Hospital nga 30 Janwali.
On 5 February, Bill and Melinda Gates announced a $100 million donation to the WHO to fund vaccine research and treatment efforts along with protecting "at-risk populations in Africa and South Asia".

Nga 5 Ogwokubiri, Bill ne Melinda Gates baalangirira obuyambi bwa bukadde bwa doola 100 eri ekitongole kya WHO okukola ku kunoonyereza kw’eddagala erigema n’okukola ku bujjanjabi wamu n’okukuuma "abantu abali mu buzibu mu Afrika ne South Asia".
Interaksyon reported that the Chinese government donated 200,000 masks to the Philippines on 6 February, after Senator Richard Gordon shipped 3.16 million masks to Wuhan.
Interaksyon kyategeeza nti gavumenti ya China yagabira eggwanga lya Philippines obukookolo 200,000 nga 6 Ogwokubiri nga Omubaka Richard Gordon amaze okuweereza obukookolo obukadde 3.16 mu Wuhan.
On 19 February, the Singapore Red Cross announced that it would send $2.26 million worth of aid to China.
Nga 19 Ogwokubiri, Ekitongole kya Red Cross mu Singapore kyalangirira nti kigenda kusindika obuyambi obubalirirwamu obukadde $2.26 mu China.

Japan donated one million face masks to Wuhan, Turkey dispatched medical equipment, Russia sent more than 13 tonnes of medical supplies to Wuhan, Malaysia announced a donation of 18 million medical gloves to China, Germany delivered various medical supplies including 10,000 Hazmat suits, and the United States donated 17.8 tons of medical supplies to China and promised an additional $100 million in financial support to affected countries.After cases in China seemed to stabilize, the country has been sending aid to various nations hit by the pandemic.

Japan yawaayo obukookolo akakadde kamu eri Wuhan, Turkey yawaayo ebikozesebwa mu kujjanjaba, Russia yaweereza ttani z’ebikozesebwa mu kujjanjaba ezisukka mu 13 mu Wuhan, Malaysia yalangirira nti ewadde China obukadde bwa giraavu 18, Germany yatwala ebikozesebwa mu kujjanjaba ebyenjawulo omuli Hazmat suits 10,000, ate America yawa China ttani 17.8 ez’ebikozesebwa mu kujjanjaba era n’esuubiza okwongerayo obukadde bwa ssente $100 okuyamba amawanga agaali gakoseddwa. Obulwadde bwe bugenze nga bukendeera mu China, China yo ebadde eweereza obuyambi mu mawanga ag’enjawulo agakoseddwa nawookeera ono.
In March, China, Cuba and Russia sent medical supplies and experts to help Italy deal with its coronavirus outbreak.
Mu Gwokusatu, China, Chuba ne Russia baaweereza ebikozesebwa mu kujjanjaba n’abakugu okuyamba ku Italy ku coronavirus eyali abaluseewo.
Businessman Jack Ma sent 1.1 million testing kits, 6 million face masks, and 60,000 protective suits to Addis Ababa, Ethiopia for distribution by the African Union.
Munnabizinesi Jack Ma yaweereza ebikozesebwa mu kukebera akakadde 1.1, obukookolo obukadde 6, n’obuganduula 60,000 mu Addis Ababa, Ethiopia African Union ebigabe.
He later sent 5,000 testing kits, 100,000 face masks and 5 ventilators to Panama.
Oluvannyuma yaweereza ebikozesebwa mu kukebera 5,000, obukookolo 100,000 n’ebyuma ebiyambako mu kussa 5 mu Panama.
Ma also donated medical supplies to Canada.The Netherlands, Spain, Turkey, Georgia, and the Czech Republic expressed their concerns over Chinese-made masks and test kits.
Ma era yawaayo ebikozesebwa mu kujjanjaba eri Canada. Netherlands, Spain, Turkey, Georgia, ne Czech Republic beemulugunya ku bukookolo n’ebikozesebwa mu kukebera ebikolerwa mu China.
For instance, Spain withdrew 58,000 Chinese-made coronavirus testing kits with an accuracy rate of just 30%, meanwhile, the Netherlands recalled 600,000 Chinese face masks which were defective.

Okugeza, Spain yasazaamu ebikozesebwa mu kukebera coronavirus 58,000 ebikolebwa mu China nga bino obutuukirivu bwabyo bwali bwa bitundu 30% byokka, so nga Netherlands yasazaamu obukookolo bw’e China 600,000 obwali obufu.
Belgium recalled 100,000 unusable masks, thought to be from China, but were in fact from Colombia.
Belgium yasazaamu obukookolo 100,000 obwali tebusobola kukozesebwa, nga bulowoozebwa nga bwava China, naye nga mu butuufu bwali buva Colombia.
On the other hand, Chinese aid has been well-received in parts of Latin America and Africa.On 2 April, the World Bank launched emergency support operations for developing countries.
Ku ludda olulala, Obuyambi bwa China bwayanirizibwa bulungi mu bitundu by’e Latin America ne mu Africa. Nga 2 Ogwokuna, Banka y’Ensi Yonna yatongoza obuyambi obw’amangu eri amawanga agakyakula.
The WHO has commended the efforts of Chinese authorities in managing and containing the epidemic.
WHO etenderezza kaweefube wa China mu ngeri gy’ekuttemu n’okulwanyisa obulwadde.

The WHO noted the contrast between the 2002–2004 SARS outbreak, where Chinese authorities were accused of secrecy that impeded prevention and containment efforts, and the current crisis where the central government "has provided regular updates to avoid panic ahead of Lunar New Year holidays".

WHO yazuula enjawulo wakati w’obulwadde bwa SARS obwabalukawo mu 2002–2004, nga ku olwo abakulembeze ba China balumirizibwa okusirikira ebyama ekyalemesa kaweefube w’okubwewala n’okubulwanyisa, n’ekizibu ekiriwo kati nga gavumenti ya wakati "etegeeza abantu buli kiseera okwewala okubuguutana mu kwetegekera eggandaalo ly’okuyingira omwaka omupya (Lunar New Year holidays)".

On 23 January, in reaction to the central authorities' decision to implement a transportation ban in Wuhan, WHO representative Gauden Galea remarked that while it was "certainly not a recommendation the WHO has made", it was also "a very important indication of the commitment to contain the epidemic in the place where it is most concentrated" and called it "unprecedented in public health history".On 30 January, following confirmation of human-to-human transmission outside China and the increase in the number of cases in other countries, the WHO declared the outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), the sixth PHEIC since the measure was first invoked during the 2009 swine flu pandemic.

Nga 23 Janwali, ng’ayanukula eky’abakungu ba gavumenti okusalawo okuyimiriza entambula mu Wuhan, omukiise wa WHO Gauden Galea yagamba nti “newankubadde WHO si ye yakisalawo”, kyali “kikolwa kirungi nnyo era nga kiraga okwewaayo okulwanyisa obulwadde mu kitundu mwe businze okwegiriisiza” era n’akyogerako nga “ekyali kitabangawo mu byafaayo byobujjanjabi”. Nga 30 Janwali, ng’okusiigibwa okuva ku muntu okudda ku mulala kumaze okukakasibwa ebweru wa China era nga n’omuwendo gw’abalwadde gweyongera mu mawanga amalala, WHO yalangirira nti obulwadde buno kyali Kizibu kya Byabulamu eky’Ensi Yonna ekyetaaga Okufiibwako mu Bwangu (Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC)), nga kino kyamukaaga okuva ekitegeero kino bwe kyassibwawo bwe waabalukawo ekirwadde ky’omusujja gw’embizzi mu 2009.
WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom said that the PHEIC was due to "the risk of global spread, especially to low- and middle-income countries without robust health systems.
Omukulu wa WHO Tedros Adhanom yagamba nti PHEIC kino kyava ku "buzibu bw’okusaasaana mu nsi yonna, naddala mu mawanga amankuseere (low- and middle-income countries) agatalina byabujjanjabi birungi.

In response to the implementations of travel restrictions, Tedros stated that "there is no reason for measures that unnecessarily interfere with international travel and trade" and that the "WHO doesn't recommend limiting trade and movement."

Ng’ayanukula ku ky’okuyimiriza ebyentambula, Tedros yagamba nti "tewali nsonga lwaki ebyentambula n’ebyobusuubuzi mu nsi yonna bimala gataataaganyizibwa" era nti "WHO tewagira kya kukendeeza busuubuzi na ntambula."

On 5 February, the WHO appealed to the global community for a $675 million contribution to fund strategic preparedness in low-income countries, citing the urgency to support those countries which "do not have the systems in place to detect people who have contracted the virus, even if it were to emerge".

Nga 5 Ogwokubiri, WHO yawanjagira abantu mu nsi yonna okuwaayo obukadde bwa doola 675 okuvujjirira okweteekateeka mu mawanga amankuseere, n’alaga nti kyali kyetaagisa mu bwangu okuwagira amawanga ago "agatalina nkola za kuzuula bantu bakwatiddwa kawuka, singa kaba kabaluseewo ".

Tedros further made statements declaring that "we are only as strong as our weakest link" and urged the international community to "invest today or pay more later".On 11 February, the WHO in a press conference established COVID-19 as the name of the disease.

Tedros era yalangirira nti "amaanyi gaffe genkanankana n’awo we tusinga okubeerera abanafu" era n’asaba abantu mu nsi yonna "okusiga leero oba okusasula ekinene gye bujja". Nga 11 Ogwokubiri, WHO mu lukuŋŋaana lw’amawulire yalangirira COVID-19 ng’erinnya ly’obulwadde buno.
On the same day, Tedros stated that UN Secretary-General António Guterres had agreed to provide the "power of the entire UN system in the response".
Ku lunaku lwe lumu olwo, Tedros yagamba nti Ssaabawandiisi w’Ekibiina ky’Amawanga Amagatte António Guterres yali akkirizza okuwaayo "amaanyi ga UN yonna mu kulwanyisa obulwadde ".

A UN Crisis Management Team was activated as a result, allowing coordination of the entire United Nations response, which the WHO states will allow them to "focus on the health response while the other agencies can bring their expertise to bear on the wider social, economic and developmental implications of the outbreak".

Tiimu ya UN ekola ku kulwanyisa ebibamba (UN Crisis Management Team) yassibwawo, esobole okukwanaganya kaweefube w’Amawanga Amagatte gonna, nga kino WHO egamba nti kijja kubayamba "okussa essira ku byobujjanjabi ng’ebitongole ebirala bwe bireeta obukugu bwabyo okuyamba ku nsonga z’embeera z’abantu, ebyenfuna n’enkulaakulana mu kiseera ky’obulwadde buno ".

On 14 February, a WHO-led Joint Mission Team with China was activated to provide international and WHO experts on the ground in China to assist in the domestic management and evaluate "the severity and the transmissibility of the disease" by hosting workshops and meetings with key national-level institutions and to conduct field visits to assess the "impact of response activities at provincial and county levels, including urban and rural settings".On 25 February, the WHO declared that "the world should do more to prepare for a possible coronavirus pandemic," stating that while it was still too early to call it a pandemic, countries should nonetheless be "in a phase of preparedness".

Nga 14 Ogwokubiri, Tiimu ey’awamu eyakulirwa WHO mu China yassibwawo okuwaayo abakugu okuva mu nsi yonna ne mu WHO eri China okuyambako mu nkwata y’ebintu awaka n’okwekenneenya "obukambwe n’okusaasaana kw’obulwadde" nga bategeka emisomo n’enkuŋŋaana n’ebitongole ebikulu mu ggwanga n’okugenda mu bitundu okwekaliriza "ebiva mu bikoleddwa ku mutendera gw’ebitundu n’amasaza, omuli ebitundu eby’ebibuga n’eby’ebyalo". Nga 25 Ogwokubiri, WHO yalangirira nti "ensi erina okukola ekisingawo okwetegekera coronavirus ayinza okufuuka ekizibu ky’ensi yonna," n’egamba nti newankubadde obudde bwali bukyali okukiyita ekizibu ky’ensi yonna (pandemic), amawanga gaali gasaanye okubeera "nga geetegese ".

In response to a developing outbreak in Iran, the WHO sent a Joint Mission Team there to assess the situation.On 28 February, WHO officials said that the coronavirus threat assessment at the global level would be raised from "high" to "very high", its highest level of alert and risk assessment.

Ku bulwadde obwali butandise okubalukawo mu Iran, WHO yaweerezaayo Tiimu ey’Awamu (Joint Mission Team) okwekenneenya embeera. Nga 28 Ogwokubiri, abakungu ba WHO baagamba nti okwekenneenya ekizibu kya coronavirus ku mutendera gw’ensi yonna kwali kwa kulinnyisibwa okuva ku kubeera "okw’amaanyi" okutuuka ku "okw’amaanyi ennyo", nga gwe mutendera gwabwe ogw’okwekenneenya ekizibu ogusinga okuba waggulu.
Mike Ryan, executive director of the WHO's health emergencies program, warned in a statement that "This is a reality check for every government on the planet: Wake up.
Mike Ryan, nga y’akulira enteekateeka ya WHO ey’ebigwawo mu byobulamu (WHO's health emergencies program), yalabula bwe yagamba nti "Kino kya kwekebera eri buli gavument mu nsi yonna: Muzuukuke.
This virus may be on its way and you need to be ready," urging that the right response measures could help the world avoid "the worst of it".

Akawuka kano kayinza okuba nga kali mu kkubo kajja era mwetaaga okubeera abeetegefu," n’alabula nti okubeera n’enkola entuufu ez’okukalwanyisa kiyinza okuyamba ensi okwewala "ekisinga okuba ekyobulabe ".

Ryan further stated that the current data did not warrant public health officials to declare a global pandemic, saying that such a declaration would mean "we're essentially accepting that every human on the planet will be exposed to that virus."

Ryan era yagamba nti obubaka obuliwo mu kiseera kino bwali tebuleetera bakungu ba byabulamu kulangirira kizibu kino ng’eky’awamu mu nsi yonna, n’agamba nti ekirangiriro eky’engeri eno kyandibadde kitegeeza nti "tuba tukkirizza nti buli muntu mu nsi yonna ajja kukosebwa akawuka ako."
On 11 March, the WHO declared the coronavirus outbreak a pandemic.
Nga 11 Ogwokusatu, WHO yalangirira akawuka ka coronavirus ng’ekizibu eky’awamu mu nsi yonna.

The Director-General said that the WHO was "deeply concerned both by the alarming levels of spread and severity, and by the alarming levels of inaction".The WHO has faced significant criticism for what is seen as inadequate handling of the pandemic, including the late declaration of a public health emergency and the classification of the virus as a pandemic.

Director-General yagamba nti WHO yali "efaayo nnyo ku misinde emingi akawuka gye kaali katambulirako n’obukambwe bwako, n’engeri gye wataaliwo kya maanyi kikolebwa". WHO ekolokoteddwa nnyo olw’ekirabika ng’obutakola kya maanyi mu ngeri y’okukwatamu obulwadde, omuli n’okulwawo okulangirira ekizibu ky’ebyobulamu ekyetaaga okufiibwako amangu n’okubulangirira ng’ekizibu eky’ensi yonna.
The backlash included a petition for the WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom to tender his resignation, signed by 733,000 people as of 6 April.
Okukolokota kuno kwalimu okukaka Director-General wa WHO Tedros Adhanom okulekulira, nga kaweefube ono yassibwako emikono abantu 733,000 we lwatuukira nga 6 Ogwokuna.
On 26 March 2020, dozens of UN human rights experts emphasized respecting the rights of every individual during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Nga 26 Ogwokusatu 2020, abakugu ba UN ku byeddembe ly’obuntu bakkaatiriza eky’okussa ekitiibwa mu ddembe lya buli muntu mu kiseera ky’obulwadde bwa COVID-19.
The expert group stated that everyone is entitled to life-saving interventions and the government holds this responsibility.
Ekibinja ky’abakugu kyagamba nti buli muntu alina eddembe okufuna ebitaasa obulamu era nti buno buvunaanyizibwa bwa gavumenti.
The group stressed that the lack of resources or health insurance should never serve as a justification for discrimination against a specific group.
Ekibinja kino kyakkaatiriza nti ebbula ly’ebikozesebwa oba yinsuwa y’ebyobulamu tebirina kutwalibwa ng’ekyekwaso ky’okusosola abantu abamu.

The experts underscored that every individual has the right to health, including people with disabilities, belonging to minority groups, older people, internally displaced people, the homeless, those living in extremely poor conditions, people in detention, as well as refugees and other unspecified groups in need of government support.

Abakugu baakiraga nti buli muntu alina eddembe ku byobulamu, omuli n’abantu abalina obulemu, ebibinja by’abantu abatono, abakadde, abali mu nkambi z’ababudami, abatalina waabwe, ababeera mu mbeera embi ennyo, abasibe, awamu n’abanoonyi b’obubudamu n’abalala bonna abeetaaga obuyambi bwa gavumenti.
International governmental organizations are addressing the economic and social impacts of the COVID-19 crisis.
Ebitongole bya gavumenti mu nsi yonna bikola ku buzibu bwa COVID-19 eri ebyenfuna n’embeera z’abantu.

The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has launched a platform to provide timely and comprehensive information on policy responses in countries around the world, as well as viewpoints and advice.

Ekitongole ki Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development kitaddewo enkola mwe kinaayita okuwa obubaka mu budde era mu bujjuvu ku nkola eziteereddwawo mu mawanga okwetooloola ensi, awamu n’ebirowoozo n’amagezi.

From policies to strengthen health systems and the world economy to addressing the effects of lockdown and restrictions on travel, the digital hub includes a Country Policy Tracker, and aims to help countries learn from each other and to facilitate a co-ordinated global response to the coronavirus challenge.

Okuva ku nkola z’okunyweza ebyobujjanjabi n’ebyenfuna by’ensi yonna okutuuka ku kukola ku bireetebwawo omuggalo n’okuggala ebyentambula, enkola enko erimu Akalondoola Enkola mu Mawanga (Country Policy Tracker), era egenderera okuyamba amawanga okuyigira ku gannaago era n’okukwaganya kaweefube w’omu nsi yonna mu kusoomoozebwa kwa coronavirus.

The Chinese government has been criticized by the United States, UK Minister for the Cabinet Office Michael Gove, and Brazil President Jair Bolsonaro's son Eduardo Bolsonaro for its handling of the pandemic, which began in the Chinese province of Hubei.

Gavumenti ya China ekolokoteddwa United States, Minisita wa UK owa Kabineeti Michael Gove, ne mutabani wa Pulezidenti wa Brazil Jair Bolsonaro nga ye Eduardo Bolsonaro olw’engeri gye baakuttemu ekizibu kino, ekyatandikira mu Province y’e China ey’e Hubei.

A number of provincial-level administrators of the Communist Party of China (CPC) were dismissed over their handling of the quarantine efforts in Central China, a sign of discontent with the political establishment's response to the outbreak in those regions.

Abakulembeze bangi ku mutendera gwa Province mu kibiina kya Communist Party of China (CPC) baagobwa olw’engeri gye bakwatamu kaweefube wa kalantiini mu Masekkati ga China, akabonero akalaga obutali bumativu ku ngeri abakulembeze gye bakwatamu obulwadde mu bitundu ebyo.
Some commentators believe that this move was intended to protect Chinese Communist Party general secretary Xi Jinping from the public's anger over the coronavirus outbreak.

Abatunuulizi abamu balowooza nti ekikolwa kino kyagendererwamu okutaasa Ssaabawandiisi w’ekibiina kya Chinese Communist Party Xi Jinping ku busungu bw’abantu olw’ekirwadde kya coronavirus ekyali kibaluseewo.

Some Chinese officials, e.g. Zhao Lijian rejected an earlier acknowledgement of the coronavirus outbreak starting in Wuhan, in favour of conspiracy theories about the COVID-19 originating from the U.S. or Italy.

Abakungu ba China abamu, okugeza Zhao Lijian baawakanya ekyali kisoose okukkirizibwa nti akawuka ka coronavirus kaatandikira mu Wuhan, nga bawagira endowooza z’okwekobaana ezaali ziraga nti COVID-19 yatandikira mu U.S. oba Italy.

The U.S. administration of Donald Trump has referred to the coronavirus as "Chinese virus" or "Wuhan virus" saying that China's "censorship supercharged a virus that has now turned into a global pandemic", which has in turn been criticized by some critics as racism and "distract[ing] from his administration's failure to contain the disease".

Obukulembeze bwa Donald Trump mu Amerika bwogera ku coronavirus nga "Akawuka k’e China " oba "Akawuka k’e Wuhan " nga bagamba nti "okuwangulwa kwa China kwabaleetera okukola akawuka kati akafuuse ekizibu ky’ensi yonna ", nga kino nakyo kikolokoteddwa abantu abamu ng’okusosola mu langi "nga kivudde ku kulemererwa kw’obukulembeze bwe okulwanyisa obulwadde " buno.

The Daily Beast obtained a U.S. government cable outlining a communications stratagem with apparent origins in the National Security Council, with the strategy being quoted as "Everything is about China.
Daily Beast yafuna obubaka okuva mu gavumenti ya Amerika nga bulaga akakodyo k’empuliziganya okuva mu National Security Council, ng’akakodyo kalaga nti "Buli kimu kikwata ku China.

We're being told to try and get this messaging out in any way possible, including press conferences and television appearances."Outlets such as Politico, Foreign Policy, and Bloomberg have claimed that China's efforts to send aid to virus-stricken countries is part of a propaganda push for global influence.

Tutegeezebwa okugezaako okufulumya amawulire gano mu ngeri yonna esoboka, omuli enkuŋŋaana z’amawulire n’okulabikira ku ttivvi." Emikutu nga Politico, Foreign Policy, ne Bloomberg gyagamba nti kaweefube wa China ku kuweeeza obuyambi eri amawanga agakoseddwa akawuka kye kimu ku ppokoppoko waabwe ow’okufuna obuganzi mu nsi yonna.
EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell warned that there is "a geo-political component including a struggle for influence through spinning and the 'politics of generosity'".
Akulira ensonga z’amawanga amalala mu EU (foreign policy chief) Josep Borrell yalabula nti mulimu "ebyobufuzi by’amawanga omuli n’okulwanira obwannampala ne 'ebyobufuzi bya mwoyo gwa ggwanga'".
Borrell also said that "China is aggressively pushing the message that, unlike the US, it is a responsible and reliable partner."
Borrell era yagamba nti "China erwana okuyisaawo obulaga nti, obutafaanana na Amerika, bo balina obuvunaanyizibwa era beesigika."
China has also called for the US to lift its sanctions off of Syria, Venezuela and Iran, while reportedly sending aid to the latter two countries.
China era yasaba Amerika okuggya envumbo ku Syria, Venezuela ne Iran, ng’eno bw’egenda mu maaso n’okuweereza amawanga ago obuyambi.
Jack Ma's donation of 100,000 masks to Cuba was blocked by US sanctions on 3 April.
Obuyambi bwa Jack Ma obw’obukookolo 100,000 eri Cuba bwakwatibwa olw’envumbo za Amerika nga 3 Ogwokuna.
US authorities have also been accused of diverting aid meant for other nations to their own country.
Aboobuyinza mu Amerika nabo baanenyezebwa olw’okuwamba obuyambi obwali buweerezebwa mu mawanga amalala ne babwekomya.
And there have been mask-related disputes reported between other countries, such as Germany, Austria and Switzerland; and the Czech Republic and Italy.
Era wabaddewo obutakkaanya obukwata ku bukookolo wakati w’amawanga amalala, nga Germany, Austria ne Switzerland; ne Czech Republic ne Italy.
In addition, Turkey seized hundreds of ventilators destined for Spain.
Ekirala, Turkey yabowa ebikumi n’ebikumi by’ebyuma ebiyamba mu kussa (ventilators) ebyali bigenda e Spain.
In early March, the Italian government criticized the European Union's lack of solidarity with coronavirus-affected Italy.
Ku ntandikwa y’Ogwokusatu, gavumenti ya Italy yakolokota Omukago gwa Bulaaya olw’obutayimirira wamu ne Italy ng’ekoseddwa coronavirus.
Maurizio Massari, Italy's ambassador to the EU, said that "Only China responded bilaterally.
Maurizio Massari, omukiise wa Italy mu EU, yagamba nti "China yokka ye yabafaako.
Certainly, this is not a good sign of European solidarity."
Mu buli ngeri, kano si kabonero kalungi ak’omukago gwa Bulaaya."

On 22 March, after a phone call with Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte, Russian president Vladimir Putin arranged the Russian army to send military medics, special disinfection vehicles, and other medical equipment to Italy.

Nga 22 Ogwokusatu, oluvannyuma lw’okwogera ku ssimu ne Ssaabaminisita wa Italy Giuseppe Conte, Pulezidenti wa Russia Vladimir Putin yateekateeka amagye ga Russia okuweereza abasawo b’amagye, ebimotoka ebifuuyira eddagala, n’ebikozesebwa ebirala mu kujjanjaba mu Italy.
Italy's La Stampa newspaper cited an anonymous "high-level political source" that 80 percent of Russia's aid was "useless or of little use to Italy".

Olupapula (lw’amawulire) lwa Italy olwa La Stampa nga lwesigama ku "munnabyabufuzi owa waggulu ennyo" ataayatuukirizibwa lwagamba nti ebitundu 80 ku kikumi eby’obuyambi bwa Russia "tebwalina mugaso oba bwalina omugaso mutono nnyo eri Italy ".
The source accused Russia of embarking on a "geopolitical and diplomatic" charm offensive.
Munnabyabufuzi ono yalangira Russia okuzannya "ebyobufuzi" bya kabampaane.
The President of Lombardy, Attilio Fontana, and Italian Foreign Minister Luigi Di Maio dismissed the media reports and expressed their gratitude.
Pulezidenti wa Lombardy, Attilio Fontana, ne Minisita wa Italy ow’Ensonga z’Ebweru Luigi Di Maio baasambajja ebyafulumira mu mawulire ago era ne balaga okusiima kwabwe.
Russia also sent a cargo plane with medical aid to the United States.
Russia era yaweereza ennyonyi y’emigugu ng’erimu obuyambi bw’eddagala eri Amerika.

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said that "when offering assistance to US colleagues, [Putin] assumes that when US manufacturers of medical equipment and materials gain momentum, they will also be able to reciprocate if necessary."

Omwogezi wa Kremlin Dmitry Peskov yagamba nti "mu kuwaayo obuyambi eri Amerika, [Putin] asuubira nti abakozi b’eddagala mu Amerika bwe banaatereera ebintu ne bidda mu nteeko, nabo bajja kuba basobola okumusasula bwe kinaaba kyetaagisizza."
The planned NATO "Defender 2020" military exercise in Germany, Poland, and the Baltic states, the largest NATO war exercise since the end of the Cold War, will be held on a reduced scale.

Enteekateeka ya NATO eya "Defender 2020" mu Germany, Poland, n’amawanga ga Baltic, ng’eno y’enteekateeka y’amagye eya NATO esinga obunene okuva Cold War bwe yakomekkerezebwa, ejja kubaawo ng’ekendeezeddwa ku mudigido.

The Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament's general secretary Kate Hudson criticized the Defender 2020 exercise: "In the current public-health crisis, it jeopardizes the lives not only of the troops from the US and the many European countries participating but the inhabitants of the countries in which they are operating."The Iranian government has been heavily affected by the virus, with around two dozen parliament members infected as well as fifteen other current or former political figures.

Omuwandiisi wa Kakuyege w’Okuggyako Ebyokulwanyisa Namuzisa (Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament) Kate Hudson yakolokota enteekateeka ya Defender 2020: "Mu kizibu ky’ebyobulamu ekiriwo kati, kissa mu katyabaga obulamu bwa bannamagye ga Amerika n’amawanga ga Bulaaya mangi awamu ne bannansi b’omu mawanga gye bakolera." Gavument ya Iran ekoseddwa nnyo akawuka, nga bammemba ba paalamenti abasoba mu makumi abiri bakwatiddwa akawuka awamu ne bannabyabufuzi abalala kkumi na bataano.

Iran's President Hassan Rouhani wrote a public letter to world leaders asking for help on 14 March 2020, saying that his country is struggling to fight the outbreak due to lack of access to international markets as a result of the United States sanctions against Iran.The outbreak has prompted calls for the United States to adopt social policies common in other wealthy countries, including universal health care, universal child care, paid family leave, and higher levels of funding for public health.

Pulezidenti wa Iran Hassan Rouhani yawandiika ebbaluwa ey’awamu eri abakulembeze mu nsi yonna ng’asaba obuyambi nga 14 Ogwokusatu 2020, ng’agamba nti eggwanga lye likaluubirizibwa okulwanyisa obulwadde olw’okusalwa ku butale bw’ensi yonna olw’envumbo Amerika ze yassa ku Iran. Okubalukawo kw’obulwadde buno kwongedde ku kulaajanira Amerika okugoberera enkola za nnaakalyakaani (social policies) ezisangibwa ennyo mu mawanga amalala amagagga, omuli obujjanjabi obwa bonna, okulabirira abaana bonna, empummula ensasulire, n’okussa ennyo ssente mu byobujjabi bw’abantu bonna.

Political analysts anticipated it may negatively affect Donald Trump's chances of re-election in the 2020 presidential election.Diplomatic relations between Japan and South Korea worsened due to the pandemic.

Abatunuulizi b’ebyobufuzi baateebereza nti kiyinza okukosa emikisa gya Donald Trump okuddamu okulondebwa mu kulonda kwa pulezidenti okwa 2020. Enkolagana wakati wa Japan ne South Korea yasajjuka olw’ekirwadde kino.
South Korea criticized Japan's "ambiguous and passive quarantine efforts" after Japan announced anybody coming from South Korea will be placed in two weeks' quarantine at government-designated sites.

South Korea yakolokota enkola za Japani eza "kalantiini ezibuzaabuza n’obutabaamu mulamwa" oluvannyuma lwa Japan okulangirira nti buli muntu ava e South Korea ajja kussibwa mu kalantiini mu bifo ebiteereddwawo gavumenti okumala wiiki bbiri.
The South Korean society was initially polarized on President Moon Jae-in's response to the crisis.
Abantu b’e South Korea mu kusooka baali beeyawuddemu olw’engeri Pulezidenti Moon Jae-in gye yakwatamu ensonga z’ekirwadde.

Many Koreans signed petitions either calling for the impeachment of Moon over what they claimed to be government mishandling of the outbreak, or praising his response.The pandemic has allowed countries to pass emergency legislation in response.

Abakoleya bangi bassa emikono ku kiwandiiko ekisaba okugobwa kwa Moon olwa kye baayita gavumenti okukwata obubi ensonga y’ekirwadde ekibaluseewo, ate abamu nga bawagira enkola ye. Ekizibu kino kireetedde amawanga okuyisa amateeka ag’amangu okusobola okukirwanyisa.
Some commentators have expressed concerns that it could allow governments to strengthen their grip on power.
Abatunuulizi abamu balaze okutya nti kiino kiyinza okusobozesa gavumenti okunywereza mu buyinza.

In Hungary, its parliament voted to allow the prime minister, Viktor Orbán, to rule by decree indefinitely, suspend parliament as well as elections and punish those deemed to have spread false information about the virus and the government's handling of the crisis.

Mu Hungary, paalamenti yaayo yalonda ng’ekkiriza ssaabaminisita, Viktor Orbán, okufugira mu kirangiriro awatali bbanga ggere, ne bayimiriza paalamenti awamu n’okulonda n’okubonereza abo abatwalibwa okuba nga basaasaanya amawulire ag’obulimba ku kawuka n’engeri gavumenti gy’ekuttemu ekizibu kino.

The coronavirus outbreak has been blamed for several instances of supply shortages, stemming from globally increased usage of equipment to fight the outbreaks, panic buying, and disruption to factory and logistic operations.

Okubalukawo kwa coronavirus kuweereddwa ng’eky’okwekwasa olw’ebintu bingi ebikendedde, nga kiva ku bintu ebyongedde okukozesebwa ennyo okwetooloola ensi mu kulwanyisa obulwadde gye bugenze bubalukawo, okugula ebintu ebingi omulundi ogumu, n’okutaataaganyizibwa mu nkola y’amakolero n’emirimu emirala.
The United States Food and Drug Administration has issued warnings about shortages of drugs and medical equipment due to increased consumer demand and supplier disruption.

Ekitongole kya America ekikola ku by’emmere n’eddagala (United States Food and Drug Administration) kyayisa okulabula ku bbula ly’eddagala n’ebikozesebwa mu kujjanjaba olw’obwetaavu bwabyo okweyongera n’okutaataaganyizibwa mu nfulumya yaabyo.
Several localities also witnessed panic buying that led to shelves being cleared of grocery essentials such as food, toilet paper, and bottled water, inducing supply shortages.
Ebitundu bingi era byalimu okugula ebintu ebingi omulundi ogumu ekyaviirako amaduuka okuggwaamu ebintu eby’omugaso ng’emmere, ebikookooma, n’amazzi g’okunywa, so nga ne gye bisuubulwa bikendedde.
The technology industry in particular has been warning about delays to shipments of electronic goods.
Okusingira ddala abakola ebyuma bikalimagezi baalabula nti wajja kubaawo okukeerewa mu kutambuza ebyuma bino.
According to WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom, the demand for personal protection equipment has risen 100-fold.
Okusinziira ku mukulu wa WHO Tedros Adhanom, obwetaavu bw’ebintu eby’okwekuuma bulinnye emirundi 100.
This demand has led to the increase in prices of up to twenty times the normal price and also induced delays on the supply of medical items for four to six months.

Obwetaavu buno buleeseewo okweyongera mu miwendo egyekubisizzaamu emirundi egiwera amakumi abiri n’okuleetera ebintu ebikozesebwa mu byobulamu okukeerewa okutuuka emyezi egiwera ena okutuuka ku mukaaga.
It has also caused a shortage of personal protective equipment worldwide, with the WHO warning that this will endanger health workers.
Era kireeseewo ebbula ly’ebintu ebikuuma abantu mu nsi yonna, nga WHO erabula nti kino kijja kussa obulamu bw’abasawo mu katyabaga.
In Australia, the pandemic provided a new opportunity for daigou shoppers to sell Australian products into China.
Mu Australia, ekizibu ky’ekirwadde kino kyawa omukisa abasuubuzi ba daigou okutunda ebyamaguzi by’e Australian mu China.

The activity has created a shortage of baby formula in some supermarkets and was subsequently banned by the Australian government.Despite the high prevalence of COVID-19 cases in Northern Italy and the Wuhan region, and the ensuing high demand for food products, both areas have been spared from acute food shortages.

Ekikolwa kino kyaleetawo ebbula ly’emmere y’abaana abawere mu ssemaduuka ezimu era oluvannyuma ne kiwerebwa mu gavumenti ya Australia. Newankubadde waliwo abalwadde ba COVID-19 bangi mu Bukiikakkono bwa Italy ne mu kitundu ky’e Wuhan, nga noolwekyo waliyo obwetaavu bw’emmere bungi, ebitundu bino byombi tebibaddeemu bbula lya mmere liyitiridde.

Measures by China and Italy against the hoarding and illicit trade of critical products have been successful, avoiding acute food shortages that were anticipated in Europe as well as in North America.

Amakubo China ne Italy ge baayitamu okulwanyisa okugula ebintu ebingi n’obusuubuzi obutali mu mateeka gakoze, ne basobola okwewala ebbula ly’emmere eriyitiridde eryasuubirwa mu Bulaaya ne mu Bukiikakkono bwa America.
Northern Italy with its significant agricultural production has not seen a large reduction, but prices may increase according to industry representatives.
Mu bukiikakkono bwa Italy ewali obulimi obungi tewabaddeeyo bbula lya mmere lya maanyi, wabula emiwendo biyinza okulinnya okusinziira ku bakiikirira amakolero.
Empty food shelves were only encountered temporarily, even in Wuhan city, while Chinese government officials released pork reserves to assure sufficient nourishment of the population.
Amasa g’emmere ameereere gaalabwako ekiseera kitono, wadde ne mu kibuga Wuhan, ng’eno abakungu ba gavumenti ya China baggula amaterekero g’ennyama y’embizzi okukakasa ng’abantu balya ekimala.
Similar laws exist in Italy requiring food producers to keep reserves for such emergencies.
Amateeka geegamu gali ne mu Italy ng’abakozi b’emmere kibeetaagisa okukuuma emmere olw’ebibamba nga bino.

Damage to the global economy has been felt in China: according to a media report on 16 March, the economy in China was very hard hit in the first two months of 2020 due to the measures taken by the government to curtail virus spread, and retail sales plunged 20.5%.

Okukosebwa okutuuse ku byenfuna by’ensi yonna China ekuwuliddemu: okusinziira ku alipoota eyafulumira mu mawulire nga 16 Ogwokusatu, ebyenfuna mu China byakosebwa nnyo mu myezi ebiri egyasooka mu 2020 olw’enkola ezassibwawo gavumenti okulemesa akawuka okusaasaana, era ebitundibwa eri abantu byakendeera ebitundu 20.5%.
As mainland China is a major economy and manufacturing hub, the viral outbreak has been seen to pose a major destabilizing threat to the global economy.
Olw’okuba nga China erina ebyenfuna bya maanyi era efulumya ebintu bingi, okubalukawo kw’akawuka kutaataaganyizza nnyo ebyenfuna by’ensi yonna.
Agathe Demarais of the Economist Intelligence Unit has forecast that markets will remain volatile until a clearer image emerges on potential outcomes.
Agathe Demarais owa Economist Intelligence Unit yateebereza nti obutale bujja kusigala nga tebutegeerekeka bulungi okutuusa ng’ekifaananyi ekitegeerekeka ku kiyinza okuddirira kirabise.
In January 2020, some analysts estimated that the economic fallout of the epidemic on global growth could surpass that of the 2002–2004 SARS outbreak.
Mu Janwali 2020, abeekenneenya abamu baateebereza nti obulwadde kye bunaatuusa ku byenfuna ku nkulaakulana y’ensi yonna kiyinza okusinga ku ekyo ekyaliwo olw’obulwadde bwa SARS mu 2002–2004 SARS.
One estimate from an expert at Washington University in St. Louis gave a $300+ billion impact on the world's supply chain that could last up to two years.

Okuteebereza kw’omukugu omu mu Washington University mu St. Louis kwalaga ekkonde lya buwumbi bwa doola 300 n’okusingawo ku bintu ebikolebwa mu nsi yonna nga kino kiyinza okubeerawo okumala emyaka egiwera ebiri.
The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) reportedly "scrambled" after a steep decline in oil prices due to lower demand from China.

Ekibiina ky’Amawanga Agatunda Amafuta (Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC)) kigambibwa nti “kyagwa” oluvannyuma lw’ebbeeyi y’amafuta okukendeera ennyo olw’okukendeera kw’obwetaavu bwago mu China.
Global stock markets fell on 24 February due to a significant rise in the number of COVID-19 cases outside mainland China.
Obutale bw’emigabo mu nsi yonna bwagwa nga 24 Ogwokubiri olw’okweyongera ennyo mu muwendo gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 wabweru wa China.

On 27 February, due to mounting worries about the coronavirus outbreak, various U.S. stock indexes including the NASDAQ-100, the S&P 500 Index, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average posted their sharpest falls since 2008, with the Dow falling 1,191 points, the largest one-day drop since the financial crisis of 2007–08.

Nga 27 Ogwokubiri, olw’okweyongera okweraliikiriza ekirwadde kya coronavirus, ebibalo by’enkola y’emigabo (stock indexes) bingi mu U.S. omuli NASDAQ-100, S&P 500 Index, ne Dow Jones Industrial Average byalaga okukka kw’emiwendo okukyasinze okuva mu 2008, nga Dow yakka obutundutundu 1,191, nga kuno kwe kukka okwali kukyasinze okuba okunene okuva ku katyabaga k’ebyenfuna aka 2007–08.
All three indexes ended the week down more than 10%.
Ebibalo byonsatule byamalako wiiki nga biri wansi ebitundu 10%.
On 28 February, Scope Ratings GmbH affirmed China's sovereign credit rating, but maintained a Negative Outlook.
Nga 28 Ogwokubiri, Scope Ratings GmbH baakakasa nti China yali ekyetengeredde mu byenfuna (sovereign credit rating), wabula baalaga nti kino kyali kisobola okukyuka (Negative Outlook).
Stocks plunged again based on coronavirus fears, the largest fall being on 16 March.
Emigabo gyaddamu ne gikka olw’okutya coronavirus, ng’okukka okungi kwaliwo nga 16 Ogwokusatu.
Many consider an economic recession to be likely.
Bangi balowooza nti wajja kubaawo okugwa mu byenfuna (economic recession).
Economist Mohamed El-Erian praised central banks' and states' timely emergency measures.
Munnabyanfuna Mohamed El-Erian yatendereza enkola za banka eza wakati n’amasaza.
Central banks are reacting more quickly than they did to the 2008 financial crash.
Banka za wakati zaasitukiddemu mangu okusinga bwe zaakola mu kudobonkana kw’ebyenfuna okwa 2008.
Tourism is one of the worst affected sectors due to travel bans, closing of public places including travel attractions, and advice of governments against any travel all over the world.

Ebyobulambuzi kye kimu ku bitongole ebisinze okukosebwa olw’okuyimiriza entambula, okuggala ebifo by’olukale omuli n’ebyo ebyettanirwa abatambuze, n’okuwabula kwa gavumenti okwewala okutambula okw’engeri yonna okwetooloola ensi yonna.
As a consequence, numerous airlines have cancelled flights due to lower demand, including British Airways, China Eastern Airlines, and Qantas, while British regional airline Flybe collapsed.

Ekyava mu kino, ennyonyi ezisinga zaasazaamu entambula zaazo olw’obutettanirwa bulungi, omuli British Airways, China Eastern Airlines, ne Qantas, so nga kampuni y’ennyonyi y’e Bungereza eya Flybe yo yagwa.
The impact on the cruise line industry was at a level never seen before.
Ekyatuusibwa ku kampuni z’amaato agalambuza abantu kyo kyali tekirabwangako emabega.
Several train stations and ferry ports have also been closed.
Sitashoni z’eggaali z’omukka nnyingi n’emyalo gy’ebidyeri nagyo gyaggalwa.
The epidemic coincided with the Chunyun, a major travel season associated with the Chinese New Year holiday.
Obulwadde buno bwajjira mu kiseera kyekimu ne Chunyun, ekiseera ky’okutambula ennyo mu kwetegekera oluwummula lw’Omwaka gwa China Omupya.

A number of events involving large crowds were cancelled by national and regional governments, including annual New Year festivals, with private companies also independently closing their shops and tourist attractions such as Hong Kong Disneyland and Shanghai Disneyland.

Emikolo mingi egibaamu abantu abangi gyasazibwamu gavumenti ya wakati n’ez’ebitundu, nga mwemuli n’ebikujjuko by’Omwaka Omupya, nga n’amakampuni ag’obwannannyini gaggalawo awamu n’ebifo by’abalambuzi nga Hong Kong Disneyland ne Shanghai Disneyland.
Many Lunar New Year events and tourist attractions have been closed to prevent mass gatherings, including the Forbidden City in Beijing and traditional temple fairs.
Emikolo gy’Omwaka Omupya mingi n’ebifo by’abalambuzi byaggalwa okwewala okukuŋŋaanya abantu abangi, omuli Forbidden City mu Beijing n’emyoleso gy’omu masinzizo amakadde.
In 24 of China's 31 provinces, municipalities and regions, authorities extended the New Year's holiday to 10 February, instructing most workplaces not to re-open until that date.

Mu province za China 24 ku ezo 31, zi munisipaali, n’ebitundu, abakulembeze baayongezaayo oluwummula lw’Omwaka Omupya okutuuka nga 10 Ogwokubiri, ne balagira emirimu egisinga obutaggulawo okutuusa olunaku olwo.
These regions represented 80% of the country's GDP and 90% of exports.
Ebitundu bino bikola ebitundu 80% eby’enfuna y’eggwanga (GDP) n’ebitundu 90% eby’ebintu ebitundibwa ebweru w’eggwanga.

Hong Kong raised its infectious disease response level to the highest and declared an emergency, closing schools until March and cancelling its New Year celebrations.The retail sector has been impacted globally, with reductions in store hours or temporary closures.

Hong Kong yalinnyisa ku mutendera gwayo ogw’okulwanyisa endwadde ezisiigibwa n’egutuusa ku ogwo ogusinga okubeera waggulu (highest level) era n’erangirira akaseera aka kazigizigi, n’eggala amasomero okutuusa mu Gwokusatu era n’esazaamu ebikujjuko by’Omwaka Omupya. Obusuubuzi bw’ebintu ebiguzibwa abantu ba bulijjo (retail sector) bukoseddwa mu nsi yonna, ng’amaduuka gaakendeeza ku ssaawa ze gaggulirawo oba okugira nga gaggaddewo.
Visits to retailers in Europe and Latin America declined by 40%.
Okugula ebintu ku basuubuzi bano mu Bulaaya ne Latin America kwakendeera ebitundu 40%.
North America and Middle East retailers saw a 50–60% drop.
Abatunzi ab’ekika kino mu North America ne Middle East baafuna okukendeera kw’emirimu gyabwe kwa bitundu 50–60%.
This also resulted in a 33–43% drop in foot traffic to shopping centres in March compared to February.
Kino era kyavaamu okukendeera kwa bitundu 33–43% okw’abantu abatambuza ebigere okugenda mu maduuka mu Gwokusatu bw’ogeraageranya n’Ogwokubiri.

Shopping mall operators around the world imposed additional measures, such increased sanitation, installation of thermal scanners to check the temperature of shoppers, and cancellation of events.According to a United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America estimate, the pandemic-induced recession could leave between 14 and 22 million more people in extreme poverty in Latin America than would have been in that situation without the pandemic.

Abaddukanya ebizimbe by’amaduuka ebinene (shopping malls) okwetooloola ensi bassaawo ebigobererwa ebirala, ng’okwongera ku buyonjo, okussaawo obupima ebbugumu ly’abaguzi, n’okubaako emikolo gye basazaamu. Okusinziira ku kuteebereza kwa United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America, okugwa kw’ebyenfuna okunaaleetebwa ekizibu ky’obulwadde buno kuyinza okuleka abantu abalala abali wakati w’obukadde 14 ne 22 mu bwavu obuyitiridde mu Latin America okusinga nga bwe kyandibadde singa ekizibu kino tekyagwawo.
In January and February 2020, during the height of the epidemic in Wuhan, about 5 million people in China lost their jobs.
Mu Janwali n’Ogwokubiri 2020, obulwadde we bwasingira okuba obungi mu Wuhan, abantu obukadde nga 5 mu China baafiirwa emirimu gyabwe.

Many of China's nearly 300 million rural migrant workers have been stranded at home in inland provinces or trapped in Hubei province.In March 2020, more than 10 million Americans lost their jobs and applied for government aid.

Bangi ku bantu mu China abali eyo mu bukadde nga 300 abaddukira mu byalo okukola baakonkomalira awaka mu province z’omunda oba mu Hubei province. Mu Gwokusatu 2020, Abamerika abasoba mu bukadde 10 baafiirwa emirimu gyabwe ne basaba obuyambi bwa gavumenti.

The coronavirus outbreak could cost 47 million jobs in the United States and unemployment rate may hit 32%, according to estimates by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis.The lockdown in India has left tens of millions of Indian migrant workers (who are paid through daily wages) unemployed.The survey from the Angus Reid Institute found that 44% of Canadian households have experienced some type of unemployment.Nearly 900,000 workers lost their jobs in Spain since it went into lockdown in mid-March 2020.

Okubalukawo kwa coronavirus kuyinza okuviirako okufiirwa emirimu obukadde 47 mu Amerika era n’abantu abatalina mirimu ne batuuka ku bitundu 32%, okusinziira ku kuteebereza kwa Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis. Omuggalo mu India gulesse obukadde n’obukadde bw’Abayindi abakozi ba lejjalejja nga tebalina mirimu. Okunoonyereza okwakolebwa Angus Reid Institute kwakizuula ng’ebitundu 44% eby’amaka mu Canada gafunye ku kizibu ky’obutaba na mirimu. Abakozi kyenkana 900,000 baafiirwa emirimu gyabwe mu Spain okuva lwe baagenda mu muggalo mu makkati g’Ogwokusatu 2020.

During the second half of March, 4 million French workers applied for temporary unemployment benefits and 1 million British workers applied for a universal credit scheme.Almost half a million companies in Germany have sent their workers on a government-subsidized short-time working schemes known as Kurzarbeit.

Mu kitundu ekyokubiri eky’Ogwokusatu, Abakozi mu France obukadde 4 baasaba obuyambi olw’okuba nga tebalina mirimu mu kiseera kino (temporary unemployment benefits) ate abakozi akakadde 1 mu Bungereza baasaba ebbanja ery’awamu (universal credit scheme). Amakampuni emitwalo nga ataano mu Germany baasindika abakozi baabwe ku nkola ya gavumenti ey’okukolera n’okusasulirwa ekiseera ekitonoko emanyiddwa nga Kurzarbeit.
The German short-time work compensation scheme has been adopted by France and Britain.
Enkola ya Germany ey’okukolera n’okusasulirwa ekiseera ekitono etandikiddwa ne mu France ne Britain.
The performing arts and cultural heritage sectors have been profoundly affected by the pandemic, impacting organizations' operations as well as individuals—both employed and independent—globally.
Ebisaawe bya katemba n’okukuuma obuwangwa nabyo bikoseddwa nnyo ekizibu kino, nga kiziŋŋamizza emirmu gy’ebitongole n’abantu ssekinnoomu—abakozesebwa n’abeekozesa—mu nsi yonna.

Arts and culture sector organizations attempted to uphold their (often publicly funded) mission to provide access to cultural heritage to the community, maintain the safety of their employees and the public, and support artists where possible.

Ebitongole by’okuyiiya n’obuwangwa byagezaako okusigala nga bikola emirimu gyabyo (nga gino gitera okubeera nga gusasulirwa bantu) egy’okukkiriza abantu okugenda mu bifo by’obuwangwa, okukuuma abakozi baabyo n’abantu abalala nga balamu, n’okuyamba abayiiya we kiba kyetaagisizza.

By March 2020, across the world and to varying degrees, museums, libraries, performance venues, and other cultural institutions had been indefinitely closed with their exhibitions, events and performances cancelled or postponed.

Mu Gwokusatu 2020, mu nsi yonna, amakaddiyiro, amaterekero g’ebitabo, ebifo ewategekerwa ebiyiiye, n’ebitongole by’ebyobuwangwa ebirala byali biggaddwa nga n’emyoleso, n’emikolo emirala gisaziddwamu oba gyongezeddwayo.

In response there were intensive efforts to provide alternative services through digital platforms.Another recent and rapidly accelerating fallout of the disease is the cancellation of religious services, major events in sports, and other social events, such as music festivals and concerts, technology conferences, and fashion shows.

Oluvannyuma lwa kino waaliwo kaweefube ow’amaanyi okutuusa ku bantu obuweereza nga bayita ku mikutu gya kompyuta. Ekintu ekirala ekivudde mu bulwadde kwe kuyimiriza obuweereza bw’eddiini, ebyemizannyo, ebintu ebirala ebikwata ku byokwesanyusa, ng’ebivvulu by’ennyimba ne konsati, emisomo gya tekinologiya, n’emikolo gy’emisono.

The film industry has also experienced disruption.The Vatican announced that Holy Week observances in Rome, which occur during the last week of the Christian penitential season of Lent, have been cancelled.
Ekisaawe kya cinema nakyo kifunye okutaataaganyizibwa. Vatican yalangirira nti okukuza Wiiki Entukuvu mu Rooma, okubaawo mu wiiki y’Ekisiibo esembayo, kusaziddwamu.
