U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention(CDC) esemba abakozi abalina obubonero bw’obulwadde obukwata omussizo (acute respiratory illness) basigale ewaka okutuusa ng’omusujja gubaamuse, nga baweddeko obubonero bw’omusujja, n’obubonero obulala okumala waakiri essaawa 24 nga tebakozesezza ddagala likkakkanya musujja era nti enkola z’okuwummuza abakozi ku mirimu zirina okuba nga zisobola okukyusibwakyusibwa, okukkiriza abakozi okusigala ewaka okulabirira abalwadde, era nti abakozi balina okubeera nga bamanyi bulungi enkola zino.

According to OSHA, medium exposure risk jobs include those that require frequent or close contact within six feet (1.8 m) of people who are not known or suspected COVID-19 patients, but may be infected with SARS-CoV-2 due to ongoing community transmission around the business location, or because the individual has recent international travel to a location with widespread COVID-19 transmission.

Okusinziira ku OSHA, emirimu egirimu obulabe obutonotono mulimu egyo egyetaagisa abantu okusemberegana buli kiseera mu bbanga ery’effuuti omukaaga (1.8 m) ku bantu abatamanyiddwa nti balina oba bateeberezebwa okubeera ne COVID-19, naye nga bayinza okuba nga balina SARS-CoV-2 olw’okusaasaana kw’obulwadde obwo mu kitundu bizinensi eyo mw’eri oba olw’okuba omuntu oyo yagendako mu nsi ez’ebweru mu kifo ekimanyiddwa nga kikoseddwa COVID-19.

These include workers who have contact with the general public such as in schools, high-population-density work environments, and some high-volume retail settings.Engineering controls for this and higher risk groups include installing high-efficiency air filters, increasing ventilation rates, installing physical barriers such as clear plastic sneeze guards, and installing a drive-through window for customer service.Administrative controls for this and higher risk groups include encouraging sick workers to stay at home, replacing face-to-face meetings with virtual communications, establishing staggered shifts, discontinuing nonessential travel to locations with ongoing COVID-19 outbreaks, developing emergency communications plans including a forum for answering workers’ concerns, providing workers with up-to-date education and training on COVID-19 risk factors and protective behaviors, training workers who need to use protecting clothing and equipment how to use it, providing resources and a work environment that promotes personal hygiene, requiring regular hand washing, limiting customers' and the public's access to the worksite, and posting signage about hand washing and other COVID-19 protective measures.Depending on the work task, workers with at least medium exposure risk may need to wear personal protective equipment including some combination of gloves, a gown, a face shield or face mask, or goggles.

Muno mulimu abakozi abakwatagana n’abantu abalala gamba ng’ab’omu masomero, ebifo ebikolerwamu emirimu abantu abangi, n’ebifo by’amaduuka ebirimu omujjuzo. Okutangira okw’obuyiiya (Engineering controls) ku bifo bino n’ebibinja ebiri mu bulabe obw’amaanyi mulimu okuteeka obutimba obusengejja ennyo empewo ku bizimbe, okwongeza ku bunene bw’obumooli, okuteekawo obuntu obulinga obusenge obusiikiriza omuntu ng’akuba emyasi, n’okuteekawo eddirisa abajja okugula nga bali mu mmotoka mwe baweererezebwa nga tebavuddeemu. Okutangira okw’obukulembeze (Administrative controls) ku kibinja kino ekirimu obuzibu obuneneko mulimu okukubiriza abakozi okusigala ewaka, okusikiza enkiiko ezirimu okulabagana maaso-ku-maaso ne zizzibwa ku yintaneeti, okuteekawo okukolera mu mpalo, okusazaamu okutambula okuteetaagisa nnyo mu bifo ebirimu ennyo obulwadde bwa COVID-19, okutondawo enteekateeka y’empuliziganya ey’amangu omuli n’okukola ku nsonga z’abakozi, okuwa abakozi amawulire agakwata ku COVID-19 wamu n’okubasomesa ku bulwadde obwo wamu n’engeri gye bayinza okubwekuuma, okusomesa abakozi abeetaaga okukozesa engoye ez’okwesabika n’okubalaga engeri y’okukozesa ebyuma bye baba balina okukozesa, okuwa abakozi eby’okukozesa n’okubassa mu bifo ebisobola okuyonjebwa obulungi n’abantu kinnoomu okubeereramu abayonjo, okukubiriza abakozi okunaaba mu ngalo buli kiseera, okukugira bakasitoma n’abantu abalala okutuuka mu kiro ewakolerwa, n’okuteekawo ebipande ebikubiriza abantu okunaaba mu ngalo n’obubaka obulala obw’okwekuuma COVID-19. Okusinziira ku mulimu nga bwe guba gufaanana, abakozi ababa mu buzibu bw’okusiigibwa obulwadde basaana ne beesabika omuli okwambala giraavu, egganduula, akakookolo n’ebigaalubindi.
Workers in this risk group rarely require use of respirators.
Abakozi abali mu kibinja ekirina obuzibu eky’engeri eno tebatera kwetaaga kukozesa bikozesebwa kussa.

If a person becomes sick on an airplane, proper controls to protect workers and other passengers include separating the sick person from others by a distance of 6 feet, designating one crew member to serve the sick person, and offering a face mask to the sick person or asking the sick person to cover their mouth and nose with tissues when coughing or sneezing.

Omuntu bw’alwalira ku nnyonyi, engeri ennungi ez’okutangira abakozi n’abasaabaze abalala mulimu okwawula omuntu omulwadde okuva ku balala ne bamuwa ebbanga lya fuuti 6, okufuna omu ku bakozi okulabirira omulwadde oyo, n’okuwa akakookolo omuntu oyo omulwadde oba okusaba omuntu oyo omulwadde okubikka omumwa n’ennyindo n’obupapula obukozesebwa okwerongoosa ng’akolola oba okwasimula.

Cabin crew should wear disposable medical gloves when tending to a sick traveler or touching body fluids or potentially contaminated surfaces, and possibly additional personal protective equipment if the sick traveler has fever, persistent cough, or difficulty breathing.

Abakozi b’oku nnyonyi balina okwambala giraavu ezikozesebwa omulundi ogumu nga baweereza omusaabaze omulwadde oba nga bakwata ku luzzizzi oluva mu mubiri oba ku kintu ekirabika nga kigenzeeko obuwuka, n’okwesabika singa omuntu gwe baweereza alabika ng’alina omusujja, akolola olutata, oba ng’azibuwalirwa mu kussa.

Gloves and other disposable items should be disposed of in a biohazard bag, and contaminated surfaces should be cleaned and disinfected afterwards.For commercial shipping, including cruise ships and other passenger vessels, hazard controls include postponing travel when sick, and self-isolating and informing the onboard medical center immediately if one develops a fever or other symptoms while on board.

Giraavu n’ebirala ebikozesebwa omulundi ogumu bisaanye okussibwa mu kaveera akasuulibwamu ebintu ng’ebyo (biohazard bag), n’ebintu ebiddugaziddwa ne birongoosebwa era ne bifuuyirwako eddagala oluvannyuma. Ate amaato agasaabaza ebyamaguzi omuli n’emmeeri z’abasaabaze, ebitangira obulabe bye bino, okwongezaayo okutambula ng’oli mulwadde, okweyawula n’okutegeeza abakozi b’oku lyato bw’owulira omusujja oba obubonero obulala ng’oli ku lyato.

Ideally, medical follow-up should occur in the isolated person's cabin.For schools and childcare facilities, CDC recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.

Ekituufu kiri nti, okulondoola omulwadde kulina okukolebwa mu kasenge omulwadde mw’aba ateereddwa. Ate ku masomero ne mu bifo ebirabirirwamu abaana, CDC esemba okuggalawo okumala akaseera katono ekifo kisobole okuyonjebwa n’okutta obuwuka singa omuntu omulwadde aba abadde mu kizimbe ky’essomero ne bwe kiba nti mu kitundu ekyo bubadde tebusaasaanye.

When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as canceling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.

Bwe waba nga waliwo okusaasaana kw’obulwadde okusaamusaamu mu kitundu, obukodyo bw’okweyawula busobola okukozesebwa, gamba ng’okusazaamu okulambula, okusimba ennyiriri ku ssomero, n’enkuŋŋaana endala ennene gamba ng’okukola dduyiro oba ebibiina ebya kkwaya oba okuliira awamu mu ddiiro ly’essomero, okwongeza ku mabanga ku ntebe z’abayizi, okukyusakyusa mu budde abaana mwe bajjira ne bwe baddirayo ewaka, okukendeeza ku bagenyi abateetaagisa nnyo, n’okukozesa woofiisi ey’enjawulo ey’ebyobulamu ku baana abalina obubonero obulinga obwa ssenyiga.

When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.For law enforcement personnel performing daily routine activities, the immediate health risk is considered low by CDC.

Bwe wabaawo okusaasaana okw’amaanyi mu kitundu, ku kakodyo k’okwewa amabanga, kisaana okwongerako n’okuggala amasomero okumala ebbanga eriwera. Eri abakuumaddembe abakola emirimu gya buli lunaku, obulabe bw’okukwatibwa obulwadde butwalibwa CDC okuba nga butono nnyo ddala.

Law enforcement officials who must make contact with individuals confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 are recommended to follow the same guidelines as emergency medical technicians, including proper personal protective equipment.
Abakuumaddembe abalina okukwatagana n’abantu abakakasiddwa nti balina COVID-19 baweebwa amagezi okugoberera enkola ze zimu ng’abajjanjabi ab’amangu, omuli n’okukozesa ebyokwesabika omubiri gwonna.

If close contact occurs during apprehension, workers should clean and disinfect their duty belt and gear prior to reuse using a household cleaning spray or wipe, and follow standard operating procedures for the containment and disposal of used PPE and for containing and laundering clothes.

Okukwatagana bwe kubaawo ng’omuntu akwatibwa, abakozi balina okulongoosa n’okufuuyira obuwuka ku byambalo byabwe nga tebannaddamu kubikozesa nga bakozesa eddagala erifuuyira mu nju oba okusiimula, n’okugoberera emitendera egimanyiddwa wonna mu kulongoosa ebyokwesabika wamu n’okwoza engoye.
OSHA considers certain healthcare and mortuary workers to be at high or very high categories of exposure risk.
OSHA kitwala abakozi b’ebyobulamu abamu n’abakola mu mawanika okubeera mu buzibu obw’amaanyi ennyo ddala ku kukwatibwa obulwadde.
High exposure risk jobs include healthcare delivery, support, laboratory, and medical transport workers who are exposed to known or suspected COVID-19 patients.

Emirimu egireetera abantu okubeera mu mbeera ey’obulabe ennyo mulimu abalabirira abalwadde ewaka, ababawanirira, abakola mu magezeserezo, n’abagoba b’abebyobulamu abasemberera abalwadde abamanyiddwa oba abateeberezebwa okuba nti balina COVID-19.
These become very high exposure risk if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on, or collect or handle specimens from, known or suspected COVID-19 patients.

Bano babeera mu bulabe obw’amaanyi ddala, abakozi bwe beenyigira mu mitendera egirimu okupima omukka (aerosol-generating procedures) ku balwadde, oba bwe bakwata ku sampolo okuva ku bantu abamanyiddwa oba abateeberezebwa okubeera ne COVID-19.
Aerosol-generating procedures include intubation, cough induction procedures, bronchoscopies, some dental procedures and exams, or invasive specimen collection.

Mu mitendera gy’okupika omukka (aerosol-generating procedures) mulimu okuleetera omuntu okukolola, bronchoscopies, emitendera egirimu okukola n’okukebera amannyo (dental procedures), oba invasive specimen collection.

High exposure risk mortuary jobs include workers involved in preparing the bodies of people who had known or suspected cases of COVID-19 at the time of their death; these become very high exposure risk if they perform an autopsy.Additional engineering controls for these risk groups include isolation rooms for patients with known or suspected COVID-19, including when aerosol-generating procedures are performed.

Emirimu egirimu obulabe obw’amaanyi egy’okukola ku bafu mulimu egy’okutegeka emibiri gy’abantu ababadde bamanyiddwa nti balwadde oba nga bateeberezebwa okuba ne COVID-19 mu kiseera we baafiira; bano babeera mu bulabe bwa maanyi ddala bwe bakebera omulambo. Okutangira kw’obuyiiya (engineering controls) ku bibinja by’abantu bano abali mu bulabe obw’amaanyi mulimu okukozesa ebisenge okwawula abalwadde abamanyiddwa nti balwadde oba abateeberezebwa okubeera ne COVID-19, omwo nga mwe muli n’emirundi okupika omukka (aerosol-generating procedures) lwe kuba kukoleddwa.
Specialized negative pressure ventilation may be appropriate in some healthcare and mortuary settings.
Enkola eya specialized negative pressure ventilation eyinza okuba ennungi mu mbeera z’ebyobulamu ezimu n’enkwata y’emirambo.
Specimens should be handled with Biosafety Level 3 precautions.
Sampolo eziggyibwa ku bantu zirina kukwatibwa n’obwegendereza obw’amaanyi ddala (Biosafety Level 3 precautions).

The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that incoming patients be separated into distinct waiting areas depending on whether they are a suspected COVID-19 case.In addition to other PPE, OSHA recommends respirators for those who work within 6 feet of patients known to be, or suspected of being, infected with SARS-CoV-2, and those performing aerosol-generating procedures.

WHO esemba abalwadde abapya okwawulibwa nga bassibwa mu bifo ebirindirwamu eby’enjawulo bwe baba nga bateeberezebwa okubeera ne COVID-19. Okwongereza ku nkola endala eza PPE, OSHA esemba okukozesa ebyuma ebissizibwamu eri abo abakolera mu bbanga erya fuuti 6 nga baliraanye abalwadde ba SARS-CoV-2 oba abateeberezebwa okuba nabwo wamu n’abo abakola ku mitendera gy’okupima omukka (aerosol-generating procedures).

In the United States, NIOSH-approved N95 filtering facepiece respirators or better must be used in the context of a comprehensive, written respiratory protection program that includes fit-testing, training, and medical exams.

Mu America, obukookolo bwa N95 obwakakasibwa NIOSH oba obusingawo bulina kukozesebwa mu mbeera etegekeddwa obulungi omuli okusooka okubugezesa, okutendeka ababukozesa, okutendekebwa, ne mu kukebera kw’ekisawo.

Other types of respirators can provide greater protection and improve worker comfort.The WHO does not recommend coveralls, as COVID-19 is a respiratory disease rather than being transmitted through bodily fluids.

Ebika by’ebissizibwamu ebirala bisobola okuyamba mu ngeri esingako n’okugumya abakozi nga bakola egyabwe. WHO tesemba kukozesa ovulo kubanga COVID-19 bulwadde bwa mu mussizo so tebutambulizibwa mu luzzizzi lwa mu mubiri.
WHO recommends only a surgical mask for point-of-entry screening personnel.
WHO esembe okukozesa akakookolo akakozesebwa mu kulongoosa abalwadde eri abakola ku kusunsula abalwadde.

For those who are collecting respiratory specimens from, caring for, or transporting COVID-19 patients without any aerosol-generating procedures, WHO recommends a surgical mask, goggles, or face shield, gown, and gloves.

Eri abo abaggya sampolo z’omu mussizo ku bantu, abalabiriraa, oba abatambuza abalwadde ba COVID-19 awatali kukozesa aerosol-generating procedures, WHO esemba okukozesa akakookolo akakozesebwa mu kulongoosa, gaalubindi oba ekibikka ku maaso, ne giraavu.
If an aerosol-generating procedure is performed, the surgical mask is replaced with an N95 or FFP2 respirator.
Omutendera gw’okupima omukka (aerosol-generating procedure) bwe gukolebwa, akakookolo akakozesebwa mu kulongoosa kasikizibwa N95 oba FFP2 respirator.

Given that the global supply of PPE is insufficient, WHO recommends minimizing the need for PPE through telemedicine, physical barriers such as clear windows, allowing only those involved in direct care to enter a room with a COVID-19 patient, using only the PPE necessary for the specific task, continuing use of the same respirator without removing it while caring for multiple patients with the same diagnosis, monitoring and coordinating the PPE supply chain, and discouraging the use of masks for asymptomatic individuals.

Olw’okuba nti ebyokwesabika (PPE) tebimala, WHO esemba okukendeeza ku kukozesa ebyokwesabika nga bakozesa okujjanjaba naye ng’omusawo n’omulwadde tebasisinkanye (telemedicine), okukozesa ebisiikiriza gamba ng’amadirisa agatangaala, okukkiriza abo bokka abajjanjaba obutereevu okuyingira ekisenge n’omulwadde wa COVID-19, okukozesa ebyokwesabika ebyo byokka ebyetaagisa ku ekyo ekikolebwa, okukozesa ekissizibwamu ekimu ng’olabirira abalwadde abawera abalina obulwadde obw’engeri emu, okulondoola n’okukwanaganya embunyisa y’ebyokwesabika, n’obutakkiriza kukozesa bukookolo eri abalwadde abatalabikirako bubonero.
WHEREAS on March 4, 2020, I proclaimed a State of Emergency to exist in California as a result of the threat of COVID-19;
NEWANKUBADDE nga 4 Ogwokusatu 2020, nalangirira embeera eya kazigizigi mu California olwa nawookeera wa COVID-19;
and WHEREAS in a short period of time, COVID-19 has rapidly spread throughout California, necessitating updated and more stringent guidance from federal, state, and local public health officials;
era NEWANKUBADDE mu kaseera katono, COVID-19 asaasaanidde California yenna, era nga kino kyetaagisa okuluŋŋamizibwa okuva mu gavumenti z’ebitundu, amawanga n’abeebyobulamu mu bitundu;

and WHEREAS for the preservation of public health and safety throughout the entire State of California, I find it necessary for all Californians to heed the State public health directives from the Department of Public Health.

era NEWANKUBADDE olw’okukuuma ebyobulamu mu bantu wamu n’ebyokwerinda mu Ssaza lyonna erya California, ndaba nga kyetaagisa abatuuze b’omu California bonna okussa omwoyo ku biragiro by’Ekitongole ekikola ku byobulamu mu bantu (Department of Public Health).

NOW, THEREFORE, I, GAVIN NEWSOM, Governor of the State of California, in accordance with the authority vested in me by the State Constitution and statutes of the State of California, and in particular, Government Code sections 8567, 8627, and 8665 do hereby issue the following Order to become effective immediately:

AWO NO, NOOLWEKYO, NZE, GAVIN NEWSOM, Gavana w’Essaza lya California, nga nkozesa obuyinza obwankwasibwa mu Ssemateeka w’Essaza lino wamu n’amateeka g’Essaza lya California, ate naddala obutundu 8567, 8627, ne 8665, nangirira Ekiragiro kino era kitandikirewo okukola:
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED THAT:
NDAGIRA WANO NTI:

1) To preserve the public health and safety, and to ensure the healthcare delivery system is capable of serving all, and prioritizing those at the highest risk and vulnerability, all residents are directed to immediately heed the current State public health directives, which I ordered the Department of Public Health to develop for the current statewide status of COVID-19.

1) Olw’okukuuma ebyobulamu mu bantu n’ebyokwerinda era n’olw’okukakasa nti abeebyobulamu basobola okuweereza abantu bonna, era n’olw’okukulembeza abo abali mu bulabe obw’amaanyi n’abasobola okukosebwa, bannansi bonna balagirwa wano nti bagondere ebiragiro by’Essaza eby’ebyobulamu, bye nagamba Abeekitongole ky’Ebyobulamu okuteekateeka olw’embeera ya COVID-19.
Those directives are consistent with the March 19, 2020, Memorandum on Identification of Essential Critical Infrastructure Workers During COVID-19 Response, found at: https://covid19.ca.gov/.

Ebiragiro ebyo bikwatagana bulungi n’ebyo ebya nga 19 Ogwokusatu 2020, Obubaka ku Kunokolayo Abakozi abasinga okwetaagisa mu Kiseera kya COVID-19 (Memorandum on Identification of Essential Critical Infrastructure Workers During COVID-19 Response), ebiri ku mukutu: https://covid19.ca.gov/.
ORDER OF THE STATE PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICER
EKIRAGIRO KYA OMUKUNGU W’EBYOBULAMU MU SSAZA

To protect public health, I as State Public Health Officer and Director of the California Department of Public Health order all individuals living in the State of California to stay home or at their place of residence except as needed to maintain continuity of operations of the federal critical infrastructure sectors, as outlined at https://www.cisa.gov/critical-infrastructure-sectors.

Olw’okukuuma obulamu bw’abatumu, nze ng’Omukungu era Ssenkulu w’Ebyobulamu mu Ssaza lya California, ndagira abantu bonna ababeera mu Ssaza lya California okubeera ewaka oba gye basula okuggyako nga bayitiddwa okugenda okuddukanya emirimu egitalina kuyimirira nga bwe kiragibwa ku mutuku https://www.cisa.gov/critical-infrastructure-sectors.

In addition, and in consultation with the Director of the Governor's Office of Emergency Services, I may designate additional sectors as critical in order to protect the health and well-being of all Californians.

Mu ngeri y’emu, ate era ne mu kwebuuza ku Gavana w’Obuweereza Obwamangu (Director of the Governor's Office of Emergency Services), nnyinza okunokolayo ebitongole ebirala ng’ebyetaagisa mu mbeera eno olw’okukuuma obulamu n’obulungi bw’abantu b’omu California bonna.

Pursuant to the authority under the Health and Safety Code 120125, 120140, 131080, 120130(c), 120135, 120145, 120175 and 120150, this order is to go into effect immediately and shall stay in effect until further notice.

Nga nsinziira ku buyinza obuli mu Tteeka ly’Ebyobulamu n’Okwerinda (Health and Safety Code) 120125, 120140, 131080, 120130(c), 120135, 120145, 120175 ne 120150, ekiragiro kino kirina okussibwa mu nkola amangu ddala era kirina okugobererwa okutuusa nga waliwo ekikyusiddwamu gye bujja.

The federal government has identified 16 critical infrastructure sectors whose assets, systems, and networks, whether physical or virtual, are considered so vital to the United States that their incapacitation or destruction would have a debilitating effect on security, economic security, public health or safety, or any combination thereof.

Gavumenti enokoddeyo ebitongole 16 eby’omugaso ennyo ng’ebyobugagga byabwe, emiyungiro, n’obukolaganyi, si nsonga oba birabwako oba bya ku yintaneeti bitwalibwa nga bya mugaso nnyo mu America era nga singa biggyibwamu amaanyi oba byonoonebwa kiyinza okuzaala embeteza ku byokwerinda, mu byenfuna, ne mu byobulamu mu bantu oba mu bisaawe ebyo byonna.
I order that Californians working in these 16 critical infrastructure sectors may continue their work because of the importance of these sectors to Californians' health and well-being.
Ndagira wano nti abantu b’omu California bonna abakolera mu bitongole ebyo eby’omugaso 16 bagende mu maaso n’emirimu gyabwe olw’omugaso gw’ebitongole ebyo mu by’Obulamu bw’abantu b’omu California.
This Order is being issued to protect the public health of Californians.
Ekiragiro kino kiteereddwawo olw’okukuuma ebyobulamu bw’abantu b’omu California.
The California Department of Public Health looks to establish consistency across the state in order to ensure that we mitigate the impact of COVID-19.
Ekitongole kya California eky’Ebyobulamu kifuba okulaba nti ebikolebwa wonna mu ssaza bye bimu era n’okufuba okutangira okukosa okuva ku COVID-19.
Our goal is simple, we want to bend the curve, and disrupt the spread of the virus.
Ekigendererwa kyaffe kyangu, twagala okukkakkanya n’okutaataaganya ensaasaana y’akawuka.
The supply chain must continue, and Californians must have access to such necessities as food, prescriptions, and health care.
Akajegere k’okusaasaanya ebyamaguzi kalina okweyongera okutambula era abantu b’omu California balina okufuna ebyetaago ng’emmere, eddagala n’obujjjanjabi.

When people need to leave their homes or places of residence, whether to obtain or perform the functions above, or to otherwise facilitate authorized necessary activities, they should at all times practice social distancing.

Abantu bwe baba nga beetaaga okuva mu maka gaabwe oba gye basula, okuweerezebwa oba okuweereza ku mirimu egyo egyogeddwako waggulu, oba okuyambako mu mirimu egikkirizibwa egyetaagisa, buli kiseera balina okwewa amabanga.

2) The healthcare delivery system shall prioritize services to serving those who are the sickest and shall prioritize resources, including personal protective equipment, for the providers providing direct care to them.
2) Enkola y’obujjanjabi ejja kuweereza ng’essa ku mwanjo abo abayi ennyo era mu kukozesa ebyokwesabika abajjanjabi abalabirira obutereevu abalwadde be bajja okussibwa ku mwanjo.
3) The Office of Emergency Services is directed to take necessary steps to ensure compliance with this Order.
3) Omukungu w’Obuweereza obw’Amangu alagirwa wano okukola ekyetaagisa okulaba nti Ekiragiro kino kissibwa mu nkola.
4) This Order shall be enforceable pursuant to California law, including, but not limited to, Government Code section 8665.
4) Ekiragiro kino kijja kussibwa mu nkola okusnziira ku Mateeka ga California omuli n’Akatundu ka Gavumenti 8665.
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that as soon as hereafter possible, this Order be filed in the Office of the Secretary of State and that widespread publicity and notice be given of this Order.
KYONGERA OKULAGIRWA WANO nti amangu ddala nga bwe kisoboka wano, Ekiragiro kino kiwandiikibwe mu Woofiisi ya Minisita akola ku Nsonga z’omunda mu ggwanga era kisaasaanyizibwe wonna nga bwe kisoboka.

This Order is not intended to, and does not, create any rights or benefits, substantive or procedural, enforceable at law or in equity, against the State of California, its agencies, departments, entities, officers, employees, or any other person.

Ekiragiro kino kiruubirira naye nga tekigenderera, kutondawo ddembe oba miganyulo, kutondawo mitendera oba tteeka lissibwa mu nkola oba lyenkanankana n’eryo ery’Eggwanga lya California, ebitongole byalyo, aboobuyinza, abakozi, oba omuntu omulala yenna.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF I have hereunto set my hand and caused the Great Seal of the State of California to be affixed this 19th day of March 2020.
OKUSOBOLA OKUKIKAKASA nkitaddeko omukono ne Sitampu Enkulu ey’Essaza lya California olwaleero nga 19 Ogwokusatu 2020.
FROM: Katherine Maher, Wikimedia Foundation CEO
OKUVA EWA: Katherine Maher, Wikimedia Foundation CEO
TO: All Wikimedia Foundation staff
ERI: Abakozi ba Wikimedia Foundation
SUBJECT LINE: [Covid-19] Lightening the load and preparing for the future
ENSONGA: [Covid-19] Okukendeeza ku mirimu n’okwetegekera ebiseera eby’omu maaso
SEND DATE/TIME: 14 March, 2020, 00:24 UTC
ENNAKU Z’OMWEZI/ESSAAWA LW’ESINDIKIDDWA: 14 Ogwokusatu, 2020, 00:24 UTC
LICENSING: CC0: No rights reserved
LAYISINSI: CC0: Tewali ddembe lyesigaliziddwa
We find ourselves in remarkable circumstances this month.
Tuli mu mbeera etali nnyangu omwezi guno.
The COVID-19 epidemic is something that makes clear our global human interconnectedness and the responsibilities we have to one another.
Nawookeera wa COVID-19 atulaze bulungi nti abantu bonna mu nsi bakolagana era babeerana era buli omu alina obuvunaanyizibwa eri munne.

We don’t have precedent for its challenges, but we do know that our best response relies on the sort of global empathy, cooperation, and community building that sits at the heart of this organization.
Tetulina kyakulabirako ku kusoomoozebwa kuno, naye tumanyi nti okwanukula kwaffe kusinziira ku kulumirirwa wonna mu nsi, enkolagana, n’obukolaganyi mu bantu obuzimbirwamu ekitongole kino.
The camaraderie and care we have seen among all of our colleagues over email, calls, and chats is a remarkable validation of the incredible humans we are fortunate enough to work with.

Obwasseruganda n’okufaayo kwe tulabye mu bannaffe nga batuwandiikira email, nga bakuba amasimu, n’okunyumya ku ssimu kiraga bulungi nti abantu be tukolagana nabo balumirirwa era tuli ba mukisa okukolagana nabo.
I couldn’t be more grateful and proud to count you all as colleagues.
Sirina ngeri ya njawulo gye nnyinza kubeebazaamu mikwano gyange.
Last week, someone shared with me their appreciation for our work.
Wiiki ewedde, waliwo omuntu eyanneebazizza olw’emirimu gye tukola.
They reminded me how meaningful it is for the world to be able to turn to Wikipedia right now, and what a powerful symbol it is for this critical resource to remain online and available to all.
Kyanzijukizizza obukulu bw’ensi okuddukira ku Wikipedia mu kiseera kino, nti era kano kabonero ka maanyi akalaga nti Wikipedia ya muwendo nnyo era esaana ebeere ku yintaneeti buli muntu emugase.
Your work makes this possible, whether you keep the sites stay up or our colleagues paid or our communities safe.
Omulimu gwo gw’okola gutusobozesa okutuuka ku buwanguzi buno, ng’oyamba okubeezaawo omukutu ku yintaneeti, ng’oyamba okusasula abakozi baffe oba abantu okubeera mu mbeera etaliimu bulabe.
The world needs the information that Wikipedia provides, now more than ever.
Mu kiseera kino, ensi yeetaaga obubaka obuli ku Wikipedia okusinga obwedda bwonna.
This is a moment in which not only what we do, but how we do it, will make a meaningful impact on the world.
Kino kye kiseera mwe tulabira nti ebintu bye tukola n’engeri gye tubikolamu biyamba okubaako kye bikola mu nsi.
Because of the importance of this mission and your role in it, we will be making some significant adjustments to how we work together, starting this coming week.
N’olw’omugaso gw’okwewaayo kuno ate n’omulimu gwo ku nsonga eno, tujja kubaako enkyukakyuka ze tukola mu ngeri gye tukolamu okutandika ne wiiki eyo ejja.
Adjustments to our work and schedules
Okukyusakyusa mu mirimu n’enteekateeka zaffe
As Robyn mentioned previously, the c-team met last night to discuss our approach and schedule for the coming days and months.
Nga Robyn bwe yagamba emabegako awo, akakiiko kaasisinkanye mu kiro ekyayise okwogeraganya ku nkola yaffe n’enteekateeka yaffe enaagobererwa mu nnaku n’emyezi egijja.
In that conversation, we considered what we thought would be an appropriate response to what we’re facing and the best way to keep the organization sustainable during this time.
Mu mboozi yaffe, twayogedde ku kye tulowooza nti y’engeri gye twandyeteeseteeseemu olw’obuzibu bwe twolekedde n’engeri esinga obulungi ey’okukuuma ekitongole okubeera nga kitambula mu kiseera kino.
Overwhelmingly we wanted to remove stress and support our mission for the long term.
Ffenna wamu twayagadde okweggyako okunyigirizibwa tuwagire ekyetume kyaffe okumala ebbanga eriwera.
If you need to dial back, that’s okay.
Bw’oba ng’oyagala okuddamu okukuba, tewali buzibu.
For all staff, contractors, and contract workers:
Eri abakozi bonna, bakontulakita, n’abakozi ab’ekiseera:
our daily working expectations will be about 4 hours a day, or 20 hours a week until further notice.
tusuubira okukola essaawa 4 buli lunaku oba essaawa 20 mu wiiki okutuusa lwe tunaddamu okukyusa eyo gye bujja.
We’re not declaring a holiday - if you are able to work more normal hours, the mission can use you.
Tetulangiridde luwummula – bw’oba ng’osobola okukola okusinga ku ssaawa ezo, ekitongole kino kisobola okukukozesa.
However, the world is unpredictable right now, and whether you need to care for loved ones, get groceries, or go to the doctor, your well-being is our priority.
Wabula, mu kiseera kino kati ensi teteeberezeka era bw’oba ng’oyagala kulabirira baagalwa bo, okugula ebyokukozesa ewaka, oba okugenda mu ddwaliro, bw’obeera omulamu naffe kye tusinga okwagala.
We are not tracking your time.
Tetugenda kulondoola budde bwo.
If you are sick, do not work.
Bw’oba ng’oli mulwadde, tokola.
This should go without saying, but we’re saying it.
Kino twandibadde tetukyogerako naye tulabye nga kisaana okwogerako.
No sick days or PTO required - just tell your manager and help your team revise calendars and schedules to make sure key areas of work are covered.

Ennaku z’okulwala oba okusasulwa olw’obutaba ku mulimu tebyetaagisa – tegeeza butegeeza maneja wo era oyambe b’okola nabo okukyusa mu by’otegese okukola okukakasa nti ebitegekeddwa okukola byonna bifiibwako.
(If you are diagnosed positive for COVID-19, please let Bryan within T&C Ops know so T&C can help with support and make sure your situation gets appropriate attention from management).

(Bw’okeberwa n’osangibwa ng’olina COVID-19, tegeeza Bryan ku T&C Ops know so T&C akuwe obuyambi obwetaagisa era ajja kufuba okulaba nti obeera bulungi era ng’ofuna obuyambi obwetaagisa okuva mu bukulembeze bwaffe).
Hourly folks will be fully paid.
Abakolera ku buli ssaawa bajja kusasulwa mu bujjuvu.
We have already said, and are recommitting to honor our commitments to our contractors and hourly staff colleagues.
Tukyogeddeko, era twongera okukiggumiza wano nti tujja kussa ekitiibwa mu bye twetema eri bakontulakita baffe ne bannaffe abatukolera buli ssaawa.
Everyone will be paid on the basis of their usual hours worked during normal circumstances.
Buli muntu ajja kusasulwa okusinziira ku ssaawa ze eza bulijjo mu mbeera eza bulijjo.
This includes if you are sick and unable to work.
Muno mulimu n’okutunuulira ekiseera bw’oba ng’oli mulwadde oba nga tosobola kukola.
If you want to work, we support you.
Bw’oba ng’oyagala okukola, tukuwagira.
Many people use work as a way of channeling their stress with the world around us.
Abantu bangi bakozesa emirimu ng’omukutu gw’okweggyako okunyigirizibwa okuva mu bantu/ebintu ebibeetoolodde.
What we do can be incredibly rewarding, especially during times like this.
Bye tukola bimatiza era bivaamu ebibala naddala mu kiseera ekiringa kino.
Again, this is about your self-care.
Nkiddamu wano nti kiri gy’oli okwerabirira.
Our ask is that you communicate with your manager, so we know what to expect and can adjust accordingly.
Kye tukusaba kye kino nti yogera ne mukama wo tumanye kye tuyinza okusuubira era tukyuseemu nga bwe kyetaagisa.
Some work is considered essential.
Emirimu egimu gitwalibwa okubeera egy’omugaso ennyo.
There are some things that we must keep doing.
Waliwo ebintu ebitalina kuyimirira.
The SRE, HR Ops, Trust & Safety, and Fundraising teams (among others) do critical work that may need additional support.
SRE, HR Ops, Trust & Okuba obulungi, ne tiimu z’okusonda (n’ebirala) bikola emirimu egy’enjawulo egyetaaga obuyambi obulala.
We’ll begin a process with all departments to assess current objectives and shift our focus to supporting what’s essential for our mission.
Tuja kutandika kaweefube w’okwekaliriza ebigendererwa byaffe mu kiseera kino era tuseetule bye tutunuulidde kati tusobole okuwagira ebikulu mu bye tukola.
There’s plenty to do for all of us, we just will all focus on the most essential projects.
Tulina bingi eby’okukola, kye twetaaga kwe kwemalira ku pulojekiti ezisinga obukulu.
Slowing now won’t hurt later.
Okukendeeza ku mbiro tekijja kutukosa gye bujja.
We do not plan to go “double-time to catch up” once the pandemic has passed.
Tetuteekateeka “kukubisaamu budde bwe tukolera nga tusasulira bwe tufiiriddwa” nnawookeera ng’aweddewo.
You will not be expected to work extra hours to meet deadlines which are now unrealistic.
Tosuubirwa kukolera budde busukka ku obwo bw’obadde okoleramu olw’okukwata nsalessale atasoboka.
We accept that circumstances have changed, and will work to set new targets and timelines where appropriate.
Tukkiriza nti embeera ekyuse, era tujja kukola ebiruubirirwa ebiggya tukyuse ne nsalessale we kinaaba kyetaagisiza.
What happens with the APP (Annual Planning)?
Kiki ekinaakolebwa ku Nteekateeka y’Omwaka (Annual Planning)?
To adjust to our new reality and daily working hour expectations, we intend to adjust the timeline for the delivery of our 2020-2021 Annual Plan.

Okukyusa okudda mu mbeera y’obulamu gye tunaabaamu, n’ebisuubirwa mu budde obukolerwamu buli lunaku, tusuubira okukyusaamu mu nnaku za nsalessale ku ebyo bye twagala okutuukako mu Nteekateeka y’Omwaka gwaffe 2020-2021.

Our intention is to propose an extension of our 2019-2020 plan that allows more time for budgeting to allow employees to prioritize critical work, self-care, and care for loved ones while accommodating those who need or wish to work a reduced schedule over the next few weeks.

Ekigendererwa kyaffe kwe kuteesa okwongezaayo enteekateeka yaffe eya 2019-2020 kituwe obudde obulala okukoleramu embalirira abakozi basobole okukulembeza emirimi emikulu, okwerabirira, n’okulabirira abantu baabwe ate ng’era tufaayo ne ku abo abaagala okukolera obudde obutonoko mu wiiki entonotono ezijja.
This timeline extension greatly reduces current planning workloads and pressure across the whole organization.
Okwongezaayo kuno kikendeereza ddala enteekateeka eriwo ku mirimu n’okupeekebwa okumaliriza emirimu okuliwo mu kiseera kino mu kitongole kyonna.
We will introduce our proposal to the Board next week and will update delegates and teams on the next steps as soon as we have confirmation.
Tujja kwanjula ebiteeso byaffe eri Olukiiko Olufuzi mu wiiki ejja era tujja kutegeeza abakiise n’abalala ku bye tulina okuzzaako nga bwe tunaaba tumaze okubikakasa.
Thank you to the APP team for your leadership in this.
Mwebale nnyo bannange mwenna olw’Enteekateeka n’olw’obukulembeze mu nsonga zonna.
Office status, exposure, and cleaning
Embeera ya woofiisi, okubozi bw’okusiigibwa, n’okuyonja
Last week, we learned that one of our SF-based colleagues may have been exposed to the COVID-19 virus.
Wiiki ewedde, twategeezebwa nti omu ku bannaffe ow’omu San Francisco alabika yasiigibwa akawuka ka COVID-19.
However, out of an abundance of caution, we employed an antiviral cleaning crew to disinfect all surfaces in the San Francisco office.
Wabula, mu kwegendereza okungi, twafuna eddagala eritta obuwuka ne tufuuyira ekifo kyonna n’ebintu mu woofiisi y’omu San Francisco.
They utilized a hospital-grade anti-viral solution to disinfect every surface, as well as the lobby and elevator banks accessing our floor.
Baakozesa eddagala erikozesebwa okutta obuwuka mu malwariro okutta obuwuka ku buli kintu, mu kifo ewatuukirwa, ebikondo by’omu lifuti ebituuka ku mwaliiro gwa woofiisi yaffe.
The building is employing its own duty-of-care protocol utilizing products that support the safety of their tenants.
Bannannyini kizimbe nabo baakozesa engeri zaabwe ez’okulabirira abakozi baabwe.
We feel comfortable that the office will be well-prepared for when we decide to return.
Tuwulira emirembe nti woofiisi ejja kuba nteeketeeke bulungi we tunaasalirawo okuddayo okukola.
Our DC office is located in a WeWork, which has shared its COVID-19 protocol with us and all DC-based staff members.
Woofiisi yaffe ey’omu DC eri mu WeWork, era ng’ekifo ekyo kitulaze ku nteekateeka yaakyo ey’okulwanyisa COVID-19 era n’abakozi bonna ab’omu kifo ekyo enteekateeka eno bagigunyeeko.
As of last week, our DC office moved to a fully remote setup in line with the guidance shared with San Francisco.
Wiiki ewedde we yaggweerako, woofiisi yaffe ey’omu DC yajjululwa n’ezzibwa mu kifo ekyesuulidde ddala ewala nga tugoberera okuluŋŋamizibwa kwa San Francisco.
As some of our NYC-based colleagues know, we have also been in discussion about leasing a location in Brooklyn.
Era nga bannaffe abamu ab’omu NYC bwe bamanyi, tubadde mu kwogerezeganya tupangise ekifo mu Brooklyn.
These discussions are continuing but may be delayed.
Okwogerezeganya kuno kukyagenda mu maaso naye kuyinza okulwisibwa.
Some of our colleagues are working remotely for the first time.
Abamu ku bannaffe bakolera waka ate nga guno gwe mulundi gwabwe ogusoose.
Our long-time remote colleagues know that it can be an adjustment, and wanted to offer you some advice:
Abamu ku bannaffe be tukolaganye nabo ebbanga mu ngeri eyo bakimanyi nti kirimu okusoomooza, era bandyagadde okubaako amagezi ge bawa:
Limit the length of meetings to at most one or two hour increments.
Enkiiko muzikuumire mu bbanga eriri wakati w’essaawa emu oba bbiri.
If longer sessions are required, consider how they can be broken up over the course of several days.
Okusisinkanira ebbanga eddene bwe kuba kwetaagisa, tunula mu ngeri ensisinkana ezo gye zisobola okukutulwakutulwamu ne zidda ku nnaku ez’enjawulo.
Clearly define the meeting, have an agenda, and send reading materials in advance.
Buli lukiiko luteekeko ensonga, tegeka ebyokuteesaako era weereza ebyetaaga okusomako ng’obudde bukyali.
Make video the default, with tools like Google Docs and Zoom to facilitate live collaboration and connection.
Viidiyo gye muba mukulembeza nga mukozesa n’ebirala nga Google Docs ne Zoom okuyambako mu kuwuliziganya okwo okw’obuliwo.
Have a lead to facilitate every meeting, someone to monitor the chat for questions and track the speaker list, and someone to help take notes (or do collaborative note-taking).

Mubeere n’omuntu akulemberamu buli lukiiko, omuntu alina okulondoola okwogeraganya n’ebibuuzo ne biweebwa ekiseera era n’okulondoola abalina okwogera ate n’omuntu alina okunokola ebiteesebwa (oba n’okukkaanya mwenna ne mubaako bye munokola).
Send an email to tech support if you need a comfortable headset.
Bw’oba nga weetaaga emizindaalo gy’omu matu, weereza email eri abakola ku bya tekinologiya bakuweereze emizindaalo emirungi.
Use your wellness reimbursement for snacks.
Kozesa ssente ezikuddizibwa okubeera obulungi ogulemu obumpwakipwaki.
Join the #remoties channel in Slack to talk with your colleagues about distributed work
Weeyunge ku mukutu gwa #remoties mu Slack oyogereganye ne banno ku bikwata ku mirimu egigabiddwa
The HR Operations team is looking into webinar-based ergonomics guidance to support the increase in distributed work across the Foundation.
Ekitongole Ekikola ku nsonga z’Abakozi kitunula mu nsonga y’okuwuliziganyiza ku yintaneeti (webinar-based ergonomics guidance) okusobola okuyambako ku mirimu egigabiddwa mu Kitongole kyonna.
This past week we asked all community grant recipients to cancel Wikimedia-funded public events, such as editathons, until the WHO declares the pandemic to be over.

Mu wiiki eyo ewedde, twasaba abaafuna ssente z’okukola emirimu basazeemu emikolo gyonna egisasulirwa Wikimedia gamba nga editathons, okutuusa ng’ekitongole kya WHO kirangiridde nti nnawookeera aweddewo.

We let them know that we understood that our request for cancellations and other restrictions could make it impossible to complete their agreed-upon grant activities and that no one would be penalized for having to delay or modify those goals.

Twabategeeza nti tukitegeera bulungi nti okubasaba okusazaamu n’okukugira ebintu ebimu kizibuwaza okukola ku byokukola ebimu bye baategeka era nti tewali muntu ajja kubonerezebwa olw’okulwawo okumaliriza oba okukyusaamu mu byategekebwa.
This coming week we will follow up with additional guidance on Wikimania and other regional and thematic community conferences.
Mu wiiki eyo ejja, tujja kulondoola okuluŋŋamizibwa okulala ku Wikimania ne ku ssemasomo nnamiramwa ate n’ezo ez’omu bitundu ebirala.
The general sentiment from around the global community seems to be both sadness at the disruption but relief at the clarity and ability to focus on their own communities, Wikimedia and otherwise.

Kye tusinga okulaba mu bannaffe wonna mu nsi kiri nti bannaffe banakuwavu olw’okusazaamu okw’engeri eyo naye ate bawewuka bwe bateegeera nti balina kwemalira ku ebyo eby’omu kitundu kyabwe, Wikimedia n’ebirala.
Going forward, the CRT is working to set up a page on Meta-Wiki to provide a space for the community to monitor the impact and follow our communications with them.
Mu ebyo ebijja mu maaso, CRT ekola butaweera okuteekawo omuko ku Meta-Wiki okuteerawo abantu ebbanga okulondoola engeri gye bakwatiddwako n’okugoberera ebyempuliziganya yaffe nabo.
Staying in touch around COVID-19 related issues
Okubeera mu mpuliziganya ku nsonga ezikwata ku COVID-19
We’ll be sending an invitation to your calendars for next Thursday, 14:00 UTC/07:00 PT for a special staff meeting.
Tujja kubayita nga tuyitira mu kalenda zammwe mu lukiiko olw’enjawulo ku Lwokuna olujja, ku ssaawa 14:00 UTC/07:00 PT.
We’ll use this time to share additional updates, answer your questions and spend some time connecting with each other.
Tujja kukosesa ekiseera kino okugabana ku nsonga endala, okwanukula ebibuuzo byammwe era tumaleyo obudde butonotono nga tunyumyamu.
We’re in this together and here to help however we can.
Ensonga eno tugirimu ffenna era ffenna tulina okuyambagana mu ngeri yonna esoboka.
In the meantime, you can continue to find the information from this email, and all other essential COVID-19 related information, on Office Wiki.
Ebyo nga biri awo, osobola okusanga obubaka buno ku email ne ku mikutu emirala egiriko obubaka obwekwanya ku COVID-19, ne ku Office Wiki.
The CRT will keep these pages updated and all the information in one place.
CRT kijja kufuba okuteeka obubaka obwakasembyeyo okufunika mu kifo kimu.
We are also working to maintain regular communications with staff who reside in countries that are currently significantly affected.
Tufuba era okukola okufuna empuliziganya buli kiseera n’abakozi abali mu mawanga agakoseddwa ennyo mu kiseera kino.
If you have any questions about travel, events, a major workstream, or coverage challenge, or anything else you may need help with, please don’t hesitate to notify and work with the CRT.

Bw’oba ng’olina ekibuuzo kyonna ku bikwata ku ntambula, emikolo, omulimu gwonna oba okusoomoozebwa ku kukola ku by’olina okukolako, oba ekintu ekirala kyonna kye weetaaga okukuyambamu, tolonzalonza kututegeeza era kolagana ne CRT.
We’re here to help provide support and liaise as needed.
Tuli bulindaala okuyamba n’okukolagana naawe ku nsonga eyeetaagisa.
If you have a confidential or sensitive matter, please email Bryan Judan - Director of HR International Global Operations.
Bw’oba ng’olina ensonga ey’ekyama oba ey’okwegendereza, tukusaba oweereze email ewa Bryan Judan, Ssenkulu w’Emirimu mu Nsi Yonna (Director of HR International Global Operations).
None of these changes should be seen as an abandonment of our work and obligations.
Enkyukakyuka zino zonna teziteekeddwa kulabika ng’ezitusuuzaawo emirimu gyaffe n’obuvunaanyizibwa.
Rather, they are a recognition that at this moment, our work and obligations will likely need to adapt in a way we have not in the past.
Wabula, zituyamba okutegeera nti mu kiseera kino, emirimu gyaffe n’obuvunaanyizibwa oboolyawo birina okukyukamu okwawukanako ku bwe kibadde emabega.
These are the steps we believe are necessary to support this one another so that we can continue to work, provide our movement with the support they need, and the world with the service they rely on.

Ebigobererwa bino tukkiriza nti byetaagisa okusobola okuwagiragana tusobole okugenda mu maaso nga tukola, okuwagira ekibiina kyaffe mu ngeri yonna eyeetaagisa, n’okuweereza abantu n’obuweereza kwe beesigamye.
Our planned work will be there waiting for us when the time comes.
Emirimu gye twategeka gijja kubaawo nga gitulindiridde ekiseera bwe kinaatuuka.
For now, it is time to support one another and create space for the important work that will be coming in the weeks and potentially months ahead.
Mu kiseera kino, kisaana nnyo okuyambagana era tuteekewo ebbanga ery’okukoleramu emirimu emikulu egijja mu wiiki ezijja mu maaso eyo oboolyawo n’emyezi egijja.
We need all of you to make that happen, and so we need you all to take care of yourself and your families so that you can be at your best when the need arises.
Mwenna tubeetaaga okusobozesa kino okubaawo, noolwekyo tubeetaaga mwenna okwerabirira ne famire zammwe musobole okubeera mu mbeera ennungi nga tubeetaaze.
Now, please -- wash your hands and don’t touch your face!
Kaakati, bambi – naaba mu ngalo era teweekwata mu maaso!

Katherine, the CRT (Amanda K, Amy V, Bryan J, Doreen D, Gregory V, Jaime V, Joel L, Lynette L, Ryan M, and Tony S), and the rest of the Leadership Team (Grant I, Heather W, Jaime V, Janeen U, Lisa S, Robyn A, Ryan M, and Toby N).

Katherine, CRT (Amanda K, Amy V, Bryan J, Doreen D, Gregory V, Jaime V, Joel L, Lynette L, Ryan M, ne Tony S), n’abakulembeze abalala (Grant I, Heather W, Jaime V, Janeen U, Lisa S, Robyn A, Ryan M, ne Toby N).
The SARS-CoV-2 virus is the cause of COVID-19 (coronavirus disease 2019), a contagious respiratory disease that was first identified in December 2019, in Wuhan, Hubei, China.
Akawuka ka SARS-CoV-2 ke kaleeta COVID-19 (obulwadde bwa coronavirus 2019), obulwadde bw’omuyungiro gw’okussa obusiigibwa obwasooka okuzuulibwa mu Deesemba wa 2019, mu Wuhan, Hubei, China.
The disease is a type of coronavirus, the same family that includes SARS, MERS, and some varieties of the common cold.
Obulwadde obwo kika ky’akawuka ka coronavirus, nga kali mu kika kye kimu omuli SARS, MERS, n’ebika bya ssennyiga ebimu ebimanyiddwa.
It was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) on 11 March 2020.
Ekitongole kya World Health Organization (WHO) kyabulangirira ng’ekirwadde ekikambwe nga 11 Ogwokusatu 2020.
While much about COVID-19 is still unknown, preliminary data suggests that it is more virulent and contagious than the seasonal flu, and less virulent but more contagious than SARS and MERS.

Newankubadde nga bingi ebikwata ku COVID-19 tebimanyiddwa, ebizuuliddwawo biraga nti bwa bulabe nnyo era busaasaana mangu okusinga ssennyiga owa bulijjo, naye ate si bwa bulabe nnyo kusinga SARS ne MERS newankubadde nga busaasaana nnyo okubusinga
Older people and those with underlying conditions are the most at risk of serious complications including death.
Abantu abakuliridde n’abo abasangiddwa n’obulwadde obulala be basinga okuba mu bulabe okufuna obukosefu obw’amaanyi omuli n’okufa.
Due to the spread of the disease, you are advised not to travel unless necessary, to avoid being infected, quarantined, or stranded by changing restrictions and cancelled flights.

Olw’okusaasana kw’obulwadde buno, osabibwa obutatambula okuggyako nga tekyewalika, okusobola okwetangira okusiigibwa obulwadde, ng’oteekeddwa mu kalantiini, oba okusoberwa olw’obukwakkulizo obukyukakyuka n’okusazaamu entambula z’ennyonyi.
Avoid crowded places whenever possible.
Weewale ebifo ebirimu abantu abangi nga bwe kisoboka.
This is not just to protect you, but also those you come in contact with.
Kino si kya kukuuma ggwe wekka, naye n’abantu b’okwatagana nabo.
As it happens, you probably aren't missing much by staying home, as many attractions around the world are closing their doors to avoid spreading the disease.
Ekituufu kiri nti, oboolyawo tolina ky’osubwa nnyo singa obeera osigadde ewaka, kubanga ebintu ebisikiriza okwetoloola ensi yonna biggaddewo okutangira okusaasaanya obulwadde.

If you do need to travel, take precautions as you would for other infections: wash your hands frequently, avoid touching your face, cough and sneeze into your elbow or a tissue, and avoid contact with sick people.

Bw’oba oyagala okutambula, weegendereze nga bwe wandikoze ku ndwadde endala: naaba mu ngalo buli kiseera, weewale okwekwata mu maaso, kololera oba nyiriza mu lukokola oba akapapula akeerongoosa, era weewale okukwatagana n’abantu abalwadde.
Before traveling, read up on the extensive and fast-changing array of travel restrictions that have been imposed around the world.
Nga tonnatambula, sooka osome nnyo ku nkyukakyuka ezibeerawo buli kaseera ku bukwakkulizo bw’okutambula obuteereddwawo okwetooloola ensi.
After travel, monitor your health and consider self-isolation for two weeks to avoid transmitting the disease to others.
Bw’odda oluvannyuma lw’okutambula, londoola obulamu bwo era olowooze ku kweyawula okumala wiiki bbiri okwewala okusaasaanya obulwadde eri abalala.
Transportation from long-distance passenger flights to local buses has been curtailed or completely shut down in many countries due to low demand or government orders.

Okutambuliza abantu ku baasi z’omu kitundu ababa batambulidde ku nnyonyi eŋŋendo empanvu kusaliddwako oba kiggyiddwawo ddala mu mawanga agasinga olw’abazikozesa okukendeera oba olw’ebiragiro bya gavumenti.
Many international and regional borders are closed.
Ensalo ttabamawanga ne ttababitundu ezisinga ziggaddwawo.
If you are away from home, and especially if you are in another country, consider returning home as soon as possible; this may get even more difficult as restrictions continue to change.

Bw’oba ng’ovudde ewaka, naddala singa oba ng’oli mu ggwanga ddala, lowooza ku ky’okudda eka amangu ddala; kino kiyinza okweyongera okukaluba olw’ensonga nti obukwakkulizo bweyongera okukyusibwakyusibwa.
In some cases it may simply not be possible, even if you're healthy and meet the legal requirements for entry.
Ebiseera ebimu, kiyinza obutasobokera ddala, ne bw’oba ng’oli mulamu ate nga n’ebisaanyizo byonna ebikuyingiza mu ggwanga obirina.
If you can't find a way back to your country, contact your nearest embassy or consulate for assistance.
Bw’oba olemereddwa okuddayo mu ggwanga lyo, tuukirira ekitebe ky’eggwanga lyo ekikuli okumpi osobole okuyambibwa.
They may be able to organize an evacuation, identify non-regularly scheduled flights, or give you an emergency loan to pay for transport.
Bayinza okusobola okukutegekera engeri y’okukuzzaayo, okukufunira ennyonyi ezitali za lukale, oba okukuwola ssente z’entambula ez’amangu.
In case they can't, make preparations in case you need to stay where you are for an extended period.
Bwe balemererwa, weetegeke singa kiba kikwetaagisa okusigala w’oli okumala ebbanga eryeyongeramu.
If you do find a way back home, be prepared that it may be expensive, inconvenient, and have unusual restrictions (such as no checked baggage).
Bw’oba ofunye engeri y’okudda ewaka, weetegeke nti kiyinza okuba eky’ebbeeyi ennyo, ekitaataaganya, n’okubaako obukwakkulizo obutali bwa bulijjo (okugeza ennyonyi obuteetikka migugu).
As of early April 2020, the number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 is approaching one million.
Bwe gwatuukira Ogwokuna 2020, omuwendo gw’abantu abakakasibwa okubeera n’obulwadde bwa COVID-19 gwali gukunukkiriza akakadde kalamba.
Though the disease started in mainland China, it has spread around the world and China has fewer confirmed cases and deaths than several other countries.
Newankubadde obulwadde bwatandikira mu China, busaasaanidde ensi yonna era China yo erina abalwadde batonoko n’abafudde okusinga amawanga agamu amalala.
Europe is the new epicenter of the pandemic.
Ssemazinga wa Bulaaya kaakati y’asingamu nawookeera ono.

All but a handful of countries have reported at least one case, with the highest numbers of reported cases in the United States, Spain, Italy, Germany, France, mainland China, Iran, and the United Kingdom.
Kyenkana buli ggwanga ng’oggyeko ag’olubatu gafunyeeyo waakiri omulwadde omu, ng’omuwendo gw’abalwadde ogusinga obunene guli mu United States, Italy, Germany, France, China, Iran, ne United Kingdom.
Local transmission is established in many countries in all major inhabited regions of the world except some Pacific island nations.
Okusaasaana kw’obulwadde munda mu mawanga kukakasiddwa mu mawanga mangi mu bitundu ebikulu ebibeeramu abantu mu nsi yonna okuggyako amawanga agali mu bitundu by’ebizinga bya Pacific.
(See updates from the WHO.)
(Laba amawulire okuva ku WHO.)
The full extent of the spread is uncertain, due in part to limited testing.
Obugazi bw’okusaasaana butankanibwa, olw’ensonga nti okukebera kutono.

Many countries are experiencing a severe shortage of test kits, and the authorities have not been able to test everybody who is at high risk, so the real number of cases is probably much higher than the official one.

Amawanga mangi tegalina bikozesebwa kukebera, era n’abakwatibwako tebannaba kufuna busobozi kukebera buli muntu ali mu katyabaga akanene okufuna obulwadde, noolwekyo, omuwendo gw’abalwadde gwennyini guyinza okuba nga munene nnyo okusinga ogwo ogumanyiddwa.
Countries also differ in their testing and reporting practices, so comparisons of the number of reported cases do not tell the full story of how the epidemic has progressed in different areas.

Era amawanga gaawukanya enkola zaago mu kukebera n’okufulumya ebikwata ku bulwadde, noolwekyo okugeraageranya omuwendo gw’abalwadde ogufulumiziddwa tekiraga kifaananyi kituufu ku ngeri obulwadde gye busaasaanye mu bitundu eby’enjawulo.
The virus is transmitted through respiratory droplets and through objects.
Akawuka kasaasaanyizibwa okuyita mu matondo g’omuyungiro gw’okussa n’okuyita ku bintu.
The coronavirus is a relatively large virus, meaning it is not truly airborne: it will settle down in respiratory droplets.
Akawuka ka coronavirus kawuka kagazi, ekitegeeza nti tekasaasaanira mu mpewo mwokka: kabeera ne mu luzzizzi lw’omu nnyindo ng’omuntu assa.
Staying two metres (six feet) away from other people is usually enough to prevent transmission through this route.
Okubeera mmita bbiri (fuuti mukaaga) okuva ku bantu abalala kitera okuba nga kimala okutangira okusiigibwa akawuka okuyita mu ngeri eno.
Transmission from objects can happen, for example, if someone sneezes, touches a doorknob, and then other people touch the doorknob and then touch their faces.
Kisoboka okukwatibwa akawuka okuva ku bintu, okugeza, singa omuntu ayasimula, akwata ku munyolo gw’oluggi, abantu abalala nabo ne bakwata ku munyolo ogwo ate ne beekwata mu maaso.
The SARS-CoV-2 virus may last on cardboard for up to 24 hours and on plastic for up to 3 days.
Akawuka ka SARS-CoV-2 kayinza okumala ku lubaawo essaawa 24 ne ku pulasitiika ennaku 3.
Transmission via the fecal–oral route may also be possible.
Busobola n’okusaasaana okuyita mu kulya obubi.
Evidence suggests that COVID-19 is contagious even without symptoms, though to what extent is still being investigated.
Obujulizi obuliwo bulaga nti COVID-19 osobola okumusiiga ne bw’oba tolina bubonero bwonna, newankubadde nga okumanya oba nga kino kisoboka kyenkana ki kikyanoonyerezebwako.
Common symptoms include a fever, dry cough, and fatigue.
Obubonero obwa bulijjo mulimu olusujjasujja, ekifuba ekitakutuka n’ekimenyoomenyo.
Other less common symptoms include shortness of breath, a sore throat, headache, muscle pain, or sputum production.
Obubonero obulala obutali bwa maanyi mulimu okuziyira, amabwa mu bulago, okulumwa omutwe, okulumwa ennyingo, oba okufuna akakolondolwa.
Some patients have very mild symptoms, similar to a cold.
Abalwadde abamu bafuna obubonero butono nnyo, obwekuusa ku ssennyiga.
Serious complications include pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and multi-organ failure leading to disability or death.
Obuvune obw’amaanyi mulimu lubyamira, okukaluubirizibwa okw’amaanyi mu kussa, n’okulemererwa kw’ebitundu by’omubiri eby’enjawulo ekiyinza okuviirako obulemu oba okufa.
About 80% of infections result in mild symptoms, while the remaining may result in hospitalization.
Abalwadde nga ebitundu 80% bafuna obubonero obutonotono, so ng’ate abasigadde basobola n’okuweebwa ebitanda mu ddwaliro.
Case fatality rate is estimated at 1-3% of infected individuals, most of whom are elderly with underlying health conditions.
Abantu abalowoozebwa okuba nga bafudde obulwadde buno bali wakati w’ebitundu 1 ne 3 ku kikumi, abasinga obungi nga bakadde abasangiddwa n’ebirwadde ebirala.
The fatality rate is much higher for those over 70 but significantly lower for those under 40.
Abantu abasinga okufa beebo abali waggulu w’emyaka 70 so ng’aomuwendo mutono ddala ogw’abo abali wansi w’emyaka 40.

Those most at risk of COVID-19 infection and serious complications are the elderly and those with weakened immune systems or underlying health conditions like cardiovascular disease, diabetes, hypertension, chronic respiratory disease, and cancer.

Abasinga okuba mu bulabe bw’okukwatibwa ekirwadde kya COVID-19 wamu n’okukosebwa ennyo be bakadde n’abo abalina abasirikale b’omubiri abanafuye oba abasangiddwa n’ebirwadde ebirala nga obulwadde bw’omutima, sukaali, entunnunsi, obulwadde bw’ekiwanga, ne kookolo.
Not many cases are reported in children and most of these are mild or moderate, though a significant fraction do get pneumonia.
Obulwadde tebunnalabibwa nnyo mu baana abato era abazuuliddwa boolesa obubonero butono ddala oba si bwa maanyi, newankubadde ng’abasinga bafuna lubyamira.
Occupationally, health care workers have higher risk compared to others with clusters of disease among workers and in health care settings.
Mu by’emirimu, abajjanjabi balina omukisa gwa waggulu okukwatibwa obulwadde okusinga ku bannaabwe abakola n’abantu abalina endwadde endala nga nabo bakolera mu bifo ebijjanjabirwamu.

The time between being exposed to the virus and the emergence of symptoms (incubation period) is typically between 2 and 14 days, though there has been one reported case in China where symptoms appeared 27 days after exposure.

Ebbanga wakati w’okufuna akawuka n’okweyoleka kw’obubonero (ebbanga ly’okwaluza) liri wakati w’ennaku 2 ne 14, newankubadde waliwo omulwadde omu agambibwa okuba nti obubonero bweyoleka luvannyuma lwa nnaku 27 ng’amaze okufuna akawuka.
As of February 2020, the period of infectiousness is unknown, but is likely most significant when people are symptomatic.
Bwe zaatuukira Ogwokubiri 2020, ng’ekiseera omuntu ky’asobola okumala ng’asiiga akawuka tekimanyiddwa, naye kirabika kibeerawo nnyo ng’abantu batandise okulaga obubonero.
There is evidence of transmission from people who don't have symptoms, although to what extent is still being investigated.
Waliwo obukakafu nti obulwadde busaasaanyizibwa abantu abatalaga bubonero, naye ng’obunene bw’ensonga eno tebumanyiddwa bulungi.
It is unclear whether it is possible to be reinfected with the virus after recovering from it the first time around.
Tekyekakasia oba ng’omuntu awonye obulwadde omulundi ogusooka asobola okuddamu n’asiigibwa akawuka.
Long-term effects for people who have recovered remain unclear, but there is evidence of reduced lung capacity in some recovered patients.
Obukosefu obusigalawo okumala ebbanga mu bantu abassuuse tebumanyiddwa, naye waliwo obukakafu nti amawuggwe g’abantu abamu abassuuse ganafuwa.
Testing for the virus usually consists of a swab inserted through the nose or a throat swab which is analysed in a laboratory for the virus.
Mu kukebera akawuka, oyisibwa akawero mu nnyindo oba mu mumiro oluvannyuma ne byekebejjebwa mu ggezeserezo.
The current "gold standard" test involves extracting the genetic material from the sample and analysing it for known genetic markers of the virus.
Enkola eriwo esinga okumanyibwa mu kukebera erimu okuggya obutaffaali bw’endagabutonde mu sampolo, ne bwekenneenyezebwa okulaba oba mulimu emikululo gy’obuwuka bw’onna obuli mu butaffaali.
There is no established test assessing for the virus or antibodies in the blood, although tests are being developed.
Tewali kukebera kawuka oba basirikale ba mubiri kuteereddwawo nga bakebera musaayi, newankubadde ng’okukebera okw’engeri eyo kuli mu kukulaakulanyizibwa.
There is no test to establish immunity to the virus.
Tewali kukebera kusobola kulaga nti omuntu alina obusibage ku kawuka.
Many governments around the world have advised their citizens not to travel unnecessarily amid the pandemic.
Gavumenti nnyingi okwetooloola ensi balabudde bannansi baabwe obutamala gatambula mu kiseera kya nnawookeera.
Lots of airlines and package holidays are making it easy for you by waiving cancellation and change fees.
Kkampuni z’ennyonyi ezisinga n’abakola ku by’empummula banguyirizzaako abantu nga baggyawo ssente ezitanzibwa olw’okusazaamu oba okukyusaamu okutambula.
Particularly avoid cruise ship travel.
Okusingira ddala weewale okutambulira ku mmeeri.

Older travelers and those with underlying health conditions are most at risk and should avoid travel that puts them at risk, such as long plane flights, visits to crowded places, and especially cruises, even outside of severely affected areas.

Abasaabaze abakadde n’abo abaasangibwa n’ebirwadde be basinga okuba n’obusobozi okusiigibwa era basaanye beewale okutambula okubateeka mu buzibu, okugeza ng’okutambulira mu nnyonyi eŋŋendo empanvu, okukyalira ebifo ebirimu abantu abangi, naddala okutambulira ku mmeeri, ne bwe kiba wabbali w’ebifo ebikoseddwa ennyo.
In affected areas, most experts recommend a practice known as social distancing.
Mu bifo ebikoseddwa, abakugu bawagira enkola emanyiddwa nga tonsemberera.
This means minimising contact with others by keeping a distance of six feet or two meters from them and avoiding gathering together in groups.
Kino kitegeeza okukendeeza ku kusemberera abantu abalala ng’olekawo ebbanga lya fuuti mukaaga oba mmita bbiri okuva ku munno n’okwewala okukuŋŋaanira mu bibinja.
Some areas permit small groups; others prohibit all group gatherings.
Ebifo ebimu bikkiriza obubinja obutonotono; ebirala byo bigaanira ddala okukuŋŋaana okw’engeri yonna.
Measures you are encouraged to take include working from home whenever possible, avoiding crowds and avoiding leaving your home unless absolutely necessary.
Ebintu by’okubirizibwa okukola mulimu okukolera ewaka bwe kiba kisoboka, okwewala ebibinja n’okwewala okuva mu maka go okuggyako nga tekyewalika.
If you must go out, try to stay at least 2 meters (6 feet) away from other people.
Bwe kiba nti oteekeddwa okutambula, fuba okulekawo ebbanga lya mmita 2 (fuuti 6) okuva ku bantu abalala.
In many places these measures are required.
Mu bifo ebisinga obungi, enkola zino zeetaagisa.
Follow hygiene practices like for flu prevention.
Goberera enkola z’obuyonjo nga ezigobererwa okutangira ssennyiga.
Frequently wash your hands with soap and warm water, and then dry your hands on a clean towel.
Naaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni wamu n’amazzi agabuguma buli kiseera, era engalo zo ozikaze n’akagoye akayonjo.
As coronaviruses are enveloped viruses, washing your hands with soap kills the virus by disrupting the mostly fat-based viral envelope.
Engeri gye kiri nti obuwuka bwa coronavirus busabikiddwa, okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni kitta obuwuka okuyita mu kwabya olububi omusabikiddwa obuwuka obwo.
Effective hand washing requires rubbing your hands for at least 20 seconds.
Okunaaba engalo obulungi olina okuzikuuta waakiri okumala obutikitiki 20.
Drying your washed hands physically removes some germs from your skin (so don't skip that step, and don't share towels).
Okusiimuula engalo zo kiggyako obuwuka obumu okuva ku lususu lwo (noolwekyo tobuuka mutendera ogwo, naye togabana busiimuula).
If soap and water are not available, then use a >60% alcohol-based hand sanitizer.
Bwe kiba nti tewali ssabuuni na mazzi, awo kozesa eddagala erinaaba mu ngalo okutta obuwuka nga lirimu ebitundu ebitakka wansi wa 60% eby’omwenge.

Alcohol is a quick germ-killer, but it's not quite instant, so this still requires the same 20 seconds of rubbing your hands together, making sure that every single scrap of skin gets wet, and then you have to wait about another minute, for the alcohol to completely dry.

Omwenge gutta mangu obuwuka naye nga tegukolerawo bwekityo nagwo gwetaaga obutikitiki 20 ng’okuuba engalo zo ng’ofuba okulaba nti buli kanyomero ka lususu lwo katoba era olindeko eddakiika endala ng’emu, omwenge ogwo gukale bulungi.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with your hands.
Weewale okukwata mu maaso go, ennyindo n’emimwa gyo.
Most people touch their faces every few minutes, all day long.
Abantu abasinga beekwata mu maaso buli luvanyuma lw’eddakiika entonotono, olunaku lwonna.
Try to do this less, and try to wash your hands before touching your face.
Kino kikole emirundi mitono ddala era gezaako okunaaba engalo zo nga tonnakikola.
Also, try to avoid touching surfaces you don't have to touch in the first place, at least with your bare hands.
Mu ngeri y’emu, weewale okukwata ku bintu by’otolina kukwatako, waakiri tobikwata na ngalo nga si nsabike.
Cough and sneeze into your elbow or a tissue, and then immediately throw away the tissue and wash your hands.
Kolola era oyasimulire mu lukokola lwo oba mu kapapula akakozesebwa okwerongoosa, era amangu ago okasuule ate onaabe mu ngalo.
Don't stand or sit near people who might be sick.
Toyimirira oba kutuula kumpi na muntu ayinza okuba omulwadde.
Stay at least one meter – and ideally two meters (six feet) – away.
Weesuule waakiri mmita emu – naye n’gokusinga mmita bbiri (fuuti mukaaga) – okuva ku muntu omulala.
As a quick way to eyeball this distance, imagine that you and the other person both reached your hands towards each other.
Ng’engeri ennyangu ey’okunnyonnyolamu ebbanga lino, kitwale nti ggwe n’omuntu omulala mwembi mwegololedde emikono.
Could you touch the other person's hand without taking a step towards that person?
Osobola okukwata ku mukono gw’omuntu omulala nga toseetudde kigere kweyongera gy’ali?
If the answer is yes, then you're too close.
Bwe kiba nga kisoboka, kitegeeza nti musembereganye nnyo.
Clean objects and surfaces that a lot of people touch, such as doorknobs, phones, and television remotes with regular household cleaner.
Yonja ebintu n’ekungulu kw’ebintu abantu kwe bakwata, gamba nga eminyolo, essimu, ne limooti za ttivvi ng’okozesa bye muyonjesa ewaka ebya bulijjo.
Disinfect the surfaces with a suitable disinfectant, such as diluted household bleach.
Tta obuwuka obuli kungulu ku bintu n’ekitta obuwuka ekisaanidde, gamba ng’ebirungo ebipeeruusa nga bijaabuluddwa.
Stay home when you are sick, and avoid contact with other people until your symptoms are gone.
Sigala ewaka nga oli mulwadde, era weewale okukwatagana n’abantu abalala okutuusa ng’obubonero bw’obulwadde bugenze.
Do not share personal items that come into contact with saliva, such as toothbrushes, eating utensils, drinks, water bottles, and towels.
Togabana bintu byo ebikwatagana n’amalusu, gamba nga obusenya, ebiriirwako, eby’okunywa, eccupa z’amazzi, ne tawulo.
The practice of serving yourself from a common plate with your own chopsticks, common in China, should be avoided.
Enkola ey’okuliira ku ssowaani emu newankubadde ng’oliisa buti bwo, ekirabikira ennyo mu China, kisaanye okwewalibwa.
Greet people without touching them.
Buuza abantu nga tobakutteeko
Avoid hugs, kisses, handshakes, fist bumps, and any other contact.
Weewale okugwa mu kifuba, okunywegera, okukwata mu ngalo, okubonga, n’okukwatagana okulala kwonna.
If it's impossible to avoid contact, then wash your hands both before and after.
Bwe kiba nga tekisoboka kwewala kukwatagana na bantu balala, olwo nno naaba mu ngalo zo nga tonnakwatagana nabo n’oluvannyuma ng’omaze.
It won't protect you from the coronavirus, but it will partially protect you from the flu, which remains a greater risk than COVID-19 in many areas.
Tekijja kukutangira kawuka ka corona, naye kijja kuyambako okukutangira sennyiga, alabika nga wa bulabe bwa maanyi n’okusinga COVID-19 mu bitundu bingi.
This also saves you from unnecessary worry if you get the flu and think it might be the coronavirus.
Kino era kikutaasa okweraliikirira okuteetaagisa singa ofuna sennyiga n’olowooza nti oboolyawo kawuka ka corona.
If you are elderly or otherwise in a high-risk group and can be vaccinated for pneumonia, get that vaccination.
Bw’oba ng’okaddiye oba ng’oli mu ttuluba lyabo abanguyirwa okukosebwa ng’osobola okugemebwa lubyamira, genda ogemebwe.

It won't protect you from viral pneumonia from COVID-19, but some COVID-19 patients have died of bacterial pneumonia that attacked their weakened lungs, so a pneumonia vaccination could save your life.
Tekiggya kukutangira kufuna lubyamira ava ku COVID-19, naye abalwade ba COVID-19 abamu bafudde lubyamira eyakwata amawuge gaabwe aganafuye, noolwekyo okukugema lubyamira kyanditaasa obulamu bwo.
Wearing masks is recommended for those who are suspected of carrying of disease and those who are in close contact with those infected.
Okwambala obukookolo kisembebwa eri abo abasuubirwa okuba nga balina obulwadde wamu n’abo abasemberera abalwadde.
For those who are asymptomatic, the WHO does not recommend masks, though some national governments do.
Eri abo abatalina kabonero konna, ekibiina kya WHO tekibasemba kwambala bukookolo, newankubadde nga gavumenti ezimu zikikaka.
Wearing a mask of some kind is required in some countries and cities in an effort to reduce community transmission.
Okwambala akakookolo ak’engeri yonna kya buwaze mu nsi ezimu n’ebibuga mu kaweefube w’okukendeeza okusaasaana kw’akawuka mu bantu.
There are worldwide shortages of surgical masks.
Waliwo ebbula ly’obukookolo obukozesebwa mu kujjanjaba okwetoloola ensi yonna.
If you do wear a mask, make sure to use it correctly.
Bw’oba ng’oyambadde akakookolo, kakasa nti okakozesa bulungi.
The mask should cover your nose and mouth and fit without gaps.
Akakookolo kalina okubikka ennyindo yo n’omumwa ne kagyako bulungi awatali kulekawo mabanga.
Wash your hands before putting on the mask and avoid touching the mask while wearing it.
Naaba mu ngalo nga tonnayambala kakookolo era weewale okukwata ku kakookolo ng’omaze okukambala.
If you do touch it, wash your hands immediately afterwards.
Bw’oba okakutteko, naaba mu ngalo amangu ddala nga waakamala okukakwatako.
When the mask becomes damp, discard and replace it.
Akakookolo singa kabisiwala, kasuule ofune akalala.
Remove it from the back, throw it away, and then wash your hands.
Kaggyeemu ng’okayisa mabega, okasuule, bw’omala onaabe mu ngalo.
Remember that masks are not a substitute for good hygiene: continue to wash your hands frequently.
Jjukira nti obukookolo tebutegeeza nti olwo omaze mu by’obuyonjo: genda mu maaso n’okunaaba mu ngalo buli kiseera.
Don't stock up on masks if you don't need them.
Totereka bukookolo bungi bw’oba nga tobwetaaga.
Mask shortages mean that healthcare workers are having trouble getting a hold of masks, which puts everyone at risk.
Ebbula ly’obukookolo litegeeza nti abajjanjabi bakaluubirirwa okubufuna, ekiteeka obulamu bwa buli muntu mu matigga.
That includes N95 respirators, which are not recommended for the general public – these are specialist equipment which must be fitted to be optimally effective.
Kino kizingiramu n’ebyuma ebiyambako mu kussa ebya N95, ebitasembebwa kukozesebwa buli muntu - bino byuma bya kikugu ebiteekeddwa okuteegekebwa mu butuufu bwabyo okusobola okukola obulungi.
Leave them for healthcare workers.
Birekere abajjanjabi.
Avoid crowded areas, especially enclosed areas without much air circulation, such as conferences, performances, shopping malls, public transportation, and religious services.
Weewale ebifo omuli abantu abangi, naddala ebizimbe ebitalina bulungi w’oyisiza mpewo, gamba ng’enkuŋŋaana, ebivvulu, ebifo by’obusuubuzi, entambula ey’olukale, n’enkuŋŋaana.
Events which involve a large scale gathering of people, from religious pilgrimages to music concerts, are being canceled worldwide, in an effort to contain the spread of the virus.
Emikolo egirimu okukuŋŋaanya abantu abangi, nga mwe muli okulamaga n’ebivvulu by’ennyimba, byasazibwamu mu nsi yonna, mu kaweefube w’okutangira okusaasaana kw’akawuka.
Tourist attractions, businesses, and transportation may be closed, especially in affected countries.
Ebisikiriza abalambuzi, bizinensi, n’eby’entambula biyinza okuggalwawo, naddala mu nsi ezikoseddwa.
Some canceled events, especially performances, sporting events, and classes, are being moved online, which means you can experience them without traveling.
Emikolo egimu egisaziddwamu, naddala ebivvulu, eby’emizannyo n’okuyigirizibwa, biteereddwa ku mitimbagano, ekitegeeza nti osobola okubifuna awatali kutambula.
At petrol/gas stations, use gloves or wipe down the handle with a disinfectant wipe if you can.
Ku masundiro g’amafuta/, kozesa giraavu oba simuula ku kikondo n’eddagala eritta obuwuka bw’oba osobola.
After filling up, clean your hands with hand sanitizer.
Bw’omala okuteekamu amafuta, yonja engalo zo n’eddagala eritta obuwuka bw’omu ngalo.
The U.S. and Canadian governments recommend avoiding travel by cruise ship.
Gavumenti za U.S. ne Canadian zisemba eky’okwewala okutambulira ku mmeeri.
Infections spread easily on board, and medical care is limited.
Obulwadde busaasaana mangu mu kusaabala, ate nga eby’obujjanjabi bitono ddala.
Amid a cruise ship outbreak, quarantines and docking are challenging partly due to the large number of people aboard.
Singa obulwadde bubalukawo ku mmeeri, kalantiini n’okugoba ku mwalo kizibuwala olw’ensonga nti abantu baba bangi ku mmeeri.

Even cruise ships without confirmed cases have been denied permission to dock due to virus fears, and in the high-profile case of the Diamond Princess in Japan, hundreds of people were infected on the ship.

N’amaato agasaabaza abantu agatalinaako mulwadde yenna akakasiddwa gagaaniddwa okugoba ku myalo olw’okutya akawuka, ate ku nsonga y’eryato eriyitibwa Diamond Princess mu Japan, ebikumi n’ebikumi by’abantu byakosebwa ku mmeeri.
If you believe you may be infected, call a hospital or local emergency medical services instead of going in person to avoid infecting others.

Bw’oba nga olowooza nti okwatiddwa obulwadde, kubira eddwaliro oba ab’ebyobulamu abakola ku bujjanjabi obw’amangu mu kitundu kyo essimu mu kifo ky’okwetwala ggwe okusobola okutangira okusiiga abalala.
Mention your symptoms and travel history.
Yogera ku bubonero by’ofunye ne gy’obadde otambulira.
Wear a medical mask and follow the instructions of authorities and doctors.
Yambala akakookolo era ogoberere ebiragiro ebikuweebwa ab’obuyinza n’abasawo.
See also: Flight and health
Laba ne bino: Okulinnya ennyonyi n’ebyobulamu
On a plane, follow the same hygiene practices as anywhere else: wash hands frequently, or use alcohol-based hand sanitizer if it's not convenient to leave your seat, and avoid touching your face.

Ku nnyonyi, gooberera amateeka g’eby’obuyonjo nga ewalala wonna: naaba mu ngalo buli kiseera, oba kozesa amazzi agalimu omwenge n’eddagala eritta obuwuka aganaabibwa mu ngalo (alcohol-based hand sanitizer) bwe kiba nga kikukaluubiriza okusituka w’otudde, era weewale okwekwata mu maaso.
Researchers have found that passengers in window seats have less risk of contact with sick people.
Abanoonyereza bakizudde nti abasaabaze abatuula mu bifo eby’oku madirisa si kyangu nnyo kusemberera bantu balwadde.
Try to book a window seat, and avoid moving around the cabin during the flight.
Fuba okufuna ekifo ky’oku ddirisa, era weewale okutambulatambula mu nnyonyi mu kiseera ky’olugendo.
After washing your hands and before sitting down, use disinfectant wipes to wipe down the area around your seat.
Bw’omala okunaaba mu ngalo nga tonnaba kutuula, kozesa obusiimuula obutta obuwuka okusiimuula awo awaliraanye w’otuula.
Wipe hard surfaces, and if your seat is leather you can wipe that too.
Siimuula kungulu w’ebintu ebikaluba, ate omusipi gwo bwe guba gwa ddiba nagwo osobola okugusiimuula.
Don't wipe a cloth seat, as the moisture can make transmission easier.
Entebe bw’eba ya lugoye tosiimuulako, kubanga okunnyuukirira kusobola okwanguyizaako okusaasaanya obulwadde.
When using disinfectant wipes, follow the instructions on the packaging.
Bw’oba ng’okozesa obusiimuula obutta obuwuka, goberera ebiragiro ebiri ku kisabika.
And remember, viruses enter through your mouth, nose, and eyes – wiping down the area doesn't hurt, but it's not a substitute for proper hygiene.
Jjukira nti, obuwuka buyingirira mu kamwako, ennyindo, n’amaaso - okusiimuula mu bifo ekyo tekirina buzibu, naye ate tekisaanidde kukolebwa nga kyekwaso obutakuuma bya buyonjo ebisaanidde.
Wash your hands and avoid touching your face.
Naaba mu ngalo era weewale okwekwata mu maaso.
And use a tissue to touch the touch screen or other controls.
Era kozesa akapapula akagonvu akeesiimuzibwa ng’okwata ku sikuliini oba ekintu ekirala.
When using the lavatory, use paper towels to turn off the faucet and open the door, then throw them away.
Bw’oba ng’okozesa kaabuyonjo, kozesa obutawulo obw’obupapula okunyoola omunyolo olwo ogulewo oluggi, oluvannyuma obutawulo obusuule.
Airlines in affected areas are taking steps to reduce transmission and keep passengers safe.
Ennyonyi eziri mu bifo ebikoseddwa zikola ekisoboka okukendeeza okusaasaana n’okukuuma abasaabaze nga tebalina buzibu.
For instance, these may include cleaning facilities more frequently, allowing flight attendants to wear masks, and serving prepackaged instead of freshly heated meals.
Okugeza, muno muyinza okubaamu okulongoosa ennyonyi buli kiseera, okukkiriza abakola ku nnyonyi okwambala obukookolo, n’okugaba eby’okulya ebyategekeddwa edda mu kifo ky’ebyo ebifumbiddwaawo.
