Two confirmed cases involved people who seemed to have caught the disease from their late father, who became ill after a visit to Qatar and Saudi Arabia.
Abalwadde ababiri abaakakasibwa baali bantu babiri abaalabika ng’obulwadde obwo baabuggya ku kitaabwe eyaafa, eyalwala ng’avudde mu lugendo lwe yaliko mu Qatar ne Saudi Arabia.
Despite this, it appears the virus had trouble spreading from human to human, as most individuals who are infected do not transmit the virus.
Wadde ng’ekyo kyaliwo, kirabika nti akawuka kaalina obuzibu okusaasaana okuva ku muntu omu okudda ku mulala, kubanga abantu abamu abalwala tebasiiga balala kawuka ako.
The final name for the virus is Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV).
Erinnya ly’akawuka erikakasiddwa lye lya Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV).

The only U.S. cases (both survived) were recorded in May 2014.In May 2015, an outbreak of MERS-CoV occurred in the Republic of Korea, when a man who had traveled to the Middle East, visited four hospitals in the Seoul area to treat his illness.

Abalwadde bokka abaali mu Amerika (bombi baawona) baalabibwa muGwakutaanu 2014. Mu Gwokutaanu 2015, okubalukawo kwa MERS-CoV kwagwawo mu Korea, omusajja eyali agenzeeko mu Middle East, yagenda okujjanjabibwa mu malwaliro ana mu kitundu ky’e Seoul.
This caused one of the largest outbreaks of MERS-CoV outside the Middle East.
Kino kyaleetawo okubalukawo kw’obulwadde bwa MERS-CoV, okumu ku okwo okukyasinze okuba okw’amaanyi ebweru wa Middle East.
As of December 2019, 2,468 cases of MERS-CoV infection had been confirmed by laboratory tests, 851 of which were fatal, a mortality rate of approximately 34.5%.
Mu Deesemba 2019, abalwadde 2,468 ba MERS-CoV baakakasibwa n’okukebera mu magezeserezo, abalwadde 851 baafa, bye 34.5% ku balwadde abo.
In December 2019, a pneumonia outbreak was reported in Wuhan, China.
Mu Deesemba 2019, lubyamira yabalukawo mu Wuhan, China era amawulire ne gafuluma.

On 31 December 2019, the outbreak was traced to a novel strain of coronavirus, which was given the interim name 2019-nCoV by the World Health Organization (WHO), later renamed SARS-CoV-2 by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses.

Nga 31 Deesemba 2019, obulwadde obwo bwalondoolwa ne bukwanyizibwa ku bulwadde bwa coronavirus obwaliwo awo mu kitundu, era mu kiseera WHO ne kibuwa erinnya ery’ekiseera 2019-nCoV, oluvannyuma Akakiiko k’Ensi yonna Akanoonyereza ku Buwuka, International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses ne babutuuma SARS-CoV-2.

Some researchers have suggested the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market may not be the original source of viral transmission to humans.As of 17 April 2020, there have been at least 153,822 confirmed deaths and more than 2,240,191 confirmed cases in the coronavirus pneumonia pandemic.

Abanoonyereza abamu balowooza nti akatale k’emmere akayitibwa Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market kayinza okuba nga si ye nsibuko y’okusaasaana kw’akawuka mu bantu. Olwa 17 Ogwokuna 2020 we lwatuukira, waakiri abantu nga 153,822 baali bafudde era n’abalwadde ba nawookeera wa lubyamula nga baweze 2,240,191.
The Wuhan strain has been identified as a new strain of Betacoronavirus from group 2B with approximately 70% genetic similarity to the SARS-CoV.
Obulwadde bw’omu Wuhan bulabiddwa nga ng’obulwadde obupya obwa Betacoronavirus okuva mu kibinja 2B ng’ebitundu kumpi 70% eby’endagabutonde bifaanana ne SARS-CoV.
The virus has a 96% similarity to a bat coronavirus, so it is widely suspected to originate from bats as well.
Akawuka kafaanana ne bat coronavirus ebitundu 96%,bwe katyo kateeberezebwa okuba nga nako kaava mu buwundo.
The pandemic has resulted in travel restrictions and nationwide lockdowns in several countries.
Nawookeera aleeseewo okukugirwa mu ntambula wamu n’emiggalo egisaanira eggwanga eddamba mu mawanga mangi mu nsi.
Coronaviruses have been recognized as causing pathological conditions in veterinary medicine since the 1930s.
Coronavirus zirabiddwa ng’ezireeta obulwadde mu nsolo okuva mu myaka gya 1930.
Except for avian infectious bronchitis, the major related diseases have mainly an intestinal location.
Ng’oggyeeko obulwadde bwa avian infectious bronchitis, obulwadde obukulu obwefaanaanyiriza okusinga bubeera mu byenda.
Coronaviruses primarily infect the upper respiratory and gastrointestinal tract of mammals and birds.
Okusinga ennyo Coronavirus zikwata kitundu kya mussizo ekyawaggulu mu nsolo ne mu binyonyi.
They also cause a range of diseases in farm animals and domesticated pets, some of which can be serious and are a threat to the farming industry.
Era zireeta n’obulwadde obw’enjawulo mu nsolo ezirundibwa n’obusolo obuzannyisibwa obubeera ewaka, obulwadde obwo obumu busobola okubeera obw’amaanyi era ne bukaluubiriza n’omulimu gw’obulunzi.
In chickens, the infectious bronchitis virus (IBV), a coronavirus, targets not only the respiratory tract but also the urogenital tract.
Mu nkoko, akawuka kano infectious bronchitis virus (IBV), ak’ekika kya coronavirus, tekalumba mussizo gwokka wabula n’omuyitiro gw’omusulo (urogenital tract).
The virus can spread to different organs throughout the chicken.
Akawuka kasobola okusaasaanira mu bitundu by’enkoko eby’enjawulo.

Economically significant coronaviruses of farm animals include porcine coronavirus (transmissible gastroenteritis coronavirus, TGE) and bovine coronavirus, which both result in diarrhea in young animals.

Mu byenfuna, obuwuka bu-coronavirus obulumba ensolo z’omu malundiro mulimu porcine coronavirus (transmissible gastroenteritis coronavirus, TGE) ne bovine coronavirus, obuwuka bwombi obwo buleeta ekiddukano mu nsolo ento.

Feline coronavirus: two forms, feline enteric coronavirus is a pathogen of minor clinical significance, but spontaneous mutation of this virus can result in feline infectious peritonitis (FIP), a disease associated with high mortality.

Feline coronavirus: karimu enkula za mirundi ebiri, feline enteric coronavirus kawuka akaleeta obulwadde akatatiisa nnyo, naye akasolo kano bwe kazaalukana ennyo kasobola okuleeta obulwadde obuyitibwa infectious peritonitis (FIP), obulwadde buno butta nnyo.

Similarly, there are two types of coronavirus that infect ferrets: Ferret enteric coronavirus causes a gastrointestinal syndrome known as epizootic catarrhal enteritis (ECE), and a more lethal systemic version of the virus (like FIP in cats) known as ferret systemic coronavirus (FSC).

Mu ngeri y’emu, waliwo ebika bya coronavirus bibiri ebikosat ferret: Ferret enteric coronavirus kalwaza ebyenda (gastrointestinal syndrome) era obulwadde buno buyitibwa epizootic catarrhal enteritis (ECE), ate kyo ekika ky’akawuka kano ekisinga okuba eky’obulabe (gamba nga FIP mu mmese) kiyitibwa ferret systemic coronavirus (FSC).
There are two types of canine coronavirus (CCoV), one that causes mild gastrointestinal disease and one that has been found to cause respiratory disease.
Waliwo ebika bibiri ebya canine coronavirus (CCoV), akamu kaleeta obulwadde obuyitibwa mild gastrointestinal n’akalala akazuuliddwa nga kaleeta obulwadde mu mussizo.
Mouse hepatitis virus (MHV) is a coronavirus that causes an epidemic murine illness with high mortality, especially among colonies of laboratory mice.
Mouse hepatitis virus (MHV) kika kya coronavirus akaleeta epidemic murine illness, obulwadde buno butta okukamala, naddala mu Magana ga mususu ow’omu magezeserezo.
Sialodacryoadenitis virus (SDAV) is highly infectious coronavirus of laboratory rats, which can be transmitted between individuals by direct contact and indirectly by aerosol.

Sialodacryoadenitis virus (SDAV) ko kawuka akaleeta ennyo obulwadde mu mmese z’omu ggezeserezo, obulwadde obwo busobola okusaasaanyizibwa abantu kinnoomu nga bakwataganye butereevu ate n’obutali butereevu okuyitira mu nnyindo (aerosol).
Some strains of MHV cause a progressive demyelinating encephalitis in mice which has been used as a murine model for multiple sclerosis.
Obulwadde obumu obwa MHV buleeta progressive demyelinating encephalitis mu mususu akozeseddwa ng’ageraageranyizibwako (murine model) mu multiple sclerosis.
Significant research efforts have been focused on elucidating the viral pathogenesis of these animal coronaviruses, especially by virologists interested in veterinary and zoonotic diseases.

Kaweefube w’okunoonyereza awerako ateereddwa mu kwongera okunnyonnyola enkula y’akawuka ak’omu nsolo (animal coronaviruses), naddala abanoonyereza ku buwuka abanoonyereza ku ntambula y’obulwadde okuva mu nsolo okudda mu bantu.
Porcine coronavirus (transmissible gastroenteritis coronavirus of pigs, TGEV).
Akawukaka ka Porcine coronavirus (transmissible gastroenteritis coronavirus ow’omu mbizzi, TGEV).
Bovine coronavirus (BCV), responsible for severe profuse enteritis in of young calves.
Akawuka ka Bovine coronavirus (BCV), akasaasaanya severe profuse enteritis mu nnyana.
Feline coronavirus (FCoV) causes mild enteritis in cats as well as severe Feline infectious peritonitis (other variants of the same virus).
Akawuka ka Feline coronavirus (FCoV) kaleeta mild enteritis mu kkapa wamu ne mu severe Feline infectious peritonitis (ebika by’akawuka ako ebirala).
the two types of canine coronavirus (CCoV) (one causing enteritis, the other found in respiratory diseases).
ebika bya canine coronavirus (CCoV) ebibiri (ekimu nga kireeta enteritis, ate ekirala kisangibwa mu bulwadde bw’omussizo).
Turkey coronavirus (TCV) causes enteritis in turkeys.
Akawuka ka Turkey coronavirus (TCV) kaleeta enteritis mu ssekkoko.
Ferret enteric coronavirus causes epizootic catarrhal enteritis in ferrets.
Akawuka ka Ferret enteric coronavirus kaleeta epizootic catarrhal enteritis mu busolo obufaananako kkapa (ferrets).
Ferret systemic coronavirus causes FIP-like systemic syndrome in ferrets.
Akawuka ka Ferret systemic coronavirus kaleeta FIP-like systemic syndrome busolo obufaananako kkapa (ferrets).
Rabbit enteric coronavirus causes acute gastrointestinal disease and diarrhea in young European rabbits.
Akawuka ka Rabbit enteric coronavirus kaleeta acute gastrointestinal disease n’ekiddukano mu bumyu bw’e Bungereza obuto.
Porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PED or PEDV), has emerged around the world.
Akakawuka ka Porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PED oba PEDV), kabuluseewo mu nsi yonna.
b'Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is an infectious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
Obukwadde bwa b'Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) bulwadde obusiigibwa obuleetebwa severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
Common symptoms include fever, cough, and shortness of breath.
Mu bubonero obusinga okulabika mulimu omusujja, okukolola, n’okubaka omukka.
Other symptoms may include fatigue, muscle pain, diarrhea, sore throat, loss of smell, and abdominal pain.
Obubonero obulala mulimu kimenyoomenyo, obulumi mu binywa, embiro, amabwa mu mimiro, okulemererwa okuwunyiriza, n’okulumizibwa mu lubuto.
The time from exposure to onset of symptoms is typically around five days but may range from two to fourteen days.
Ebbanga okuva lwe bukwata omuntu okutuuka ku kiseera w’alabikirako obubonero litera kubeera awo mu nnaku ttaanu naye nga ziyinza okukyuka ne ziba wakati w’ennaku bbiri n’ekkumi na nnya.
While the majority of cases result in mild symptoms, some progress to viral pneumonia and multi-organ failure.
Weewaawo abalwadde abasinga beeyolekerako obubonero obutali bwa maanyi abamu bafuniramu ddala lubyamira n’ebitundu by’omubiriebimu ne biremererwa.
As of 17 April 2020, more than 2.24 million cases have been reported across 210 countries and territories, resulting in more than 153,000 deaths.
Olwa 17 Ogwokuna 2020 we lwatuukira, abalwadde abasukka mu bukadde 2.24 be bategeerekese mu mawanga n’ebitundu 210 era nga mu bo 153,000 bafudde.
More than 568,000 people have recovered.The virus is primarily spread between people during close contact, often via small droplets produced by coughing, sneezing, or talking.
Abantu abasukka 568,000 bawonye. Okusinga ennyo akawuka kasaasaanira mu bantu abasembereganye ennyo, naddala nga buyitira mu luzzizzi olujja omuntu ng’akolodde, ng’akubye omwasi, oba mu kwogera.
While these droplets are produced when breathing out, they usually fall to the ground or onto surfaces rather than being infectious over long distances.
Weewaawo oluzzizzi lufuluma omuntu ng’assizza omukka, lutera okugwa ku ttaka oba ku bintu, so tebukwata bantu beesudde bbanga ddene.
People may also become infected by touching a contaminated surface and then touching their eyes, nose, or mouth.
Abantu era basobola okukatibwa obulwadde nga bakutte ku kifo ekiriko obuwuka ate olwo ne beekwata mu maaso, mu nnyindo, oba ku mimwa.
The virus can survive on surfaces up to 72 hours.
Akawuka kasobola okubeera ku kintu okumala essaawa 72.

It is most contagious during the first three days after the onset of symptoms, although spread may be possible before symptoms appear and in later stages of the disease.The standard method of diagnosis is by real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) from a nasopharyngeal swab.

Kasinga kusiigibwa mu nnaku ezisooka essatu oluvannyuma lw’okulabika kw’obubonero, wadde ng’okusiigibwa kusoboka okubaawo ng’obubonero tebunneeyoleka ne ku mitendera gy’obulwadde egy’oluvannyuma. Akakodyo akasinga okukozesebwa okubukera ke ka real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) nga baggya oluzzizzi mu mussizo.
The use of masks is recommended for those who suspect they have the virus and their caregivers.
Kisembebwa okukozesa obukookolo ku abo abateebereza nti balina akawuka wamu n’abo ababalabirira.
Recommendations for mask use by the general public vary, with some authorities recommending against their use, some recommending their use, and others requiring their use.
Ebisembebwa mu kukozesa obukookolo mu bantu bonna, ate ng’aboobuyinza abamu babugaana, abamu basemba okubukozesa ate abalala nga bataddewo ekiragiro okubukozesa.
Currently, there is no vaccine or specific antiviral treatment for COVID-19.
Mu kiseera kino, tewali ddagala ligema oba erikkakkanya ku COVID-19.
Local transmission of the disease has been recorded in most countries across all six WHO regions.
Okusaasaana kw’obulwadde munda mu mawanga kulabiddwa mu mawanga mangi ag’enjawulo mu bitundu bya WHO omukaaga.
Those infected with the virus may be asymptomatic or develop flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, fatigue, and shortness of breath.
Abo abakwatiddwa obulwadde bayinza obuteeyolekerako bubonero oba obutafuna bubonero bwekwanya ku ssenyiga nga omusujja, okukolola, ekimenyoomenyo, n’okukaluubirirwa okussa.

Emergency symptoms include difficulty breathing, persistent chest pain or pressure, confusion, difficulty waking, and bluish face or lips; immediate medical attention is advised if these symptoms are present.

Mu bubonero obw’amangu mulimu okukaluubirirwa mu kussa, okulumizibwa mu kifuba okutatadde oba okunyigirizibwa, okutabukatabuka, okukalemererwa okutambula n’okumyukirira mu maaso oba mu ku mimwa; kyamagezi okufuna obujjanjabi obw’amangu obubonero obwo bwe bugaana okugenda.
Less commonly, upper respiratory symptoms such as sneezing, runny nose or sore throat may be seen.
Obubonero obutatera kulabika mulimu, upper obubonero bw’omussizo ogwawaggulu gamba ng’okukuba emyasi, eminyira egikulukuta oba amabwa mu nnyindo.
Gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea have been observed in varying percentages.
Obubonero obwekwanya n’omuyungiro gw’olubuto (Gastrointestinal symptoms) gamba nga such as okusinduukirirwa emmeeme, okusesema n’embiro bulabiddwa mu bigero eby’enjawulo.
Some cases in China initially presented only with chest tightness and palpitations.
Mu kusooka, abalwadde abamu mu China basooka kuwulira kuzitoowererwa mu kifuba n’entunnunsi okukubira okumukumu.
In some, the disease may progress to pneumonia, multi-organ failure, and death.
Mu bantu abamu, obulwadde busobola okweyongera okukula ne buvaamu lubyamira, ebitundu by’eomubiri ebiwera okulemererwa okukola, n’okufa.
This is called the incubation period.
Kino kiyitibwa ekiseera ky’okuzaalukana.
The incubation period for COVID-19 is typically five to six days but may range from two to 14 days.
Ekiseera ky’okuzaalukana ekya COVID-19 kiri awo wakati w’ennaku ttaanu n’omukaaga naye nga kisobola okusingawo ne kiba wakati w’ennaku bbiri ne 14.
97.5% of people who develop symptoms will do so within 11.5 days of infection.Reports indicate that not all who are infected develop symptoms.
Abantu ebitundu 97.5% abafuna obubonero, babufuna mu nnaku 11.5 nga bamaze okukwatibwa obulwadde. Alipoota ziraga nti si buli akwatibwa obulwadde nti yeeyolekerako obubonero.
The role of these asymptomatic carriers in transmission is not yet fully known; however, preliminary evidence suggests that they may contribute to the spread of the disease.
Omulimu gw’abo abatalabikirako bubonero mu kusaasaanya obulwadde tegunnaba kumanyika mu bujjuvu; wabula, obubaka obusookerwao bulaga nti basobola okusaasaanya obulwadde.

The proportion of infected people who do not display symptoms is currently unknown and being studied, with the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (KCDC) reporting that 20% of all confirmed cases remained asymptomatic during their hospital stay.

Ekitungu ky’abantu abalwadde abateeyolekerako bubonero tegumanyiddwa mu kiseera kino era bakyanoonyerezebwako, era ng’Ekitongole kya Korea ekiyitibwa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (KCDC) kyategeeza nti abalwadde abakakasiddwa ebitundu 20% baali tebeeyolekerako bubonero mu kiseera we baabeerera mu ddwaliro.
China's National Health Commission began including asymptomatic cases in its daily cases on 1 April; of the 166 infections on that day, 130 (78%) were asymptomatic at the time of testing.

Ekitongole kya China ekya National Health Commission kyatandika okubala abalwadde abateeyolekerako bubonero mu balwadde ba buli lunaku nga 1 Ogwokuna; ku balwadde 166 ab’olunaku olwo, abalwadde 130 (78%) tebeeyolekerako bubonero mu kiseera we baabakeberera.
Both sputum and saliva can carry large viral loads.
Ebikolondolwa n’amalusu bisobola okubeeramu obuwuka obuwerera ddala.
Loud talking releases more droplets than normal talking.
Okwogerera waggulu kuleetera omuntu okuvaamu oluzzizzi okusinga okwogera okwabulijjo.
A study in Singapore found that an uncovered cough can lead to droplets travelling up to 4.5 meters (15 feet).
Okunoonyereza mu Singapore kwazuula nti omuntu bw’akolola nga tabisse ku mimwa kumuleetera okuvaamu oluzzizzi olusammukira mu bbanga lya mmita 4.5 (fuuti 15).

Though the virus is not generally airborne, the National Academy of Science has suggested that bioaerosol transmission may be possible and air collectors positioned in the hallway outside of people's rooms yielded samples positive for viral RNA.

Wadde ng’akutwaliza awamu akawuka tekasaasaanira mu mpewo, ekitongole kya National Academy of Science kigamba nti okusaasaana kw’omu mpewo okuyitibwa (bioaerosol transmission) kuyinza okusoboka era obuntu obukwata empewo obwateekebwa ebweru w’amanyumba g’abantu bwavaako sampolo eziraga nti zaalimu RNA.
Some medical procedures such as intubation and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) may cause respiratory secretions to be aerosolised and thus result in airborne spread.

Emitendera gy’eddagala egimu gamba nga intubation ne cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) giyinza okubaamu obuntu obuva mu missizo obusaasaanyizibwa mu pewo bwe butyo ne buvaamu endwadde ezisaasaanyirizibwa mu mpewo.

While there are concerns it may spread via feces, this risk is believed to be low.The virus is most contagious when people are symptomatic; while spread may be possible before symptoms emerge, the risk is low.

Weewaawo waliwo okutya nti obulwadde buyinza okusaasaana nga buyitira mu bubi, obulabe bwa kino bulowoozebwa okuba obutono. Akawuka kasinga kukwata ng’abalwadde beeyolekerako obubonero; wadde ng’okusiiga kusoboa ng’obubonero tebuneeyoleka, obulabe bwa kino butono.

The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) says while it is not entirely clear how easily the disease spreads, one person generally infects two to three others.The virus survives for hours to days on surfaces.

Ekitongol kya Bulaaya ekirwanyisa endwadde ekiyitibwa European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) kigamba nti wadde nga tekitangala bulungi ku bwangu endwadde kw’esaasaanira, okutwaliza awamu, omuntu omu asiiga abantu babiri oba basatu abalala. Akawuka kamala ebbanga eriri wakati w’essaawa n’ennaku nga kali kungulu ku bintu.
Specifically, the virus was found to be detectable for one day on cardboard, for up to three days on plastic (polypropylene) and stainless steel (AISI 304), and for up to four hours on 99% copper.

Okusinga ennyo, akawuka kalabiddwa nga kasobola okukengebwa nga kamaze olunaku lumu ku kabada, n’ennaku ssatu ku pulasitiika (polypropylene) ne ku bintu ebitatalagga (AISI 304), ate n’okumala essaawa nnya ku bintu ebirimu kkopa aweza ebitundu 99%.
This, however, varies depending on the humidity and temperature.
Wabula, ebbanga lino lyawuka okusinziira ku luzzi oluli mu bbanga n’ebbugumu.
Soap and detergent are also effective if correctly used; soap products degrade the virus' fatty protective layer, deactivating it, as well as freeing them from skin and other surfaces.

Ssabbuuni n’ebirungo ebirongoosa (detergent) nabyo bikola bulungi bwe bikozesebwa obulungi; ebintu ebirimu ssabbuuni bitta olususu lw’akawuka olukakuuma, bikamalamu amaanyi era bikaggyako olukuta lwonna n’okubugoba ku bintu ebirala.

Other solutions, such as benzalkonium chloride and chlorhexidine gluconate (a surgical disinfectant), are less effective.In a Hong Kong study, saliva samples were taken a median of two days after the start of hospitalization.

Ebintu ebirala ebiyiika nga benzalkonium chloride ne chlorhexidine gluconate (ekirungo ekitta obuwuka ekikozesebwa mu kulongoosa abantu), tebikola bulungi. Mu kunoonyereza okwakolebwa mu Hong Kong, sampolo z’amalusu zaggyibwa ku bantu mu kigero ky’ennaku nga bbiri nga bamaze okuweebwa ebitanda.
In five of six patients, the first sample showed the highest viral load, and the sixth patient showed the highest viral load on the second day tested.
Ku balwadde abantu ku mukaaga, sampolo eyasooka yalaga nti erimu obuwuka bungi ate omulwadde owoomukaaga yalabika ng’alina obuwuka bungi ku lunaku olwokubiri lwe yakeberwa.

Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is a novel severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus, first isolated from three people with pneumonia connected to the cluster of acute respiratory illness cases in Wuhan.

Akawka ka Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) kawuka ka akakosa omussizo akayitibwa novel severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus, akaasooka okulabibwa mu bantu basatu abaalina lubyamira nga yeekwanya ku bulwadde obw’amaanyi obukosa omussizo obwalabibwa mu balwadde mu Wuhan.
All features of the novel SARS-CoV-2 virus occur in related coronaviruses in nature.
Obubonero bwonna obwa novel SARS-CoV-2 virus bujjawo mu buwuka bwonna obwekwanya ne coronaviruses mu kikula.
Outside the human body, the virus is killed by household soap, which bursts its protective bubble.SARS-CoV-2 is closely related to the original SARS-CoV.

Akawuka ako bwe kabeera ebweru w’omubiri gw’omuntu gaka nga kakwataganye ssabbuuni, ssabbuuni abalusa olwovuyovu lw’akawuka olukabeera ebweru. SARS-CoV-2 kakwatagana bulungi n’akawuka ka SARS-CoV akaasooka.

The lungs are the organs most affected by COVID-19 because the virus accesses host cells via the enzyme angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), which is most abundant in the type II alveolar cells of the lungs.

Amawuggwe ge gasinga okukosebwa COVID-19 kubanga akawuka kayingira mu butaffaali nga kayitira mu enzyme angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), akasinga okulabikira mu type II alveolar cells mu mawuggwe.
The virus uses a special surface glycoprotein called a "spike" (peplomer) to connect to ACE2 and enter the host cell.
Akawuka kakozesa olususu olw’enjawulo olwa glycoprotein oluyitibwa "eriggwa" (peplomer) okweyunga ku ACE2 ne kayingir amu kataffaali kwe keekwata.
Acute cardiac injury was found in 12% of infected people admitted in hospital in Wuhan, China, and is more frequent in severe disease.
Okukosebwa kw’omutima okw’amaanyi kwasangibwa mu balwadde ebitundu 12% abaaweebwa ebitanda mu Wuhan, China, era kalabika nnyo mu ndwadde ez’amaanyi.

Rates of cardiovascular symptoms is high, owing to the systemic inflammatory response and immune system disorders during disease progression, but acute myocardial injury may also be related to ACE2 receptors in the heart.

Ekigero ky’obubonero obwekwanya ku mutima n’emisiwa (cardiovascular symptoms) kiri waggulu, nga kiva ku systemic inflammatory response n’obuzibu mu muyungiro gw’obusibage mu kiseera ky’okweyongera kw’obulwadde, naye acute myocardial injury buyinza nabwo okuba nga bwekwanya ku ACE2 receptors mu mutima.
ACE2 receptors are highly expressed in the heart and are involved in heart function.
ACE2 receptors zirabikira nnyo mu mutima era zeetaba mu nkola y’omutima.

A high incidence of thrombosis (31%) and venous thromboembolism (25%) have been found in ICU patients with COVID-19 infections and may be related to poor prognosis.Autopsies of people who died of COVID-19 have found diffuse alveolar damage (DAD), and lymphocyte-containing inflammatory infiltrates within the lung.

ekizibu ky’okwekwata kw’omusaayi (31%) n’okuzibikira kw’emisiwa (venous thromboembolism) (25%) bisangiddwa mu balwadde ba COVID-19 abeetaaga abujjanjabi obw’enjawulo abalina era nga buyinza okuba nga bwekwanya ku nteebereza enkyamu. Okukebera emirambo gy’abantu abafudde COVID-19 kuzudde diffuse alveolar damage (DAD), n’obusibage bw’obutaffaali omuli omusaayi ogwekutt mu mawuggwe.
Although SARS-COV-2 has a tropism for ACE2-expressing epithelial cells of the respiratory tract, patients with severe COVID-19 have symptoms of systemic hyperinflammation.
Newankubadde nga SARS-COV-2 atambulira ku kusikirizibwa kwa ACE2-omuli epithelial cells ez’omussizo, abalwadde ba COVID-19 abayi balina obubonero bwa systemic hyperinflammation.
In particular, pathogenic GM-CSF-secreting T-cells were shown to correlate with the recruitment of inflammatory IL-6-secreting monocytes and severe lung pathology in COVID-19 patients.
Okusinga ennyo, pathogenic GM-CSF-secreting T-cells zaalagibwa okuba nga zikwatagana ne inflammatory IL-6-secreting monocytes ne severe lung pathology mu balwadde ba COVID-19.
Lymphocytic infiltrates have also been reported at autopsy.
Obukulungwa obwekwafu (Lymphocytic infiltrates) bulabiddwako mu kukebera emirambo egifudde.
The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease.
WHO kifulumiza enseetuka y’okunoonyereza ku bulwadde buno nnyingi.
The standard method of testing is real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR).
Okukbera okwa bulijjo kwe kwa real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR).
The test is typically done on respiratory samples obtained by a nasopharyngeal swab; however, a nasal swab or sputum sample may also be used.
Okukebera kuno kutera kukolebwa ku sampolo eziggyibwa mu mussizo era nga zifunibwa ne swab ey’omu mussizo; wabula swab ey’omu nnyindo oba ekikolondolwa nabyo bisobola okukozesebwa.
Results are generally available within a few hours to two days.
Ebivaamu bitera okufunibwa mu bbanga eriri wakati w’essaaawa entonotono n’ennaku bbiri.
Blood tests can be used, but these require two blood samples taken two weeks apart and the results have little immediate value.
Okukebera omusaayo nakwo kusobola okukozesebwa naye sampolo ezo zirina okubeera bbiri nga ziggyibwa ku muntu mu bbanga lya wiiki bbiri ezeesudde era ebivaamu tebitera kugasa mu kaseera ak’amangu.

Chinese scientists were able to isolate a strain of the coronavirus and publish the genetic sequence so laboratories across the world could independently develop polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests to detect infection by the virus.

Bannassaayansi b’e China baalengera obulwadde bwa coronavirus era ne bafulumya ebikwata ku bulwadde obwo (genetic sequence) olwo amagezeserezo mu nsi yonna ne gaba nga gasobola, kinnalimu okukola ku nteekateeka y’okukebera obulwadde bw’akawuka ako (polymerase chain reaction) (PCR).
As of 4 April 2020, antibody tests (which may detect active infections and whether a person had been infected in the past) were in development, but not yet widely used.

Nga 4 Ogwokuna 2020, okukebera abasirikale b’omubiri (okusobola okukenga obulwadde obuli mu mubiri n’oba ng’omuntu yabadde alwadde emabegako) kwali mu nkulaakulanya, naye nga kwali tekunnaba kukozesebwa wonna.
The Chinese experience with testing has shown the accuracy is only 60 to 70%.
Obumanyirivu bw’okukebera mu China bulaze nti obutuufu bw’okukbera wakati w’ebitundu 60 okutuuka ku 70% byokka.

The FDA in the United States approved the first point-of-care test on 21 March 2020 for use at the end of that month.Diagnostic guidelines released by Zhongnan Hospital of Wuhan University suggested methods for detecting infections based upon clinical features and epidemiological risk.

Ekitongole kya FDA mu Amerika kyayisa okukebera okw’amangu okukolebwa ku mulwadde (first point-of-care test) okukozesebwa nga 21 Ogwokusatu 2020 ku nkomerero y’omwezi ogwo. Ebigobererwa mu kukebera ebyafulumizibwa eddwaliro Zhongnan Hospital mu Wuhan University byalimu okuteesa obukodyo obw’okukenga obulwadde nga bwesigamiziddwa ku bubonero n’obulabe obw’engeri y’okunoonyereza ku bulwadde(features and epidemiological risk).
Bilateral multilobar ground-glass opacities with a peripheral, asymmetric and posterior distribution are common in early infection.
Bilateral multilobar ground-glass opacities with a peripheral, asymmetric and posterior distribution are common in early infection.
Subpleural dominance, crazy paving (lobular septal thickening with variable alveolar filling), and consolidation may appear as the disease progresses.
Bino biyinza okubaawo ng’obulwadde bugenda bukula Subpleural dominance, crazy paving (lobular septal thickening with variable alveolar filling), ne consolidation.
Few data are available about microscopic lesions and the pathophysiology of COVID-19.
Obubaka butono obuliwo ku bizimbulukusa (microscopic lesions) ne pathophysiology of COVID-19 butono ddala.
The main pathological findings at autopsy are:
Ebizuuliddwa ebikulu mu kukebera abantu abafudde bye bino:
Macroscopy: pleurisy, pericarditis, lung consolidation and pulmonary oedema
Macroscopy: pleurisy, pericarditis, lung consolidation ne pulmonary oedema
Four types of severity of viral pneumonia can be observed:
Ebika bina ebikambwe ebya lubyamira asaasanyizibwa akawuka bye bisobola okwekkenneenyezebwa:
mild pneumonia: pulmonary oedema, pneumocyte hyperplasia, large atypical pneumocytes, interstitial inflammation with lymphocytic infiltration and multinucleated giant cell formation
lubyamira atali wa maanyi: pulmonary oedema, pneumocyte hyperplasia, large atypical pneumocytes, interstitial inflammation with lymphocytic infiltration ne multinucleated giant cell formation
severe pneumonia: diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) with diffuse alveolar exudates.
lubyamira omukambwe: diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) ne diffuse alveolar exudates.
DAD is the cause of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe hypoxemia.
DAD y’aleeta obuzibu obw’amaanyi mu kussa “acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)” ne hypoxemia ow’amaanyi.
healing pneumonia: organisation of exudates in alveolar cavities and pulmonary interstitial fibrosis
okuwonya lubyamira: oba enteekateeka y’ebiva mu bibuno by’ebijijo ne pulmonary interstitial fibrosis
Blood: disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC); leukoerythroblastic reaction
Omusaayi: disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC); leukoerythroblastic reaction

Preventive measures to reduce the chances of infection include staying at home, avoiding crowded places, washing hands with soap and water often and for at least 20 seconds, practising good respiratory hygiene and avoiding touching the eyes, nose or mouth with unwashed hands.

Ebikolebwa okukendeeza ku mikisa gy’okusiigibwa mulimu okubeera ewaka, okwewala ebifo ebirimu abantu abanti, okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni n’amazzi emirundi egiwera okumala waakiri sekonda 20, okweyisa mu ngeri ennyonjo ku by’engeri y’okussa n’okwewaka okukwata mu maaso, ennyindo oba mu kamwa nga tonnanaaba mu ngalo.
The CDC recommends covering the mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing or sneezing and recommends using the inside of the elbow if no tissue is available.
Ekitongole kya CDC kisemba okubikka ku mimwa n’ennyindo n’akagoye buli lw’obeera ng’okolola oba okukuba emyasi era kisemba okufunya omukono n’oyasimula oba okukolola bw’oba nga tolina kagoye.
Proper hand hygiene after any cough or sneeze is encouraged.
Okuyonja engalo obulungi engalo ng’omaze okukolola oba okukuba emyasi kisembebwa.

The CDC has recommended the use of cloth face coverings in public settings, in part to limit transmission by asymptomatic individuals.Social distancing strategies aim to reduce contact of infected persons with large groups by closing schools and workplaces, restricting travel and cancelling large public gatherings.

Ekitongole kya CDC kisemba okukozesa akagoye akabikka ku maaso ng’omuntu ali mu lujjudde, ekigendererwa ekimu mu kino kwe kwewala okusiiga obulwadde naddala ku balwadde abaneeyolekerako bubonero. Obukodyo bw’okwewa amabanga bugenderera okukendeeza ku kukwatagana kw’abantu abalina obulwadde n’ebibinja by’abantu ebinene ng’amasomero gaggalwa n’ebifo ebikolerwamu, okukugira okutambula n’okusazaamu enkuŋŋaana z’abantu abanti.
Distancing guidelines also include that people stay at least 6 feet (1.8 m) apart.
Ebigobererwa by’okwewa amabanga era bizingiramu n’okuba nti abantu beesuula waakiti fuuti 6 (1.8 m).

There is no medication known to be effective at preventing COVID-19.As a vaccine is not expected until 2021 at the earliest, a key part of managing COVID-19 is trying to decrease the epidemic peak, known as "flattening the curve".

Tewali ddagala limanyiddwa nga liziyiza COVID-19. Ekiseera eky’amangu eddagala erigema we lisuubirirwa okulabika, kiri mu mwaka gwa 2021, akakodyo ak’okulwanyisa COVID-19 kwe kugezaako okukendeeza okutumbiira kw’obulwadde, ekiyitibwa "okuseeteeza akoole".

The CDC also recommends that individuals wash hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after going to the toilet or when hands are visibly dirty, before eating and after blowing one's nose, coughing or sneezing.

Ekitongole kya CDC era kyasemba abantu kinnoomu okunaaba engalo ne ssabbuuni n’amazzi okumala waakiri sekonda 20, naddala nga bavudde mu kaabuyonjo oba ng’engalo zirabikira ddala nti ziddugala, nga tebannaba kulya ne nga bamaze okunyiza, okukolola oba okwasimulaalso.

It further recommends using an alcohol-based hand sanitiser with at least 60% alcohol, but only when soap and water are not readily available.For areas where commercial hand sanitisers are not readily available, the WHO provides two formulations for local production.

Ekitongole era kisemba okukozesa sanitizer alimu omwenge oguwera waakiri ebitundu 60%, naye ng’ekyo bakikola nga waakiri sabbuuni n’amazzi tebiriiwo. Mu bitundu ebitaliimu sanitizer zitundibwa, ekitongole kya WHO kiwa amagezi ga mirundi ebiri ku ngeri gye ziyinza okukolebwa.
In these formulations, the antimicrobial activity arises from ethanol or isopropanol.
Mu kukola batyo, enkola y’eddagala eritta obuwuka liva mu mwenge (ethanol) oba isopropanol.
Hydrogen peroxide is used to help eliminate bacterial spores in the alcohol; it is "not an active substance for hand antisepsis".
Hydrogen peroxide akozesebwa okuyambako okumalawo bacterial spores mu mwenge; si "kirungo ekikola okutta obuwuka mu ngalo (hand antisepsis)".
Glycerol is added as a humectant.
Glycerol ateekebwamu okuvaamu oluzzizzi (humectant.
People are managed with supportive care, which may include fluid therapy, oxygen support, and supporting other affected vital organs.
Abantu bakolebwamu na bujjanjabi obubawanirira, obuyinza okuzingiramu, amazzi, okuteekebwako omukka (oxygen), n’okuwanirira ebitundu by’omubiri ebiba bikoseddwa.
The CDC recommends that those who suspect they carry the virus wear a simple face mask.
Ekitongole kya CDC kisemba nti abo abateebereza nti balina akawuka, bambale akakookolo akangungu.
Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) has been used to address the issue of respiratory failure, but its benefits are still under consideration.
Okuteekebwako omukka (Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, ECMO) kukozeseddwa okukola ku kizibu ky’okulemererwa okussa naye ng’emiganyulo gy’enkola eno gikyatunuulirwa.
Personal hygiene and a healthy lifestyle and diet have been recommended to improve immunity.
Obuyonjo obw’omuntu kinnoomu n’okwefaako mu byobulamu n’okulya emmere erimu ebiriisa ey’enjawulo bisembebwa okwongera ku busibage bw’omuntu.

Supportive treatments may be useful in those with mild symptoms at the early stage of infection.The WHO and Chinese National Health Commission have published recommendations for taking care of people who are hospitalised with COVID-19.

Obujjanjabi obuwanirizi buyinza okuyamba abo abalina obubonero obutali bwa maanyi ng’obulwadde bwakabakwata. WHO ne Chinese National Health Commission bafulumizza ebisembebwa okujjanjaba abantu abaweereddwa ebitanda nga balina COVID-19.
Intensivists and pulmonologists in the U.S. have compiled treatment recommendations from various agencies into a free resource, the IBCC.

Abasawo abalabirira abalwadde abayi (Intensivists) n’abasawo abajjanjaba emissizo (pulmonologists) mu Amerika bawandiise ebyokukola ebisembebwa okuva mu bitongole eby’enjawulo ne babiteeka mu kiwandiiko ekyobwereere, IBCC.
As of April 2020, there is no specific treatment for COVID-19.
Mu Gwokuna 2020, tewali bujjanjabi bwa COVID-19 bwatuukiddwako.
For symptoms, some medical professionals recommend paracetamol (acetaminophen) over ibuprofen for first-line use.
Mu kujjanjaba obubonero, abakugu abamu basemba okukozesa paracetamol (acetaminophen) over ibuprofen ng’eddagala erisookerwako.
Precautions must be taken to minimise the risk of virus transmission, especially in healthcare settings when performing procedures that can generate aerosols, such as intubation or hand ventilation.

Okwegendereza kulina okubaawo okendeeza ku bulabe bw’okusiiga akawuka, nadddala mu malwaliro nga waliwo ebikolebwa ku mulwadde ebiyinza okuleeta oluzzizzi gamba ng’okuteekebwamu akaseke (intubation) oba ekyuma ekiyamba mu kussa ekikwatibwa mu ngalo (hand ventilation).

For healthcare professionals caring for people with COVID-19, the CDC recommends placing the person in an Airborne Infection Isolation Room (AIIR) in addition to using standard precautions, contact precautions and airborne precautions.The CDC outlines the guidelines for the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) during the pandemic.

Eri abasawo abajjanjaba abalwadde abalina COVID-19, ekitongole kya CDC kisemba okuteeka omuntu mu kisenge ekirimu obulungi empewo (AIIR) okwo nga kw’otadde okukozesa okwegendereza okwa bulijjo, okwegendereza kw’okukwatagana n’abantu n’okwegendereza okukwata ku mpewo. CDC kinokola ebigobererwa mu kukozesa ebyokwesabika (PPE) mu kiseera kya nawookeera.
The recommended gear is: PPE gown, respirator or facemask, eye protection, and medical gloves.When available, respirators (instead of facemasks) are preferred.
Ebyokwesabika ebisembebwa bye bino: egganduula, akassizibwamu, akakookolo, ekibikka amaaso, ne giravu z’ekisawo. Bwe biba nga weebiri, ebissizibwamu (mu kifo ky’obukookolo) bye bisingako.
N95 respirators are approved for industrial settings but the FDA has authorised the masks for use under an Emergency Use Authorisation (EUA).
Obussizibwamu obwa N95 busembebwa okukozesebwa mu bifo eby’amakolero naye FDA kyawa obuyinza okukozesa obukookolo mu kaseera k’amangu (EUA).
They are designed to protect from airborne particles like dust but effectiveness against a specific biological agent is not guaranteed for off-label uses.
Bikolebwa okukuuuma omuntu eri obutundutundu obutambulira mu mpewo gamba ng’enfuufu, nae obukuumi obwenkomeredde eri obuwuka tebwekakasika mu nkozesa etali ntuufu.
When masks are not available, the CDC recommends using face shields or, as a last resort, homemade masks.
Obukookolo bwe buba nga tebuliiwo, ekitongole kya CDC kisemba nti bwe waba nga tewali kyakukozesa, obukookolo obukolebwa ewaka busobola okukozesebwa.
Most cases of COVID-19 are not severe enough to require mechanical ventilation or alternatives, but a percentage of cases are.
Abalwadde ba COVID-19 abasinga tebaba bayi nnyo kutuuka ku ssa lya kubateekako mukka naye nga waliwo ekigero ky’abantu abagwetaaga.

The type of respiratory support for individuals with COVID-19 related respiratory failure is being actively studied for people in hospital, with some evidence that intubation can be avoided with a high flow nasal cannula or bi-level positive airway pressure.

Ekika ky’obuwanirizi bw’omussizo obwetaagisa ku bantu abalina obuzibu obwekwanya n’obwa COVID-19 mu kussa bwetegerezebwa naddala ku bantu abali mu malwaliro, era waliwo obubaka obulaga nti okuteekebwamu akapiira kuyinza okwewalibwa ne bakozesa high flow nasal cannula oba bi-level positive airway pressure.
Whether either of these two leads to the same benefit for people who are critically ill is not known.
Tekimanyiddwa oba ng’ekimu ku bino kivaamu ebirungi bye bimu eri abalwadde abali obubi.

Some doctors prefer staying with invasive mechanical ventilation when available because this technique limits the spread of aerosol particles compared to a high flow nasal cannula.Severe cases are most common in older adults (those older than 60 years, and especially those older than 80 years).

Abasawo abamu basinga kwagala kukozesa nkola ya invasive mechanical ventilation bw’eba nga weeri kubanga akakodyo kano kakendeeza ku nsaasaanya y’obutundutundu bw’ogeraageranya ne high flow nasal cannula. Abalwadde ababeera obubi basinga kulabikira mu bantu abakuluko (abo abasussa emyaka 60 ate naddala abo abasussa emyaka 80).

Many developed countries do not have enough hospital beds per capita, which limits a health system's capacity to handle a sudden spike in the number of COVID-19 cases severe enough to require hospitalisation.

Amawanga mangi agaakula edda tegalina bitanda by’abalwadde bimala bw’ogeraageranya n’omuwendo gw’abantu be balina, kino kikendeeza ku busobozi bw’amalwaliro okukola ku balwadde singa wabaawo embeera y’okutumbiira kw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 ate nga bonna beetaaga okuweebwa ebitanda.
One study in China found 5% were admitted to intensive care units, 2.3% needed mechanical support of ventilation, and 1.4% died.
Okunoonyereza okumu mu China kwazuula nti ebitundu 5% bassibwa ku bujjanjabi obwenjawulo mu malwaliro, ebitundu 2.3% baali beetaaga ebyuma ebissizibwamu ate ebitundu 1.4% baafa.
In China, approximately 30% of people in hospital with COVID-19 are eventually admitted to ICU.
Mu China, abantu nga 30% abalwadde ba COVID-19 nga bali mu malwaliro balwa ddaaki ne bassibwa ku bujjanjabi obw’enjawulo (ICU.
Mechanical ventilation becomes more complex as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) develops in COVID-19 and oxygenation becomes increasingly difficult.
Ekyuma ekissizibwamu (Mechanical ventilation) kyongera okuzibuwala kubanga obuwladde bwa acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) bujja ne COVID-19 era okufuna omukka nakwo kweyongera okuzibuwala.
Ventilators capable of pressure control modes and high PEEP are needed to maximise oxygen delivery while minimising the risk of ventilator-associated lung injury and pneumothorax.

Ebyuma ebissizzibwamu (Ventilators) ebisobola okukola ku kunyiriza ne PEEP owa waggulu (high PEEP) yeetaagibwa okuleeta omukka gwa oxygen ogumala ate nga waliwo n’okukendeeza ku bulabe obwekwanya ku kyuma ekissizzibwamu (risk of ventilator-associated lung injury and pneumothorax).
High PEEP may not be available on older ventilators.
PEEP eya waggulu (High PEEP) eyinza okuba nga teri ku byuma ebissizibwamu ebikadde.
Research into potential treatments started in January 2020, and several antiviral drugs are in clinical trials.
Okunoonyereza ku bujjanjabi obusoboka kwatandika mu Janwali 2020, era eddagala lingi erirwanyisa obuwuka (antiviral drugs) ligezesebwa mu kiseera kino.
Remdesivir appears to be the most promising.
Remdesivir lye lirabika okubaamu essuubi.
Although new medications may take until 2021 to develop, several of the medications being tested are already approved for other uses or are already in advanced testing.

Weewaawo ng’eddagala eppya liyinza okulwawo okukolebwa okutuuka eyo mu 2021, eddagala eddala erigezesebwa lyakakasibwa dda okukozesebwa ku bulwadde obulala era kati okugezesa kwalyo kuli ku mitendera gya waggulu.
Antiviral medication may be tried in people with severe disease.
Eddagala erirwanyisa obuwuka (Antiviral medication) liyinza okugezesebwa ku bantu abalina obulwadde obw’amaanyi.

The WHO recommended volunteers take part in trials of the effectiveness and safety of potential treatments.The FDA has granted temporary authorisation to convalescent plasma as an experimental treatment in cases where the person's life is seriously or immediately threatened.

WHO kyasemba bannakyewa okwetaba mu kugezesa enkola y’eddagala ennungi n’okulaba oba nga teririimu bulabe. Ekitongole kya FDA kiwadde olukusa olw’ekiseera ku convalescent plasma ng’obujjanjabi obw’ekiseera mu mbeera obulamu bw’omuntu obulamu bw’omuntu we bubeerera mu katyabaga.
It has not undergone the clinical studies needed to show it is safe and effective for the disease.
Terinnaba kunoonyerezebwako kwandiyinzizza kulaba oba nga teririimu bulabe n’okumanya oba nga lijjanjaba obulwadde obwo.
In February 2020, China launched a mobile app to deal with the disease outbreak.
Mu Gwokubiri 2020, China yatongolza app y’essimu z’omu ngalo okuyambako mu kulondoola okubalukawo kw’obulwadde.
Users are asked to enter their name and ID number.
Abakozesa basabibwa okuteekamu amannya gaabwe ne nnamba ya ID.
The app is able to detect 'close contact' using surveillance data and therefore a potential risk of infection.
App esobola okukenga 'okusembereganat' ng’ekozesa obubaka bw’okulondoola, noolwekyo eyambako okukenga obulabe bw’obulwadde obuyinza okujja.
Every user can also check the status of three other users.
Buli mukozesa asobola okukebera embeera y’abakozesa abalala basatu.

If a potential risk is detected, the app not only recommends self-quarantine, it also alerts local health officials.Big data analytics on cellphone data, facial recognition technology, mobile phone tracking and artificial intelligence are used to track infected people and people whom they contacted in South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore.

Bwe wabaawo obulabe obuyinza okugwawo obukengeddwa, app tekoma ku kukusemba kweteeka mu kalantiini, naye etemya ne ku boobuyinza abeebyobulamu mu kitundu. Big data analytics ku bubaka bw’essimu z’omu ngalo, tekinologiya akenga amaaso, okulondoola amasimu ag’omu ngalo ne artificial intelligence bikozesebwa okulondoola abantu abakwatiddwa obulwadde n’abantu be baakwataganyeeko nabo mu South Korea, Taiwan ne Singapore.
In March 2020, the Israeli government enabled security agencies to track mobile phone data of people supposed to have coronavirus.
Mu Gwokusatu 2020, gavumenti ya Yisirayiri yasobozesa ebitongole okulondoola obubaka bw’oku masimu g’omu ngalo ag’abantu abateeberezebwa okubeera ne coronavirus.
The measure was taken to enforce quarantine and protect those who may come into contact with infected citizens.
Kino kyakolebwa olw’okunyweza eky’abantu okweteeka mu kalantiini n’okukuuma abo abayinza okukwatagana n’abo abalina obulwadde.
Also in March 2020, Deutsche Telekom shared aggregated phone location data with the German federal government agency, Robert Koch Institute, in order to research and prevent the spread of the virus.

Mu Gwokusatu 2020, Deutsche Telekom yagabana obubaka obukwata ku bifo abantu we baba bali n’ekitongole kya gavumenti ekya, Robert Koch Institute, kikole okunoonyereza n’okutangira okusaasaanya obulwadde.
Russia deployed facial recognition technology to detect quarantine breakers.
Russia yakola tekinologiya akenga amaaso nga bagenderera okulaba abo abadduka mu kalantiini.
Italian regional health commissioner Giulio Gallera said he has been informed by mobile phone operators that "40% of people are continuing to move around anyway".
Omukungu w’Ekitongole kya Italy eky’Ebyobulamu, Giulio Gallera yagamba nti yategeezebwa ab’amasimu g’omu ngalo nti " abantu ebitundu 40% bakyeyongera okutambulatambula".
German government conducted a 48 hours weekend hackathon with more than 42.000 participants.
Gavumenti ya Bugirimaanyi yakola okunoonyereza kwa ssaawa 48 ku wiikend (hackathon) n’abeetabi abasukka mu 42.000.
Also the president of Estonia, Kersti Kaljulaid, made a global call for creative solutions against the spread of coronavirus.
Mu ngeri y’emu Pulezidenti wa Estonia, Kersti Kaljulaid, yakubira ensi yonna omulanga okuyiiya engeri ez’enjawulo ez’okulwanyisa coronavirus.
Individuals may experience distress from quarantine, travel restrictions, side effects of treatment or fear of the infection itself.
Abantu kinnoomu bayinza okwekyawa olwa Kalantiini, okukugirwa okutambula, okukosebwa okuva ku bujjanjabi oba okutya okubulwadde bwennyinis.
BBC quoted Rory O'Connor in saying, "Increased social isolation, loneliness, health anxiety, stress and an economic downturn are a perfect storm to harm people's mental health and wellbeing."

BBC yagamba nti Rory O'Connor yayogera ebigambo bino, "Okweyongera okweggya ku bantu, ekiwuubaalo, okucamuukiririra, okunyigirizibwa n’okweveera kw’ebyenfuna, bintu ebitaataaganya ebirowoozo n’embeera y’obulamu bw’abantu."
The disease may take a mild course with few or no symptoms, resembling other common upper respiratory diseases such as the common cold.
Obulwadde buyinza okujja nga si bwa maanyi ne bwoleka obubonero butono oba ne butalaga, nga bufaananako n’obwo obulala obutera okukwata omussizo ogwa waggulu gamba ssenyiga owa bulijjo.
Mild cases typically recover within two weeks, while those with severe or critical diseases may take three to six weeks to recover.

Obulwadde obutali bwa maanyi butera okugendera mu bbanga lya wiiki nga bbiri, ate obwo obw’amaanyi oba obulwadde obw’amaanyi buyinza okutwala ebbanga eriri wakati wa wiiki ssatu ne wiiki mukaaga okuwona.

Pregnant women may be at higher risk for severe infection with COVID-19 based on data from other similar viruses, like SARS and MERS, but data for COVID-19 is lacking.In some people, COVID-19 may affect the lungs causing pneumonia.

Abakyala abazito bayinzaokubeera mu bulabe bwa maani okukwatibwa COVID-19 okusinziira ku buwuka obulala nga SARS ne MERS, naye obubaka obukwata ku COVID-19 ku nsonga eno tebunnaba kufunika. Mu bantu abantu, COVID-19 ayinza okukosa amawuggwe olwo ne bafuna lubyamira.
In those most severely affected, COVID-19 may rapidly progress to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) causing respiratory failure, septic shock or multi-organ failure.

Eri abo abakoseddwa ennyo, COVID-19 ayinza okukulira ku mbiro n’afuukamu obulwadde obw’amaanyi obukosa omussizo (acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) ne kivaamu okulemererwa okussa, septic shock oba ebitundu by’omubiri ebiwera okulemererwa okukola emirimu gyabyo.
Complications associated with COVID-19 include sepsis, abnormal clotting and damage to the heart, kidneys and liver.
Obulwadde obwekwanya ku COVID-19 mulimu okulemererwa kw’ebitundu by’omubiri okukola (sepsis), okwekwata kw’omusaayi (abnormal clotting) n’okukosebwa ku mutima, ensigo n’ekibumba.

Clotting abnormalities, specifically an increase in prothrombin time, have been described in 6% of those admitted to hospital with COVID-19, while abnormal kidney function is seen in 4% of this group.

Okwekwata kw’omusaayi, naddala okweyongera kw’omusaayi okulwawo okwekwata (increase in prothrombin time), byonna ebyo birabiddwa mu balwadde ebitundu 6% abaweereddwa ebitanda mu ddwaliro olw’obulwadde bwa COVID-19, so ng’ate obuzibu bw’ensigo bulabiddwa mu balwadde abawera 4% mu kibinja ebyo.
Approximately 20-30% of people who present with COVID-19 demonstrate elevated liver enzymes (transaminases).
Abantu nga 20-30% abalina COVID-19 bazimba (elevated liver enzymes, transaminases).
According to the same report, the median time between onset of symptoms and death was ten days, with five being spent hospitalised.
Okusinziira ku alipoota y’emu eyo ekigero ky’obudde okuva obubonero lwe butandise n’okufa kyali ennaku kkumi ng’ennaku kkumi bazimala bali ku bitanda mu malwaliro.
However, patients transferred to an ICU had a median time of seven days between hospitalisation and death.
Wabula, abalwadde abateekebwa ku bujjanjabi obw’enjawulo (ICU) bwalina ekigero ky’obudde wakati w’ennaku musanvu ng’omulwadde ali mu ddwaliro n’okufa.
In a study of early cases, the median time from exhibiting initial symptoms to death was 14 days, with a full range of six to 41 days.
Mu kunoonyereza ku balwadde abaasooka, ekigero ky’obudde omuntu w’alagira obubonero n’okufa kyali wakati w’ennaku 14 n’ekirala wakati w’ennaku 6 n’ennaku 41.
In a study by the National Health Commission (NHC) of China, men had a death rate of 2.8% while women had a death rate of 1.7%.
Mu kunoonyereza kwa National Health Commission (NHC) mu China, omuwendo gw’abasajja abaali bafa baali awo ku bitundu 2.8% ate abasajja baali ku bitundu 1.7%.
Histopathological examinations of post-mortem lung samples show diffuse alveolar damage with cellular fibromyxoid exudates in both lungs.
Okukebera okwesigamiziddwa ku byafaayo (Histopathological examinations) ku sampolo z’abafu kulaga okukosebwa kwa diffuse alveolar damage wamu ne cellular fibromyxoid exudates mu mawuggwe gombi.
Viral cytopathic changes were observed in the pneumocytes.
Enkyukakyuka za Viral cytopathic zaalabibwa mu pneumocytes.
The lung picture resembled acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
Ekifaananyi ky’amawuggwe kyafaanana okuba n’obulwadde bwa acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
In 11.8% of the deaths reported by the National Health Commission of China, heart damage was noted by elevated levels of troponin or cardiac arrest.

Mu baafa ebitundu 11.8% ebyategeezebwa Ekitongole kya National Health Commission ekya China, okukosebwa kw’omutima kwalabibwa nga kulimu ebigero by’okulemererwa kw’omutima (troponin or cardiac arrest).
According to March data from the United States, 89% of those hospitalised had preexisting conditions.Availability of medical resources and the socioeconomics of a region may also affect mortality.

Okusinziira ku bubaka bw’omu Gwokusatu okuva mu United States, ebitundu 89% ku abo abaaweebwa ebitanda mu malwaliro baalina obulwadde obullala. Obujjanjabi obuli mu kitundu n’embeera y’ebyenfuna nabyo bisobola okwongeza ku muwendo gw’abalwadde abafa.
Estimates of the mortality from the condition vary because of those regional differences, but also because of methodological difficulties.
Okuteebereza kw’omuwendo gw’abafa kukyukakyuka kubanga mu bitundu ebyo mulimu enjawulo, naye era n’olw’obukalubo bw’enseetuka.
The under-counting of mild cases can cause the mortality rate to be overestimated.
Okubalira wansi abo abatali balwadde nnyo kisobola okuleetera omuwendo gw’abafa okubalirwa waggulu.
However, the fact that deaths are the result of cases contracted in the past can mean the current mortality rate is underestimated.
Wabula, olw’okuba nti abafa baba abo abafunye obulwadde ge buvuddeko, kisobola okutegeeza nti omuwendo gw’abafa gubalirwa wansi.

Smokers were 1.4 times more likely to have severe symptoms of COVID-19 and approximately 2.4 times more likely to require intensive care or die compared to non-smokers.Concerns have been raised about long-term sequelae of the disease.

Abanywa sigala baalina mikisa egibalirwa ku bitundu 1.4 okufuna obubonero obw’amaanyi obwa COVID-19 wamu ng’emirundi 2.4 okwetaaga obujjanjabi obw’amangu oba okufa bw’ogeraageranya n’abo abatanywa. Waliwo okutya okulagiddwa ku abo abalina obulwadde obulala.
The Hong Kong Hospital Authority found a drop of 20% to 30% in lung capacity in some people who recovered from the disease, and lung scans suggested organ damage.

Aboobuyinza mu Ddwaliro lya Hong Kong baazuula okukka mu busobozi bw’ekibumba nga kuli wakati w’ebitundu 20% ku 30% mu bantu abamu abaawona obulwadde ate sikaani ezaakolebwa ku mawuggwe nga ziraga nti gaakosebwa.
This may also lead to post-intensive care syndrome following recovery.
This may also lead to post-intensive care syndrome following recovery.
As of March 2020, it was unknown if past infection provides effective and long-term immunity in people who recover from the disease.
Mu Gwokusatu 2020, kyali tekimanyiddwa oba ng’obulwadde obulala omuntu bw’asangibwa nabo bumuwa obusibage obulungi eri abalwadde abaawoona obulwadde obwo.

Immunity is seen as likely, based on the behaviour of other coronaviruses, but cases in which recovery from COVID-19 have been followed by positive tests for coronavirus at a later date have been reported.
Obusibage bulabika, okusinziira ku neeyisa ya coronavirus endala, naye ate abalwadde abawonye COVID-19 oluvannyuma bwe bazzeemu okukeberwa, bazuuliddwa nga balina coronavirus.
These cases are believed to be worsening of a lingering infection rather than re-infection.
Abalwadde abo balowoozebwa nti bafuna ekirwadde ekirala so si kuddamu kufuna bulwadde obwo.
The virus is thought to be natural and have an animal origin, through spillover infection.
Akawuka ako kalowoozebwa okubeera ak’obutonde era nga kava mu nsolo nga kaabuuka bubuusi ne kajja mu bantu (spillover infection).
The actual origin is unknown, but by December 2019 the spread of infection was almost entirely driven by human-to-human transmission.
Ensibuko yennyini temanyiddwa, naye Deesemba 2019 we yatuukira ensaasaana y’obulwadde obwo yali yeemalidde ku kutambulira mu bantu.
A study of the first 41 cases of confirmed COVID-19, published in January 2020 in The Lancet, revealed the earliest date of onset of symptoms as 1 December 2019.
Okunoonyereza okwakolebwa ku balwadde 41 aba COVID-19 abaasooka okukakasibwa, okwafulumizibwa mu Janwali 2020 mu The Lancet, kwalaga nti obubonero obwasooka okulabika bwaliwo nga 1 Deesemba 2019.
Official publications from the WHO reported the earliest onset of symptoms as 8 December 2019.
Ebiwandiiko ebyafuluma mu butongole okuva mu WHO byategeeza nti obubonero obwasooka okulabika bwaliwo nga 8 Deesemba 2019.
Several measures are commonly used to quantify mortality.
Several measures are commonly used to quantify mortality.

These numbers vary by region and over time and are influenced by the volume of testing, healthcare system quality, treatment options, time since initial outbreak and population characteristics such as age, sex and overall health.

Emiwendo gino gyawukana okuva mu kitundu ekimu okudda mu kirala era nga kino kiva ku bungi bw’okukebera, omutindo gw’obujjanjabi, obujjanjabi obuliwo, ekiseera okuva obulwadde we bwatuukirayo n’ensonga endala ez’abantu nga emyaka, ekikula n’embeera y’obulamu bwabwe okutwaliza awamu.

In late 2019, WHO assigned the emergency ICD-10 disease codes U07.1 for deaths from lab-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and U07.2 for deaths from clinically or epidemiologically diagnosed COVID-19 without lab-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection.The death-to-case ratio reflects the number of deaths divided by the number of diagnosed cases within a given time interval.

2019 nga guggwaako, WHO kyateekawo koodi ey’amangu ICD-10 disease codes U07.1 ku baafa obulwadde bwa SARS-CoV-2 nga bakakasiddwa mu ggezeserezo ne U07.2 abaafa nga kiva mu kukebera ne balaba nga bafudde COVID-19 awatali kukeberebwa mu ggezeserezo kukakasa nti ddala bulwadde bwa SARS-CoV-2. Ekigero ky’omuwendo gw’abafa n’abalwadde kiraga omuwendo gw’aba mu kiseera ekigere.
Based on Johns Hopkins University statistics, the global death-to-case ratio is 6.9% (153,822/2,240,191) as of 17 April 2020.
Okusinziira ku bibalo bya John Hopkins University, ekigero ky’okufa n’obulwadde mu nsi yonna kiri ebitundu 6.9% (153,822/2,240,191) olwa 17 Ogwokuna 2020 we gwatuukira.

The number varies by region.Other measures include the case fatality rate (CFR), which reflects the percent of diagnosed individuals who die from a disease, and the infection fatality rate (IFR), which reflects the percent of infected individuals (diagnosed and undiagnosed) who die from a disease.

Omuwendo ogwo gukyuka okusinziira ku kitundu. Obukodyo obulala mulimu ekigero ky’abalwadde abafa (CFR), omuwendo ogulaga omuwendo ku kikumi ogw’abo abakebeddwa ne bafa olw’endwadde, n’abakwatibwa obulwadde (IFR), omuwendo ogulaga abantu abalwadde (abakebeddwa ate era ne baddamu ne bakeberwa) ne bafa olw’obulwadde obumu.
These statistics are not time bound and follow a specific population from infection through case resolution.
Ebibalo bino tebigendera ku ssaawa era bigoberera abantu ab’engeri emu okuva lwe bafunye obulwadde okutuuka ku nkomerero yaabwe (nga bawonye oba nga bafudde).
While not all infected people develop antibodies, the presence of antibodies may provide information about how many people have been infected.
Weewaawo abantu bonna abalwala tebafuna basirikale balwanyisa ndwadde, omuntu okubeera n’abasirikale abalwanyisa endwadde kiyinza okutuwa obubaka ku muwendo gw’abantu abakwatiddwa abalwadde.
In the epicentre of the outbreak in Italy, Castiglione d'Adda, a small village of 4600, 80 (1.7%) are already dead.
Mu Italy obulwadde gye bwasinga okwegiriisiza, ekyalo ekitonotono ekiyitibwa Castiglione d'Adda, abantu 4600, 80 (1.7%) baafa.
In Gangelt, the disease was spread by Carnival festivals, and spread to younger people, causing a relatively lower mortality, and not all COVID-19 deaths may have been formally classified as such.

Mu Gangelt, obulwadde bwasaasaanira mu bikujjuko ebyakazibwako Carnival festival, era omwo mwe bwava ne bukwata abavubuka, abantu batonotono ne bafa ear si buli muntu eyafa obulwadde bwa COVID-19 nti yategeerebwa nti bwe bumusse.
Furthermore, the German health system has not been overwhelmed.
Era, amalwaliro g’omu Bugirimaanyi tegazitoowereddwa balwadde.
In the Netherlands, about 3% may have antibodies, as assessed from blood donors.
Mu Netherlands, abantu nga 3% balina abasirikale abalwanyisa endwadde, nga bwe kyalabibwa mu bagaba omusaayi.
69 (0.004% of the population) have been confirmed to have died from COVID-19.
69 (ebitundu by’abantu 0.004%) bakakasiddwa nga bafudde COVID-19.
The impact of the pandemic and its mortality rate are different for men and women.
Okukosebwa okuva ku nawookeera wamu n’ekigero ky’abantu abafudde bya njawulo ku basajja ne ku bakazi.
Mortality is higher in men in studies conducted in China and Italy.
Okusinga ennyo, abasinze okufa basajja okusinziira ku kunoonyereza okukoleddwa mu China ne Italy.
The highest risk for men is in their 50s, with the gap between men and women closing only at 90.
Obulabe obusinga okuba mu basajja, buli mu abo abali mu myaka egya 50s, ate ng’ebbanga eriri wakati wak’abasajja n’abakazi liri ku myaka 90.
In China, the death rate was 2.8 percent for men and 1.7 percent for women.
Mu China, ekigero ky’abafa kyali 2.8 ku kikumi mu basajja, ne 1.7 ku kikumu mu bakazi.
The exact reasons for this sex-difference is not known, but genetic and behavioural factors could be a reason.
Ensonga yennyini ereetawo enjawulo eno mu kikula temanyiddwa naye ng’endagabutonde n’enneeyisa byandibaamu omuzinzi.

Sex-based immunological differences, lesser prevalence of smoking in women and men developing co-morbid conditions such as hypertension at a younger age than women could have contributed to the higher mortality in men.

Enjawulo mu busibage eyeesigamiziddwa ku kigula, abakyala obutanywa nnyo sigala ate n’abasajja okubeeramu obulwadde obw’enjawulo gamba nga entunnunsi ku myaka emimpi okusinga bwe kiri mu bakazi kyandiba nga kyaleetera omuwendo gw’abasajja abafa okubeera waggulu.
In Europe, 57% of the infected individuals were men and 72% of those died with COVID-19 were men.
E Bulaaya, ebitundu 57% eby’abalwadde baali basajja era ebitundu 72% ku abo abaafa COVID-19 baali basajja.
As of April 2020, the US government is not tracking sex-related data of COVID-19 infections.
Ogwokuna 2020 we gwatuukira, gagumenti ya Amerika yali terondoola bubaka bukwata ku kikula mu balwadde ba COVID-19.
Research has shown that viral illnesses like Ebola, HIV, influenza and SARS affect men and women differently.
Okunoonyereza kulaze nti obulwadde bw’obuwuka nga Ebola, HIV, yegu (influenza) ne SARS bukosa abasajja n’abakazi mu ngeri ya njawulo.
A higher percentage of health workers, particularly nurses, are women, and they have a higher chance of being exposed to the virus.
Abajjanjabi abasinga obungi naddala bannansi, bakazi, kitegeeza nti balina emikisa mingi okusiigibwa akawuka ako.
The World Health Organization announced on 11 February 2020 that the official name of the disease would be "COVID-19".
WHO Kyalangirira nga 11 Ogwokubiri 2020 nti erinnya ly’obulwadde ettongole buyitibwe "COVID-19".
WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus explained that CO stands for corona, VI for virus, D for disease, and 19 for when the outbreak was first identified: 31 December 2019.
Ssenkulu wa WHO, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus yannyonnyola nti CO kikiikirira corona, VI ku lwa virus, D ku lwa bulwadde, ne 19 ku lw’ekiseera ekirwadde lwe kyasooka okulabibwa: 31 Deesemba 2019.

The name had been chosen to avoid references to a specific geographical location (e.g. China), animal species or group of people, in line with international recommendations for naming aimed at preventing stigmatisation.The virus that causes COVID-19 is named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

Erinnya lyalondebwa okwewala okujuliza ku kifo kyonna (gamba nga China), ebika by’ensolo oba ekibinja ky’abantu, nga bagobererwa ebisembebwa mu nsi yonna okwewala okusosola. Akawuka akaleeta COVID-19 kayitibwa severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
The WHO additionally uses "the COVID-19 virus" and "the virus responsible for COVID-19" in public communications.
WHO era kikozesa "akawuka COVID-19" ne "akawukaka akavunaanyizibwa ku COVID-19" mu kuwuliziganya kwabwe n’abantu.
Both the disease and virus are commonly referred to as "coronavirus".
Byo byombi, obulwadde n’akawuka bitera okwogerwako nga "coronavirus".
During the initial outbreak in Wuhan, China, the virus and disease were commonly referred to as "coronavirus" and "Wuhan coronavirus".
Mu kiseera we bwasooka okubalukirawo mu Wuhan, China, akawuka n’obulwadde byali biyitibwa "coronavirus" ne "Wuhan coronavirus".

In January 2020, WHO recommended 2019-nCov and 2019-nCoV acute respiratory disease as interim names for the virus and disease in accordance with 2015 guidance against using locations in disease and virus names.

Mu Janwali 2020, WHO kyasemba 2019-nCov ne 2019-nCoV acute respiratory disease ng’amannya ag’ekiseera okuyitibwa akawuka n’obulwadde nga bagoberera okuluŋŋamizibwa okwa 2015 okugaana okukozesa ebifo kutuuma endwadde n’obuwuka.
The official names COVID-19 and SARS-CoV-2 were issued on 11 February 2020.
Amannya amatongole COVID-19 ne SARS-CoV-2 gaafulumizibwa nga 11 Ogwokubiri 2020.
Due to capacity limitations in the standard supply chains, some digital manufacturers are printing healthcare material such as nasal swabs and ventilator parts.
Olw’obusobozi obutono mu kukola ebintu ebiri ku mutindo, ab’amakolero abamu bafulumya ebikozesebwa mu byobulamu nga swab z’omu nnyindo n’ebitundu by’ebyuma ebiyamba mu kussa.

In one example, when an Italian hospital urgently required a ventilator valve, and the supplier was unable to deliver in the timescale required, a local startup reverse-engineered and printed the required 100 valves overnight.

Mu kyokulabirako ekimu, eddwaliro ly’omu Italy bwe lyali lyetaaga valve y’oku kyuma ekiyamba mu kussa, abikola n’alwawo okugireeta mu budde bwe yeetaagirwamu, ekkolero ly’omu nsi eyo lyatandika okuyiiya amagezi era ne likola valve 100 ezaali zeetaagibwa mu kiro kimu.

After the initial outbreak of COVID-19, conspiracy theories, misinformation and disinformation emerged regarding the origin, scale, prevention, treatment and other aspects of the disease and rapidly spread online.

Oluvannyuma lw’okubalukawo kwa COVID-19, okwasooka, ebiteeberezo ebirimu obwekobaanyi, amawulire amakyamu byatandika okuyitiŋŋana nga byogera ku nsibuko, obunene, enziyiza n’enzijanjaba y’oubulwadde obwo wamu n’ebirala ebikwata ku bulwadde obwo era ne bisaasaana wonna ku yintaneeti mu kaseera mpa wekaaga.
Humans appear to be capable of spreading the virus to some other animals.
Abantu balabika nga basobola okusiiga ensolo obulwadde buno.
The study failed to find evidence of viral replication in pigs, ducks, and chickens.
Okunoonyereza kwalemererwa okuzuula obubaka obulaga okwekubisaamu kw’obuwuka mu mbizzi, mu mbaata, ne mu nkoko.
No medications or vaccine is approved to treat the disease.
Tewali ddagala oba ddagala ligema lyakakasiddwa ku bulwadde buno.
International research on vaccines and medicines in COVID-19 are underway by government organisations, academic groups and industry researchers.
Okunoonyereza kw’ensi yonna ku ddagala erigema n’eddagala lya COVID-19 likolebwako ebitongole bya gavumenti ez’enjawulo, ebibiina by’abanoonyereza, n’abanoonyereza mu makolereo.
In March, the World Health Organization initiated the "SOLIDARITY Trial" to assess treatment effects of four existing antiviral compounds with the most promise of efficacy.
Mu Gwokusatu, WHO kyatandikawo enkola eya "OKUKOLERA AWAMU mu Kugezesa" okwekaliriza eddagala eririwo ery’emirundi eno balabe erisinga okukola obulungi.
There is no available vaccine, but various agencies are actively developing vaccine candidates.
Tewali ddagala ligema naye ebitongole eby’enjawulo biri ku kaweefube wa kugezaako kufuna eryo erinaayamba.
Previous work on SARS-CoV is being utilised because SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 both use the ACE2 receptor to enter human cells.
Okunoonyereza okw’emabegako ku SARS-CoV kukozesebwa kubanga SARS-CoV ne SARS-CoV-2 bwombi bukozesa ACE2 receptor okuyingira mu butaffaali bwy’omuntu.
There are three vaccination strategies being investigated.
Waliwo engeri z’eddagala erigema za mirundi esatu erinoonyerezebwako.
First, researchers aim to build a whole virus vaccine.
Okusooka, abanoonyereza baluubirira okukola eddagala ly’akawuka eryawamu.
The use of such a virus, be it inactive or dead, aims to elicit a prompt immune response of the human body to a new infection with COVID-19.
Okukozesa akawuka akalinga ako, si nsonga oba kalamu oba kafu, kuluubirira okuleetawo obusibage obukolerawo mu mubiri gw’omuntu eri obulwadde obupya wamu ne COVID-19.
A second strategy, subunit vaccines, aims to create a vaccine that sensitises the immune system to certain subunits of the virus.
Engeri endala, eddagala erigema eriyitibwa ‘subunit vaccines’, engeri eno eruubirira kukola ddagala erigema erireetera obusibage bw’omubiri okukenga akawuka nga kalumbye omubiri.
In the case of SARS-CoV-2, such research focuses on the S-spike protein that helps the virus intrude the ACE2 enzyme receptor.
Ku SARS-CoV-2, okunoonyereza okwo kusonze ku S-spike protein eyamba akawuka okuyingirira ACE2 enzyme receptor.
A third strategy is that of the nucleic acid vaccines (DNA or RNA vaccines, a novel technique for creating a vaccination).
Engeri ey’okusatu y’eyo eya nucleic acid vaccines (DNA oba RNA vaccines, akakodyo akapya ak’okutondawo eddagala erigema).
Experimental vaccines from any of these strategies would have to be tested for safety and efficacy.On 16 March 2020, the first clinical trial of a vaccine started with four volunteers in Seattle.

Eddagala ly’okugema erigezesebwa okuva mu nkola zino zijja kwetaagisa okugezesa okulaba nga teririna bulabe n’okujjanjaba obulungi. Nga 16 Ogwokusatu 2020, okugezesa obujjanjabi okwasooka kwatandika n’abantu bana abeewaayo okugezeserezebwako mu Seattle.

The vaccine contains a harmless genetic code copied from the virus that causes the disease.Antibody dependent enhancement has been suggested as a potential challenge for vaccine development for SARS-COV-2, but this is controversial.

Eddagala erigema lirimu genetic code ezitalina bulabe ezakoppebwa okuva ku kawuka akalwaza obulwadde obwo. Okutumbula amaanyi g’abasirikale b’omubiri kimenyeddwa ng’ekisobola okusoomooza okukola eddagala erigema erya SARS-COV-2, naye kino kibuzaabuza.
There are more than 300 active clinical trials underway as of April 2020.
We tutuukidde mu Gwokuna 2020, waliwo okugezesa kw’ekisawo okusoba mu 300 okukolebwa.
Seven trials were evaluating already approved treatments for malaria, including four studies on hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine.
Okugezesa kwa mirundi musanvu kwali kwekenneenya eddagala eryamala edda okukakasibwa okujjanjaba omusujja, nga mwe muli n’okunoonyereza kwa mirundi ena ku hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine.
Repurposed antiviral drugs make up most of the Chinese research, with nine phase III trials on remdesivir across several countries due to report by the end of April.

Eddagala erirwanyisa obuwuka erikozesebwa okujjanjaba obulwadde obulala lye likola ekitundu ekisinga obunene mu kunoonyereza kwa China, nga balina okugezesa okuli ku mutendera III kwa mirundi mwenda ku remdesivir okwetoloola amawanga agawerako nga baakufulumya alipoota ku nkomerero ya Apuli.

A dynamic review of clinical development for COVID-19 vaccine and drug candidates was in place, as of April 2020.Several existing antiviral medications are being evaluated for treatment of COVID-19, including remdesivir, chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, lopinavir/ritonavir and lopinavir/ritonavir combined with interferon beta.

Okwekeneenya okw’amaanyi okw’ekisawo okw’okukola eddagala erigema erya COVID-19 n’ebisobola okubeera eddagala byaliwo, mu Apuli 2020. Eddagala erirwanyisa obuwuka eririwo lingi liri mu kwekenneenyezebwa okulaba oba lisobola okujjanjaba COVID-19, nga mwe muli, remdesivir, chloroquine ne hydroxychloroquine, lopinavir/ritonavir ne lopinavir/ritonavir nga mugattiddwamu interferon beta.
There is tentative evidence for efficacy by remdesivir, as of March 2020.
Mu Gw’okusatu 2020, waaliwo obubaka obutannakakasibwa nti remdesivir, yandiba nga ajjanjaba.
Clinical improvement was observed in patients treated with compassionate-use remdesivir.
Waalabikawo okussuukamu mu balwadde abajjanjabibwa ne compassionate-use remdesivir.
Phase III clinical trials are being conducted in the US, China and Italy.Chloroquine, previously used to treat malaria, was studied in China in February 2020, with preliminary results.

Omutendera III ogw’okugezesa kw’ekisawo gukolebwao mu US, China ne Italy. Chloroquine, eyakozesebwanga okujjanjaba omusujja, yekkeneenyezebwa mu China mu Gwokubiri 2020, era nga waliwo ebisookerwako ebyazuulibwa.
However, there are calls for peer review of the research.
Wabula, waliwo okusaba okwekenneenya okw’abakugu ab’enjawulo ku binoonyerezebwako.
Korean and Chinese Health Authorities recommend the use of chloroquine.
Ab’ebyobulamu mu Korea ne China bawagira okukozesa chloroquine.
However, the Wuhan Institute of Virology, while recommending a daily dose of one gram, notes that twice that dose is highly dangerous and could be lethal.
Wabula, wadde nga Wuhan Institute of Virology, bawagira okumira doozi emu buli lunaku eweza gulaamu emu, balabula nti bw’okubisaamu mu doozi eyo kya bulabe nnyo era kiyinza okukutta.

On 28 March 2020, the FDA issued an emergency use authorisation for hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine at the discretion of physicians treating people with COVID-19.The Chinese 7th edition guidelines also include interferon, ribavirin or umifenovir for use against COVID-19.

Nga 28 Ogwokusatu 2020, FDA yayisa ekiragiro eky’amangu ngekkiriza okukozesa hydroxychloroquine ne chloroquine nga basinziira ku kuwabula kw’abasawo abajjanjaba abalwadde ba COVID-19. Olufulumya olwo 7 lw’ebigobererwa Abachina era lugattako interferon, ribavirin oba umifenovir mu kujjanjaba COVID-19.
Preliminary data indicate that high doses of ribavirin are necessary to inhibit SARS-CoV-2 in vitro.
Ebyakazuulibwawo biraga nti doozi ennyingi eza ribavirin zeetaagisa okutangira SARS-CoV-2 mu vitro.

Nitazoxanide has been recommended for further in vivo study after demonstrating low concentration inhibition of SARS-CoV-2.Studies have demonstrated that initial spike protein priming by transmembrane protease serine 2 (TMPRSS2) is essential for entry of SARS-CoV-2 via interaction with the ACE2 receptor.

Nitazoxanide awagiddwa okwongera okunoonyerezebwako mu bintu ebiramu oluvannyuma lw’okwolesa obunafu mu kutangira SARS- CoV-2. Ebizuuliddwa biraga nti initial spike protein priming eya transmembrane protease serine 2 (TMPRSS2) ya mugaso nnyo okuyingiza SARS-CoV-2 nga yeegatta ne ACE2 receptor.

The studies of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine with or without azithromycin have major limitations that have prevented the medical community from embracing these therapies without further study.Oseltamivir does not inhibit SARS-CoV-2 in vitro and has no known role in COVID-19 treatment.

Okunoonyereza ku chloroquine ne hydroxychloroquine nga mulimu oba temuli azithromycin zirina obunafu bungi obulemesezza abasawo okukkiriza okukozesa obujjanjabi buno nga tebwongedde kunoonyerezebwako. Oseltamivir takugira SARS-CoV-2 mu vitro era omugaso tegumanyiddwa COVID-19.
Cytokine storm can be a complication in the later stages of severe COVID-19.
Cytokine storm buyinza okuba obukosefu obw’amaanyi nga COVID-19 anyiinyitidde.

There is evidence that hydroxychloroquine may have anti-cytokine storm properties.Tocilizumab has been included in treatment guidelines by China's National Health Commission after a small study was completed.

Waliwo obukakafu nti hydroxychloroquine ayinza okubaamu ebirungo bya anti-cytokine storm properties. Tocilizumab ateereddwa mu bigobererwa aba China National Health Commission okujjanjaba oluvannyuma lw’okukola okunoonyereza okutonotono.
It is undergoing a phase 2 non randomised test at the national level in Italy after showing positive results in people with severe disease.
Eri ku mutendera 2 ogw’okugezesa okwetegekere ku mutendera gw’eggwanga mu Italy oluvannyuma lw’okulaga obubonero bw’obulwadde mu bantu abayi.
Combined with a serum ferritin blood test to identify cytokine storms, it is meant to counter such developments, which are thought to be the cause of death in some affected people.
Kati ligattiddwamu serum ferritin blood test okuzuula cytokine storms, era nga ligenderera kutangira bintu nga bino, ebirowoozebwa okutta abalwadde abamu.

The interleukin-6 receptor antagonist was approved by the FDA based on retrospective case studies for treatment of steroid refractory cytokine release syndrome induced by a different cause, CAR T cell therapy, in 2017.

Interleukin-6 receptor antagonist yakakasibwa ekitongole kya FDA nga beesigama ku kunoonyereza okw’emabega okujjanjaba steroid refractory cytokine release syndrome ereetebwa ekintu ekirala, CAR T cell therapy, mu 2017.
To date, there is no randomised, controlled evidence that tocilizumab is an efficacious treatment for CRS.
Okutuusa leero, tewali bukakafu bwa nkukunala nti tocilizumab ajjanjaba n’awonya CRS.

Transferring purified and concentrated antibodies produced by the immune systems of those who have recovered from COVID-19 to people who need them is being investigated as a non-vaccine method of passive immunisation.

Okukyusa abasirikale b’omubiri abalongooseddwa n’okugattibwa nga bakoleddwa omuyungo gw’obusibage ogw’abo abawonye COVID-19 ne bateekebwa mu bantu ababeetaaga kyekennenyezebwa ng’enkola etangira obulwadde ng’omuntu tagemeddwa.
This strategy was tried for SARS with inconclusive results.
Enkola eno yagezesebwa ku SARS naye nga ebyazuulibwa tebyali bya nkomeredde.
Viral neutralisation is the anticipated mechanism of action by which passive antibody therapy can mediate defence against SARS-CoV-2.
Okunafuya obuwuka y’enkola ey’okujjanjaba nga ekozesa obuwuka bu kyesirikidde okulwanyisa SARS-CoV-2.
Other mechanisms however, such as antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and/or phagocytosis, may be possible.
Enkola endala wabula, nga antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity ne/oba phagocytosis, zisoboka.
Other forms of passive antibody therapy, for example, using manufactured monoclonal antibodies, are in development.
Enkola endala ey’okujjanjabisa abasirikale abalwanyisa endwadde ba kyesirikidde, okugeza, okukozesa abasirikale abalwanyisa endwadde abaweeseddwa abayitibwa monoclonal, bali mu kukolebwa.
Production of convalescent serum, which consists of the liquid portion of the blood from recovered patients and contains antibodies specific to this virus, could be increased for quicker deployment.

Okukola convalescent serum, omuli omusaayi okuva ku balwadde abawonye era mulimu abasirikale abalwanyisa endwadde ezireetebwa akawuka kano, kusobola okwongerwako okusobola okwongera ku kukukola eddagala.
Coronavirus diseases, a group of closely related syndromes
Endwadde za Coronavirus, ekibinja ky’obubonero obufaanagana
Li Wenliang, a doctor at Central Hospital of Wuhan, who later contracted and died of COVID-19 after raising awareness of the spread of the virus.
Li Wenliang, dokita mu Central Hospital e Wuhan, oluvannyuma yakwatibwa obulwadde bwa COVID-19 era n’ekyavaamu n’afa ng’amaze okumanyisa ku nsaasaana y’akawuka ako.
